HEADLINE: Washington and Tokyo Reducing Trade Tensions

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 24

 BODY:
The United States and Japan have begun to defuse the trade tensions threatening to destroy their global partnership.
Recent moves by the Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to make it easier to sell American products, including supercomputers, in Japan are easing tensions and reducing the likelihood of trade retaliation this summer. American officials have reacted cautiously, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said on Friday, ''It won't ever be enough, but I think we're showing that we can make some progress.''
Mr. Brady made the comment after six hours of trade and economic talks with Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan. 
His meeting followed by a week a visit to Japan by Commerce Secretary Robert C. Mosbacher, and by three weeks the meeting in Palm Springs between Mr. Kaifu and President Bush.
 
Critic Relents a Bit
Even such a stern critic of Japan as Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, the ranking Republican on the Senate's trade subcommittee, found after a recent trip to Tokyo ''a recognition that the time had come to redress the grievances we had.''
The progress comes as the Japanese financial markets are going through one of the most severe shakeouts of the postwar era.
Since the start of this year, the Tokyo Stock Exchange has lost a quarter of its value, and the yen is trading at its lowest levels in more than three years.
Fearful that the market weakness might spread to other financial centers, Mr. Brady yesterday went along with a request by Mr. Hashimoto to reaffirm earlier pledges to stabilize exchange rates.
Mr. Brady and Mr. Hashimoto had scheduled their meeting as part of the preparations for the meeting in April of the finance ministers of the Group of Seven - the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy.
 
Maintaining Confidence
Mr. Brady, a former investment banker who led a United States Government study of the October 1987 stock market collapse, said Friday, ''It is very important that these big moves go through the world financial system in a way that people can continue to have confidence and conduct business.''
A two-paragraph communique issued after the meeting signaled no policy initiatives. But it reaffirmed a working relationship between the Governments that Mr. Brady and Mr. Hashimoto apparently hope will deter speculators.
Mr. Hashimoto sought Mr. Brady's participation in a statement of reassurance largely for domestic political consumption in Japan.
It left several questions unanswered, including whether there would be increased intervention by the Governments to bolster the value of the yen against the dollar and whether the United States would cut its interest rates to try to curb the dollar's strength.
 
Policy on the Dollar
The Treasury has expressed concern that a strong dollar will weaken American competitiveness by making United States exports too expensive. But the Federal Reserve Board and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, have maintained that high interest rates are needed to prevent inflation, and Mr. Brady has deferred.
The Federal Reserve likes a strong dollar because it means lower priced imports and it resists lower interest rates because of fears the economy would be overstimulated and inflation aggravated.
Japanese officials made it clear that they regarded the reaffirmation of monetary cooperation with the United States as essential to continued progress on the trade front.
And Mr. Hashimoto fears his political prospects would be irreparably damaged by continued market disruptions in Tokyo, Japanese officials said.
The link between the monetary talks and the trade disputes was demonstrated when American and Japanese negotiators announced a preliminary agreement on Friday to open the Japanese Government's market to American supercomputers.
Although the accord is subject to final approval, it is likely to remove an American threat to retaliate against Japan if procurement practices were not revamped by June.
Under the 1988 Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act, the United States has identified as priorities for investigation the Japanese market for supercomputers, satellites and wood products.
Under the statute, the President could order retaliation if the two Governments do not reach agreement by June 16 on elimination of the barriers.
American trade officials have reported some progress on forest products. The satellite sector is proving the most difficult.
 
Upholding the Law
Asked Thursday whether the United States would retaliate against Japan if the trade deadlines were not met, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, responded, ''I was sworn to uphold the law and I cannot fail to do so.''
But she said she was ''very hopeful that we will have sufficient progress,'' adding: ''It's in everyone's least interest if we close markets. It's in everyone's best interest if we make progress.''
In addition to the June deadlines, Japan and the United States are engaged in broader talks on making changes in the structure of Japanese and American society.
Known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, Tokyo and Washington are facing a mid-April deadline for an interim report on what progress is being made toward changing laws and practices that hinder efforts to reduce the United States' $49 billion trade deficit with Japan last year.

HEADLINE: Eyes to Left, Democrats Edge Toward the Center

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, March 24

 BODY:
Two very different political visions collided here today: A group of centrist Democrats asserted that the national party must change to reclaim the support of middle-class voters, while the Rev. Jesse Jackson asserted that the American mainstream was moving toward him.
The Democratic Leadership Council, a group of elected officials who are trying to nudge the party toward the center, spent two days arguing that the party must reject the orthodoxies of the past and move toward a philosophy that emphasizes economic growth, ''expanding opportunity, not government,'' getting tough on criminals, and helping America compete in the world marketplace.
Then Mr. Jackson, the once and potential future candidate for the party's Presidential nomination, gave a liberal credo as the party's proper direction. He said his longstanding support for deep cuts in military spending, higher taxes on the rich and major new domestic spending programs were now the positions of the mainstream. 
''In 1990 the world has changed, the people are moving our way, and we are more united than ever,'' he said.
Mr. Jackson, who has clashed often with the group, and who is considered by many members to be far too liberal, asserted that he and the group now stand on common ground on many of these issues.
Officials with the council begged to differ. ''We trust that a few people in the press have a brain in their heads,'' said Al From, executive director of the group.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the new chairman of the council, said, ''While we favor tax fairness and think the middle class is overtaxed, we don't think the Democratic Party should lead with class warfare.''
The debate reflects a party groping toward the 1992 Presidential election, trying to rebuild a Presidential majority in the electoral college and a national image after losing five of the past six Presidential elections.
 
Innovation Is Emphasized
The leadership council, along with its offshoot, the Progressive Policy Institute, is trying to position itself as the innovative wing of the party that can free Democrats from the New Deal orientation and outmoded approaches of its past.
''Instead of fighting rear-guard actions to preserve programs created in the 30's and 60's, we need to recapture the bold vision and experimental spirit that is the true legacy of Roosevelt, Truman, Kennedy and Johnson,'' Senator Charles S. Robb of Virginia told the group.
The council, founded in reaction to the party's landslide Presidential defeat in 1984, is pushing a party philosophy intended to recapture the middle-class voters who deserted the Democrats in droves in the past three Presidential elections.
A ''New Orleans Declaration'' embraced here this weekend emphasizes civic obligation rather than entitlement, getting tough on criminals rather than ''explaining away their behavior,'' and implementing social welfare programs that ''bring the poor into the nation's economic mainstream, not maintain them in dependence.''
The declaration is a broad statement of philosophy and contained few specifics.
On the domestic front, the council pushes programs like national service, modeled on the G.I. Bill of Rights, in which college students would receive aid in exchange for a period of work like teaching or community service.
On the international front, the council has long taken a more hawkish approach to national security issues than has much of the party.
Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the chairman of the Armed Services Committee and a leader in this group, repeated here this weekend, ''We must recognize that the collapse of Communism does not mean the end of danger in the world.''
Still, despite the group's efforts to redefine and redirect the party, it faces a ''fourth-year problem,'' as Elaine Kamarck, one of its analysts, put it. ''We start out to rethink and then the fourth year comes along and what do we do? We nominate a New Deal liberal,'' she said.
After the 1984 election, some of the council's members were prime movers in the creation of Super Tuesday, the round of early primaries, heavily concentrated in the South, which many Democrats hoped would produce a more centrist, electable nominee. The effort was widely seen as a classic example of the law of unintended consequences, providing a major boost to two of the more liberal candidates in the field, Mr. Jackson and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.
 
Ways to Promote Philosophy
Now, the Leadership Council is talking about a grass-roots effort to promote its philosophy and ideas in advance of 1992, beginning with a newspaper ad campaign. ''Eastern Europe isn't the only place that needs new democratic ideas,'' as one ad declares.
Governor Clinton told the group today that it should focus more on ideas than on the mechanics of winning the White House, asserting, ''Any political resurgence depends on the intellectual resurgence of our party.''
Some of its analysts say they long for the kind of basic debate over issues and philosophy that the Republicans went through in the late 1970's when Reaganism triumphed over the more traditional wing of the party.
This sense, that the party needs that kind of debate, accounts, in part, for the group's preoccupation with Mr. Jackson, widely seen as the leader of the party's liberal wing. It invited him to speak at today's event.
Mr. Jackson demurred when pressed on any Presidential plans for 1992.
''That is not my focus,'' he said, noting that he was active in a variety of causes.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: M.I.T.;
A Lofty Experiment In Curriculum Fizzles

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Three years ago, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Committee on Curricula approved a 12-subject experimental program titled ''Human Contexts of Science and Technology.'' It was an attempt to make undergraduates more aware of the impact of science and engineering on society.
Now, M.I.T. administrators concede that they offered a curriculum and virtually no one came.
With two exceptions, attendance has been sparse at the 12 interdisciplinary classes offered at various times during the last five semesters on subjects dealing with ethics and social responsibility. 
Only ''AIDS: Scientific Challenge and Human Challenge'' and ''Engineers, Scientists and Public Controversies'' proved popular enough to continue, with an average of about 25 enrollees, school officials said. But two other courses - ''Automation, Robotics and Unemployment'' and ''Life and Institutions of Science'' -were canceled, said Margaret S. Richardson, assistant dean for curriculum support. After the present semester there will be no Human Contexts courses, she said.
Ms. Richardson heads the newly formed Context Support Office, which is to replace the formal courses in ethics and social issues with less formal workshops and colloquiums, research projects and lectures.
 
'Nobody's Shedding Tears'
Context is now being co-directed by Lawrence M. Lidsky, a professor in the nuclear engineering department, and Merritt Roe Smith, a professor of the history of technology. ''Nobody's shedding tears over the loss of Context subjects,'' Mr. Lidsky said.
The reason for the anemic enrollments is straightforward: Students will not voluntarily devote time to courses that do not satisfy requirements for graduation.
''What it comes down to is 'Can you offer credit that counts towards a student's degree?' '' said Lacinda R. Hummel, a junior biology major from Bloomington, Ill., who sat as a student representative on the review group.
The idea for a formal program on the scientist's social responsibility came to life through the investigations of two working groups, one from the School of Humanities and Social Science, the other from the School of Engineering. The groups devised 12 courses, both seminars and lectures.
In its July 1989 report, the Context Review Group gave several reasons for the Context Initiative, as it has become known. These included making students and instructors aware of the contexts - cultural, political, economic, environmental and ethical -within which the practice of science and engineering takes place.
''We are likely to be more effective in our professional work when we are aware of the way in which social values influence the work we usually think of as purely disciplinary,'' the report said. It added that scientists and engineers have the responsibility ''to be aware of the potential social effects of their work, so that they will be able to inform the society they serve of the likely consequences of new technologies.''
 
Redesigned Biology Course
Despite the initiative's failure as formal curriculum, it did prompt several professors to include ethical and social considerations in their otherwise technical classroom discussions. For example, Paul T. Matsudaira and Brent H. Cochran, biology professors, have redesigned the introductory course, moving its emphasis away from molecular biology to a more general view that includes population genetics, physiology and ecology.
One approach is to assign students weekly readings from publications like Science magazine and The Economist. These are discussed at recitations, whose function has traditionally been limited to expounding on material covered in lectures.
'' 'Context' is another name for real life,'' said Edward F. Crawley, an aeronautics and astronautics professor who teaches a departmental course called unified engineering. Nowadays, he begins class a few minutes early with discussions of the social and political aspects of engineering: how changes in the Soviet Union will influence the careers of students in the class; the politics of the space program; the ethical implications of compromises in design.
''Students are very interested,'' he said. ''They find it unusual that professors are willing to talk about things other than solid mechanics.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Columbia;
Students Repair Storm Damage At Health Center

DATELINE: JAYUYA, P.R.

 BODY:
Thirty-six students from Columbia University and Barnard College spent spring break helping to repair a Methodist health center and camp that was severely damaged by Hurricane Hugo.
Damage at the mountaintop complex, the Bishop Fred P. Corson Health Center and Camp, was estimated at $150,000.
''The roof was blown off the chapel and all the furniture ruined,'' said the Rev. Miguel Arroyo, the pastor of the local Methodist church and the director of the camp. The hurricane, which lashed the island on Sept. 18, also destroyed the camp pool, four cabins and the roof on a large room used for meetings and dining. 
The center is in the rural barrio Mameyes de Jayuya, about 50 miles southwest of San Juan. ''It serves as a community center for the people from the barrio,'' Mr. Arroyo said.
 
Camp for the Poor
It was founded 35 years ago with grants from the Methodist Church of Philadelphia, he said. Throughout the years many groups have come from the United States to help maintain the center. The names of people from Iowa, Washington, Florida and Indiana are scratched into concrete steps and sidewalks around the complex.
A dispensary staffed by a doctor four days a week opened at the center two years ago. A nurse and a social worker also work out of the complex.
''The camp is used every summer by the Police Athletic League to bring in four groups of 100 poor city youths who stay a week,'' Mr. Arroyo said. ''At other times we use the camp for retreats by people of all denominations.''
The students arrived from New York City two weeks ago. The group, acting under the auspices of the Methodist Church of Puerto Rico, was assembled by the Rev. H. Scott Matheney, Columbia's Presbyterian chaplain, and the Rev. James Karpen, its Methodist chaplain.
 
Surprising Response
Group members raised $6,000 from campus organizations and churches in New York to buy materials and make a donation to the center. The students paid for their own transportation and did their own cooking and laundry when not wielding hammers and paintbrushes.
''I did a lot of the cooking,'' said Renee Pearl, a junior from New York City who is majoring in architecture. ''But I also painted that mural,'' she said, pointing to a painting of twigs and vines crawling up the sides and over the top of a concrete arch over the kitchen.
Matthew Kohl, from Fredonia, N.Y., who completed his undergraduate program in economics and philosophy in February, said he helped paint the health center. ''I also helped repair a roof, before I fell through it,'' he said. ''Then I had to help fix the roof again.''
Since coming to Columbia eight years ago, Mr. Matheney said, he has seen ''a growing number of students getting involved'' in charity projects like repairing the center.
''But last year I don't think we would have gotten as big a group as this,'' he said. ''This response really blew us away. We expected 15 and got more than 100 inquiries.''
Before the group from Columbia and Barnard arrived, four other groups from the United States had helped with the rebuilding. The Columbia group left on Thursday morning.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Purdue;
The Race Is On To Ready Students For Globalization

DATELINE: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind.

 BODY:
As more free markets open in Eastern Europe, progress continues on the Pacific rim and Europe moves toward economic unification in 1992, Purdue is striving to keep pace by adopting curriculum changes that will internationalize the outlook and training of its students.
The program may also help faculty members, its architects say, through research with foreign colleagues.
Administrators, including President Steven C. Beering, predict that it will also benefit the companies who depend on the university for help in research, in monitoring new technology and in analyzing the economic policies of foreign countries. ''We're now teaching Japanese and Chinese at Purdue,'' Mr. Beering said. ''We have new affiliations in China and are expanding our affiliations in Europe.'' Many of the new proposals involve study abroad. 
The initial phase began when a small group of faculty members and deans from each of the university's 12 schools appointed a committee to examine the changes the school should make to meet the challenges of globalization. The first steps - planning new programs in each of the university's 12 schools - took almost two years, said D. Woods Thomas, the director of international education and research and one of the chief architects of the program.
The next step was a four-day workshop in January that brought in consultants from industry, government and education to evaluate the recommendations.
Mr. Thomas said administrators and faculty members are now reviewing the revised plans, and some proposals are already under way.
The Schools of Engineering and Liberal Arts are proposing a program under which a student can earn both engineering and liberal arts degrees. Susan Schell, Mr. Thomas's assistant, said engineering majors will add courses in foreign languages and general culture to help make them more marketable. Engineering students now have room for only 12 elective credits of the 120 required.
The School of Agriculture has suggested developing an international minor that would incorporate foreign-language training and some form of international experience.
The School of Consumer and Family Services proposes developing programs in English as a second language for foreign exchange students.
 
Exporting Education
The School of Education plans master's and doctoral programs in international studies and a network for exporting education technology to Africa, Asia and Latin America.
The School of Management will offer a new executive master's program featuring executives on both sides of the Atlantic in anticipation of European unity.
The Schools of Pharmacy, Nursing and Health Sciences are developing a graduate program in radioactive waste management in concert with the French atomic energy agency.
The School of Technology is preparing study-abroad options in Australia, New Zealand and Great Britain and extended cooperative-education programs with American multinationals and foreign companies overseas.
The School of Veterinary Medicine is creating a program in international medical studies that will include summer jobs and coordination with the Peace Corps or a similar agency.
Ms. Shell said the university would seek financing from the state for the ideas, some of which will begin this fall.

HEADLINE: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;
Middle Eastern, Spanish And (of Course) French

 BODY:
This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current.
 
Al Amir
Diner's Journal (Jan. 26, 1990), 1431 Second Avenue, at 74th Street (212-737-1800) - The economical menu at Al Amir, a new Middle Eastern restaurant with white marble floors and well-spaced tables, has many enticing choices. Besides the exceptional baba gannouj, hummus and lemony tabbouleh, there are specialties like marinated turnip and a fabulous Lebanese moussaka, a cold eggplant with garlic and minced onions. Arayess, another appealing appetizer, combines ground lamb, onion and cinnamon in pita bread, baked until the bread is dark and crisp. Among the entrees are charcoal-grilled baby lamb chops and grilled lemon-marinated chicken. Appetizers are $3.50 and $4; entrees, $15 to $20. Sunday dinner 5 P.M. to midnight. 
 
Alcala
**(March 18, 1988), 349 Amsterdam Avenue, between 76th and 77th Streets (212-769-9600) - At Alcala, it's fun to start off at the tapas bar where the hot and cold tidbits are fresh and savory. Among the more intriguing tapas are the fried calamari, marinated anchovies and shellfish salad in an herb vinaigrette. To accompany the tapas, Alcala offers perhaps the best selection of Spanish wines in New York. Good entrees include grouper with vegetables, roasted suckling pig and crisply sauteed salmon steak with two sauces. For dessert the rich almond tart, orange flan and Catalonian cream are recommended. Appetizers are $4 to $9, entrees $14 to $19. Sunday hours are 2 to 10 P.M.
 
Gerard's Place
Diner's Journal (Feb. 2, 1990), 201 East 65th Street (212-935-8888) -Gerard Pangaud, formerly of Aurora, has opened his own restaurant where he serves French peasant cooking. The setting is spacious, with Provencal touches. As an appetizer, seared tuna encrusted with black pepper comes alongside a crepe filled with ratatouille. Another starter is stuffed pig's foot; the meat and gelatin are mixed with truffles and served with a woodsy Perigourdine sauce. Entrees include the terrific braised oxtail and the roasted cod with crispy garlic, accompanied by Brussels sprouts, cubed potatoes and beetroots. The chef also prepares ''seven-hour lamb,'' the leg slowly cooked and served with assorted beans. Appetizers are $6 to $9.50, entrees $17 to $19. Sunday hours, 4 to 9 P.M.
 
La Cite
*(Feb. 2, 1990) 120 West 51st Street (212-956-7100) - La Cite is a rococo extravaganza. It has a main dining area resembling a festively garish brasserie and a cozier grill room withessentially the same food at slightly lower prices. One of the best entrees is the golden-skinned, spit-roasted chicken with raisins, mushrooms and pearl onions. Other main course options are grilled salmon with dill vinaigrette, lamb steak with white beans, and a deftly grilled swordfish steak with homemade potato chips. There are shellfish of all sorts for starters, including excellent oysters and sea urchins. The grill features a sizzling skillet of small, sweet mussels as an appetizer. Main dining room: appetizers are $5 to $12; main courses $18 to $28. Grill: appetizers are $4.75 to $13, entrees $9.50 to $19. Sunday hours in the grill are 11:30 A.M. to 2 A.M., and 5 P.M. to midnight in the main room.
 
La Tulipe
**(Dec. 23, 1988) 104 West 13th Street (212-691-8860) - La Tulipe's appealing setting is the ground floor of a Village brownstone. There is a little Parisian-style bar up front. The chef, Sally Darr, who owns La Tulipe with her husband, John, presents some alluring and homey fare. Among the recommended dishes are the regal Parmesan souffle and fried zucchini fritters. New to the appetizer list is a Provencal pistou soup. Roast chicken with a snowdrift of buttery mashed potatoes, squab with braised cabbage and bacon, and sauteed bay scallops drizzled with brown butter are entrees worth noting. For dessert, diners won't go wrong with apple tart, or the l'ile flottante with praline sauce. Dinner is prix fixe at $62, served from 6 to 10 P.M.
 
WHAT THE STARS MEAN
 
(None) Poor to satisfactory
* Good
** Excellent
*** Extraordinary
 
These ratings reflect the reviewer's reaction primarily to food, with ambiance and service taken into consideration. Menu listings and prices are subject to change.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Tokyo's Bubble Bursts With A Vengeance

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
''This has the feel,'' said the man from Nikko Securities, ''of a bubble being burst.''
And so it did, as what had been the world's largest and highest-flying stock market came tumbling down.
It was Japanese individual investors who had provided the last buying for the Tokyo market, urged on by the Government's decision earlier this year to let them finance a larger proportion of share purchases with borrowed money. From the end of 1989 to early this month, margin debt outstanding soared 22 percent, to $67 billion. 
And why not buy? Many Japanese citizens, dreaming of owning a decent house close to Tokyo, concluded that the only way to get the money was to speculate in stocks. ''They felt the authorities would not allow the market to fall,'' said Peter Tasker, the head of Japanese research for Kleinwort Benson.
That retail surge helped to keep the more speculative stocks rising in the first two months of 1990, even as the larger stocks were starting to weaken under the pressure of rapidly rising interest rates. But last week, the second section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the home of many smaller stocks, plunged 9.3 percent.
The Nikkei 225, an index of larger stocks, ended the week off 6.9 percent, at 30,372.16. The rise in Japan's discount rate on Tuesday did not help the yen, and hurt stocks. The low point was reached around midday Thursday, when the Nikkei was below 29,000 for the first time in 14 months. But with concerted central bank intervention to support the yen, share prices then began to firm. On Friday, some American institutions were said to be buying cautiously.
For the first time since early 1987, the Japanese equity market is worth less than the American one, according to Morgan Stanley Capital International. Even with the gains at the end of the week, the Nikkei is down 22 percent this year in yen terms, and 27 percent in dollars. That is further than the Nikkei fell in the worldwide crash of 1987, but this crash has had little impact outside Japan, where many think it is simply a correction of Japanese overvaluation. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 36.94 points to 2,704.28 last week, but is still up 77.03 points in March.
The good news for Japan is that despite rising interest rates, the economy and corporate profits are still growing, although at a slower rate than before.
''The economic fundamentals are still in place,'' said Lawrence S. Prager, the chief fundamental analyst and strategist at Nikko. ''You just have to get valuations back in line.'' The Nikkei still trades at 45 times forecasted profits.
There is hope that Japanese institutions, which have been heavy sellers, will buy this week, when trades count in the new fiscal year, beginning April 1. There is talk that the Government may authorize purchases by some pension funds that had been barred from the market.
One rumor smacked of desperation. Mr. Tasker of Kleinwort said there was talk of changing the accounting rules, so that an institution that loses money in stocks can keep that fact confidential.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/March 18-23

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
The Tokyo stock market has caught New York on the way down. An investor who bought Japanese stocks on Sept. 4, 1987 would now be no better off than one who bought American stocks the same day. A 6.9 percent drop in the Nikkei average last week, to 30,372.16, left the total value of Tokyo's stocks slightly lower than New York's. Linkage? The Dow, while jittery, fell just 1.3 percent to 2,704.28. Donald M. Krueger, director of research at Sanyo Securities America Inc., expects the Tokyo market to regain its composure after the Japanese fiscal year ends March 31. But then, he admits, the end of the year, when financial institutions are eager to shine, was the last time he would have expected a market plunge. ''If it seems I'm looking for glimmers of hope,'' he said, ''you're right.'' 
 
 
 
7-Eleven Seeks a Friend
 
It might become the 1990's answer to the leverage binge of the 1980's: An American concern drowning in debt reaches out to a wealthy Japanese corporation for rescue. On Thursday, the Southland Corporation, whose 7-Eleven stores form the nation's largest convenience chain, agreed to sell 75 percent of its stock to the Ito-Yokado Group of Tokyo. Ito-Yokado already controls 7-Eleven Japan, with stores on many an urban sidestreet dispensing sushi, Slurpees and sugary pastries. The deal, worth about $1 billion, faces two major obstacles: Holders of the ''junk bonds'' that financed Southland's 1987 leveraged buyout are unlikely to swallow an agreement giving them maybe 22 cents on the dollar. And the Japanese fear a backlash against their acquisition of another major American company.
 
 
 
Uproar In Brazil
 
In the first full week of Brazil's radical new fight against inflation, layoffs spread, grocers accused of violating a price freeze were arrested, concerts and flights were canceled - and some prices actually fell. Brazil's new President, Fernando Color de Mello, and his Economy Minister, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, are also planning to trim the bloated Government bureaucracy and sell state enterprises. The wealthy are practically in revolt, but the majority of Brazilians seem to support the tough measures.
 
 
 
Banks Smile on Venezuela
 
Venezuela hopes its debt deal with United States banks works out better than Mexico's. Venezuela and its bankers reached a basic agreement Tuesday covering about $20 million in loans. An earlier deal with Mexico failed to provide new loans or reduce debt payments enough to fuel adequate growth, some economists say. With Venezuela, the banks have several options, so the impact won't be clear for months. But bankers appear more confident about Venezuela's ecomomy than Mexico's, and more likely to grant new loans. ''By the looks of things, they'll get some debt relief and may be able to patch together some sort of recovery,'' said Lance Taylor, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
 
 
 
Supercomputer Accord
 
The United States and Japan said on Friday that they had reached an agreement to give American supercomputer makers much better access to the Japanese market. Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady met on Friday to pursue further negotiations.
 
 
 
The Unified Mark
 
Just eight months after the fall of the Berlin wall, East and West Germany plan to unify their currencies. Last week, West German officials set a July 1 goal for making their mark common to both countries. Ekkehard Seigert, an economist at Deutsche Bank A.G., said that speculators are buying East German marks in anticipation of a favorable exchange rate. The West Germans have already offered to exchange East German savings at a ratio of 1 to 1. They hope that a unified currency and the end to many special benefits will slow the flow of East German resettlers. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative allies, strong proponents of reunification, won East German elections a week ago.
 
 
 
Europe's Labor in '92
 
Labor tensions loom as the European Community approaches 1992. Will competition from low-paid workers in Spain, Greece and Portugal force French and West German workers to lower their sights? Or will the European Community's social charter, as it's called, require the low-wage nations to improve their labor conditions? ''It's a north-south issue, like the difference between the United States and Mexico,'' said Gregory Schoepfle, director of foreign economic research at the United States Department of Labor. The Department co-sponsored a conference last week on these debates and the consequences for American workers. Representatives from West Germany said their workers would be as well-treated as ever. West German unions, deeply involved in corporate management and national politics, have grown and thrived even as American unions have shrunk.
 
 
 
COMPANIES
 
Deal in the Wings for UAL
 
Finally, a deal for the UAL Corporation might be ready for takeoff. The three United Airlines unions and an investor group affiliated with Coniston Partners offered $150 a share in cash, plus other paper of less certain value, on Monday. Analysts say the unions and the investors stand a good chance of ousting the chief executive, Stephen M. Wolf. Investors took a beating when a $300-a-share offer from Mr. Wolf and the pilots fell through last Octo ber. The UAL board agreed to negotiate while it searches for a better offer.
 
 
 
Adland's Sneaker Stomp
 
Want a business more perilous than bungee-cord jumping? Try advertising. Chiat/Day/Mojo created a television commercial for Reebok International Ltd. that featured two men diving from a bridge with elastic bungee cords tied to their sneakers. The one wearing Reeboks springs back into sight; all that's left of his companion is a pair of Nikes, empty and dangling. Parents complained. What if the kids attempt the same stunt? So Reebok decided to throw the commercial over the bridge and will not run it again as is. Chiat/Day/Mojo had already leaped, resigning the $40 million Reebok account in January.
 
 
 
Fixed-Price Matzohs?
 
The Justice Department thinks it has discovered one more Passover plague: overpriced matzoh. On Tuesday, a Federal grand jury indicted B. Manischewitz & Company on a criminal charge of price-collusion with competitors for at least six years. Manischewitz was founded more than a century ago by a Cincinnati rabbi of that name. The company, now based in Jersey City, dominates the market for matzoh and kosher wine. Manischewitz has denied any wrongdoing.
 
 
 
In Brief
 
President Bush nominated T. Timothy Ryan Jr. on Thursday to direct the Office of Thrift Supervision, a day after a judge ruled that the agency lacked authority to seize failing institutions.
 
*
 
A Federal judge dismissed almost entirely a $150 million Xerox Corporation lawsuit on Friday that accused Apple Computer Inc. of using copyrighted screen display technology.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Inflation's Still With Us
 
Inflation stays stubborn. February's rate of five-tenths of 1 percent, released last week, was higher than expected. David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, said that annual inflation has stabilized at about 4.5 percent. ''That's the good news,'' he said. ''The bad news is, we are probably not going to see any break in that level until next year, at the earliest.''
 
 
 
Oil Hurts the Trade Figures
 
Record oil imports keep the nation from narrowing its trade deficit. January's deficit widened to $9.3 billion from $7.7 billion the month before.
 
 
 
Bamboo Blossoms
 
Bamboo blossoms, Asia benefits. Scientists in India said last week that they had brought forth bamboo blossoms in the laboratory for the first time. Their achievement will allow bamboo cultivation and the breeding of improved strains, to the advantage of several Asian economies. Many Asian nations depend on bamboo for building materials, household goods and high-protein livestock fodder. Bamboo has strange reproductive habits: It normally flowers and produces seeds only once, after growing between 12 and 120 years. The scientists got some bamboo cuttings to flower much more quickly in a mixture including sugar, plant growth hormones and coconut milk. Might not work in an Indian restaurant, but the bamboo evidently loved it.

LENGTH: 1880 words

HEADLINE: The Art of Luring Japanese Executives to American Firms

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
American and European corporations are hunting a rare and elusive quarry: the high-level Japanese executive willing to abandon lifetime employment with a Japanese company for speedier advancement and more money at a Western concern.
For Western companies, these executives provide perhaps the best means of establishing links to the sometimes insular Japanese business community. And the managers' understanding of the Japanese culture and economy is invaluable to foreigners trying to pry their way into the expansive market in Japan. ''We have a very good idea of what Japanese clients want,'' said one Japanese executive in Tokyo who recently joined an American investment bank. ''That is not always the same thing that American clients want,'' added the executive, who asked no to be named.
But in targeting the Japanese, these recruiters face daunting social and tactical obstacles. While Japanese executives who join Western companies can earn four times more money than they can working for Japanese concerns - not to mention getting spectacular perquisites - most are unwilling to give up the stability and job security they receive in Japan. Most large Japanese companies, after all, offer cradle-to-grave employment. They recruit graduates of the most prestigious Japanese universities and place them on carefully structured, lifelong career paths. 
''The manager every multinational corporation would like right now is a strong Japanese executive doing a responsible job for a Japanese company who has some international experience,'' said Dayton Ogden, chief executive of Spencer Stuart, a New York executive search firm. ''But given the tradition of lifetime employment, that is still a tough sell.''
Even so, multinational companies have unleashed a swarm of recruiters into Tokyo to woo these executives. In the last five years, their activities have increased ''almost exponentially,'' said Robert G. Cox, managing director of A.T. Kearney Inc., a consulting firm based in New York with an office in Tokyo since 1970. And Spencer Stuart says that revenues of its Tokyo office have tripled since it opened in 1985.
Indeed, these Western recruiters are beginning to enjoy success in Japan. Traditional attitudes about lifetime employment seem to be cracking a bit, particularly among Japanese executives who have been exposed to different employment standards and life styles in America and Europe, while working at subsidiaries of Japanese companies.
What is more, the idea of changing employers is gaining acceptance in Japan. Smaller Japanese companies with international aspirations have become more aggressive in their recruitment tactics, introducing the notion of job hopping into the culture. ''Between Japanese companies, recruiting is becoming more common,'' said one Japanese executive. ''These small but strong domestic companies need managers from larger companies, which already have global operations.'' (See box.) To guard against defections, a few big Japanese companies have acted defensively. Some are hiring American and European executives to develop Western-style human resources departments and enhanced benefits packages. For example, the Mitsubishi Corporation recently introduced incentive raises for employees in its financial services division, presumably to stem departures.
In a few cases, Japanese employers are even circumventing the strict rules that have governed advancement in the workplace. Western recruiters speak in hushed tones of an ambitious junior manager at one of the largest Japanese investment banks who was promoted over his superiors when the company learned he was getting impatient with his pre-arranged advancement schedule.
American financial service companies have been more successful than manufacturing and industrial companies in recruiting Japanese executives. That is because Western banks offer Japanese executives training, not available in Japan, that is useful back home. ''Investment banking is one area where the United States has been very strong, particularly in mergers and acquisitions,'' said Christine R. Houston, a partner at Korn/Ferry International, whose office in Japan works chiefly for Western investment and commercial banks. ''The Japanese have been a little behind in banking, so they look at jobs with American banks as valuable learning experience.''
Recruiters say recently repatriated managers are most likely to join a Western company. The best time to approach Japanese executives is about three months after they return home from an American or European assignment.
''It's very difficult for them to integrate again after being overseas, so you find many of them more willing to listen to your offers,'' said George C. Fifield, a partner with Egon Zehnder International Inc., a Swiss executive search firm with an office in Tokyo since 1973. ''They're still trying to adjust to a much smaller house and commuting longer distances. Their children are having difficulty adapting to new schools and their wife resents the renewed social and familial obligations she has in Japanese society.''
The Japanese executives most sought after by both Western and Japanese companies are 35 to 45 years old, fluent in English and experienced in international business, said T. Lee Pomeroy, a consultant with Egon Zehnder. Managers with postgraduate degrees from American universities - Japanese employers often reward their most promising employees with education abroad - are in especially high demand.
Consider Akio Katsuragi, who left his Japanese employer to join the Bankers Trust Company in New York in 1987. Mr. Katsuragi had been recruited out of prestigious Tokyo University by the Industrial Bank of Japan, which then sent him to law school at the University of Pennsylvania. When the Industrial Bank of Japan acquired the IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company four years ago, Mr. Katsuragi was sent to New York, its base, to learn about the subsidiary. After a year and a half, with the urging of a former colleague, he joined Bankers Trust.
''I could see 15 years ahead of me before I ever reached a truly senior level of the company, and that's very discouraging,'' he said. ''A friend of mine in a similar position to mine once compared himself to a Porsche, equipped with all the latest technology - but he's stopped dead in Tokyo traffic.'' Nevertheless, recruiters say that even executives like Mr. Katsuragi, who have considerable experience with Western employment practices, regard changing jobs as a big risk. The fear is that the move will radically and permanently change their lives.
Going back to a big Japanese company after leaving is virtually impossible. After all, Japanese tradition has been betrayed. ''You don't go from Sumitomo to Morgan Stanley to Shearson and then back to Sumitomo,'' said Mr. Ogden of Spencer Stuart. ''You're not a pariah but you're definitely regarded as in a different category.''
There are other reasons why a healthy majority of Japanese executives are unwilling to break with tradition. Takeo Kani, a vice chairman of IBJ Schroder, told of a young man who recently joined the Industrial Bank of Japan. A baseball star in college, he was offered far more money to play professional baseball in Japan than he receives as an entry- level bank employee. But Mr. Kani said the young man's primary concern was assuring himself long-term employment, which a career in professional baseball could not offer.
''Like baseball, Western companies pay far better compensation,'' Mr. Kani said. ''But they may not move you up the company hierarchy in a systematic way. If you want to move up, you have to make it happen yourself. But Japanese companies prepare a progression that will last through your life. That's security.''
That makes recruiting these managers difficult. To start with, a recruiter would be lucky to have one call returned from 10 Japanese candidates, Mr. Fifield of Egon Zehnder said. By comparsion, he said, he would expect 7 of 10 Americans to return his calls.
Moreover, Japanese employees do not take time off work to meet with recruiters or their clients, so interviews and negotiations take place late at night or on weekends. As a result, Mr. Fifield said, searches for Japanese executives take two to three times longer than searches for comparable Western executives.
''Even though it's getting easier to recruit there, in Japan the process just takes a lot longer,'' said Mr. Cox of A.T. Kearney. ''You have to drink a lot of green tea before you pop the question.''
 
 
 
HEADHUNTING FOR THE JAPANESE
Until recently, it was unheard of for Japanese companies to hire outside headhunters. Japanese conglomerates like Mitsubishi and Daiwa regularly use American recruiters to find Western managers for their offices abroad. But they have preferred handling local recruiting themselves, usually fishing candidates directly out of Japan's most prestigious universities and providing them with lifetime jobs.
There hasn't been any change of heart, but the rules of recruitment are starting to shift. Five years ago, the Tokyo Executive Search Company, a Japanese recruiting firm, conducted 80 percent of its searches for Western companies looking for Japanese executives. But the firm, which has a joint venture partnership with Ward Howell Group International, a New York-based management consulting firm, says those accounts have shrunk to 60 percent as recruitment for local companies has climbed.
Its Japanese clients tend to be smaller, expansion-minded companies. ''They can't grow their own executives to manage the new divisions and subsidiaries they want to get into, so they raid the bigger companies,'' said Max M. Ulrich, former chairman and currently an adviser to Ward Howell. Dayton Ogden, chief executive of Spencer Stuart, said that a small but growing portion of his New York-based search firm's business in Japan comes from recruiting Japanese executives for closely held or family-owned Japanese businesses. Many of these companies were formed after World War II, and their founders are now at retirement age.
Not surprisingly, the professionals most willing to consider changing companies, recruiters say, are in their 20's and 30's, younger people who have grown impatient with the rigid Japanese career track. They are drawn by the competitive salaries and the more important titles and positions offered by these small companies.
George C. Fifield, a partner at Egon Zehnder International Inc., a Swiss firm with an office in Tokyo, compares the Japanese career ladder to a python that hasn't yet fully digested its latest meal. ''You've got this bulge in there, and young people looking ahead and seeing that bulge are frustrated,'' he said. ''As long as the python has this slug moving through it, you're going to see ambitious younger employees looking for a way around it.''
American recruiters, of course, hope that the recruitment activities of smaller companies will make the practice more acceptable in Japan, particularly among the big conglomerates. ''That's where the gravy is,'' said Mr. Ogden. ''The key to becoming really successful is to break into the indigenous Japanese market and start moving these executives between Japanese companies.''

HEADLINE: California Bankers No Longer Fear Outsiders

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
For years, California bankers have been bracing for the second California gold rush. Come next January, banks from other states can expand into the state's huge and lucrative market. And bankers in the state have feared that New York giants like Citicorp, Chase and Chemical would swoop in and buy large California banks, creating continent-spanning empires.
But as the magic date draws near, it is shaping up to be a less earthshaking event than was thought when the California legislature approved the interstate banking bill in 1986. Most New York banks, weakened by problems with third world debt, can no longer afford to buy a huge California bank. And the California banks, having had five years to prepare, have armed themselves for the conflict. Like Japanese banks, they have bought up attractive independents in the state, leaving little for the New Yorkers.
''Most bankers have forgotten whatever fears they might have had at the time,'' said Howard Gould, the former California banking superintendent who is now managing director of the Secura Group, a consulting firm in Pasadena, Calif. 
Indeed, the major banks in the state, with the exception of First Interstate Bankcorp, are entering the new era in a stronger position than ever. And they are likely to have the fast-growing economy of the nation's largest state and its ringside seat on the Pacific Rim to themselves, maintaining what some consumer groups see as an oligopoly.
In fact, the California banks could end up becoming the nation's premier banks, eclipsing their rivals in New York. It is not surprising, then, that rather than 1991, attention here is focused on the new leaders of three of the state's four largest banks, who were recently appointed to replace executives who shaped those institutions for more than a decade.
At BankAmerica, the state's leading bank, Richard Rosenberg, a marketing whiz, is replacing A.W. Clausen. At Security Pacific, the state's second-largest bank, Robert H. Smith has just replaced Richard J. Flamson. At First Interstate in Los Angeles, down-to-earth Edward M. Carson is expected to reverse some policies of the expansion-minded Joseph J. Pinola. Only at Wells Fargo & Company, ruled by penny-pinching Carl Reichardt, is no change in the works.
Not everyone is convinced that 1991 will be a ho-hum affair. ''It's a sort of once-in-a-lifetime event,'' said Mr. Smith.
While New York banks may not be able to afford to buy into California, there could be mergers of equals between big banks in both states. In addition, California banks will be able to expand into other states after 1991. While they may shun the crowded New York retail market, other areas like the Southeast, might be attractive.
Some analysts believe the Japanese-owned California banks may take most advantage of that new opportunity. Never prohibited from buying California banks, Japanese banks have purchased almost all of the state's medium-sized banks and control 25 percent of its banking assets.
Despite a recent softening in the real estate market and the threat of defense spending cutbacks, California remains almost too attractive for outsiders to ignore. Citicorp, the largest New York bank, is still expected to increase its presence here. And First Interstate, reeling from loan losses, might prove to be a tempting acquisition. ''Everybody figures it will be somebody's Christmas present,'' said one investment banker.
Some super-regional banks, like NCNB of North Carolina, might also move into California. Comerica Inc. of Detroit staked its claim last September, agreeing to buy Plaza Commerce Bancorp of San Jose next year.
The 1986 California interstate banking law was the fruit of persistent lobbying for several years by the New York banks. Some consumer groups also favored the move to stimulate competition. There are more than 400 banks in California, but the four giants control about 65 percent of all deposits. Consumer groups say that California consumers receive less interest on deposits and pay higher interest on loans than in more competitive areas like New York. Yet California bankers claim they compete furiously - on service rather than rates.
But consumer advocates do not expect much change in 1991. The New York banks are not the powerhouses they once were. Although Wells Fargo has only half the assets of Chase Manhattan, its market capitalization is 20 percent higher. The strongest New York banks, J.P. Morgan and Bankers Trust, are not much interested in retail banking, California's main attraction.
Besides, small banks, with assets below $1 billion, are almost the only thing left to buy. And as David A. Brooks, Citicorp's executive in charge of consumer banking in the West, puts it, Citicorp would have to buy as many as 35 to 40 small banks to become as big a player as it would like in California.
Another possibility is to buy a savings and loan. Some of the state's thrifts have as much as $20 billion or more in assets - a substantial market position. But some bankers worry that a thrift's customers would leave after a takeover since they typically look for the best interest rates rather than the long-term relations that banks offer.
That leaves First Interstate, which is considered the most likely takeover candidate in the state. Established before interstate banking restrictions took effect, First Interstate operates in 13 Western states, making it easy for an acquirer to sell off pieces to help finance a purchase. Its banks in California, Oregon, Washington and Nevada are performing well. But the company's results have been dragged down by loan problems in Arizona and, particularly, Texas, which it entered in 1987. The problems caused a net loss of $124.5 million in 1989.
First Interstate would be the most logical acquisition in the state for Citicorp. But both Wells Fargo and Security Pacific say they would be interested. BankAmerica is also thought to be intrigued. ''It's really a question of who is going to pull the trigger,'' said Donald K. Crowley, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, based here.
But analysts say everyone is afraid of pulling the trigger for fear of driving First Interstate into the arms of another bank. That could buy First Interstate time. Mr. Carson, 60, who will take over from Mr. Pinola in June, said First Interstate is ''not looking for a buyer,'' although it is not intent on staying independent ''at all costs.'' He added, however, ''if we perform the way we think we will, then it's in our shareholders' best interest to stay independent.''
Mr. Carson says that unlike his predecessor, his goal is not expansion, but to ''maximize what we've got.'' He has already cut the holding company's headcount to 200, from 500, and says he would sell off some smaller banks in states like Colorado and Wyoming to raise cash, while keeping its major banks, including those in Arizona and Texas.
The bank's recent stock offering, through which Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company bought a 10 percent stake in First Interstate, alleviated its capital crunch. Although the buyout firm says it will be a passive investor, analysts say it might eventually buy First Interstate itself or force its sale.
Bankamerica has undergone a similar transformation. A few years ago, suffering from huge losses from bad loans, BankAmerica was a carcass from which competitors were biting off chunks of market share. Having slimmed down, revved up marketing and put its loan portfolio in order, the bank is a feared giant again. And Mr. Rosenberg, who has headed the bank's California retailing operations since 1987 and will take over from Mr. Clausen in May, is expected to strengthen its retail banking operations in California and elsewhere in the West.
Mr. Rosenberg and most of the other top brass at BankAmerica are veterans of Wells Fargo, as is Jerry A. Grundhofer, head of Security Pacific's California bank. They have spread a style of banking throughout California that turned Wells Fargo into the state's premier bank in terms of profit growth and stock appreciation, although some analysts are now concerned by its large number of loans in troubled areas like real estate and leveraged buyouts.
The philosophy, pioneered by Wells's chairman Mr. Reichardt, is simple: Cut costs to the bone and expand by acquiring banks in one's own state, eliminating redundancies and achieving more efficiencies than buying in another state. Wells is now digesting three small banks to further bolster its market share in Southern California. ''San Diego County is bigger than the entire economy of Oregon,'' said Robert L. Joss, a vice chairman. ''Would you buy a bank in Oregon or would you try to expand in San Diego?''
If any California bank takes advantage of 1991 to move outside the state or merge with a New York bank, it is likely to be Security Pacific. Security, which has expanded into other businesses like investment banking and consumer finance, believes size is necessary for American banks to compete with giants from Japan and Europe. ''If that means being a $200 billion or $150 billion organization by merging with someone, so be it,'' said Mr. Smith, who has long been the heir apparent and had a role in shaping the bank's policies.
 
 
 
CITICORP ON THE PROWL IN CALIFORNIA
John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, has defined three strategic new markets for his bank: Western Europe, Japan and California. That leaves little doubt that the nation's largest bank plans to take advantage of the opening of the California market.
Citicorp already has more than 5,000 employees in the state, engaged in everything from corporate lending to designing automated teller machines. It boasts more credit card holders in California than any bank except Bank of America. And Citicorp, which has long emphasized retail banking, established a foothold in California in 1982 by purchasing a troubled Oakland thrift and renaming it Citicorp Savings.
But trying to turn an ailing thrift into a healthy bank was tougher than Citicorp envisioned. Citicorp Savings has assets of only $7 billion and very low profits. Many consumers and businesses in California are still not aware of Citicorp's presence. ''We're not arrogant enough to believe we're here until customers believe we're here,'' said David A. Brooks, who is in charge of consumer banking for Citicorp in the West.
But 1991 and new thrift regulations could change that. To start, Citicorp Savings will get a new name next month, Citibank Federal Savings Bank, to identify it more as a bank. Citicorp will also be able to combine back office operations of its banks and its thrifts, which could lower Citicorp Savings's costs.
And Citicorp will begin marketing banking services to its credit-card holders in the state. ''If we could just get our card base to bank with us, we'd be the largest bank in California,'' Mr. Brooks said.
But Mr. Brooks, a former vice chairman of Crocker National Bank, said the marketing campaigns won't be effective unless Citicorp has more branches. Right now, Citicorp Savings has 95 branches in the San Francisco Bay area, putting it among the top five banks and thrifts. But in Southern California, the 35 branches are woefully inadequate. ''You can't compete without bricks and mortar,'' he said. That probably means acquisitions, starting in 1991. Mr. Brooks would not comment on whether Citicorp would want to buy First Interstate Bancorp. But he did say that to become a major player in the state's largest metropolitan areas, Citicorp would prefer one or two large acquisitions to numerous small ones.
Some analysts say Citicorp, with its capital base weak and its stock depressed, is not in a great position to make such a move right now. But Mr. Brooks said if the right deal came along at the right price, it could raise the money. ''By the end of the 1990's we will be a big player in this marketplace,'' he said.

HEADLINE: All About/Composite Materials;
Light and Tough, New Materials Head for the Mass Marketing Stage

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
From the outside, today's automobiles still appear to be nearly all steel. But about 8 percent of their weight consists of composites -strong, light combinations of complementary substances. Bumpers, doors, body panels and station wagon tailgates are all commonly made from these materials. Ten years ago, the composite content was less than 2 percent; by the year 2000, some producers of composites contend, their materials will predominate.
Long used for elite tennis rackets, golf clubs and fiberglass pleasure boats, composites are poised to enter the mass market. In the last decade, uses have been found for them in areas ranging from aircraft and missile construction to artificial limbs. Next might come bridges and houses. The Congressional Office of Technology Assessment estimates that composite sales will grow from $2 billion a year now to $20 billion by the year 2000.
Composites can be more stronger and more corrosion-resistant than steel and lighter than aluminum, cutting an airplane's weight by 25 percent to 40 percent. They consist of layers of fibers woven or bonded into sheets of plastic, metal or ceramics to make lightweight materials far stronger than any one of the materials alone. 
Fiberglass is one of the common composites, in which a fiber, like glass, is combined with a base material of polyester, vinyl or epoxy. Advanced composites were developed for to meet needs for higher performance, especially in the aerospace industry. They use more exotic and far more expensive materials - carbon, boron, ceramics and graphite.
Chemical companies are especially enthusiastic about the potential growth. Hercules Inc. of Wilmington, Del., has become a leader in graphite fiber composites, used primarily in aircraft. The company's annual composite sales have doubled in five years, to $150 million, and are expected to double again by 1995. E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which developed the Kevlar composite fiber for bulletproof clothing, has increased sales of composites by about 25 percent a year for the last five years.
The growth in demand for composites faces two obstacles: expense and reduced military spending. High labor expenses make advanced composites far more costly than steel or aluminum. The materials often have to be bonded and shaped by hand. Aluminum costs about $3 a pound, but an advanced composite used in aircraft costs $40 to $70 a pound, approaching the price of silver.
Military contracts account for about 45 percent of the composite market. Some manufacturers are already seeing their military business drop. Now the Pentagon's demand for composites depends on the fate of two projects: the Stealth bomber, which probably contains the most sophisticated use of composites so far, and the Navy's proposed all-composite submarine.
 
THE COMPETITION
 
Again, the U.S. May Lose an Early Lead
 Composites, like consumer electronics, could become another case of the failure of American companies to exploit their initial advantages, according to industry analysts. American companies have led in developing composite materials, but foreign chemical companies are catching up. Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. of Britain and BASF A.G. and Hoechst A.G. of West Germany are among the leading composite producers in Europe. Japanese companies including Toray Industries and the Mitsubishi Rayon Company spend at least 10 percent of their revenues from composites on research and development, more than twice the rate of their American competitors. Among the Japanese innovations are composite engine parts. American auto makers have responded with a joint venture to study composites.
Jack R. Vinson, a professor at the University of Delaware Center for Composite Materials, says the Japanese Government and industry have once again coordinated their research efforts more closely than their United States counterparts. ''There is a serious threat that we will fall behind in the development of the next generation of composite materials,'' he said.
Foreign steel companies are also developing composites. In Japan, the Nippon Steel Corporation is seeing how composites could replace steel in automobiles and appliances. ''The Japanese steel companies realize that the demand for steel will gradually be replaced by the demand for composites,'' said Jonathan Aylen, a professor of economics at the University of Salford in England. ''And they are preparing for it.'' And American steel companies? Little or no research on composites, he said.
 
COST CONSIDERATIONS
 
High-Priced Materials And Lots of Labor
As long as composites remain reltively low volume and labor intensive, costs will stay high. An aircraft wing that one worker can shape from aluminum usually requires a crew of 20 for composites.
But new manufacturing processes are being developed. Composite-making machinery is ''probably the fastest-growing industry in the country,'' said W. Brandt Goldsworthy, president of Alcoa/Goldsworthy Engineering, which has developed machinery to assemble composite plies and shape them automatically. The company can build a composite airplane wing with a single equipment operator. Mr. Goldsworthy urges composite makers to adopt the sort of automation common with other materials. ''Then labor costs will shift,'' he said.
 
FUTURE USES
 
From Bridges to the Roof Over Your Head
 For some researchers delving into the uses of composite materials, all-composite autos are only the beginnings of their ambitions. Why not have composite-car commuters drive over composite bridges to reach their composite homes? First, the bridges. Some experts predict that composites will be used to string cables and lay decks across bridges, perhaps even by the year 2000. Joseph M. Plecnik, a professor at California State University at Long Beach, is already studying the idea of using composites in bridges on a grant from the Federal Highway Administration. ''A composite bridge would not have the corrosion problem you find with other materials,'' he said.
Professor Vinson of the University of Delaware said that the housing industry is likely to use composites for walls and roofs. He foresees plants that could turn out such pieces of homes, complete with insulation and wiring, for assembly on the site. No carpenters, no high labor costs. ''I think we're on the verge of a revolution in the use of composite materials,'' the professor said.
 
FIRST CHOICE IN ARTIFICIAL LIMBS
Again and again, amputees had the same complaint, John A. Sabolich said. Their artificial limbs, aluminum or plastic, were stiff and inflexible, giving them jolts with every motion or step. Mr. Sabolich, president of the Sabolich Prosthetics Research Center of Oklahoma City, decided to develop limbs made from composites - strong, lightweight, durable and springy. ''So in, say, an articial foot, it returns all the energy that the patient puts into the step,'' Mr. Sabolich said. ''It produces a step that our patients say feels more natural.'' The advantages of composites are so great that they have quickly become the first choice for artificial limbs. ''Five years ago we were not making any prosthetic devices using composites,'' Mr. Sabolich said. ''Today, 6 of every 10 patients have artificial limbs that use composite materials.'' The skin-like shells on the limbs are nearly all composites, he said.
Mr. Sabolich has used carbon-based composites for artificial fingers, legs, shoulders, hips and arms. He was not satisfied to make legs that would merely let amputees comfortably walk. ''My main objective,'' he said, ''was to produce a material that would enable disabled people to run.''
Mr. Sabolich said that the nation's 2 million amputees represent a huge potential market. His company and its major competitor, Flex Foot Inc., are both private and do not disclose sales figures.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The Complete Return on Investment

BYLINE: By GELVIN STEVENSON; Gelvin Stevenson, an economist, is a consultant to the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility in New York.

 BODY:
Behind every tract of rain forest that is cleared, every factory that is shuttered and locked and every oil-clogged beach lies an investment decision. These decisions may have paid big dividends to shareholders and other investors - they may have made certain individuals wealthier - but they also have harmed the economy, society and environment.
Traditionally, individuals and corporations have evaluated their investments only according to the financial return to the investor. But if we are to create a decent and sustainable world, we must develop a way to evaluate investments and measure their complete return. The complete return on an investment includes not only the immediate financial reward, but also the financial and physical consequences to other people, the environment and society. 
For some investments, ones that pollute the environment or destroy neighborhoods, the complete return can be very low or even negative. Such investments attack the economic and moral foundations of society, even though they may pay handsome dividends to individual investors. The greater their number, the wider their effect.
With environmental and social crises worsening, it is imperative that society shift more of its investments toward activities with high complete returns. This is not to argue for inefficiency or corporate suicide, but for a higher level of social consciousness. Indeed, such a shift is a major goal of the burgeoning movement for socially responsible investing - in the securities of public and private companies, and in the projects of nonprofit organizations.
The movement is growing. Already, $450 billion in pension funds, endowments and foundations is subjected to screening that limits investments to socially responsible companies. In addition, many investors are taking more direct routes to influencing corporate behavior, including persuasion, proxy fights and product boycotts.
A growing number of religious investors, funds, foundations and individuals are also investing in nonprofit, community-based organizations that provide high complete returns but low financial returns. These organizations are doing good, but are not enriching their investors very fast. The Creative Investment Program of the Presbyterian Church Foundation, for example, is the largest of the 50 or so religious investment programs and has more than $8 million to invest. Together, these religious foundations have committed more than $30 million to nonprofit institutions that serve human needs. These foundations make safe loans, at below-market interest rates, to organizations that attempt to achieve positive social goals.
When I was working at the Presbyterian Church Foundation, helping them invest their money, one of my favorite projects was the purchase of the loans of five neighborhood housing service partnerships around the country. These purchases allowed the housing organizations to make new loans to residents who were otherwise considered ''nonbankable.''
A typical home improvement loan from the neighborhood partnership went to a disabled man and his 87-year-old mother who lived on Social Security in Richland Center, Wis. They borrowed from the partnership to replace their water heater, repair their leaky roof and insulate their home. The total return to the Presbyterian Foundation for supporting this organization was only 4.5 percent - about the rate of inflation. But the complete return was much higher. Another aspect of socially responsible investing is to inject capital directly into emerging companies that have a social purpose. While risky, such investments may even provide a high financial return. One company I am working with is developing pollution control products while another is developing alternatives to cooling systems that deplete the ozone layer. The return to society that these companies offer - if they are successful - makes investing in them worth the risk.
Even though social investing is growing, the allure of quick profits and a high rate of return - no matter what the social cost - remains. But we have a choice. We can we reject investments that damage the environment and the social fabric of our country voluntarily, or we can have these investments limited by legal means. Either way, we have no choice but to limit investments that pay poor social returns. Nothing less is at stake than the decency of our society, the vitality of our economy and the ability of our planet to sustain life.
