HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
A Good Day for Bottom Fishing

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
Skittish investors should stay out of today's ''junk bond'' market. But conditions are ideal for ''bottom fishers,'' the hardy souls with a strong tolerance for risk who scout for bargains in the ruins. And, according to Thomas J. Herzfeld, a Miami-based investment adviser, closed-end funds are the best bargains in today's junk market.
Prices of closed-end funds, which trade on major exchanges like common stock, are set by supply and demand, with fund shares trading at a premium or discount to the value of the bonds in their portfolios. Because of the battering taken by the junk bond market, many closed-end junk funds are trading at prices lower than the value of the bonds in their portfolios. And because many of the bonds held by the funds have been discounted, too, some funds are selling for what Mr. Herzfeld calls a ''double discount.'' 
Many of the closed-end junk bond funds came to market in the last two years and prices have fallen on each wave of bad news: the RJR Nabisco downgrade, the fall of Campeau, the Drexel bankruptcy. Some prices now are down more than 50 percent. ''When sellers panic, the odds are tipped in favor of the buyers,'' said Mr. Herzfeld, who specializes in closed-end fund investment and analysis.
Of course, not everyone thinks closed-end junk funds are such good deals. Some analysts, worried that prices on publicly traded junk bond funds will fall even more, still warn investors to stay away. They say that even if the economic picture is brighter than it was late last year, when the junk market collapsed, many junk bond issuers may still have trouble repaying debt because of industry or company-specific problems.
But there are bargains in closed-end funds for investors who like risk, analysts say. Mr. Herzfeld said the best deals are funds that hold about 30 to 40 percent of junk bonds. That is because some investors who usually buy investment-grade funds got sloppy and bought funds that had some junk; when they realized that, they dumped their shares. That depressed the prices of funds with only moderate amounts of junk.
As a result, paradoxically, prices are now lower for funds that hold higher-quality issues than for those loaded with junk. Right now, Mr. Herzfeld likes Prudential Strategic Income Fund Inc. Managers of the fund, which sells near a 6 percent discount, have announced a meeting this summer to consider converting to an open-end mutual fund. Management supports that, Mr. Herzfeld said, so it's likely to pass. If it does, investors who bought the fund at a discount pick up a bonus: the difference between the discount and the full net asset value of their shares.
Because of their big discounts, he also likes Putnam's Master Income Trust and Master Intermediate Income Trust.
Andrew A. Davis, an associate analyst with Paine Webber, favors the Oppenheimer Multi-Sector Income Trust, which holds about one-third of its portfolio in junk bond issues. The fund came to market at a premium in January 1989 but pulled back from the junk market soon afterward, a move that Mr. Davis calls ''tremendous foresight.'' But because it halved its junk bond holdings, the fund had to cut its dividend and the price of its shares fell to a discount.
For investors who believe that the junk bond market will rebound strongly, Mr. Davis recommends Van Campen Merritt's Limited Term High Income Trust. The fund is fully invested in junk bonds and management says the bonds in the portfolio were culled from the higher-quality issues in the junk bond market. And because the fund's dividend was cut late last year, another dividend cut is not likely soon, Mr. Davis says.
But do-it-yourselfers looking for bargains in closed-end junk bond funds should be careful. ''You've got to get in there and get your hands dirty to evaluate the investment,'' Mr. Davis warned. Analysts say investors should investigate the quality of the issues held by a fund. But that's easier said than done, especially in the wake of Drexel's demise and the market's upheaval. And the declining market makes it even harder: The junk bond group as a whole is now prone to overvaluation by fund managers, Mr. Herzfeld said. Investors interested in closed-end junk bond funds should find out how the fund's manager values the portfolio.
Today's queasy market makes the quality of the issues in a portfolio all the more important. Funds that buy top-grade junk bonds, of course, usually perform better than those holding more distressed ones. You can get this information by speaking to the stockbroker who sold you the fund or by calling the fund's management, Mr. Davis said.
Over all, analysts say, if you feel a closed-end junk bond fund is a bargain when it sells at a 10 percent discount, wait until the discount hits 15 percent to compensate for the possibility that the manager overvalued the bonds in the portfolio.
For his part, Mr. Herzfeld buys bond funds when they trade at a discount that is at least 3 percentage points wider than their average discounts - as long as similar funds are trading at a smaller discount.
 
 
 
CHOOSING YOUR MIX
In today's tumultuous markets, not everything works out as planned. Investors who hoped to capture fat gains from ''junk bond'' funds, for example, were sorely disappointed.
But, investors seeking safety may want to look at middle-of-the-road mutual fund offerings, which are delivering just what they promise. There are two types. A ''balanced'' fund mixes stocks and bonds in a ratio that depends on the manager's reading of the investment climate. The manager of a ''convertible security'' fund chooses corporate securities, usually preferred stock or bonds, that can be converted to common stock at a set price. Neither type gives investors the sometimes-sizzling returns of a stock fund, but they perform better than bond funds.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
More on Mexico's Debt

BYLINE: By ENRIQUE VILATELA; Enrique Vilatela, an economist, is assistant secretary for external financing at the Mexican Ministry of Finance.

 BODY:
The complex nature of the debt agreement negotiated between Mexico and its creditor banks last month has led to some confusion regarding its implications for Mexico's economy.
Debt relief that results from the agreement derives from reductions in the principal amount of close to $7 billion. The interest reduction option gives Mexico additional savings of approximately $800 million a year for the next 30 years, which is equivalent to a principal reduction of around $8 billion. Thus the total debt relief package negotiated this year is equivalent to approximately $15 billion. If these numbers are added to the $5 billion in debt reductions negotiated in 1989, Mexico's total foreign debt drops to approximately $80 billion from $100 billion at the beginning of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's term in December 1988. 
The objective of the Mexican debt relief package was to reduce Mexico's debt. It has now been successfully implemented. As a result, some of the same banks that chose the principal or the interest reduction options are now also willing to consider giving new money to Mexico in the form of trade lines of credit and project financing.
Clear political leadership, fiscal discipline and sound and consistent economic policies make Mexico a much more promising and safer place in which to invest. No valid economic analysis of Mexico can be made by mixing up the financial and tax motivations of the bankers who chose not to give new loans in the package, with the motivations of the business executives who seek, and find, political stability, controlled inflation rates, competitive labor costs, adequate infrastructure, promotional legislation and an advantageous geographic location in an open and export-oriented country. Banks do not lend money to developing countries because of the unstable economic conditions derived from unrealistic economic policies.
Investors are now finding excellent conditions to develop new industries. For example, one might look at the impressive growth in the maquiladora programs. Investment in these assembly and manufacturing plants along the border with the United States has been growing 20 percent a year.
Mexico is facing the last years of the century with great expectations and optimism. For the first time in years, Mexico has the chance to develop and to play a major role in the world economy and, gradually, to improve the quality of life of its population. Mexico will not pass up this opportunity.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1996 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION: THRESHOLD OF PAIN;
Will All This Tax Talk Lead to New Taxes? (Hint: It Usually Does)

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
SUDDENLY, prominent Congressmen are proposing higher taxes and President Bush is reading their lips. Almost overnight, a Federal tax increase seems possible.
Does that mean people should brace for a reversal of the Reagan years? One answer is that there is nothing to reverse. Taxes rose all through those years, notwithstanding Mr. Reagan's enshrinement as a tax cutter.
What was eliminated in Federal taxes crept back in many local ways - higher property taxes, sales taxes, bridge tolls, garbage disposal fees, state income taxes - and in not-so-local ways, like a big increase in Social Security taxes. And the decade ended as it began, with Americans still paying out in taxes 22.3 percent of their total income, according to the Commerce Department. 
The question, then, is not whether a tax increase is in the wings. One always is. The questions are who will levy new taxes - the Federal Government or the hard-pressed states and cities or all of the above - and what new inequities, real or imagined, will be created among classes of taxpayers.
The issue is a hot one now, in large part because the economy has slowed and is thus generating less tax revenue. Since Americans usually resist efforts to wean themselves from many public services, much of the talk lately is of higher taxes rather than cuts in spending.
Even economists who favor spending cuts as a means of eliminating the Federal budget deficit argue that tax increases are also needed to do the job.
''We are an extremely rich country,'' said Henry J. Aaron, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and an advocate of a balanced budget. ''The question is whether we are raising enough to cover the public expenditures that bipartisan majorities insist the nation requires. And we aren't.''
Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is a big voice in this debate, and like many others, he abhors the budget deficit, which is still more than $100 billion a year. What he proposes reflects the mix of taxes and spending cuts now becoming popular. He would freeze most domestic spending for a year, to save $105 billion. He would cut military spending by $150 billion over five years. He would increase taxes on alcohol, tobacco and gasoline, to raise $100 billion a year, and increase the tax rate for the wealthiest Americans, whose incomes have grown faster than their taxes, to bring in $44 billion. Finally, he would put off increases in Social Security payments for a year.
Governors and mayors have their own plans for higher taxes as they seek to offset the losses resulting from a weak economy - without having to cut back sharply on programs undertaken during the boom years of the 1980's.
The squeeze is especially painful in the Northeast. Mayor David N. Dinkins is drawing fire for suggesting an increase in New York City's real estate taxes. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would cancel a planned New York State income tax cut for the wealthy and raise taxes on telephone calls and gasoline - proposals that aren't helping his popularity. And Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut announced last week that he will not run for a third term, in part because he traded popularity among voters for $1 billion in additional taxes, including a big sales tax increase.
''It has been very difficult for states that believe they should raise taxes to do so, when their constituents are being told by President Bush that higher taxes aren't necessary and the solution is to cut spending,'' said Nigel Gault, senior economist at DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic consulting service.
President Bush had kept the Federal Government out of the crossfire with his declarations against new taxes. But now his opposition might be giving way, although the evidence of that is still rather meager. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, has endorsed Mr. Rostenkowski's tax proposals and President Bush has responded politely, saying he is willing to negotiate.
Some people dismiss the President's politeness as political maneuvering. But others say that Mr. Bush, inadvertently or intentionally, has now blessed the tax-raising process and will in time be drawn inexorably into it.
He might not have any choice, given the reluctance to make big spending cuts. The Federal Government, the states, the counties and the cities - all of them together - are not raising enough revenue to contain the Federal budget deficit and the new ones that are developing in many states and cities.
For years, state and municipal governments found ways to pay for services when the Reagan Administration found ways to cut Federal aid. In the process, property taxes, sales taxes and state income taxes have risen to absorb more than 7 percent of the national income, up from 6.5 percent in 1980. Federal income taxes, on the other hand, have fallen to 9.5 percent from 11.2 percent of total income.
Most of the lost money came back to the Federal Government in the form of higher revenues from higher Social Security payroll taxes. But that money went into a special trust fund.
As Federal income tax collections fell, so did the subsidies to the states and cities. Between 1980 and 1989, Federal money for such major items as low-income housing, clean water, job training, public transit, sewage treatment plants and garbage disposal shrank by more than $50 billion a year. New York City today gets only 9.6 percent of its total revenue from the Federal Government, compared with nearly 16 percent in 1981.
But if Federal funds dried up, Federal requirements did not. Washington issued new regulations for waste disposal and other environmental concerns, for example.
And who got the bill? ''Solid waste disposal is probably the hottest topic today among our members,'' said Douglas Peterson, senior policy analyst at the National League of Cities. ''They are being forced to close landfill sites and replace them with costly incinerators and recycling programs.''
Most costly of all was the Government's broadening of Medicaid coverage, requiring huge new outlays for a health insurance program that is largely financed by the states.
''Mostly it has been the Federal Government saying, 'Do this, do that, and you pay for it,' '' said Marsha Howard, research director for the National Association of State Budget Offices.
The money to carry out these Federal marching orders has been easier to raise in some states than in others. The prosperous northwestern states, for example, currently raise more than enough in taxes for all their needs. Wyoming and Wisconsin are well enough off to consider tax reductions without cutbacks in services. Arkansas, Idaho and Iowa are getting by.
But in other places, especially in the Northeast, shortfalls are reaching into the hundreds of millions of dollars. More than 25 states face either tax increases or spending cuts or both if they are to balance their budgets, a legal requirement that nearly every state and municipality in the nation has imposed on itself.
The scramble to cut costs and raise taxes might not have been necessary in a stronger economy. On the whole, the states and cities might have continued to get by on their own resources. From 1983 until 1988, most of them did, finishing each year with surplus funds.
But in recent months, growth in the Gross National Product has slid below an annual rate of 2 percent. The budget surpluses have disappeared in all but a handful of states, and the total shortfall in the fiscal year 1990 is expected to come to more than $35 billion, according to Commerce Department estimates.
The problem is that, no matter what, tax revenues invariably rise strongly in boom times and not so much when the economy is weak. The taxes that are most sensitive to swings in the economy include corporate income taxes and sales taxes, a main source of income for states and cities.
Revenue from sales taxes rose from 1983 to 1988 at a healthy 8 percent to 14 percent a year across the nation, but last year the rise was only 6.4 percent. The reasons for that are not completely clear. Despite the economic slowdown, Americans still have plenty of income. But surveys of consumer confidence show many Americans to be nervous about spending big chunks of their salaries on cars and big appliances, which in turn produce most sales tax revenue.
The money goes instead into untaxed essentials, like medical care and food, and into untaxed nonessentials, like catalogue purchases and video rentals.
Governor O'Neill has tried to remedy this problem in Connecticut by broadening the sales tax base -the state does not have an income tax - to cover things like consultants' fees, window cleaning, exterminators' services and appliance repairs. And the Governor persuaded the Connecticut Legislature to raise the sales tax to 8 percent from 7.5 percent.
The Northeast in particular has brought down the total national revenue from sales taxes. Four big industries in the region have fallen on hard times: military contracting, computer manufacturing, financial services, and home and office construction. The upshot is that revenue from sales taxes has shrunk in Massachusetts and is growing elsewhere at a rate of less than 5 percent a year.
Property taxes, on the other hand, are less sensitive to downturns, and local governments rely heavily on them. Through the 1980's, property tax revenue rose at an annual rate of more than 10 percent, reaching $127 billion in 1988, the last year for which figures are available.
And perhaps inevitably, property owners are beginning to revolt. This month, officials in two counties in the suburbs of Washington rolled back property tax increases. Resistance movements are also springing up in Vermont, Maine, Nebraska and Wisconsin.
For Ronald Snell, an official of the National Conference of State Legislatures, the message is clear. ''For those states that want to raise taxes,'' he said, ''the options are being narrowed to higher sales taxes and high income taxes.''
At the Federal level, assuming that resistance to significant cuts in spending will continue, there are two other options. One is to raise income taxes and the other is to live with a budget deficit. The deficit is in violation of the Gramm-Rudman law, which requires an ever-lower amount, and an income tax increase is not very popular, despite Mr. Rostenkowski's efforts, although many economists think higher taxes make sense.
Mr. Aaron of Brookings, for example, notes that taxes as a percentage of national wealth are lower in the United States than in most other industrial countries, and the share of national income going into taxes has remained essentially unchanged in this country for two decades.

HEADLINE: CAPITALISM'S CHANCES: A U.S. Expert's View;
Prognosis for Soviet Economy Is Grave, but Improving

BYLINE: By ED A. HEWETT; Ed A. Hewett is a specialist on the Soviet economy at the Brookings Institution in Washington.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LAST week Mikhail S. Gorbachev allowed a tantalizing peek at how he intends to use his new powers as President to push through radical economic changes. Nikolai Petrakov, Mr. Gorbachev's new personal adviser on economics, broke the news in a rather matter-of-fact interview with a Soviet press agency in which he likened the new reform to Poland's cold-turkey plunge into a market economy.
Clearly the economic crisis has scared Soviet leaders out of the paralysis they had been in for years. The Soviet Government now has two good economists in positions of authority, where a year ago there were none. There's Mr. Petrakov, a kind of Russian Milton Friedman, and Leonid I. Abalkin, who is less radical and but nevertheless free of the old orthodoxy. 
If the two men have their way, Soviet consumers will be in for some shocks - for example, unemployment. But if all goes well, as early as this summer the transformation of the system into a market economy could be well under way. By 1991, the economy could begin to take off. That turn of events would come none too soon.
In 1989 the Soviet economy showed unmistakable signs of falling into a tailspin. Even inflated official statistics show no industrial growth as of late 1989 and falling output in the first two months of this year. The only thing growing rapidly is the supply of cash. Consumers are buying everything in sight, then either stashing products like soap and canned foods at home or bartering. Big cities like Leningrad and Moscow are responding with bans on sales of scarce items like refrigerators and some foods to ''foreigners'' - defined as anyone from outside the city - in only one sign that the Soviet economy is disintegrating into many autarkic entities.
To be sure, the roots of the crisis precede Mr. Gorbachev, but his policies have made matters worse. The last five years have seen a succession of sometimes incoherent partial changes, carried out under duress by a recalcitrant bureaucracy. In 1988, for example, Soviet enterprises were ordered to link wages and bonuses to sales, in an effort to force them to satisfy consumers. But no effort was made to hold down money-supply growth or to increase competition. Enterprises simply used their near-monopoly powers to raise revenues by shifting from lower-priced items to ''improved'' products like new models of refrigerators or new brands of sausages for which price went up more than quality.
The alarming deterioration was evident to the naked eye in Moscow early this month. Because of the hemorrhaging money supply, taxi drivers who six months ago accepted rubles from tourists now demand Marlboros or dollars. Black marketeers who would pay six to seven rubles for a dollar a year ago will now pay up to 30.
Soviet leaders are desperately searching for a way out. The result has been a seesaw of radical, then cautious, then radical proposals. Last summer Mr. Gorbachev made the first of several moves intended to set things right when he appointed Mr. Abalkin as Deputy Prime Minister and chairman of the new State Commission on Economic Reform. Mr. Abalkin designed a strategy to create a market economy. After several meetings with Soviet leaders and economists, his plan was submitted for discussion last November in a meeting of Communist Party, Government and business leaders in Moscow.
Mr. Abalkin's approach calls for an open system integrated into the world economy. Changes would include the denationalization of three-quarters of state assets. Most manufacturing plants would be leased to workers or converted into public corporations, whose stock could be traded on a new stock market. Most goods would trade at market prices and capital would circulate through a two-tiered banking system divided into a central bank similar to the Federal Reserve and commercial banks of the United States.
At the time, Mr. Abalkin proposed to start the overhaul immediately, but to go about it slowly, over five or six years. The reaction to the Abalkin program was mixed, but in general the mood was cautious and Mr. Gorbachev was silent. That opened the way in December for Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov to push a different program through the Congress of People's Deputies. His approach pulled back from Mr. Abalkin's fairly slow reform, choosing instead three years of so-called stabilization, supposedly achieved through rapid growth by administrative fiat. Economic reform would then follow. It was wishful thinking worthy of Leonid I. Brezhnev and a severe blow to those who thought that economic perestroika had finally come of age.
But it was also in December that Mr. Gorbachev appointed Mr. Petrakov, a passionate pro-marketeer, as his personal adviser on economics. Since December Mr. Petrakov has spent hours, sometimes entire days, with Mr. Gorbachev, devising comprehensive changes, with the intention of introducing them quickly soon after the Soviet leader acquired his expanded presidential powers. Those powers are now his, and the real Mikhail Gorbachev is about to stand up.
Over the next few months one can hope to expect a flurry of decrees and draft laws that taken as a whole will resemble the plans that Mr. Abalkin had rejected as too risky -in other words, the Polish approach.
The ministries controlling individual enterprises, like the automobile industry, are set to be abolished. The enterprises would be released from their bureaucratic shackles and converted into joint-stock companies.
 
Rubles for Dollars
Under Mr. Petrakov's plan, possibly beginning as early as this summer, prices would be freed and would surely rise quickly. But then they should stabilize if, as is likely, wages are frozen (as in Poland), and the money supply is under tight central control. The ruble would be devalued, and quite possibly some form of partial convertibility of rubles into dollars would be introduced.
If this program takes effect as quickly as it did in Poland, the result is almost certain to be inflation and unemployment, and therefore considerable social tension. But after that, as early as 1991, the Soviet economy could begin a substantial recovery. The prospect of strikes and possibly unrest will surely lead some leaders to argue against this cold bath. But for Mr. Gorbachev and his supporters, it is increasingly clear that if they do not move decisively, the tensions will be far greater in the long run.
It is too soon to tell if Mr. Petrakov's reforms will be introduced and if they will then be carried out. A great deal can go wrong along the way, including a paralyzing conflict over the Baltic states.
But if Mr. Gorbachev does not move this year to set his economy on a totally new course, he will put at risk everything he - and the rest of the world - have gained over the last five years.

LENGTH: 825 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Governor Urges Great Leap and Volunteers to Go First

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
THE Governor of New Jersey has come came up with an alternative to tiptoeing around tax increases: jump in with both feet, to the tune of $2 billion; and while you're at it, overhaul the tax system, wipe out a $580 million deficit and redistribute wealth all at the same time.
''I have just been struck by how hungry people are for leadership,'' said the Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, who has been in office less than two months. There were many critics, however, and some politicians said that the leader he most resembled was Robin Hood.
For better or worse, Mr. Florio's determination to link a specific tax policy to specific social goals stood in sharp contrast to stopgap strategies like that of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in New York, who last week offered a menu of tax increases a la carte and invited the Legislature to choose. 
Whether the Florio plan might become a model for other states whose coffers have been caught short by economic downturn depends in large part on whether the new Governor can soon convince New Jersey taxpayers, possibly in the next 18 months, that short-term pain is in the state's long-term interest. Mr. Florio proposed more than $2 billion in tax increases, including $1 billion in new sales taxes and a doubling of the income taxes on the most affluent residents. He called for cuts in programs from drug treatment to support for the arts, programs that are adored by dozens of well-organized interest groups. His overhaul of the tax system would entail, among other things, shifting money from the affluent taxpayers to poor school districts and to others in need.
Although he was following a dangerous path, Mr. Florio said, he was also sending a message to some Democrats in Congress and fellow Democratic governors: if the party is too timid to lead, he argued, it is following the most dangerous strategy of all.
''The easiest way to not have anybody against you,'' he said, ''is to go into hibernation for a two-year period in Congress or a four-year period in a statehouse.''
His plan's success was by no means certain. The Democratic Speaker of the Assembly, Joseph V. Doria, said he was deeply troubled by parts of it, including the elimination of a popular tax rebate for homeowners. Republicans said the income tax increase - raising the rate from 3.5 percent to 7 percent for those making more than $100,000 a year - would end New Jersey's ''pro-business environment.''
If the plan backfires, either from a revolt in the Democratic Legislature or among the taxpayers, or from a deepening downturn in the economy, some politicians predicted that Mr. Florio may have set himself up for a one-term governorship.
''The issue isn't about simply keeping your job,'' said Douglas C. Berman, the state treasurer and the budget's chief architect. ''It's about doing what you were elected to do.''
 
Setting the Table
While Mr. Florio was announcing his budget, his neighbor Mario Cuomo, who is considered a favorite among potential candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1992, was taking a step-by-step approach to New York's worsening budget picture. One day, he announced support for higher gasoline tax. The next, he suggested a smorgasbord of tax increases, including a personal property tax on automobiles and a higher tax rate on corporations, from which the Legislature could choose.
Reflecting the political dangers of raising taxes, Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut announced last week he would not run for re-election, citing as one reason the political costs of last year's tax increases.
George Sternlieb, a professor of urban studies at Rutgers University, contended that an income tax increase will hurt economic growth.
But, he added, he believed that Mr. Florio was testing the appeal of a revitalized liberalism that might just work politically in an era when Reagan Republicanism may have run its course. ''Florio is saying the party can't win with me-too Republicanism,'' Mr. Sternlieb said. ''There is a significant chunk of the electorate that is looking for new leadership. And Mr. Cuomo is increasingly looking like Hamlet, with so much difficulty making up his mind.''
In fact, Mr. Florio's decision to do so much so soon was based on a good deal of calculation, politicians here say. The pain and protests will strike most severely in his first year and a half in office. With luck, things will improve by next year, and by 1993, when Mr. Florio is up for re-election, the hope is that New Jersey may have a surplus and the complaints of voters will have become a distant memory. His aides note that they left corporate taxes alone, in part not to discourage businesses.
If all goes according to plan, Mr. Florio says, by the end of his first term New Jersey will be protected from future budget crises as the economy heats and cools, the tax system will be fairer, and other leaders might conclude that risky policies can be good politics.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 25, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 815 words

HEADLINE: Serious Times, Trivial Politics

 BODY:
News flash: The Kennedy Library at Harvard University, to encourage better leadership, will bestow its first Profile in Courage Award this year on a public official who follows his conscience instead of the opinion polls.
Think about that. Has conscience become so rare in Washington that the exercise thereof merits a reward for courage? The library seems to think so, and it's not alone. According to a series in The Times last week, even politicians agree that government in America has reached a state of paralysis, crippled by a shallow and hugely expensive political system that inhibits serious debate and exalts evanescent opinion polls over leadership. 
The result, says former Vice President Walter Mondale, is a politics of irrelevance and avoidance. What 200 years of democracy have come to is a tawdry system where poll takers wield more influence than economists and scientists, where negative advertising makes legislators afraid to debate (much less act on) controversial issues, where the costs of running for office render the effective exercise of office impossible.
The idea that the paraphernalia of American politics - the media gurus, the 30-second attack spots, the costs of campaigning - cheapens politics isn't new. What's new is the virtual unanimity among politicians that the system has spun out of control and that something has to be done about its worst excesses - among them these:
The Slash-and-Burn Campaign. American politics has never been confused with a parlor game. But modern technology has escalated the stakes -and the savagery. As Robert Caro's latest book on Lyndon Johnson points out, if a politician in the l940's wanted to tar an opponent, he'd leak a few unsavory charges to his friends in the press and wait for the fuse to burn down. Nowadays, personal attacks can be delivered, and reputations destroyed, in 30-second television blasts beamed into millions of living rooms.
That explains why politicians put less faith in serious discussion than in unenlightening, savage commercials. And why highly paid political strategists search not for an overriding policy issue but an image or code word that can grab and hold the attention of distracted voters. Whether these take-no-prisoners tactics work is less important than the firm belief that they do. ''It would be great to run a campaign on a high level,'' said Al LaPierre, executive director of Alabama's Democratic Party. ''But that's a utopia we're not going to see.''
The Power of Money. Television campaigns cost money and more money. Senators elected in 1988 spent an average of $3.7 million - up 22 percent from only two years before.
The relentless pursuit of money has exacted its own toll on the quality of American politics. The search for money takes up as much as half an officeholder's time. The need for money encourages sleazy efforts to bypass existing spending laws, and favors incumbents by inhibiting all but the wealthiest challengers. The presence of money ties politicians to special interests.
Television, everyone's favorite culprit, is also everyone's favorite savior. The chairmen of the Democratic and Republican Parties, who agree on little else, have both taken up the call for free television time. Ron Brown, the Democrat, says free time would curb campaign costs, break the link between money and political success, and invite new leadership into the political arena.
Lee Atwater, the Republican who happily accepts responsibility for George Bush's negative campaign, says five minutes of free time would force campaigns out of the 30-second swamp. ''To fill five minutes, you'd have to put on substance and you'd have to be very thoughtful.''
These proposals, like others on Capitol Hill, reflect a commendable concern over the emptiness of political discourse. But such proposals may well raise First Amendment concerns, especially if the television stations are asked to foot the bill. Lowering campaign television costs is worth considering. But no single institution, television included, should be asked to pay for clean politics.
The process by which Americans choose their leaders needs reform. It cheats voters, inhibits candidates and discourages leadership. Reducing the costs of campaigning and tightening laws on campaign financing will do much to free politicians from the tyranny of the present system. But to focus exclusively on process, as many analysts do, will not answer public cynicism or usher in a new world of robust debate.
At the end of the day, a few brave people will have to confront their nervous advisers and, even at the risk of defeat, embrace unpopular positions. The issues are out there. On some of them, like the environment, the schools and the nation's dwindling competitiveness, the public seems well ahead of its leaders.
Process is important; but process alone cannot supply political courage.

HEADLINE: Black Hopes in the U.S. and South Africa

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Roger Wilkins is correct in outlining the parallels between the struggles of blacks in the United States and in South Africa (Op-Ed, Feb. 22); however, the divergences may be more telling and revealing.
In 1948 apartheid was imposed, and Pretoria suggested that a major reason was that the African National Congress and its allies were no more than the domestic hands of Moscow, and stern measures were required. In 1954 Brown v. Board of Education signalled the beginning of the end for American-style apartheid. That Washington was having difficulty pointing to human rights violations in Eastern Europe when blacks in the Deep South could not vote had a major influence on the process. 
In 1990, as the cold war recedes and Pretoria finds it more difficult to pose as the lonely bastion against Communism in Africa, Nelson Mandela is released, and in his first public words, he gives thanks not only to the A.N.C. but also to the South African Communist Party and its leader, Joe Slovo. In the United States, however, the leading black organization, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, fired W.E.B. Du Bois in 1948 in a capitulation to cold war pressures, shunned Paul Robeson and other domestic equivalents of Mr. Mandela, precisely because they were perceived as too far to the left.
Only recently, because of wariness about ties to the left of groups like the A.N.C., have the N.A.A.C.P. and other civil rights organizations taken up the anti-apartheid cause. The cold war has come and the cold war has gone while many civil rights organizations still act as if global developments have no impact in this country, while interest rates and economic growth are increasingly influenced by developments in Bonn, Tokyo and elsewhere.
Mr. Mandela, on the other hand, pointed to international solidarity as a major reason for his release. Our left allergy has hampered our movement, has provided fertile ground for the anti-Semitic allusions of Louis Farrakhan, Public Enemy and others, and so in 1990 it is possible to be more optimistic about the situation of blacks in South Africa than their American counterparts.
This helps account for the emotional outpouring among African-Americans at Mr. Mandela's release. We were subliminally mourning our own lost opportunities.
 
GERALD HORNE
Chairman, Black Studies Department, U. of California, Santa Barbara
 Santa Barbara, Calif., March 2, 1990

HEADLINE: As Highways Crumble, Bush Stumbles

BYLINE: By Neil Goldschmidt; Neil Goldschmidt, Governor of Oregon, was Secretary of Transportation in the Carter Administration.

DATELINE: SALEM, Ore.

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has once again spoken out of both sides of its mouth: first, amid much fanfare, it declares that fixing the country's transportation system is in the national interest; then it turns around and sticks the states and localities with the bill.
It is beyond debate that the national interest is well-served by a healthy transportation system. It is the key to the nation's productivity, to keeping us internationally competitive, to using energy efficiently, and to maintaining air quality. It is also beyond debate that our transportation system is urgently in need of repair. This is not a job to be taken up piecemeal; it is a job for the nation. 
The Bush transportation policy, as recently articulated by Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner, is partly based on the premise that the states and localities are not doing their part to maintain this vital system. But the facts say otherwise. In 1988, states provided 50 percent of the funds invested in highways; localities paid about 28 percent; the Federal Government paid the remaining 22 percent.
In Oregon, we spoke the dreaded ''T'' word: taxes. Our gas tax has risen nearly 200 percent in a decade; last year, 18 other states increased motor-fuel taxes, and New York may do the same. States are clearly willing to take a greater role in addressing highway and transit needs. But any transportation policy maker who understands the size of the problem would not reduce Federal funding.
Let's look at the interstate highways, a truly national system linking all the states. While it makes up only 1 percent of the nation's highway mileage, the 43,000-mile system handles more than 21 percent of all vehicle miles traveled in the U.S.
Under existing ''match'' formulas, maintaining conditions and services at roughly current levels would require about $6.4 billion from the Federal Government each year. Currently, Federal funding is less than half that amount.
As maintenance and repair costs mount, there is no national plan to prevent further damage to the highways by keeping railroad branch lines open, thereby lessening heavy truck movements across our roads. To further improve the interstate system to meet deficiencies and respond to growth in travel would require about $15 billion in Federal funds at the current match formulas. Presently, the Federal authorization for all highway programs combined is about $14 billion.
The Federal Government has paid 92 percent of the cost of building this system - more than $100 billion. The Federal Government paid for it, and it ought to behave as if it owns it. That means paying 92 percent of the cost of maintaining, repairing and expanding it.
The Bush Administration says it can't afford that. Yet billions for infrastructure are bottled up in Federal trust funds. Why? Because each dollar spent from the trust fund would increase the deficit by $1 - a political taboo in the Reagan-Bush era.
And what about public transit? If the President was serious about improving air quality, energy conservation and improving quality of life, he would not continue to reduce the Federal investment in public transit.
Between 1981 and 1988, the Federal share of spending on transit decreased by 50 percent. In 1981, state and local spending made up 64 percent of all transit dollars. By 1988, that share grew to more than 80 percent. How much more does the President expect the states to bear?
Across the nation, we have potholes and broken bridges that reduce driving speed; bottled-up barge traffic; endless circling in crowded skies; and higher prices for products as they move from harvest to harbor, from factory worker to foreign buyer.
Gridlock and dirty air is not a policy; dependence on oil imports is not a policy; a scheme to shift the tax burden for fixing all this to the states is not a policy. Our country was built by those who knew that the efficient flow of people and products between states was critical to our nation. It is why they explicity protected the Federal interest in interstate commerce in the Constitution.
President Bush's transportation plan is not a policy. It is surrender of the Federal Government's role as the states' partner in insuring the economic viability of our nation.

HEADLINE: SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Colorful Needlepoint That Reflects Brazil

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH HEILMAN BROOKE; ELIZABETH HEILMAN BROOKE, who lives in Rio de Janeiro, often writes for The Times about the arts in Brazil.

 BODY:
LIKE much of Brazil's heritage, the tradition of Brazilian needlepoint comes from its Portuguese past. The stitches found in intricate needlepoint tapestries or rugs have been developed from the Portuguese Arraiolos stitch, named after a small town in Portugal.
These stitches, in rugs and tapestries, convey very Brazilian scenes, the exotic animal and floral life of the Amazon, the pastures and produce of Goias, folk motifs from the island of Marajo in the Amazon River.
The Arraiolos stitch has influenced needlepoint across Europe. Both the needlework of Mary Queen of Scots and the peasant embroidery of Eastern Europe contain this ancient and well-traveled stitch. 
Madeleine Colaco, creator of the Brazilian stitch, derived from the Arraiolos stitch, is considered the doyenne of Brazilian needlepoint. At 81, Mrs. Colaco is still painting her colorful designs and overseeing her needlepoint workshop and studio in Marica, about one hour out of Rio de Janeiro. Born in Tangier, Mrs. Colaco first studied needlework and wools at the palace of Mulai Hafid in Tangier. Later, while living in Portugal, she saw the possibilities of the Arraiolos stitch (a simple cross stitch, crossed by a long half-cross stitch, which is then crossed by a short half-cross, then again by a long half-cross stitch). Escaping the intellectual repression of the Salazar regime, in 1940 Mrs. Colaco and her family moved to Brazil, and there she developed the Brazilian stitch.
Toucans, flamingos, butterflies and banana palms serve as vibrant inspiration for Mrs. Colaco's tapestries, as do the diverse people and places she has come to know in Brazil. She has designed a flora- and fauna-filled tribute to the Brazilian landscape architect Roberto Burle Marx and is currently working on a tribute to Francisco (Chico) Mendes, the rubber worker killed in December 1988 for his efforts to protect the Amazon rain forest.
All her tapestries are executed in the Brazilian stitch, which is practically impossible to unravel. She also uses the Bayeux stitch for artistic outlining. Most of the wool in Mrs. Colaco's tapestries comes from Brazil, but metallic threads, cotton, raffia and acrylics are among the other materials found in a Colaco tapestry.
Fruits and little parakeets in shades of blue and green are the subject for a vertical tapestry with a red background. Approximately 4 feet 3 inches by 2 feet 4 inches, the piece sells for $4,000 (at 72 new cruzados to the dollar).
The needlepoint artistry of Madeleine Colaco, and of her daughter Concessa Colaco, can be found on the walls of European and American museums, galleries and corporate headquarters. In Brazil, the primary showcases for the increasingly popular needlepoint rugs are small showrooms in whitewashed houses in the northeastern town of Recife. Casa Caiada rugs are now sold in the United States and Britain, as well as throughout Brazil.
In 1966, two relatives, Edith and Maria Digna Cavalcanti Pessoa de Queiroz, decided that they would organize some of the local embroiderers to make a few needlepoint rugs. Today, a thousand women throughout the state of Pernambuco annually hand-stitch about 100,000 square feet of Casa Caiada needlepoint.
A look at Casa Caiada's tile-roofed showroom quickly explains the origin of its name. In Portuguese, caiada means whitewashed, and like the picturesque historic district in nearby Olinda, the neighborhood of Iputinga features small whitewashed houses strung along dirt or cobblestone roads.
One dusty signpost is the sole indication that a driver is on the right track to Casa Caiada's showroom. But it seems that all Recife taxi drivers know the 30-minute route, and even if you are traveling elsewhere, many drivers gratuitously recommend a visit to see Recife's well-known rugs.
There is no sign to greet visitors to the Casa Caiada showroom or to reassure first-timers that they have found it. But inside, a smiling receptionist and invigorating air-conditioning provide a welcome climate for viewing Casa Caiada's designs. Rugs in a variety of patterns, sizes and colors hang from the walls of the single gallery.
An average of 30 designs of rugs is available to buy directly from the showroom.
The original Casa Caiada designs were inspired by the 18th-century Portuguese tile facades of the churches and colonial houses in Recife and Sao Luis. But, as Casa Caiada's reputation grew, Maria Digna Cavalcanti Pessoa de Queiroz, today the principal owner and designer, expanded her repertory of patterns.
On the walls and in a handful of color photograph albums, a visitor will find tile-patterned rugs in greens, rusts, mustards and shades of beige, popular colors with Brazilian decorators and home owners. As you sip a refreshing glass of coconut juice, offered by the sales assistant, Guiamar Cavalcanti Cabral, you will also see geometric designs, motifs based on the tribal art of the Amazon island of Marajo, patterns featuring Brazilian birds and vegetation and floral designs in the pastels favored by Americans and Europeans.
While the sales assistant does not speak English, Mrs. de Queiroz and her daughters Patricia and Lucila do.
All of the rugs are hand stitched in pure wool in a needlepoint stitch developed by Casa Caiada to have ''more flexibility,'' according to Mrs. de Queiroz. As Sara Carter describes it in her ''Handbook of Brazilian Stitches for Wall Hangings and Rugs,'' the Casa Caiada stitch ''consists of four squares which together form a larger square. Each of the four squares contains a cross stitch with the top half-cross pointing toward the center of the larger square.'' A Casa Caiada rug has approximately 500 stitches to each square foot for an average of about one pound of embroidery wool in each square foot.
Casa Caiada rugs can be as small as 11 square feet or as large as 375 square feet. Color and size can be modified to accommodate the buyer. A rug of 43 square feet takes a minimum of four months to be custom made. Wool and dyes used in Casa Caiada rugs are made to order, and the rugs are guaranteed color fast.
Flipping through an album of Casa Caiada designs, you will see a rich assortment of patterns. Borda de Flores, or border of flowers, highlights yellow-and-salmon-colored flowers in beige hexagons and squares. Copacabana has a celadon border with red, rose, orange and purple flowers on a black background. Victorian Garden, with roses on a black background, recently won a New York design award.
RUGS are priced by the square meter, and prices vary depending on the design and where you purchase your Casa Caiada rug. Flowers on a trellis pattern, approximately 5 feet 3 inches by 3 feet, features small flowers and leaves in pink, salmon, berry and green tones on a white background. At the Recife showroom, the price is $207. An authentic Casa Caiada rug always has a trademark CC stitched along a border. Casa Caiada's Recife showroom offers the most economical price per meter, $137 per square meter in mid- March. Casa Caiada rugs are also for sale at the D e D shop in the Recife Shopping Center in Boa Viagem and the tourist shop in Recife's Mar Hotel, as well as in shops in Rio de Janeiro, Sao Paulo, New York and through representatives in Houston and London. A Casa Caiada rug bought in the United States or England has been specially treated for cooler climates, and will thus have an additional markup for this modification as well as for shipping charges.
For 11 years Maria Izabel Goberto e Silva worked as a designer for Casa Caiada and, 12 years ago, she launched her own gallery in a pretty white house with gray trim on an unmarked dirt road in the Recife neighborhood of Catanga. Taxi drivers have also learned the path to Dona Izabel's blue-shuttered showroom, knowing to turn at the statue of Padre Cicero and navigate the unmarked dirt roads.
Visiting Dona Izabel's showroom is like stopping by the home of a friend of a friend. A houseboy answers the door, as a backyard rooster seems to announce your arrival. As you survey the two big galleries, draped with Dona Izabel's needlework, she enters to greet and assist you.
An average of 100 rugs are available to buy on any given visit.
IN general, Dona Izabel's patterns are more intricate than those of Casa Caiada. While she uses the same needlepoint stitch as her competitor and has approximately the same number of stitches to the square foot, she incorporates three different sizes of the Casa Caiada stitch. All her rugs are made of pure wool and feature anywhere from 20 to 180 colors. As many as 3,000 embroiderers are in Dona Izabel's employ. Motifs are individually named and feature birds, butterflies, tropical fruits, mosaics, medallions, geometric and floral patterns. In pinks, roses and various tones of blue, Relicario is reminiscent of the rich and elaborately colored rugs of the Middle East.
While it is possible to order a design in different colors, a custom-order for a small rug takes anywhere from six months to a year to complete.
All Dona Izabel rugs have her signature embroidered on a border and all must be purchased through her in Recife. Her needlework has been on display in galleries in Porto Alegre and Curitiba and in Paris, but she does not sell in any stores. Her prices depend on the amount of work and quantity of colors featured in an individual rug. For instance, a rug measuring about 16 feet 3 inches by 7 feet 9 inches with multicolored grapes and flowers on a white background was $1,389.
She does not export rugs to the United States but is creating designs in colors and patterns, pastels and florals, specifically aimed at American buyers.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3, Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1262 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Death Overseas: After Cairo Fire

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
WHAT happens when a family member dies abroad? Events after the deaths of Marver and Sheva Bernstein, two of the four Americans who were among the 17 people who died in the Heliopolis Sheraton fire in Cairo March 1, offer a case study of how the State Department responds to such incidents overseas and provide insights that people hope they will never need.
When fire struck the hotel that Thursday, the American Consul in Cairo was immediately involved, as was the Citizens Emergency Center of the State Department in Washington. Americans were staying in the hotel, and their safety, and identification of any dead, were primary considerations. After that came the sad and tedious tasks that death begets.
In cases of death overseas, the Government must take on the role of temporary executor, delegate for the family and intermediary between grieving people in the United States and a foreign officialdom that has its own way of doing things, not always easy for foreigners to accept. 
The Bernsteins were notable people; he had been president of Brandeis University for 11 years, and she was an economist and officer in social service organizations, including the League of Women Voters. But, as it turned out, the course of events would not have been substantially different if they had been unknown American tourists.
The American consul helps make a positive identification of any American dead, assumes custody of belongings, responds to police requests and relays information on what disposition is to be made of the bodies. Sometimes, when there are few clues to the identities, as in a fire or plane crash, relatives' inquiries to Washington about those who might have been in the area provide needed data.
The Bernsteins were found in the hallway outside their room at the hotel; their passports and Dr. Bernstein's wallet were with the bodies. While this was not enough identification to base a death certificate on, it was adequate for the consul to assume that the Bernsteins were dead and to call the next of kin.
Midge Decter, the writer, who is Mrs. Bernstein's sister, said that she learned from the consul's call on Thursday that her sister and brother-in-law were almost certainly dead. ''My name was on the passport as the person to notify, and I guess the tour operator had my name too,'' Miss Decter said. She, as well as the Bernsteins' best friends, the Maurice Atkins, had copies of the itinerary, but the call came even before they had time to study it and worry.
 
Identified by Dental Records
From the first call on, Miss Decter said, the office of the Consul General in Cairo, Vincent M. Battle, and Sandra Shipshock of the Citizens Emergency Center were in regular touch - ''they were wonderful'' - and told her they were available around the clock. When the bodies could not be positively identified by any other means, the consul's office asked Miss Decter to send dental records for her sister and brother-in-law, which she did.
These arrived in Cairo on Monday, then problems arose. The Egyptian police did not have a forensic expert to make identification. ''We were told that ministerial permission was given for an F.B.I. expert to come in to do it,'' Miss Decter said, ''but that does not mean that at the street level, a foreign expert could get access.'' What Miss Decter meant was that while civilians in difficulty might bribe someone to get things done, consuls do not. Eventually, she said, the British authorities, who also wanted to identify victims, found a private dentist in Cairo qualified to identify the remains, and he also gave a positive identification for the Americans. ''Mr. Battle called, and he sent a telegram with the details, saying he would be sure to provide a rabbi when the coffin was closed,'' Miss Decter said.
The State Department has a system for families in the United States to relay money for expenses and shipping coffins home, but in the Cairo fire the Sheraton Corporation told all of the families that it would pay such expenses. Money for all related expenses is the responsibility of the family, and the State Department does not advance money for this.
Often, frustration develops over religious or political requirements. Unavailability of cremation or embalming may be another difficulty. ''Air shipment is a big problem,'' Frances Jones, a spokeswoman for the Bureau of Consular Affairs in the State Department, said. ''It is the biggest cost and requires a lot of paper work. It may take up to a week.''
Ms. Jones said that the State Department becomes involved in the death overseas of 6,000 Americans a year, and that often, even after positive identification, there is a delay in issuing a death certificate. Once it is complete, the consul can issue to the next of kin what is called a consular certificate of death, which is used for all legal purposes. This is issued in four copies, but she said additional copies were available for $4 each.
''The consul also becomes the provisional executor,'' Ms. Jones said, ''making an inventory of luggage, jewelry, documents and sending a final statement of account to the family.''
 
First Fatal Fire in 53 Years
Officers at the Sheraton Corporation, which managed the hotel for its Middle Eastern owner, Gulf Egypt for Hotels and Tourism, said the fire was the first fatal blaze in 53 years as a corporation. Robert B. Collier, vice president for marketing, said that the staff had safely evacuated more than 800 people from the six-story hotel.
Sheraton had decided some time ago that all hotels worldwide that bore its name - 454 now - would be brought up to certain standards of fire safety beyond local ordinances. Their standards required sprinklers in guest rooms, alarms, smoke and heat detectors and certain types of construction.
The target date is June 30. Some hotels have left the chain since the standards were set.
According to Mr. Collier the owner of the six-story Heliopolis Sheraton had ''agreed to our standards'' and had made a design study of the installation of sprinklers for all guest rooms.
The fire has created a higher visibility for the chain's program, Mr. Collier said. ''We are pressing to meet the June 30 deadline,'' he said. Two other hotels in Cairo bear the Sheraton name, both high-rises, El Gezirah Sheraton, with 520 rooms, and the Cairo Sheraton, with 670 rooms. The Cairo Sheraton, Mr. Collier said, is the only fully sprinklered hotel in the city.
''We need governments to take these things seriously,'' Mr. Collier said, adding that if everyone had to meet safety standards, it would not financially penalize those companies that bring older hotels up to the standards that new ones must meet.
The Bernsteins had arrived at the Heliopolis Sheraton, along with seven other participants, who survived the fire, to join a Smithsonian tour, ''Red Sea Passage,'' the next day. The 90-odd other participants, who arrived after the fire, were placed in the Ramses Hilton for the Cairo stay, according to Pru Clendenning of Smithsonian Tours.
''We have all been made more aware'' of hotel fire safety, Ms. Clendenning said. ''We see that it is appropriate to ask questions. Whoever is making the site inspection should ask about sprinklers.'' Raymond & Whitcomb, a New York travel company, was conducting the Smithsonian's tour.
Emmy Loboda at this company said, ''I don't think that we were aware'' that the hotel did not have sprinklers. ''We will surely take another look at the question.'' Mr. Collier concurred: ''People don't really ask these questions.''
