The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 25, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 48, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4356 words

HEADLINE: SCHUYLERVILLE STANDS STILL;

BYLINE: By James Howard Kunstler: James Howard Kunstler is writing a book about man's impact on the American landscape.

 BODY:
A FEW YEARS AGO I BOUGHT AN OLD house in a village named Schuylerville, 30 miles north of Albany, on the Hudson River. I'd gotten priced out of the rental market in nearby Saratoga Springs, which was awash with prosperity and tourists, and Schuylerville was full of real estate ''bargains.'' Nestled beneath steep hills running down to the riverbank, it was a sad-looking town, clearly fallen on hard times. Many of the storefronts were vacant, with dusty ''for sale'' signs taped in the windows. The surviving business establishments included a tattoo parlor, a liquor store and a shop that sold dented cans of food at cut-rate prices.
After living there awhile, I began to suspect that something drastic was happening in the lives of the people who called it home, something only hinted at by the vacant storefronts, the broken sidewalks, or the general air of rot and disrepair that hung over the village.
I had a teen-age neighbor who dressed up in all-black heavy-metal garb. At hours when boys his age are normally in school, he'd stalk past my house with a 20-pound boom box blaring out the catastrophic anthems of bands like Megadeath, Poison and Anthrax. An hour later, he'd reappear pushing a baby stroller in the opposite direction. He was the baby's father, I learned. Sometimes he would turn up on winter evenings along the old Champlain Canal, a solitary figure watching kids ice skate. 
This young man - still a boy, really - came to personify for me the essence of the town's troubles. For most of Schuylerville's inhabitants, the decade-long fiesta of capital gains known as the Reagan Years might have taken place on another planet - the World of Make-Believe. A remarkable feature of the Reagan boom, the economist Lester Thurow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology told me a year ago, was that whole regions of America were left out of it - big pockets that were chronically depressed while a few hot spots, such as Boston, Long Island, Florida, the New Jersey and Virginia suburbs, Southern California and the Silicon Valley, hummed. Here in Schuylerville, and in many other old industrial towns up the Hudson River - Mechanicville, Fort Edward, Hudson Falls - and west along the Mohawk River - Amsterdam, Johnstown, Canajoharie - it wasn't morning in America at all. It was more like 4 P.M. on the first day of winter.
THE ECHOES OF MUSKETRY STILL RING UP AND DOWN this part of the Hudson Valley, and you can't walk a hundred feet around the village without running into a blue-and-yellow state historical marker. ''Nov. 28, 1745,'' proclaims one sign, ''on these grounds the French and Indians killed Capt. Philip Schuyler and 30 others.'' The Battle of Saratoga, hallowed as the turning point of the Revolutionary War, was fought eight miles south, at Bemis Heights. The British Army massed at Schuylerville before the conflict and then skulked back here in defeat. ''At this place, General Burgoyne built his bridge of boats across the Hudson River,'' declares a marker just north of the village. ''Site of the Continental barracks where General Stark tried and condemned the Tory Lovelass as a spy,'' says another. The Redcoats parked their artillery where the elementary school stands. Burgoyne negotiated his surrender to Gen. Horatio Gates in the empty lot beside the present grocery store. Yet with all these tablets standing, history was lost on the local teen-age schoolchildren I interviewed, who weren't able to tell me in which war the great battle took place.
The Champlain Canal, built in the 1820's to create a link between Montreal and New York City, was a boon to the town's development. At mid-19th century, much of the city's stock of potatoes was grown here and shipped down by barge, as was the seemingly inexhaustible supply of lumber from the North Country. Pig iron also came down from the Adirondacks, and burnt lime from the foothills of the Green Mountains across the river in Washington County. In support of this activity were the insurers, freight forwarders, barge factories, merchants, bankers and lawyers who had their places of business in the buildings behind the canal basin, not to mention the boatmen, teamsters and common laborers who found a living from the canal. This was the first wave of prosperity, before the heyday of the great mills.
Between the two world wars a dozen factories operated in and around Schuylerville, along the Hudson proper and up the two roaring tributaries that empty into each side of the river within a mile of the village: Fish Creek and the Battenkill. One factory made window sashes and blinds. Others made paper products out of pulpwood from the nearby Adirondacks - cardboard boxes, toilet tissue, wallpaper, electric-wire insulation. There was also a cotton mill.
By 1979, all but two factories had shut down, and one of the remaining two operated at minimal capacity. Their red-brick hulks still stand ghostly along the river, but the machinery has been sold off, the roofs are caving in, and the rail spurs are rank with burdock and knapweed. Farming was equally vital to the local economy, and an even more potent stabilizing force in the community's social order. The town's historian, Tom Wood, who grew up on a dairy farm near the village, estimated that of the 100 or so farms operating in the area when he was a boy in 1950, fewer than half remain today, only 20 of any consequence - including his family's place, now run by his brother.
''When the mills shut down it was almost like doomsday around here,'' Tom Wood said. ''Then the oil crunch hit at the same time. Gas prices went way up. People couldn't commute further to work. They had to get help from Social Services. Maybe that was the beginning of some of our problems.''
FOR ALL PRACTICAL PURPOSES, SCHUYLERVILLE, and towns like it, have become colonial outposts of another America. The idea of the self-sustaining small-town economy, still so potent in our national mythology, is grimly contradicted by the vacant shopfronts and decomposing facades along Broadway, as the main street is called.
Two of the three largest commercial contributors to the tax base are the town's convenience stores, Cumberland Farms and Stewart's, both big chain operations. They exist partly because Schuylerville lies along the main road between Saratoga and Manchester, Vt., and a lot of cars pass through town, but they gobble up plenty of local dollars too. Besides taxes, the convenience stores contribute a handful of near-minimum-wage jobs to the town. What they take out is far more significant: the chance for a local merchant to make a profit, to keep that money in town, where it might be put to work, for instance, in the upkeep of a 100-year-old shopfront building downtown or a Greek Revival house on Pearl Street. But those dollars do not stay in town. The profit generated by the two convenience stores is funneled directly into distant corporate coffers. The officers of those corporations, who do not live here, have no vested interest in the upkeep of 100-year-old buildings or Greek Revival houses. So the old buildings fall into disrepair.
The Grand Union and Oneida supermarkets closed 15 years ago. The three-man police department was disbanded in the mid-1980's, following a bizarre dispute in which the Police Chief arrested the Mayor on an assault charge for grabbing his shoulder during an argument that took place beside the Cumberland Farms gas pumps. About the same time, the town movie theater had evolved into a biker bar, the kind of place where a customer once rode his Harley hog right through the front door. Not long after a patron was shot in the head and killed by a bartender playing with a gun, the establishment(Continued on Page 56) burned down, and ever since has been a charred, vacant hulk surrounded by a chicken-wire fence.
The current Mayor, 35-year-old Kim Gamache, presides over a three-member Village Board of Trustees that operates out of a room in the firehouse. He inherited a financial mess. Back in the 70's, the state ordered Schuylerville to upgrade its sewage-treatment plant. The village ignored the mandate. As a result, the state fined it $35,000. On top of that, Schuylerville was thrown out of state and Federal grant programs that would have paid for half the work. In the mid-80's, another Mayor got the fine reduced and restored some of the grants, but $800,000 in funds had slipped away. The order to build the sewage plant still stood. Now the work has finally gone forward. To pay for it, the village's sewage taxes tripled.
The post of mayor pays $1,500 a year. Gamache works as a groundskeeper at the high school. ''You can probably count the number of people involved in these things on two hands,'' he says ruefully. ''I worry about whether we're eventually going to be so wrapped up in our own lives that no one helps out. And if that happens, small towns are going to be in real trouble.''
One local entrepreneur has been wildly successful. Larry Dwyer, 38 years old, started selling used furniture in 1982, and has since taken over six downtown shopfronts, selling everything from lounge chairs to 12-person hot tubs. His customers come from all over Saratoga, Washington and Warren Counties. ''People will shop hard for big-ticket items,'' he said. Now he employs 18 people. But he has a high turnover among the unskilled men who move his furniture, he says, because they do a lot of drugs, steal merchandise and smash up his delivery trucks.
In 1988, a young violin maker named Martin Macica opened a shop in another vacant storefront. Macica, 28, is the grandson of Czechoslovak immigrants who farmed in Bacon Hill, a mile north of the village. He was a poor student who'd been in trouble as a teen-ager, he told me, but he loved music, met a fiddle maker in nearby Eagleville, and eventually spent four years apprenticing to several master instrument makers in New York City. His violins are bought mainly by professional musicians who play at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center during the summer, and he makes a decent living; his reputation in the craft is spreading. ''People really do want to be cultured,'' he said, speaking of the town. ''They're interested. They like what I'm doing here. Isn't it time we said something good about America?''
THE SAME CIRCUMSTANCES that made it possible for me to buy an old house cheaply here also turned the village into something of a county dump for welfare families. Landlords bought up decayed buildings, fixed up apartments in them with Federal Housing and Urban Development grants and, under the terms of the grants, were obliged to rent to low-income families, most of whom were on public assistance. The occupants, I was told by one social worker, frequently damaged the apartments, and the cycle was repeated.
Schuylerville's population has remained stable for decades at approximately 1,250. The New York State Department of Labor does not tally unemployment statistics for towns of under 25,000, and Saratoga County's Department of Social Services does not break down their welfare caseloads by town, so the hard figures are unavailable. But the signs of poverty are visible and insistent - in the boys who play ''ice hockey'' on the canal without skates, using tree limbs for hockey sticks and a rock for the puck; in the young mothers angrily towing grimy, sullen children; in the blackened eyes and chipped front tooth of the 12-year-old girl I saw one evening at a high school function.
''We're talking a large number of single-parent families, which has contributed not only to the poverty, but to the worsening of dysfunction, the neglect, the sexual abuse,'' said Berny Rasowsky, a Saratoga County psychiatric social worker. Rasowsky's program, Intensive Case Management, takes him into the homes of troubled families in Schuylerville. ''I also go into the school, into the workplace,'' he said, ''wherever I can stir up some change in their lives.''
One night around Halloween, I interviewed 11 children between the ages of 8 and 15 at the village youth center, a prefab aluminum structure beside the town baseball field that had been put up in 1986 with a state grant and money from private charities. Filled with Ping-Pong and pool tables, video games, a computer, a stereo, it was clearly a refuge for these kids, and more than once they expressed their gratitude for its existence. It was better than being home.
Ten of the 11 kids came from families where the natural father was not present. A few had stepfathers. Four had never met their real fathers. Most had half-brothers and half-sisters. Only 4 out of 11 ate breakfast on a regular basis, and all 4 - including an 8-year-old - said they made their own breakfasts because there was no parent in the house when they got up in the morning.
If you go by statistics, the number of cases of child abuse and sexual abuse are up countywide, from a total of 681 reports in 1983, when county officials began to keep the record, to 1,340 in 1989. These figures represent only the cases that were reported to the authorities.
''It's not that they hate their children,'' said Sandy Hunt, a supervisor with the county's Child Protective Services. ''The parents' own needs aren't being met, because they're so busy trying to deal with the basics.''
A psychologist, Frank Arcangelo, who directs the Youth Services Program at the county's mental-health clinic, suggested rather the opposite: that parents in particular were meeting too many of their own needs, while ignoring their children's basic needs, especially the need for personal attention, and he blamed television for it. ''The message it's sending is, 'You can have it all, and you can have it now.' '' The result was a loss of impulse control among adults at every level of daily life. People drank too much, smoked too much, ate too much, spent too much, gambled too much and, when impeded from incessant self-gratification, whacked their spouses and children too much.
Berny Rasowsky, the county social worker, was continually amazed at his clients' inability to manage their incomes, and at the crazy choices they made: ''I see people who have enough income, on paper, to have a manageable existence. Yet they don't.''
He told me about a young woman who worked as a dishwasher, with a partial welfare subsidy. She rented a whole living room full of furniture, including a television and a VCR, for about $3,000 a year. ''To explain to her that she could save her money and buy the stuff for so much less, that it was a matter of being patient, was impossible,'' he said.
The reasons advanced for the rise in sexual abuse were recondite and surprising.
''What I see is boundaries getting crossed in household roles,'' said Sandy Hunt. ''Children performing parental responsibilities, preparing meals, doing household chores - the parentified-child syndrome.''
''Lots of older daughters take on this caretaker role,'' said Berny Rasowsky, ''and somehow they perceive that the role entails wifelike duties to the boyfriend, the stepfather. They also do it to keep peace in the house.''
The figures on teen pregnancy were much sketchier than the abuse statistics. The county began recording them only in November 1987, and the cases included only those that came through the social-service pipeline. Henry Long, a physician's assistant in the storefront medical clinic, is often the first one to discover that a teen-ager is pregnant. On average, they're five to six weeks along and have come in because they've missed a period. If they inquire about abortion, he directs them to Planned Parenthood over in Saratoga. I asked him if the local kids appeared to be ignorant about birth control.
''No,'' he shook his head adamantly. ''They just don't bother with it. They're careless. It's silly. Everything's at their disposal, but they just don't utilize it.'' When I was interviewing the kids down at the youth center, I asked how many of them knew a teen-ager who was, or had been, pregnant. All the hands went up. I was shocked when one of the boys, a 14-year-old, proudly volunteered that his sister was pregnant - shocked because I was acquainted with their mother. She was still a young woman, in her early 30's, who worked very hard at a regular full-time job. She had raised her four children without a husband and without any help from welfare. Now her daughter was about to enter the same miserable cycle.
She agreed to submit to an interview if I didn't use her name - ''it's such a small town,'' she said - or mention where she worked. Born locally, and raised in a distressed family with an alcoholic father, she got pregnant at 16 and quit school.
The first baby's father was a mill hand in his early 20's. The couple was pressured by their parents to marry, she said, but she called it off three days before the wedding. Later, she had two more children with another young man. Returning from a trip out of state, she caught the boyfriend with another woman, ''left him cold, and never saw him again.'' He moved elsewhere and has never seen their two children again. She receives no support from him. This woman moved back home with her mother briefly, working as a grocery clerk and an apple picker, among other jobs. In time, she met another man, married him and moved to Florida. He proved to be a drug abuser. The marriage lasted four months. She was pregnant with a fourth child when she returned alone to upstate New York. That was 10 years ago.
When she learned that her oldest child was pregnant at 15, she ''cried all night long.''
Her daughter is determined to have the child, but doesn't intend to marry the father. He will continue going to community college and work to support the baby. As things stand now, she will remain at home and, in theory at least, find some way to finish high school while caring for a baby. Her mother insists that she must hold at least a part-time job - she currently works at McDonald's in the next town. It is hard to imagine that this pregnant girl will escape the Social Services trap. If nothing else, she'll need Medicaid for the baby's pediatric care. ''I've made it very clear that I'm not going to walk out on them,'' her mother said. ''But I'm not giving up my Saturday nights as a single woman to sit home and babysit. She got herself into trouble. You can't go around holding their hands. Hell, I'm still practically a kid myself. It's a no-win situation. We all lose.''
I FIRST BECAME ACQUAINTED with David Bullard 11 years ago when I was dead-broke, waiting for my first novel to come out, and he hired me to work as a straw boss in his apple orchard at harvest time. These days our relations are a lot less formal, though I call him ''Squire'' and he calls me ''Kommander.'' As a side benefit I get to picnic in his orchard and listen to him talk about local history, which he does with surpassing verve.
''We like to think that the American victory at Saratoga settled matters, but right down until 1783 the British kept raiding, even though Burgoyne surrendered,'' Bullard told me one sleeting autumn night beside his hearth in the house that had served as a British field hospital 200 years ago. ''What really produced Schuylerville was the Yankee invasion, when Governor Gerry of Massachusetts - who lent his name to the word gerrymander - instituted a head tax. My ancestor Alpheus arrived in 1810, from Sturbridge, set up as a merchant, had a sawmill, an inn, a farm, and lots of sons.'' These offspring started the bank, founded the first paper mill, practiced medicine, presided over the school board and built much of the business district. David, 59, and his two teen-age children are now the last remaining Bullards in town. Their orchard of roughly 200 acres has ''been in fruit'' since 1899. They own an additional 200 acres in woods, and corn and hay fields that they lease out. Bullard has often been subject to the blandishments of developers who, hungrily eyeing his property, seek to cash in on the lively Saratoga real-estate market by building condominiums. So far, he has heroically resisted. I say heroically because, like many other farmers, Bullard could have sold out for a tidy million or so and retired to some palm-sheltered strand. But he loves his farm and the work it requires, and he loves the old decaying village nearby, with all its history, and his view of the Hudson as it meanders south from the Adirondacks. At the same time, he is keenly aware of the changes happening in his village.
''As an employer of up to 60 people, I have a certain feel for what's going on,'' Bullard said, lighting the corncob pipe that tends to disguise the fact that he went to school abroad and speaks both French and Japanese fluently. ''I import apple pickers from Florida at great expense. Those people average $14 an hour, and I can't find anyone in Schuylerville who wants to pick apples for $14 an hour. I know I'm living on borrowed time because these pickers are becoming upwardly mobile in Florida. So I'm furiously planting dwarf trees in the forlorn hope that I'm going to be able to get local people to come out and pick these apples without ladders. In fact, it's almost put me out of business to place myself in a position where I'll be able to cope in five years - or my successors in 20 years.''
The local people won't pick fruit, but they are willing to pack apples for shipment after the harvest. It's easier work, though it pays less. ''The phone in the packing house rings 25 times a day,'' Bullard said, ''the babysitter wanting to know where the spare box of diapers is. I'm paying the woman between $6 and $9 an hour, she's paying her babysitter maybe $3.50, she's half nuts all the time worrying what's going on at home - but she drives a brand-new pick-up to work!'' For other families, it doesn't pay to work. ''I have people come to me and say they want to work, but only under the table,'' Bullard said. ''They don't want to report anything because they're going to lose their money from the Government. The system is tipping people on the margin over the wrong way. Once they start down, they keep falling, and become the bottom feeders in society.''
My old brick cottage in the village was a semi-wreck when I bought it three years ago, its original charm concealed behind wild growths of box elder on the outside and cheap paneling on the inside. It was built around 1900, by an Italian who painted angels on the bedroom ceilings. The cellar was full of wooden crates from a local soda-bottling operation that had gone out of business before World War I. Perhaps the Italian worked there. He is gone, of course, the details of his existence lost in history, like the thousands of boatmen who plied the canal, or the men who labored in the Liberty wallpaper factory, or the nameless British dragoon who was unearthed, along with the skeleton of his horse, when David Bullard's great-uncle Dan dug the foundation for his paper mill in 1866.
Town historian Tom Wood, who remembered his excitement as a farm boy coming into the village for street dances on summer nights in the 1950's, said, ''I feel that Schuylerville is sleeping.''
In 1913, the state of New York dredged the Hudson and re-routed the Champlain Canal. At the rapids north of the village, they built new locks that could accommodate bigger barges. A mile-long remnant of the old canal still runs through town, full of carp and bullfrogs. When I moved in, much of the old towpath beside it was overgrown with impassable honeysuckle thickets. Then, last summer, Tom Wood's scout troop went in with brushcutters and cleared it, so it is now possible to walk from the heart of the village clear up to Lock 5 on a turf-covered road where mules once trod pulling barges loaded with potatoes, lumber and lime.
Following the towpath its entire length for the first time one fall day, I felt happily reconnected with the past. No more than 20 yards to my right, the mighty Hudson flowed parallel to the canal. V-shaped squadrons of Canada geese honked raucously overhead. In this setting, the troubled present was detectable only in the broken smokestack of an idle mill across the river, and in the distant whine of trucks on Route 4 hauling their cargoes of Smurfs, snack foods and Nintendo games. That day, the past seemed to have more in common with the future than it does with the present. Many schemes have been advanced in recent years for promoting the economy of Schuylerville. The worst schemes, it seems to me, are those pegged to tourism and to supposedly endless supplies of leisure and gasoline, as if the village could become, say, the Colonial-history zone of a continent-sized theme park. Others view the town's future as a bedroom community for Saratoga and even Albany, a good hour away. These scenarios seem improbable to me because they simply seek to inject doses of prosperity from somewhere outside.
What remains is the Hudson River, source of all the town's past wealth. It is a more benign river in some ways than it was at the turn of the century, for the Sacandaga reservoir now collects the massive spring runoff out of the Adirondacks that used to cause regular devastating floods, and it is a cleaner river than it was 10 years ago, though hardly pristine. Today, the life of the town could hardly be more disconnected from the river. Schuylerville, and towns like it in the Hudson and Mohawk valleys, changed because their local economies ceased to matter, and it is only now beginning to dawn on us that you cannot have a community without a local economy. To buy things made far away, sold by merchants who also live far away, is to be a colony.
I think we are entering an era when small towns will have no choice except to reinvent truly local economies using local assets. The Hudson is Schuylerville's prime asset. To me, a plausible future for the town is one in which people rediscover the river's value and harness its power to make something useful in a way that is not harmful and wasteful. And in the process, perhaps, rediscover their own value.

HEADLINE: JUNGLE IS WINNING THE COCAINE WAR

 BODY:
The battle in the jungle is doomed from the outset as again the Bush Administration -- like its predessors -- ignores a basic tenet of economics: if there is no demand, there will be no need for supply (''In the Cocaine War, the Jungle Is Winning,'' by Michael Massing, March 4). The produce of the jungles in South America is feeding what the article refers to as ''the nation's immense, insatiable habit.'' Drug traffickers are engaged in bringing their product to a busy marketplace.
Interdict all you want. Give the military a new role as drug police. Pour billions into the War on Drugs. None of it will help if we as people do not find an answer to why can't we face modern life without being high. It's so much easier to send in the troops and continue the delusion that we're really doing something about the problem.
 
RANDY WILSON
 Santa Monica, Calif.

HEADLINE: HOW THE TAX CUT LOOKS NOW

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL; Peter Passell writes about economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE GROWTH EXPERIMENT
How the New Tax Policy
Is Transforming the U.S. Economy.
By Lawrence Lindsey.
260 pp. New York: Basic Books. $21.95.
Lawrence Lindsey is the most ecumenical of supply-siders, that tireless band of researchers, editorial writers and lobbyists who brought the gospel of lower taxes to Washington and made a convert of Ronald Reagan. He may also be the least inclined to hyperbole. A Harvard professor of economics who is now serving in the Bush Administration, Mr. Lindsey apparently understands the risks in claiming more than he can deliver. 
It should not be surprising, then, that in ''The Growth Experiment'' he has written a careful and sometimes convincing defense of the 1981 tax cut that put fear and loathing into the heart of the economics establishment. Nor should it really come as a shock that his agenda for further tax reform meshes with the views of a lot of people with no particular affection for Ronald Reagan or George Bush. For the catch to the message of sophisticated supply-siders like Mr. Lindsey is not in what it says about economic efficiency, but in what it usually does not say about the distribution of income.
There was a good case to be made in 1981 for using tax incentives to stimulate work, savings and innovation. But it was the politics of greed, not the economics of the supply side, that dictated the decision to deny lower-income workers most of the benefits. (And the current maneuvering by the President to cut capital gains suggests that Marie Antoinette is alive and well and running a political action committee.) The massive 1981 cut in personal and corporate income taxes was sold to Congress as the ultimate free lunch: the revenues to be reaped from accelerated economic growth, supply-siders insisted, would fully offset the initial losses. Mr. Lindsey concedes that the supply-siders overstated the case, but says that lunch did prove to be a lot cheaper than the skeptics predicted. Roughly two-thirds of the direct costs of the tax cut, he calculates, were recouped. And the offsetting revenues would have been even greater, he suggests, if Congressional Democrats had not engaged in a bidding war with the Republicans over who could deliver the most to business lobbies.
Mr. Lindsey dissembles. It is more than a little slippery for supply-siders to claim full credit for the recovery from the 1980-82 recession and the associated rebound in tax revenues. While the tax cut certainly did lift demand and thereby stimulate the economy, this job might have been better done through an easing of credit by the Federal Reserve. That would have left the economy with both lower interest rates and a lower trade deficit, permitting sustained growth through the 1980's without dependence on hundreds of billions of dollars in foreign capital.
The most interesting chapters in the book are those in which Mr. Lindsey parts company, implicitly or explicitly, with the Reagan party line. In spite of the big income tax cut, he notes, Federal tax revenues as a portion of national income remained near historical peaks during the Reagan years. Thus the primary cause of the ballooning budget deficits had to be increased spending and, in particular, defense spending: by 1987 the cumulative increase in defense outlays under Ronald Reagan amounted to $275 billion, half the total increase in debt.
Mr. Lindsey also acknowledges that ''middle- and working-class taxpayers still bear [tax] burdens far greater than they have through most of the nation's history.'' After much to-ing and fro-ing about ''fairness,'' he calls for tax reform that would have fit nicely into George McGovern's Presidential platform. He would impose a flat rate of 19 percent, with generous exemptions that eliminate income taxes for a family of four earning up to $22,000.
Mr. Lindsey cannot resist a spirited (and partly on-the-mark) defense of the current effort to offer tax breaks on capital gains. But unlike President Bush, he would link the tax preference to the closing of what is probably the most egregious loophole in the tax code: the exemption of estates from capital gains taxes.
Taxing capital gains at death would have collected $5 billion last year, mostly from the estates of the very rich. Moreover, by eliminating the incentive to hold appreciated assets until death, it would dismantle a supply-side barrier to the free movement of capital.
Mr. Lindsey is thus the sort of Reaganite liberals as well as conservatives could learn to work with, if not love. One reason to read ''The Growth Experiment'' is to get a look at the best face of supply-side economics. Another is to understand the tragedy in the co-optation of the supply side by the guardians of economic privilege.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 9, Column 3; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 873 words

HEADLINE: About Cars

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon;
Oldsmobile's Line of 'Trucks'

 BODY:
A truck from Oldsmobile?
Well, yes. Olds used to sell trucks. And if you look it up in the Standard Catalog of American Light Duty Trucks from Krause Publications of Iola, Wis., you will find such gems as a commercial version of the 1904 curved-dash Olds and that other hot-ticket item, the Economy Canopied Express, meant for vending fruits and vegetables.
True, the last of those came off the line 66 years ago. And, true, Oldsmobile's best-selling truck was a 1920 model. True, too, the 1990 version is only sort of a truck. But it surely isn't a car. 
Olds calls it a Silhouette, and it is one of three new vans from General Motors, the others being the Chevrolet Lumina APV (for all-purpose vehicle) and Pontiac's Trans Sport. They roll like peas off the same conveyor belt at Tarrytown, N.Y., and the big difference between them is their equipment and resultant window stickers.
These vans are straight out of the space age, with beautiful plastic bodies over steel frames, a la the sadly defunct Pontiac Fiero. They have fuel-injected V6 engines, front-wheel drive, acres of windshield, and a profile that would do a monorail proud.
Silhouette is, in fact, the most apt of names for a design that Oldsmobile would like to think is one giant step for van-kind.
Swoopy and innovative as it is, one might question its effect on sales of conventional Olds station wagons. Obviously, the question has occurred to Oldsmobile's brass, but the division's general marketing manager, Michael Grimaldi, said he is confident in his brave new world.
''There is a stable group of buyers out there who want the traditional station wagon,'' he said, noting that Olds will continue to offer its midsize and fullsize wagons, the Cutlass Cruiser and Custom Cruiser. ''But the minivan market has exploded. Sales now are about 800,000 a year, and we see that growing to a million or more in the 90's.''
For this first year of the decade, Olds hopes to sell 30,000 Silhouettes, and Grimaldi was frank about the lack of outward difference among the three G.M. minivans.
''What we are offering is a fully equipped van, a leading entry in the upscale market,'' he said. That means a vehicle with a base price of $17,195 and a high end approaching $20,000.
The standard van has two bucket seats aft and a middle bench that seats three. The more expensive tester, maroon with matching leather interior, had four buckets in back. Leather was a $650 option and then there was the ''touring'' suspension that cost $232. What with other items, it added up to a take-home price of $19,587.
From the side, the Silhouette features a smooth upper surface that sweeps from front bumper to the trailing edge of the roof. The windshield is raked at a 66-degree angle, and the clean exterior produces a very low .30 coefficient of drag.
The windshield measures 17.25 square feet, about a third larger than a full-size sedan's, and that creates problems at the same time that it produces fuel-saving aerodynamics and space-capsule good looks. For one thing, it could easily have meant an interior for growing orchids.
The hothouse problem was headed off with a layer of metallic film embedded in the glass to reduce solar rays by about 60 percent. But the effort to create some sort of sensible interior was less successful, and the sheer sprawl of the dash is the thing that gives pause to every first-time occupant.
Behind the wheel, you stare out at a 3-foot-deep plain of matte black, and the thought occurs that it is totally wasted space - and space that will be very hard to clean. What doesn't occur at first glance - but what becomes painfully obvious the first time that you drive into the sun - is the size of the vents needed to defrost so much glass. The vents reflect perfectly on the inside of the windshield and create large blind spots.
Then there was the way the van felt on the road.
Even with the optional larger wheels and stiffer suspension, the Silhouette wallows. It nibbles this way and that. It feels top-heavy and it behaves even worse than most vans, which generally are no great shakes in the handling department.
The problem is not peculiar to Oldsmobile, however, and I know that because I had the same difficulty with a preproduction Pontiac Trans Sport last year. At the time, I forgave the bad manners because it was a hand-built prototype. But it is hard to forgive in a production model.
Still, the Silhouette cruises easily at 65 or 70 on smooth pavement, and its 120-horsepower engine makes it economical, if not quick off the mark. The roofline is low enough to make it suitable for most garages, and the seats, which weigh only 34 pounds, are easy to remove when you want to carry cargo instead of cronies.
Which brings us to one more complaint - one that this time can't be made.
For years, I have grumbled about cars that have no place to put coffee cups. But the Silhouette's seatbacks fold to create trays, each with two cupholders. There are, further, dual cupholders in a dashboard tray, two cupholders molded into the glovebox lid and twin cupholders in the left rear wheelhousing, meaning that the Olds van offers accomodation for 14 cups and cans.
In a six-passenger vehicle, that satisfies even me.

HEADLINE: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;
New York City's Losses, Fairfield's Gains

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
A SURGE of leasing activity in Fairfield County, particularly by companies moving out of New York City, is turning Fairfield commercial realtors here bullish for the first time in almost three years.
In spite of 3-point rise in the office vacancy rate last year, to around 25 percent, optimism is buoyed by the steady absorption of existing space coupled with a steep decline in new construction.
The Southwestern Area Commerce & Industry Association, a business council based in Stamford and covering southwestern Connecticut, found in a recent study that 81 companies moved or planned to move into Fairfield County in 1989. Of the total, 48 were from New York City, with the rest from elsewhere in New York State, New Jersey, Colorado, California and other states. Stamford, which benefited substantially, contains some 14 million square feet of the county's total of about 40 million square feet of commercial space. 
While fewer large corporations are moving to the suburbs, a greater number of small companies and divisions of companies are searching for quarters there, in some cases taking small portions of buildings originally occupied by a single corporation.
Among the companies that have settled or expanded in Fairfield in the past year are Deloitte Touche, with 130,000 square feet in Wilton; Cadbury Schweppes, with a 46,000-square-foot research and development center in Trumbull and a relocation of its international beverage headquarters from London to its existing Stamford office; US West Capital Corporation of Denver to 29,000 square feet in Stamford; W. R. Grace & Company with 26,000 square feet in Stamford; and National Securities and Research with 28,800 square feet in Greenwich.
''The cost of doing business in New York, particularly rents, was one reason for moving,'' said Michael Lynch, executive vice-president of National Securities and Research, a mutual fund management firm. ''More importantly, we serve the public nationwide, and the abruptness with which our New York employees treated people was getting to be a problem. Up here they are more civil, and because there are not many firms, they can't go across the street for another $20 a week.''
Rick Rich, senior vice president of the F. D. Rich Company, Stamford's largest builder, said: ''The cycle is returning, based on the fiscal and social deterioration in New York City. This area continues to have the quality of life and allure it had in the 1970's, and it's still only 40 minutes to Manhattan.''
Paul King Jr., senior vice-president at Grubb & Ellis Realtors in Stamford, takes a more cautious view. ''A handful of Stamford buildings have gone bankrupt and others are having cash flow problems resulting from free-rent deals,'' he said. ''Some lenders are dictating lease agreements that can dislocate tenants down the road in order to facilitate the sale of a building.''
Holger Arning, a broker with William Pitt & Company Realtors in Stamford, said that ''in the first two months of this year we have had 10 announcements of moves out of New York City into the Stamford area totaling 195,000 square feet.''
In addition to moves by financial companies, management consultants, auditors and back-office bank operations, Mr. Arning said ''I have a list of 150 maritime brokers, agents, insurers and owners that have relocated in Fairfield County as a result of the decline of New York's freight piers replaced by container ports in New Jersey.''
''CONNECTICUT is still appealing for New York companies because of its lack of a personal income tax,'' said Stephen B. Heintz, the state's Commissioner of Economic Development. ''It's surprising how powerful that is. And our total tax picture compares favorably with New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts.''
Connecticut's corporate tax rate is 11.5 percent, with a surcharge on net income that the state legislature increased last year from 15 to 20 percent, to the dismay of many businesses. ''That produces an effective overall rate of 13.6 percent,'' said Mr. Heintz.
The basic corporate tax rate in Manhattan is 8.85 percent, but the total New York tax structure is higher, plus operating costs of around $16 a foot (compared with Fairfield's average of $6 a foot) and rents up to $25 a foot higher than the $17 to $25 range in Fairfield.
John Foster, senior vice-president at Cushman & Wakefield Realtor's Stamford office, noted that ''we have several potential tenants requiring hundreds of thousands of square feet for whom there is not enough space.''
''There are limited opportunities for large rentals at Primerica in Greenwich, and in Stamford at 300 Atlantic Street and 177 Broad Street,'' he said, referring to two buildings recently completed by the F. D. Rich Company. An additional 1 million square feet of space is projected countywide by Albert B. Ashforth Realtors, to be completed by the end of 1991.
Another F. D. Rich building, erected for the Singer Company in the 1970's, was taken over along with the chairmanship of the company in 1988 by Paul Bilzerian. Of the total 242,000 square feet, 137,000 square feet is occupied by Singer - now called Bi-Coastal - and seven sublease tenants. The rest is vacant.
Other companies based in Stamford - swallowed up in buyouts that left the city with a vacancy rate that zoomed from 18 percent in 1984 to 32 percent in 1988 - have disappeared altogether. But many original, unleveraged corporations that remain principal occupants of their buildings have adopted subleasing as an alternative to empty space resulting from reduced operations. Champion International and General Reinsurance in Stamford, Union Carbide in Danbury, and Primerica in Greenwich, for example, have taken in or are seeking boarders.
Stamford's Grand List, the annual compilation of all taxable properties, grew by almost $250 million a year through the 1980's to $6 billion this year, based on 1981 property values. In 1991 the city will do the 10-year revaluation required by all Connecticut municipalities. ''At that time the Grand List will jump to between $16 and $18 billion, the largest in the state,'' said Paul Pacter, Stamford's Commissioner of Finance.
''We will have a very diversified market in the end,'' said David Doern of Rostenberg Doern, Fairfield-Westchester Realtors. ''With so much space filled by 30,000- to 50,000-foot users rather than dominated by Fortune 500 companies, the region will feel less shock from economic upheavals.''

HEADLINE: Everyman Image Was Governor's Asset

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
AFTER more than nine years in office, William A. O'Neill is still often regarded - and will likely be remembered - as the state's accidental Governor, a caretaker who held the office through luck, timing and political skill.
Mr. O'Neill, who announced on Tuesday that he had finally decided not to seek a third term, was Lieutenant Governor when Gov. Ella T. Grasso resigned in failing health on Dec. 31, 1980. He was administered the oath of office that day, becoming the 84th governor of Connecticut, and was elected to a full term in 1982 and re-elected in 1986.
As Governor, Mr. O'Neill dominated state politics and fiscal policy throughout the 1980's, but his stature never neared that of his popular predecessor, Mrs. Grasso, and it appeared even smaller when compared with the national reputations of the state's neighboring governors: Mario M. Cuomo of New York, Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Thomas H. Kean, who recently completed two terms in New Jersey.
A former bar owner from rural East Hampton, where he served on the local zoning board, Mr. O'Neill was first elected to the State House of Representatives in 1966. He served six terms as a legislator before being elected Lieutenant Governor in 1978. He was also a Democratic state party chairman, from 1975 to 1978. 
Mr. O'Neill's speech on the night he was sworn into office as Governor seemed to presage the humble, self-effacing tone of his tenure. ''I'm not sure that anyone is ever ready to be the chief executive of a state or a nation or a city,'' he said. ''But you somehow find yourself when called upon to fulfill duties that you yourself and perhaps many others do not feel you capable of.''
Mr. O'Neill, who is 59 years old, is likely to be remembered as an ordinary man and a small-town conservative who turned a lack of flamboyance into a political asset. His was a style based more on personal contact and political skill than on ideological considerations.
He enjoyed marching in parades and dancing with elderly supporters at campaign rallies. Even his occasional malaprops - ''portable'' water for ''potable'' and ''astigmatism'' for ''stigma'' - were endearing to his supporters.
Critics, however, often seized upon his style, or lack thereof. In 1986, he was described as ''unprofessional, unprepared,unresponsive, unimaginative and totally uninspiring'' by Toby Moffett, a fellow Democrat who tried to force a Democratic primary against Mr. O'Neill.
The lowest blow, though, may have come in 1987, when a Republican legislator, Reginald J. Smith of New Hartford, the Senate minority leader and currently a gubernatorial candidate, called Mr. O'Neill a ''potato head,'' a reference to the Governor's round face, short-cropped hair and plodding demeanor.
 
Revenge at the Ballot Box
Mr. O'Neill always scoffed at those who attacked his style. ''I'm a workhorse, not a show horse,'' he once said. ''To be a good leader, you have to have a calming effect on people, rather than the other way around.''
And his revenge came at the ballot box. In 1982, he easily defeated his Republican opponent, Lewis B. Rome. In 1986, the Governor proved what a formidable power broker he could be when he blocked Mr. Moffett from collecting the 20 percent of the party's delegates necessary at the nominating convention. He later went only to defeat the Republican, Julie D. Belaga of Westport, by a landslide.
In 1988, United State Senator Joseph I. Lieberman called Mr. O'Neill ''the most underestimated man in Connecticut politics.''
The son of a chauffeur who opened the bar that Mr. O'Neill sold in 1989, the Governor was a combat flier in the Air Force during the Korean War and sold insurance after attending New Britain Teachers College and the University of Hartford.
He lost his first two bids for the State House of Representatives, in 1960 and 1962. In 1966, after a redistricting squabble forced cancellation of the 1964 election, Mr. O'Neill surprised many observers by beating the Middletown candidate for the Democratic nomination. He finally won the seat in 1966 by 67 votes.
In 1974, Mrs. Grasso, then a United States Representative, picked Mr. O'Neill to manage her 1974 campaign for governor. When John M. Bailey, the Democratic chairman for 30 years, died in April 1975, she backed Mr. O'Neill to fill the remainder of the term, and soon Mr. O'Neill was holding that job along with the position of House majority leader.
When Mrs. Grasso was renominated in 1978 and declined to endorse a running mate, Mr. O'Neill won the battle for lieutenant governor against the state's most ambitious Democrats, including Mr. Lieberman. Two years later, Mr. O'Neill became Governor himself. ''We walked in with great humility and pride, and we walk out the same way,'' Mr. O'Neill said on Tuesday as he stood in the formal dining room of the Governor's Residence in Hartford and told reporters that he would not run again.
Philosophically, Mr. O'Neill has been a conservative Governor who opposed a state income tax, stressed the limits of government. An important task of government is to ''bring in industry and bring in business,'' he said. ''That's what makes the whole thing go.''
He is recognized for creating four consecutive budget surpluses in the middle of the decade, setting up a rainy-day fund that has helped cover some of the state's recent budget shortfalls, improving teacher's pay to the highest in the nation outside of Alaska and responding to the collapse of the Mianus River bridge on Interstate 95 in Greenwich in 1983 with a 10-year, $6.5 billion plan of road and bridge repairs.
Mr. O'Neill's successes as Governor, however, were largely linked to the economic boom of the 1980's. His failures in the past two years, in particular his struggle to close budget shortfalls, were spurred, in large part, by the revenue drain now befalling many Northeastern state governments, a problem made worse by the reductions in Federal social programs under the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
Few chief executives can last almost a decade without scandals within their administration. Mr. O'Neill had his, though most were minor and never tainted him politically.
There was State Police Commissioner Lester J. Forst, who was discharged in 1989 after disclosure that the state police routinely tape recorded telephone calls coming in and out of barracks. There was the state tax commissioner, John G. Groppo, who resigned in 1987 after attempting to embarrass a Republican lawmaker with a secret tax file. And there was Transportation Commissioner Arthur B. Powers, who was charged with accepting bribes.
Mr. O'Neill's largest failure may have been his inability to hold back state spending in light of slowing revenue projections or to restructure the state's tax system to accommodate the fast-growing government. State spending increased at record double-digit paces throughout much of Mr. O'Neill's tenure.
The death knell for his administration may have been struck last summer, when he signed into law a $1 billion patchwork of tax increases, including a rise in the state sales tax to 8 percent, the highest in the nation. The tax hike was the largest in the state's history but was not enough to cover a shortfall of $125 million to $225 million in the fiscal year that ends June 30 and a possible $400 million gap in the next fiscal year.
Mr. O'Neill's withdrawal last week quickly put an end to the relentless attacks that have been fired at him during the past six months. Even though his belated decision left his party without a clear successor only seven months before the election, he is being publicly praised in all corners of the Democratic Party.
Even his staunchest opponents in the Republican Party are painting his departure as a statesmanlike decision. ''Any time any warrior departs the field of battle bloodied but unbowed, regardless of what side they are on, you feel respect,'' said the Republican state chairman, Richard Foley. '' I respect him.''
As for Mr. O'Neill, who as recently as March 15 said he would run for re-election, he will likely spend his last months in office being feted and toasted. He may even grow into a position as a sort of Everyman's eminence of the Democratic Party.
In his speech on Tuesday, Mr. O'Neill said he remained convinced that his policies were right and fair. He maintained that he could have won re-election despite the polls that gave him huge negative job-approval ratings. He also refused to characterize his departure as surrender to his political opponents.

SECTION: Section 12LI; Page 1, Column 5; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2155 words

HEADLINE: Westchester and Suffolk Fighting For Lyme Funds

BYLINE: By States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN a case of competitive shuttle diplomacy, Westchester and Suffolk County officials have been flying back and forth to Washington to plead for Federal help in fighting Lyme disease.
At issue is $500,000 from the first Federal outlay specifically for Lyme studies. Officials from both counties came to the Department of Health and Human Services to argue why their county and why New York State would best benefit from allocations to study Lyme, the nation's fastest-growing infectious disease after AIDS.
Caught in the bureaucratic infighting, the separate requests for money have resulted in mixed reports about the future of Federal money for research on Lyme disease in Suffolk and Westchester. What is clear is that the state should get some money, but not for many months. 
The money that brought Westchester and Suffolk officials to Washington was a fraction of last year's $7 million in Federal outlays for Lyme disease: $5 million for the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., and $2 million for the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. While the future of $500,000 of the Centers money is being decided, the remaining $1.5 million will begin the nation's first Lyme disease center in Fort Collins, Colo.
Beyond that, a maximum of $2 million in grants is available from the National Institutes of Health for Lyme disease research in the area of pathogenesis, studying why the spirochet causes the disease.
At their hours-long summit with Centers for Disease Control representatives, Suffolk officials were told to expect $250,000 in funds for New York State and that the bulk of the remaining $250,000 would go directly to their county. But the Westchester County delegation, who had met with Centers for Disease Control and Health and Human Service officials a few weeks earlier, say they were promised the entire $500,000, probably in the form of a special Westchester County-based study on Lyme disease, where the incidence of the disease is on a par with Suffolk County's.
''We have been told by H.H.S. that we can expect a half-million dollars,'' said County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, who attended last month's meeting with the county's governmental relations director, Phillippe M. Gille; its public affairs director, Claire Palermo, and Dr. Gary Wormser, chief of infectious diseases at New York Medical College and Westchester Medical Center.
Mr. O'Rourke added that the Washington trip was also to advertise this area as an ideal laboratory for national studies on the disease. ''Since we have the population both of ticks and victims, I felt that if they were going to do some research on Lyme, I didn't want it to be done in some place like Nevada,'' he said.
''Westchester is the Lyme disease capital,'' said Mrs. Palermo, who has the disease. Last year the county, which has a smaller population than Suffolk, reported almost as many cases of Lyme disease, and twice the number of cases it recorded in 1988. Suffolk and Westchester, which represent 44 percent of all Lyme disease cases nationwide, reported 1,169 and 1,159 cases last year, respectively.
Acknowledging that Suffolk also claims to be the hotbed of Lyme disease, Mrs. Palermo said, ''It is a strange contest. We're just trying to get our fair share.''
So is Suffolk. ''That's one of the reasons we called this meeting,'' said Representative George Hochbrueckner of Centereach. ''Because we read that the money would go to Westchester.'' He brought the Centers for Disease Control officials together toward the end of February with Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin, County Health Commissioner Dr. David Harris, Dr. Dennis White of the State Health Department and Dr. Raymond J. Dattwyler, who heads the Lyme Disease Center at State University at Stony Brook.
''Lyme disease has had a tremendous economic impact on us,'' said Mr. Halpin. ''Not only has there been the cost of treatment, but this has had a devastating impact on our tourist industry, especially out on the East End.''
Suffolk officials argue that since their county has the highest incidence of Lyme disease, as well as the better ''research infrastructure,'' both within the County Health Department and at the State University at Stony Brook, Federal funds would be more efficiently used in Suffolk.
Despite reports of pledges made, officials at the Centers for Disease Control say they are making no promises.
''I don't want to dispute what they say, but there are no such specific plans for the money,'' said Anne Sims, spokeswoman for the Centers, which has headquarters in Atlanta. She added, ''I don't think we'll even know who gets what until the end of the year.''
Additional word from Dr. George Hardy, who heads the Centers' Washington office, confirmed ''no guarantees'' for Lyme funding, and that no more than $250,000 had been earmarked for research applications from New York.
 
Backbiting
Those familiar with the workings of Federal funding in general and with the Lyme disease efforts in particular say that such confusion is not unusual. Noting that feuds over money, methods and medical priorities have been ripening for years, they caution that it will only get worse as the spreading disease brings more competition for scarce Federal grants.
''There's more to Lyme disease than ticks biting people,'' said Karen Vanderhoof Forschner, president of the Lyme Disease Borreliosis Foundation in Tolland, Conn., the nation's first and only Lyme referral network. ''The real story is behind the scenes: the backbiting, the infighting. From what I understand, this is exactly like what happened in the early days with AIDS.''
Representatives from the two counties say they are not trying to be competitive, they are just serious about fighting a disease that is becoming increasingly costly to combat. From salaries to testing, Westchester spent a total of $384,000 on Lyme disease last year and Suffolk paid out $200,000 to $250,000.
''If the people in Westchester can do a task better than we can, then they should do it,'' said Dr. Dattwyler of Stony Brook. ''But considering the facilities and the tests that need to be made, I don't think they can do it.''
''The idea is to lick this thing, and not to have competition between Westchester and Suffolk,'' said Mr. Gille, who was among the group of Westchester officials who returned to Washington last week to meet with the Congressional delegation to discuss, among other things, Lyme funding.
''But we think that the prevalence of cases is here. And besides, Suffolk is getting most of available funding already, through state allocations to Stony Brook.''
In fact, the great majority of the state's Lyme disease money distributed by the Tick-Borne Institute in Albany, about $400,000 over the last two years, has gone to Westchester. ''There are seven projects that have been funded now,'' said Vicki Zeldin, spokeswoman for the New York State Health Department. ''Most of them happen to be in Westchester.''
But Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget, submitted in January, reduced the Tick-Borne Institute's budget to $150,000 for next year, making Federal money increasingly important. Also in question are state grants of $100,000 that went to Lyme disease research at New York Medical College last year and the $250,000 that paid for similar studies at Stony Brook.
Gloria Wenk, an educator in Dutchess County, which received $24,000 in state money (the only state grantee outside Westchester) said that, considering the severity of budget problems, parochialism would be ''very self-centered.''
Added Ms. Wenk, who is a member of the Tick-Borne Institute advisory committee, ''Some of these counties insist that they're the only ones who have a problem. But they have to look at the big picture. The disease is spreading. This is no longer just a local problem.''
Lyme disease has now spread to 44 states, with about 80 percent of the cases in the six northeastern states of New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Massachusetts. About 20 percent of the nation's Lyme victims are in California, Wisconsin and Minnesota.
Mr. Hochbrueckner, who was instrumental in obtaining much of last year's Federal Lyme funding, will be pushing for more money in the fiscal 1991 budget. President Bush has proposed $2 million for the Centers for Disease Control; Mr. Hochbrueckner will seek an additional $3 million.
Meanwhile, Mrs. Forschner, a lobbyist who was stricken with the disease in 1984, says she has recently elicited a pledge of $7 million to $10 million in new money from the Senate Appropriations Committee. She added that she was wary about having this publicized. ''When some of these people hear about more money, they'll tear apart the Appropriations Committee'' to get the money for their own localities, she said. Mrs. Forschner says she has been charged with drawing up a list of national spending priorities for possible appropriations.
J. Michael Hall, Senate majority clerk for the Labor, Health and Human Services subcommittee, confirmed a rosy future for Lyme appropriations. ''Any disease that is trendy has potential,'' said Mr. Hall, who added that the $7 million to $10 million figure is not out of the question.
But the next few years may turn out to be crucial for Federal money for Lyme disease. ''The Appropriations Committee people say there's a diminishing return in the amount of funds spent in terms of years,'' Mrs. Forschner said. ''If someone doesn't get out there and push on Lyme disease now, it may not be such a hot topic again.''
 
SEEKING AN ACCURATE TEST FOR THE DISEASE
WHILE local governments begin to expand their search for Lyme funds, researchers continue to squabble over Lyme findings: whether the disease is treatable, whether it is fatal, and whether getting this money for research is worth all the trouble in the first place.
Tired of people engaged in ''hyping the disease,'' Dr. Raymond J. Dattwyler of Stony Brook hopes that an accurate test for the ailment will result from a concerted national Lyme effort being begun by the Centers for Disease Control.
''The tests we have are awful, and as a result, I think the disease is overdiagnosed,'' he said. ''The current lab tests can pick up spirochetes unrelated to Lyme disease. So some people are getting positive Lyme test results for something as minor as gum disease.''
Other researchers say inadequate testing could indicate an under-diagnosis. For example, the State Health Department reported about 2,328 cases of Lyme last year in Suffolk and Westchester alone and 181 cases in Nassau. But there were more than 3,000 other cases that seemed similar to Lyme but did not meet the case definition.
First recognized in 1975, Lyme disease is caused by a type of bacterium called a spirochete transmitted mainly by infected ticks found on deer or mice. Its early symptoms include a skin rash near the tick bite, aches, fever and fatigue. If left untreated, the disease can result in joint, nerve or heart problems.
''This disease is very serious, and very widespread,'' said Dr. Erica Asch. ''And even if they are treated, only 40 percent of Lyme victims feel fine.'' Dr. Asch has been working on a long-term follow-up of Lyme patients from Westchester. She said she and her colleagues, who have worked with more than 250 Lyme patients over the last year, are skeptical about those who feel Lyme is not a top priority.
''People who get this disease are unable to return to work; there have even been a couple of deaths reported,'' Dr. Asch said. Her project is threatened by the budget cuts for the state Tick-Borne Institute. ''We saw someone here who died from Lyme disease about three months ago. He was a patient who contracted the disease while emptying the lawn mower.''
Earlier this month, Gloria Wenk, a public educator who is on the Tick-Borne Institute advisory committee, got a call from a woman in Fulton County, N.Y., whose husband died of complications from Lyme disease.
Other health officials, while mindful of the importance of more research, do not see Lyme as the greatest medical need. ''It is a low priority, relative to serious heart diseases, to other infectious diseases, to Rocky Mountain spotted fever, to AIDS,'' said Dr. David E. Graham of the Suffolk Health Department. ''Influenza is far more serious in term of morbidity and mortality than Lyme disease ever was.''
Dr. Dattwyler said: ''Every few years there's a new pop disease and this is it. My feeling is that it's very important. I've dedicated my career to doing this, but if it came to funding us or funding heart disease, cancer or AIDS, we'd be last on my list.''
As the tick season approaches, medical experts agree on one thing: taking precautions. ''I think people are becoming more aware of checking themselves when they come indoors,'' said Ms. Wenk. ''You can't panic. I mean, we're bigger than these ticks.''

GRAPHIC: Photo; ''If the people in Westchester can do a task better than we can, then they should do it,'' said Dr. Dattwyler of the Lyme Disease Center at the State University at Stony Brook. ''But considering the facilities and the tests that need to be made, I don't think they can do it.'' (NYT/Michael Shavel)

HEADLINE: School Takeover: Gentle Words, Tough Action

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
FIVE months into the nation's first complete state takeover of a public school system, Dr. Elena J. Scambio, the state-appointed Superintendent in Jersey City, is trying to combine the big stick with a soft touch as she seeks to lift the city's educational system from the morass it has floundered in for years.
''We will put together the absolutely most magnificent program,'' Dr. Scambio said at a recent news conference at Ferris High School called by the New Jersey Education Association to focus attention on urban education. ''I will then take it and go out and sell it and get schools to say they'd like to try it. People will have a choice.''
The gentle words are about to be accompanied by some tough action. On April 4, in accordance with the state's school intervention law, Dr. Scambio will announce a new administration structure, and many of the more than 120 people employed in the district's main office are expected to lose their jobs. 
 
A 'Leaner' Central Office
The staff members, from clerical workers to the former Superintendent of Schools, Franklin Williams, who was removed from office when the state took control of the district in October and now serves as an assistant superintendent to several elementary schools, are being evaluated on their performance and the need for their particular positions. Dr. Scambio said the new central office would be ''leaner and more finely tuned.''
''Tensions are high and anxiety levels are great,'' said Dr. Scambio, who has scheduled placement and retirement counseling to ease the transition for those who are let go.
 
'The Tip of the Iceberg'
Administrators are not the only ones feeling pressured. A comprehensive assessment of the district's principals began in January, and dismissal proceedings have been begun against 10 tenured teachers, on grounds ranging from intoxication on the job to excessive absenteeism and poor performance. ''That's just the tip of the iceberg,'' Dr. Scambio said. Yet despite a growing list of potential antagonists, Dr. Scambio, a former Essex County Superintendent of Schools, seems to be gaining new friends daily. The New Jersey Education Association, the state's largest teachers' union, has commended her as a ''strong leader and a strong decision-maker,'' and the district's newly appointed 15-member School Board, which serves in an advisory capacity, is equally supportive.
''We're supporting her 100 percent,'' said Nadia Makar, one of the board's two municipally appointed members. ''When parents complain about things that have been neglected for years and years, she does them almost overnight, and she always follows up on board members' suggestions.''
Dr. Walter J. McCarroll, an assistant commissioner with the New Jersey Department of Education, who is overseeing the takeover initiative, said Dr. Scambio's ''style is really ideal for this kind of situation.'' He said, ''She gets a very quick fix on problems.''
Where concerns have been raised, they have more to do with the wisdom of the state's intervention plan than with Dr. Scambio's management abilities. Critics contend that the Department of Education's inexperience with city schools and lack of success in the few urban initiatives it has undertaken make it a poor candidate for making any real improvement.
The Jersey City district is the state's second largest school district, after Newark's, and encompasses 35 schools and nearly 28,000 students.
The state began its effort to take over Jersey City's schools nearly two years ago after the district repeatedly failed to meet state standards over the course of four years. The takeover attempt led to a protracted legal dispute between Jersey City's Board of Education and the Department of Education that was settled only after an administrative law judge ruled in favor of the intervention and the board decided not to appeal.
Immediately after the State Board of Education approved the takeover last Oct. 4, the city's school board was abolished and several top administrators were removed. The state began its control of all aspects of the school district for a minimum of five years.
So far, Dr. Scambio's efforts have been focused on three broad initiatives. The key element of her improvement plan is a ''site-based management'' system in which teachers, principals and parents will have a greater voice in the operations of their schools begining next fall. Advisory councils of teachers and parents are being formed, and principals will be given a say in budgetary and personnel matters.
''School empowerment will give our teachers, our administrators and our parents a feeling of ownership in this district and its future,'' Dr. Scambio said. A series of magnet schools was to be a cornerstone of the system, but that part of the plan has suffered a serious setback because of a decision by Gov. Jim Florio to suspend financing of New Jersey's controversial choice initiative, which would have provided Jersey City with the funds to set up the specialized schools. Dr. Scambio said that Jersey City would use its own funds to develop a magnet system, but that the lack of state support would delay the opening of the schools.
In a second element of her plan, Dr. Scambio is asking the business community to contribute gifts, scholarships, teaching grants, after-school and summer jobs and other help.
Among those who have responded, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has provided choir robes, the Hudson County Chamber of Commerce has agreed to pay for new band uniforms and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority offered free tickets to the Ice Capades for students with good attendance records. Donated billboards and bumper stickers are also promoting support of the public schools.
The problem of aging and neglected school buildings is the final point of focus. At Dickinson High School, a drab cafeteria has been brightened with new paint and furniture, and windows have been installed to afford a view of the New York skyline. The menu plan has been overhauled with students' opinions, and the once underused lunchroom now has waiting lines.
In other schools, there is an effort to remove graffiti as soon as the markings appear, and a long-range construction and renovation plan is under development. ?he intervention law was passed in 1988 after two years of intense debate in the Legislature. Despite substantial revisions to the original proposal, Dr. Scambio said she believed there were some major flaws in the legislation, including the lack of a mechanism to raise capital for construction projects.
It is in the area of finance that Dr. Scambio and the Department of Education may disagree most.
''The position we've taken for three years is that there have been sufficient funds,'' Dr. McCarroll said. ''It's a question of where it is spent. The budget she currently has is a reasonable budget.''
But Dr. Scambio is not so certain that the district's $197 million budget is sufficient. ''I don't know about that,'' she said. ''I'm not sure there is enough money.''
In a budget for next year Dr. Scambio will request increases in a number of areas, including textbooks, additional guidance counselors and after-school programs. There are many other things she would like to have asked for, like a program for children as young as 6 months old, but she has put those wishes aside for now because of economic reality and a lack of space.
State officials say any tax increase because of budget increases will be cushioned for Jersey City residents by an expected reduction in administrative costs and a provision in the intervention law that enables state aid to be distributed to takeover districts on a current year basis, rather than a prior year one.
Jersey City's municipal governing body is also exercising a provision of the intervention law that allows it to appeal for state aid if state-required improvements pose an unreasonable property tax burden.
Because of New Jersey's current fiscal crisis, a number of educators are worried about Governor Florio's commitment to the takeover effort. But Dr. Scambio said the Governor assured her late last month that she could count on his support.
More troubling, she said, was the slow pace of change in social institutions, especially in one where operations have been so ineffective that a simple work order would often take several years to complete. ''The thing that's bogging me down and consuming a lot of my time is analyzing those kinds of things so we can develop efficient and effective systems so that we can focus our energies on teaching and learning,'' she said.
Wrestling with a cold, the April 4 deadline and a job that turns up two more problems for every one that is addressed, Dr. Scambio had this to say about her assignment:
''No, it's not impossible, or I wouldn't be here doing it. But it's the nearest thing to impossible I've ever encountered.''

GRAPHIC: Photo; Dr. Elena J. Scambio, the state-appointed Superintendent of Schools in Jersey City (NYT/Eddie Hausner)
