LENGTH: 1411 words

HEADLINE: Florio's Fast Start Draws Support And Questions

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
IF Gov. Jim Florio's first two months in office are any indication, he is going to leave the state much different from the way he found it.
He has shocked some people, angered others and surprised many, including his supporters, with what Richard Roper, the executive director of the Council on New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University, calls ''the breakneck speed'' with which he has addressed some issues.
Mr. Florio has appointed an environmental prosecutor and signed an auto insurance bill, two items that came right out of his gubernatorial campaign.
 
Tax Increases Sought
 Within days of signing the insurance measure, Mr. Florio called for increases in both the state sales and income taxes to help close a projected $1.4 billion gap in the state budget for 1990-91 and to finance a state takeover of welfare costs. He also plans property-tax relief and increased aid to education. 
The new insurance law, which requires insurance companies to pay $1 billion to help reduce the deficit in the state-run Joint Underwriting Association, is being challenged in court by a number of insurance carriers.
While lawyers for the state battle with the insurance industry, Mr. Florio, a Democrat, will have his hands full trying to drum up votes in the Democratic-controlled Legislature to raise the sales tax to 7 percent from 6 percent, and to raise the top income tax rate from 3.5 percent for those earning $55,000 or more to 7 percent for those with incomes of $100,000 or higher. The changes would raise about $2.6 billion in increased revenue annually.
The curious thing about the rapid unfolding of Mr. Florio's program is that while the frenetic pace is making many of those who will have to deal with the changes nervous, the new Governor is acting more and more relaxed.
 
'Comfortable' With Proposals
At a news conference the day after he delivered his budget message to the Legislature, Mr. Florio sat in a chair in front of a roomful of reporters and, for an hour, answered questions about the budget cuts he has ordered and the need for major tax changes. At one point he said, ''I am as comfortable with what I am proposing as I have ever been about anything I have done.''
But while he is confident that what he is doing is correct, Mr. Florio acknowledged that he did not know if he had the votes to succeed. He began calling local officials and business leaders immediately after presenting his proposals and said he would campaign across the state to convince the electorate that sacrifices were needed to meet economic changes, improve urban education and provide property-tax relief for low- and middle-income residents.
He has ordered department heads to curtail spending in the current budget year, which ends June 30, and has given them spending targets they must meet in the coming fiscal year. ''I've told everyone to tighten your belts until you feel the buckle hitting your back,'' he said.
 
'Breathtaking' Speed and Scope
Mr. Roper said that one measure of how ''breathtaking'' the speed and scope of Mr. Florio's proposals have been was that ''people have completely forgotten about a governor named Tom Kean, who occupied the same chair for eight years.''
Thomas H. Kean, a Republican, faced many of the same financial problems as Mr. Florio when he took office in 1981, but he had to work them out with a Legislature that had Democratic majorities in both houses. Mr. Kean had pledged not to raise taxes during his first term, but was forced to sign increases in both the sales and income taxes to close a budget gap that grew to more than $700 million in his first year.
A worsening national economy was the chief cause for the budget woes then, as it is today. But when the economy turned around in the middle of Mr. Kean's first term, the higher taxes began creating large budget surpluses.
The largesse also inspired increased spending, and the budget grew to $12 billion from $6 billion in the 1980's.
Mr. Florio said that the failure of the Kean administration to create a rainy-day fund during the good years as a hedge against the inevitable economic downturn helped create the problems he found when he took office. Mr. Kean could not be reached for comment last week because he was out of town.
Mr. Florio did not adopt a no-tax pledge during his campaign, but he said he saw no need for new taxes. He said he was forced to change that assessment quickly when tax collection estimates used by the Kean administration to balance the current budget proved to be ''phony.''
Although the level of state aid to public schools will be the lowest in recent years in the coming school year, Mr. Roper said Mr. Florio's plan to provide $600 million in increased aid next year and to change the aid formula to eliminate the disparity in spending between affluent and poor districts and relieve the property tax burden in urban areas ''addresses something that a number of us have been talking about for five or six years when the economy was in better shape.''
But he questioned the wisdom of Mr. Florio's plan to ask for enactment of the sales tax increase this year and the income tax next year.
''I think he will have one chance and one chance only to get a major tax change,'' Mr. Roper said, ''and I think he should go for as much as he can get at one sitting, rather than try for it on a piece by piece basis.''
 
Reduction of Advantage Seen
Bill Walsh, a state and local tax expert with Arthur Andersen & Company, the financial consulting concern, said the tax increases proposed by the Governor would cause companies and individuals to think twice about moving into the state. ''It's not all that good,'' he said. ''It will reduce the state's competitive advantage over other nearby states.''
Raising the highest tax rate on gross incomes from 3.5 percent, a figure Mr. Walsh said ''psychologically seems reasonable,'' to 7 percent for the top wage earners could also make it ''more difficult for businesses to get good people,'' Mr. Walsh said.
On balance, however, he said the adverse impact ''should not be that great.''
In addition to increasing the sales tax, Mr. Florio wants to extend it to cover paper products, soaps, non-prescription drugs, telecommunications and vehicles weighing more than 18,000 pounds. Exemptions for clothing, food and prescription medicines would continue, leaving the state's tax among the least regressive in the country.
Although they say they have not yet worked out all the intermediate increments in the income tax between 3.5 and 7 percent, Florio administration officials say that most of the anticipated $1.2 billion in increased revenue will come from about 15 percent of the state's wealthiest taxpayers.
Although Mr. Florio's plan calls for the elimination of the average $184 in homestead rebates and the law that allows homeowners to deduct their property taxes from their income when computing their state income taxes, it also envisions creation of a new program that would provide up to $500 for those earning less than $65,000 if their property taxes equal more than 5 percent of their earnings.
 
Spending Political Capital
Mr. Florio, who said he recognized that he was spending much of his political capital early in his administration by proposing tough solutions, said, ''That's what I was elected to do.''
He said he knew he had given the Legislature ''a mouthful and then some'' to digest in the coming year, but added: ''I want to have a real balanced budget, not one balanced with phony fixes. I want to get the state off the fiscal roller coaster we've been on, and onto the road to real economic health.''
Norman Glickman, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University, called Mr. Florio's attack on the state's fiscal problems ''refreshing.''
''I see it as populist budget plan,'' Mr. Glickman said, ''and it's interesting because he has broken three political rules - the Bush rule, 'Read my lips, no new taxes'; the Koch rule by not resorting to phony accounting practices, and, most importantly, the Reagan rule by taxing upper-income residents to help lower-income individuals.
''It's very distributive, and the relief it promises is something that mayors and homeowners have been asking for for decades. It will be tough for the short term, because of the budget cuts and the new taxes, but down the road things should be better. I think he has shown some leadership.''

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Helter-Skelter Growth? No, a Worthy Plan

BYLINE: By Christy Van Horn; Christy Van Horn is executive director of New Jersey Future, a statewide organization, based in Highland Park, that represents groups and individuals dedicated to promoting a balanced state plan.

 BODY:
CITIZENS in New Jersey know what unplanned growth will bring: a blighted environment, gridlock in farm country, cities in deeper decay, communities that have lost their sense of place.
That's why, four years ago, the New Jersey Legislature empowered the State Planning Commission to develop a comprehensive growth plan for New Jersey's future. Its action reflected the statewide consensus against helter-skelter growth.
With opinions from all sectors of society, the State Planning Commission has devised a worthy, practical draft plan for balanced growth. It's a plan that preserves the vistas that uplift us and the commerce that sustains us. But misinformation about the draft plan persists, fostered by special interests who would trade our long-range prosperity - the very quality of community life - for short-range profit. 
Opponents say it is a no-growth plan that will ruin the state's economy. On the contrary, it's a growth plan that will strengthen the state's economy. Without careful planning now, the natural and human resources that make New Jersey so attractive to corporations will be lost forever. Far from discouraging growth, the draft plan proposes to manage growth on a statewide basis, using the State Labor Department's optimistic population and employment projections.
Those who argue that corporations or entrepreneurs will bypass New Jersey unless they have free run of the land are cynical and wrong. Most businesses strive to be good citizens. They have a long-term economic stake in stable, attractive communities. That's why so many companies support the state planning process.
The draft plan promotes stability. Stability and predictability benefit developers. This has been the case in Hawaii, Oregon, and Florida, and it can be true in New Jersey as well.
Other critics worry that the plan will add another layer of bureaucracy. On close reading, the draft plan burns red tape. It recommends that state agencies, counties and municipalities coordinate regulations and streamline the permitting process in order to reduce cost and delay. Under a final plan, one-stop permits will be closer to a reality.
Everyone knows the immense problems faced by New Jersey's urban centers. Despite this recognition, some argue that too much money will go to the cities under the plan. In the 1990's, the cities must be looked to for a ''return on public investments.''
The cities are gold mines. They contain the great veins of transportation, infrastructure and humanity. It took decades of systematic disinvestment by the Federal and state governments to cripple urban areas. Thoughtful planning and reinvestment can empower the cities to be full partners in the state's prosperity.
The Planning Commission has targeted 16 of the most distressed municipalities for redevelopment assistance. The draft plan encourages the state and private sector to provide incentives for revitalization.
New Jersey cannot continue to prosper unless the cities prosper. We are interdependent. For example, the smartest solution to the impending labor shortage would be to tap the pool of human resources in the cities.
As for housing, the private market has been unable to produce the type and quantity of housing most needed throughout New Jersey: low-cost and rental. The draft plan enlarges the state's responsibility to provide incentives and policies that prod the private sector to build needed housing at a profit.
Property-rights advocates are concerned that property values will fluctuate unfairly under a state plan. However, the draft plan distributes the benefits and costs of growth more fairly. The draft plan does restrain growth in some areas to protect farmland and open space. However, speculators rather than farmers make up more than 50 percent of those demanding compensation if their land becomes less marketable.
Current public policy in state and local spending has given many landowners handsome profits. Many who anticipate a continuing pattern of windfall profits from development are worried. But government cannot guarantee profit on land speculation; clearly it should not.
To give farmers a fair shake, the draft plan encourages putting in place mechanisms like the public purchase of valuable land, the transfer of development rights like the program in Burlington County, or other innovative ways to preserve farmland and compensate farmers.
The State Planning Commission has no zoning authority. Yet many still say the plan creates statewide zoning that requires ''one house per 20 acres zoning.'' The draft plan contains policy goals and guidelines. Their application remains a function of local government zoning decisions.
The draft plan encourages growth within existing communities. It says that in order to maintain viable agricultural or natural areas, a rural community should target growth in existing towns and villages. That means efficiency in expanding infrastructure and public services. The draft plan's emphasis on good design will mean better land use and nicer, more livable communities.
It also says that outside towns and villages, a different settlement pattern is needed to protect prime agricultural land. The draft plan recommends that housing densities be determined locally and be based on the current capacity of the land and infrastructure to maintain a rural character.
What's more, New Jersey is only trying to protect its remaining 600,000 acres of farmland. In Oregon, the state plan reserves more than 16 million acres strictly for agriculture, 26 times the New Jersey goal.
Finally, critics lament that even if a final plan is adopted, it has ''no teeth'' and nothing much will change. Overnight, maybe not. But the state has broad regulatory and spending powers. They will be used to achieve the goals of a final plan. But the final plan's real strength comes from consensus - the shared agreement among New Jersey's citizenry that careful planning is the key to our future.

PUB-DATE: March 25, 1990

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1, Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1921 words

HEADLINE: Fighting the Competition for Funds to Fight Lyme Disease

BYLINE: By States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE first Federal allocation for studying Lyme disease is the incentive for a contest of sorts between Westchester and Suffolk Counties, whose officials are competing here for a share of the $500,000 available.
Delegations from each county have visited the Department of Health and Human Services to argue that New York State, and one of its counties in particular, would be the best recipient of the Federal funds. While it is clear that New York will be among the states to receive funds, Westchester and Suffolk are receiving conflicting reports about their chances. The two counties together represent 44 percent of all Lyme disease cases nationwide.
The money they seek is a fraction of the $7 million in Federal allocations that were approved last year for Lyme disease, the nation's fastest-growing infectious disease after AIDS. The National Institutes of Health is receiving $5 million. The Centers for Disease Control gets $2 million, including the $500,000 at issue; the remaining $1.5 million will be used to establish the nation's first Lyme disease center in Fort Collins, Colo. 
 
Westchester Delegation Is First to Arrive
In addition, there is a maximum of $2 million in grants available from the National Institutes of Health for Lyme disease research in the area of pathogenesis, studying why the spirochete causes the disease.
The Westchester delegation was the first to arrive here, meeting in February with officials of the Centers for Disease Control and of the Health and Human Services Department. Its members said they were promised the entire $500,000, probably in the form of a special Westchester County-based study on Lyme disease.
But after an hours-long conference with representatives of the Centers for Disease Control, Suffolk officials said they were told to expect that $250,000 would go to New York State and that the bulk of the remaining $250,000 would go directly to their county.
''We have been told that we can expect a half-million dollars,'' said Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, who came here with the county's director of government relations, Philippe M. Gille; its public affairs director, Claire Palermo; and Dr. Gary Wormser, chief of infectious diseases at New York Medical College and the County Medical Center.
Mr. O'Rourke said the trip was an opportunity to advertise Westchester as an ideal laboratory for national studies on the disease. ''Since we have the population both of ticks and of victims,'' he said, ''I felt that if they were going to do some research on Lyme, I didn't want it to be done in some place like Nevada.''
 
Where Is the Lyme Disease Capital?
''Westchester is the Lyme disease capital,'' said Ms. Palermo, who has the disease. Although her county has a smaller population than Suffolk, the 1,159 cases of Lyme disease reported in Westchester last year almost equaled the 1,169 cases in Suffolk. The Westchester total was also double the number of cases it recorded in 1988.
Acknowledging that Suffolk also claims to be the center of Lyme disease, Mrs. Palermo said: ''It is kind of a strange contest. But we're just trying to get our fair share.'' So, of course, is Suffolk. ''We called this meeting because we read that the money would go to Westchester,'' said Representative George Hochbrueckner of Centereach, L.I., who brought together the Centers for Disease Control officials with Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin, County Health Commissioner Dr. David Harris, Dr. Dennis White of the State Health Department and Dr. Raymond J. Dattwyler, who heads the Lyme Disease Center at State University at Stony Brook, L.I.
''Lyme disease has had a tremendous economic impact on us,'' said Mr. Halpin. ''Not only has there been the cost of treatment, this has had a devastating impact on our tourist industry, especially out on the East End'' of Long Island.
 
Suffolk Makes Its Case
Suffolk officials argue that Federal funds would be more efficiently used in their county because it has the highest incidence of Lyme disease and also the better ''research infrastructure,'' within the County Health Department and at the State University at Stony Brook.
Officials at the Centers for Disease Control say they are making no promises. ''I don't want to dispute what they say, but there are no such specific plans for the money,'' said Anne Sims, a spokeswoman for the agency at its headquarters in Atlanta. ''I don't think we'll even know who gets what until the end of the year.''
Dr. George Hardy, who heads the Washington office of the Centers for Disease Control, confirmed that ''no guarantees'' for Lyme disease financing had been made. He said no more than $250,000 had been earmarked for research applications from New York.
Those familiar with the workings of Federal financing in general and with the Lyme disease efforts in particular say that such confusion is not unusual. Feuds over money, methods and medical priorities have been developing for years, they said, and may worsen as the spreading disease brings more competition for scarce Federal grants.
 
Backbiting and Infighting
''There's more to Lyme disease than ticks biting people,'' said Karen Vanderhoof Forschner, president of the Lyme Disease Borreliosis Foundation in Tolland, Conn., the nation's first and only Lyme referral network. ''The real story is behind the scenes: the backbiting, the infighting. From what I understand, this is exactly like what happened in the early days with AIDS.''
Representatives from Westchester and Suffolk Counties downplay the idea of competition, stressing that they are simply serious about fighting a disease that is becoming increasingly costly to combat. Westchester, which established both the first walk-in clinic, the Lyme Disease Diagnostic Center in Valhalla, and the first hotline, spent a total of $384,000 on such efforts last year. Suffolk paid out between $200,000 and $250,000.
''If the people in Westchester can do a task better than we can, then they should do it,'' said Dr. Dattwyler of Stony Brook. ''But considering the facilities and the tests that need to be made, I don't think they can do it.''
''The idea is to lick this thing, and not to have competition between Westchester and Suffolk,'' said Mr. Gille, who was among the Westchester officials who returned here last week to meet with a Congressional delegation about several issues, including Lyme disease. ''But we think that the prevalence of cases is here. Besides, Suffolk is getting most of the available funding already, through state allocations to Stony Brook.''
 
Dividing the State Money
Stony Brook received $250,000 in state grants last year for Lyme disease research, while New York Medical College received $100,000. But almost all of the state money distributed by the Tick-Borne Institute in Albany - about $400,000 over the last two years - has gone to Westchester.
''There are seven projects that have been funded now,'' said Vicki Zeldin, spokeswoman for the State Health Department. ''Most of them happen to be in Westchester.''
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget, submitted in January, proposes a reduction in the Tick-Borne Institute's budget to $150,000 for next year, making Federal money increasingly important.
Gloria Wenk is a member of the Tick-Borne Institute's advisory committee from Dutchess County, which received $24,000 in state money and was the only recipient outside Westchester. Considering the state's budget problems, she said, parochialism is ''very self-centered.''
 
Stressing the 'Big Picture'
''Some of these counties insist that they're the only ones who have a problem,'' Ms. Wenk said. ''But they have to look at the big picture. The disease is spreading. This is no longer just a local problem.'' Lyme disease has now spread to 44 states, with almost 80 percent of the cases reported in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Massachusetts. Many of the nation's other Lyme disease victims are in California, Wisconsin and Minnesota.
Mr. Hochbrueckner, who was instrumental in last year's Federal allocations for Lyme disease, will be pushing for more money in the fiscal 1991 budget. President Bush has proposed $2 million for the Centers for Disease Control; Mr. Hochbrueckner is seeking an additional $3 million.
 
RESEARCHERS STILL DIFFER ON ASPECTS OF LYME DISEASE
WHILE Westchester and Suffolk seek more funds to study Lyme disease, researchers in both counties continue to disagree about how to interpret the findings so far.
Dr. Raymond J. Dattwyler of the State University of Stony Brook on Long Island complains about people ''hyping the disease.'' He said he hoped an accurate test for the ailment would result from the national effort the Centers for Disease Control is undertaking.
''The tests we have are awful and as a result, I think the disease is overdiagnosed,'' he said. ''The current lab tests can pick up spirochetes unrelated to Lyme disease. So some people are getting positive Lyme test results for something as minor as gum disease.''
Other researchers say inadequate testing could indicate an under-diagnosis. The State Health Department, for example, reported a total of 2,328 cases of Lyme disease last year in Suffolk and Westchester Counties, and 181 cases in Nassau. But there were more than 3,000 other cases that seemed similar to Lyme but did not meet the case definition.
 
'Serious and Widespread'
First recognized in 1975, Lyme disease is caused by a type of bacterium called a spirochete, which is transmitted mainly by infected ticks found on deer or mice. Its early symptoms include a skin rash near the tick bite, aches, fever and fatigue. If left untreated, the disease can result in joint, nerve or heart problems.
''This disease is very serious, and very widespread,'' said Dr. Erica Asch, who has been conducting a long-term follow-up study of patients in Westchester. ''And even if they are treated, only 40 percent of Lyme victims feel fine.''
Dr. Asch, whose work with more than 250 patients is threatened by budget cuts for the state's Tick-Borne Institute, added: ''People who get this disease are unable to return to work. There have even been a couple of deaths reported. We saw someone here who died from Lyme disease about three months ago.''
Gloria Wenk, a public educator who is on the Tick-Borne Institute's advisory committee, said she received a call earlier this month from a woman in Fulton County, N.Y., who said her husband had died of complications from Lyme disease.
 
How High a Priority?
But other health officials, while agreeing that more research is an important goal, put Lyme disease in a different perspective.
''It is a low priority, relative to serious heart diseases, to other infectious diseases, to Rocky Mountain spotted fever, to AIDS,'' said Dr. David E. Graham of the Suffolk Health Department. ''Influenza is far more serious in term of morbidity and mortality than Lyme disease ever was.''
Dr. Dattwyler said: ''Every few years there's a new pop disease and this is it. My feeling is that it's very important. I've dedicated my career to doing this. But if it came to funding us or funding heart disease, cancer or AIDS, we'd be last on my list.''
As the tick season approaches, medical experts agree on taking precautions. ''I think people are becoming more aware of checking themselves when they come indoors,'' said Ms. Wenk. ''You can't panic. I mean, we're bigger than these ticks.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 25, 1990

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1, Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1503 words

HEADLINE: Seeking Unity, Pace Awaits New President

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: PLEASANTVILLE

 BODY:
PACE UNIVERSITY has reached to Chicago for a new president to help focus the identity of an increasingly comprehensive and complex educational system as it prepares for a new century.
Patricia O'Donnell Ewers, the 56-year-old chief academic officer at De Paul University, will succeed Wiliam G. Sharwell as the fifth president of the 84-year-old university. She will also be its first female leader. Dr. Ewers, chosen from among 150 candidates in a two-year nationwide search, will assume her duties after she moves to a new home in Hastings-on-Hudson with her husband, John, this summer.
She will oversee a sprawling university system that includes six graduate and undergraduate schools and colleges, enrolls 24,000 full- and part-time students and extends from upper Westchester to lower Manhattan. Its three main campuses, including two in Westchester, are linked by a minibus transportation network whose 100,000 passengers each year make it almost as busy as the county's public system. 
 
'There Must Be a Unifying Mission'
''How to have an institutional image when there are so many locations and programs is a major challenge,'' Dr. Ewers said. ''But there must be a unifying mission for us, whether we are in downtown New York or in Pleasantville.'' This year, for the first time, more Pace students were enrolled in Westchester than in Manhattan.
Dr. Ewers is leaving a university similar to Pace, where she helped resolve a series of challenges similar to several now facing her here. De Paul, like Pace, combines urban and suburban settings, has a reputation for business education and is developing an increasingly diverse academic program at its eight colleges and schools. De Paul, like Pace, is eager to attract high-quality students while providing educational opportunities for the less academically able.
As dean of faculties at De Paul, Dr. Ewers raised declining freshman enrollments, strengthened academic standards while providing additional programs for the less qualified, helped complete a major fund-raising effort and initiated an academic-planning process that relied on strong faculty input to redefine the goals of the institution for its 15,000 students.
Since her selection in December, Dr. Ewers has been making monthly visits to Pace. ''I don't want to spend my whole first year learning,'' she explained.
She will direct a major re-evaluation of the role of the institution, which has grown rapidly from its modest beginnings in l906 as an accounting institute in lower Manhattan, to a college in l947, to its current incarnation as the 12th-largest private university in the nation. Pace University offers degrees in more than 100 fields of study, from a master's degree in computer science to a doctorate in environmental law.
Making sense of all the parts of the Pace University system will not be an easy task, Dr. Ewers said. ''But until you do, it's hard to communicate that mission to others. We'll do it, because in five years, I want Pace to be known.''
Enrollments have leveled off, and the competition for students is growing more intense, reflecting a national trend. Dr. Ewers will oversee a university trying to change from an almost exclusively teaching institution to one in which significant amounts of research is expected, in order to raise academic standards and better compete for a limited student pool.
 
Seeking a Balance Between Two Worlds
She will supervise a $130 million annual budget that has been supported almost exclusively by tuitions but which now must find more non-tuition revenue. Trustees are in the middle of a $100 million capital campaign that Dr. Ewers will help complete.
The university is attempting to maintain an equal balance between its city and county campuses and the competing demands of two very different student populations. The trustees say they are determined to see the university continue to reflect both worlds.
They also hope to maintain and enhance their school's ''entrepreneurial'' reputation with its finely tuned response to its political, business and social environment. The university said also that it intended to remain accessible to a wide variety of student ability, reflecting what Dr. Ewers characterized as a ''strong history and tradition of access for nontraditional students.'' It is a quality, she added, that attracted her to Pace.
 
'Where Are We Going?'
What is needed, Dr. Ewers said during a visit earlier this month, is for Pace University to develop a clear, unifying focus. The process is already under way, with a small group of university leaders convening to begin discussing the goals and objectives of the university.
One of Dr. Ewer's first priorities when she arrives in July ''will be to help us answer the questions 'Who are we?' and 'Where are we going?' said Joseph M. Pastore Jr., provost of the university, ''We are at the brink of establishing academic credibility, which goes beyond our traditional reputation in business education,'' Dr. Pastore said. ''Now we must ask to what extent we can become a legitimate player in higher education. Pace is much more comprehensive today, and we must define and communicate that reality.''
Pace, to a larger extent than many other institutions of higher learning, has carved a role for itself as a school attuned to the political and corporate world around it. Becoming more research oriented while maintaining a practical, product-oriented reputation will not be an easy combination to achieve, Dr. Pastore and Dr. Ewers agreed.
Pace's Michaelian Institute of Sub/Urban Governance in White Plains has traditionally drawn upon the teaching skills and real-life experience of local political officials while it trained such leaders as the Westchester County Commissioner of Social Services, John J. Allen, and the Yonkers City Manager, Neil J. Deluca.
Local corporate leaders serve on the faculty, 12 major corporations have developed specialized employee-training programs with the university and a cooperative-education program is providing 1,400 undergraduates with paid career-related work experiences while they attend school. The majority find jobs with those same employers when they graduate.
 
Declining Enrollment
But enrollment in several university areas is declining, particularly in the master's degree program in business administration at Pace's Lubin Schools of Business in White Plains, which is not accredited by the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business.
Many members of the Pace faculty have opposed seeking accreditation, saying that it would require a larger full-time teaching staff, produce only a perception of higher academic quality and limit the university's ability to hire market-oriented business leaders. Many business leaders can teach at Pace only on a part-time basis.
The trustees have voted to seek accreditation, a move the new president supports. Chief among her priorities, Dr. Ewers said, is achieving an admittedly ''quantitative measure,'' which she said reflects ''which percentage of the faculty have published in particular journals within a five-year period.''
 
Demands in a Competitive Market
But the university, Dr. Ewers said, ''is in a competitive market, and we need to accredit the business school to reverse the M.B.A. decline. Let's get it done.''
Maintaining the university's close ties with area corporations will continue in a number of ways, Dr. Ewers said, as long as Pace remembers that ''an institution must be driven by the locale in which it is located.''
Looking at what she said was a growing number of unemployed professionals, and eager to stabilize enrollments, Dr. Ewers said she planned to initiate a master of arts in teaching for older professionals interested in changing careers.
''Look at the I.B.M. layoff situation,'' she said. ''Here you have all these sophisticated people, and here's a work force we desperately need in the schools. This is an area where we can step in and help. We must never let our agenda only be the internal agenda of the institution.''
 
Excellence Versus Access
Pace trustees and Dr. Ewers are committed to maintaining and enhancing academic standards, and she said that fact would require university officials to address what she called the ''excellence versus access'' question.
''Pace has an obligation not to be exclusive,'' Dr. Ewers said. ''That is it's tradition. You can't bring students in and charge them without offering quality education. Pace is a good school. It could be a better school.''
For students who don't meet traditional academic standards but who demonstrate academic potential, Dr. Ewers said she hoped to introduce a bridge program similar to one she began at DePaul. Such students would be invited to spend five weeks in an intensive residential summer program at Pace, where they will be given special academic help. ''Institutions like ours just can't sit back and say 'they just aren't providing us with the right kids.' ''

And Bear in Mind
 (Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest.)
FRIEND OF MY YOUTH, by Alice Munro. (Knopf, $18.95.) This collection of short stories is full of marvels of construction, inquiry and retrospection as Ms. Munro's compulsively curious men and women work at finding out what has happened in their lives.
COLLLECTED STORIES OF WALLACE STEGNER. (Random House, $21.95.) This gathering yields an overview of the author's progress and that of his medium: big, wholehearted tales that proceed with a characteristic sauntering ease.
INTIFADA: The Palestian Uprising -- Israel's Third Front, by Ze'ev Schiff and Ehud Ya'ari. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) A reporters' book that focuses on long-term trends and inquires what is distinctive or continouous about the Palestinian uprising.
FLOATING IN MY MOTHER'S PALM, by Ursula Hegi. (Poseidon, $17.95.) A deft, convincing little memoirlike novel about a girl growing up in Dusseldorf in the 1950's, a child's phantasmagoria of love versus loneliness, wholeness versus amputation.
FLOW: The Psychology of Optimal Experience, by Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi. (Harper & Row, $21.95.) "Flow," according to the author, a professor of psychology at the University of Chicago, is a lernable state of consciousness that comes with rightly interpreting what we are doing and what is happening to us.
THE TRICK OF IT, by Michael Frayn. (Viking, $17.95) The versatile British satirist is right on form in this novel about an embittered critic who marries a distinguished novelist.
SOVIET WOMEN: Walking the Tightrope, by Francine du Plessix Gray. (Doubleday, $19.95.) Brilliant, sympathetic portraits of overworked, frustrated women whose men have neither the authority of patriarchs nor the utility of househusbands.

HEADLINE: Fiscal Bureaucracy in Japan Loses Credibility

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 25

 BODY:
By engineering Japan's miraculous economic recovery after the war, steering the shaken economy deftly through the oil crises of the 1970's and then stabilizing the nation's financial markets quickly after the United States stock market collapsed in October 1987, Japan's economic policy makers won an international reputation for unparalleled management ability.
Hard earned over 40 years, that reputation has been a source of immense confidence here, even arrogance. But in the last three months, that reputation has begun to unravel. For the first time, market forces are looming larger than the powers of Government bureaucrats. 
Persistent turmoil has wracked the financial markets this year, sending stock prices down by more than 20 percent, the yen down more than 5 percent and interest rates up sharply, despite numerous Government attempts to restore order. As a result, Japan's elite bureaucrats are watching their credibility erode almost daily.
Stunning as it seems, the loss of Government control stems from measures taken by the bureaucrats themselves. In recent years, under heavy pressure from the United States, the Government initiated a process of financial liberalization that made Japan's huge capital markets more open to the world. The markets became vastly larger and more powerful, less subject to bureaucratic control - and far more volatile.
''It is not as easy to control the market as we would like to,'' a senior Finance Ministry official acknowledged. ''But that is a development that we created. If you want to have the benefits of allowing market forces in, you cannot have as much control as there was before.''
The liberalization of the financial markets included allowing interest rates to float at market-determined levels, making it easier for Japanese corporations to raise capital abroad, permitting trading in interest-rate and stock-index futures and providing foreign instititutions with increased access.
As a result of the recent turmoil, the Government must deal not just with the technical problem of what steps it can take to stabilize stock prices and bolster the battered yen, but it must also try to rebuild confidence that the system can run efficiently.
The first signs that something fundamental had changed came last fall, when the yen started to weaken against the dollar and defied every attempt by the Government to bolster it. A surprise increase in the Bank of Japan's official discount rate in October not only proved ineffectual but was followed by an unseemly public row between the central bank and the Finance Ministry over whether another increase was necessary to cool inflationary pressures.
There is no simple explanation for the slide in the yen's value. But foreign-exchange experts and economists said the yen's fall was not because of speculation but rather the belief of Japanese institutions that they can earn better returns on investments abroad. In investing overseas, these companies are in effect selling yen to buy dollars or marks or another currency, pushing down the yen's value.
Starting early this year, the yen lost even more ground. Yasushi Mieno, the central bank governor, declared that the decline was a speculative trend that would soon reverse. But it did not.
The slide of the yen came even as the Japanese economy was in sound shape: Growth has been unimpeded for nearly four years; corporate investment in research, plants and equipment is running at three times the level of the United States on a per-capita basis and inflation, though rising, is less than 3 percent annually.
 
Going Into Panic
Despite these positives, interest rates were rocketing upward, threatening the economy; the yen was still falling, threatening to increase inflation, and stock market investors were going from nervousness to panic.
Both the Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan publicly continued to say there was no sound reason for the problems. In private, officials expressed confusion and exasperation with the way the markets failed to respond to their prodding.
Perhaps the worst news came last week, when the Bank of Japan again lifted its discount rate. It was a move expected to attract capital back to Japan and strengthen the yen. Instead, the stock market had its most volatile day on Thursday and the yen remained just as weak.
The loss of confidence this spectacle engendered has been almost palpable. Until recently, for instance, the attitude of many Japanese toward American demands that Japan open its markets further was best summed up by the title of a popular book, ''The Japan That Can Say No.'' Owed to the U.S. Suddenly, a far different attitude is being expressed. Last week, Shin Kanemaru, one of the most powerful politicians in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, was quoted as telling his party: ''Japan depends on the United States, not the other way around. We owe the United States for the well-being we now enjoy.''
Richard Koo, a senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute, said: ''This has been a particularly difficult time. People are seriously questioning the ability of Japanese Government officials to keep the markets on track.''
The loss of confidence in the bureaucrats has even started turning into disdain. It is dawning on many people here that Japan has become a capital-rich, labor-poor country whose vast wealth is dedicated to making Japanese corporations competitive rather than improving the standard of living.
The huge flow of Japanese capital into the United States and other countries, which was viewed as an emblem of success until recently, is now regarded in some quarters with resentment. If used at home, that capital could be improving the lives of the Japanese. But there are not enough opportunities to invest profitably in Japan, forcing the outflow.
 
Lack of Opportunity
''The fundamental problem is a lack of investment opportunities here,'' Mr. Koo said. ''Japanese realize that they are shipping all their capital overseas and investing in improving living standards outside Japan, while their own living standards are much worse.'' Investments in Japan are made difficult, he said, by Government restrictions and distortions caused by regulators.
Michiya Matsukawa, a senior adviser to the Nikko Securities Company and former top official at the Finance Ministry, asserted, ''The point is, Japanese are frustrated by the fact that there are better investment opportunities outside Japan.''
Now the steep decline in stock prices is being blamed on the fact that the Government's misguided policies caused share prices to rise too high too fast in the first place.
''The problem is not the inability of the Government to control the decline in stock prices now, but in their having permitted the speculative bubble to have grown so big in the first place,'' said Yoshihisa Kitai, manager of the economics department at the Long Term Credit Bank. ''That was the real failure.''
 
Increasing Risks
To some extent, the Government's lack of effective action and its continuing search for measures to restore order to the financial markets has even increased the risks.
''They can act, but if they fail it will create more problems by damaging their credibility,'' said Shijuro Ogata, deputy governor at the Japan Development Bank and formerly the top international official at the Bank of Japan. ''Or they can wait for the market forces to correct themselves and risk that the markets overshoot and get even more out of control.''

HEADLINE: FIRE IN THE BRONX;
The Living Search the Faces of the Dead

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Jerome Ford stared at the photographs spread on the table at Public School 67 in the Bronx yesterday. He recognized five faces: his wife's three brothers, a teen-age niece and a cousin. He realized what the photographs meant: the five had been trapped when an illegal social club was transformed from an oasis of dancing and drinking into an inferno.
His eyes were red, his Sunday-morning stubble of a beard streaked with tears. Oblivious to the sirens and the police officers shouting into their bullhorns, keeping the crowd in line, he could think of nothing but the advice he wished his relatives had taken.
''I told them not to go,'' he said, ''but kids are kids. I knew it was dangerous.'' 
The awful ritual of identification was repeated time after time at P.S. 67 yesterday. The corridors and classrooms, usually filled with the chatter of students, were filled with the sobs of relatives, friends, friends of friends, young and old.
Like Mr. Ford, they knew the faces in the photographs - the photographs of the dead, snapshots the authorities had taken before the 87 bodies were sent to the morgue in Manhattan. Some of the loved ones screamed at the sight. Some grieved wordlessly.
One woman said she was there because her two sons had not come home after a Saturday night out. One man was worried about five friends from a neighborhood soccer team. Another was hoping against hope that he would not be shown a picture of a friend whose car he had seen outside the burned-out Happy Land Social Club, a two-story graffiti-streaked building that was an after-hours hangout favored by Central American immigrants.
''He's dead - I know,'' said 13-year-old Glenda Martinez, who said she was waiting to identify her 23-year-old uncle, Venecio.
The wait at the school was long, at least three hours for most people, and painful - a new kind of pain in a section of East Tremont that knows the pain of poor housing, drugs, unemployment and truancy. People had to stand in four different lines before they reached the room where pictures of the victims had been laid out for identification.
For some, the trip confirmed the terrible suspicions they had had since daybreak, when they realized that loved ones had never made it home. Over and over during the day, people who had seen the pictures would come out and tell others in line the sad truth: whoever they were looking for was dead.
Four women waiting in line saw a woman friend coming out of P.S. 67 and learned that some loved ones were dead. In frustration and anger, one woman knelt and began flailing her fists at a pile of cardboard boxes. Two tried to comfort each other, sobbing as they embraced.
For some, the wait at the school was tense with uncertainty: they did not know if their loved ones had been at the club when the fire started. With luck, maybe they had left the club - alive, before the blaze - and gone somewhere besides home. Maybe they had gone to a friend's apartment and fallen asleep. Clutching photographs they hoped would not match the ones on the table, they realized this was a long shot.
Joanne Colon, 27, said her brother, Luis Rodriquez, sometimes stayed out late. Sometimes he went to the Happy Land club. ''I'm a nervous wreck,'' Ms. Colon said in a shaky voice. ''I told my mother and his wife not to come down here, that I'd take care of it.''
But for some, there was no doubt, only the horrible reality of the photographs and the certainty of death. Kelly Mena found the photo of his 30-year-old brother, Rene. ''He had on his black leather coat,'' he said, blinking back tears.
A friend broke through the crowd and grabbed his arm. ''Oh, Kelly,'' the friend, Lisette Martinez, said. ''My father just told me.'' First Family Was Calm One woman fainted after she left the school and had to be carried away by Emergency Medical Service personnel.
''The very first family came in and was very calm,'' said Debra Ricciardi, the assistant director of public relations for the Red Cross of Greater New York. ''They moved right on and said, 'What do we do next?' The next woman fell to the floor and started screaming.''
Some relatives brought photographs of their own. Alva Romero went to the school with snapshots of her 18-year-old daughter, Alva Escoto; her 32-year-old brother, Kerri Romero, and four cousins: Luis Manaiza, 22; Wendy Manaiza, 18; Norman Clarke, 17, and Isabel Christina Lopez, 17. The family had moved to the Bronx from Honduras over the last seven years, she said, and now in a single night they had died.
''We came looking for a better life,'' she said, tearfully. ''We just found disappointment and disgrace.''
 
One Line, Then Another
Like the other relatives, Ms. Romero had waited in a line that started at a side door of the school, at 2024 Mohegan Avenue, a block from the Happy Land. It took about 45 minutes to work one's way to the door; police officers were admitting groups of 15 or 20 at a time.
Inside, people waited in a second line that formed in a large room, around a dozen or so white picnic tables with attached benches. Some sat, but most stood by the door, waiting for the signal to take their places in yet another line.
In the lines, and in the crowds that gathered across from the school, people talked about how the Happy Land had become a neighborhood social center. Jose Cerrato, a native of San Pedro Sula in northwest Honduras, said he left the club about 3:30 A.M. yesterday because he had drunk too much and was falling asleep. By midafternoon all he could remember was the calypso music and a particular Honduran dance, samunango teleno.
A short time after he left, the music stopped and there were firefighters and paramedics, body bags and gruesome photographs - and broken dreams.
 
'Too Much Violence Here'
Sadia Torres, 28, said her boyfriend, Jose Francisco Gonzalez, 31, had left home about 9 P.M. Saturday. Ms. Torres said she had stayed home because she was tired and there was no one to take care of her three children.
She said she had lived with Mr. Gonzalez, a construction worker, for four years, ever since he came to the Bronx from Honduras. They were making plans to go back. He did not like life in New York.
''He used to say there was too much violence here,'' Ms. Torres said as she waited her turn at P.S. 67. ''He said his land was so peaceful, and his family was there, he has no one here except for me.''
A few relatives who could not make identifications from the photographs on the tables at the school were taken to the morgue in a Police Department bus. They were escorted by a clergyman, a Red Cross worker, an official from the City Human Resources Administration and an official from the New York State Funeral Directors Association. Ms. Ricciardi said the officials from the city and the funeral directors association were there to help with funeral arrangements and, if necessary, to arrange welfare benefits.
''They said they could bury her in Honduras if I want,'' said Sagrario Gomez, who lost her 35-year-old sister and two cousins. ''But how am I going to live without Erlinda?''

GRAPHIC: photo: Officers examining the belongings of victims of the fire at the Happy Land Social Club. The police yesterday arrested a suspect, Julio Gonzalez, 36 years old. A police spokesman said he had been ejected from the club, then returned with gasoline and set the fire. (The New York Times/Chester Higgins Jr.) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Labor Party Claims Victory in Australia

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, March 25

 BODY:
Prime Minister Bob Hawke said today that his Labor Party had prevailed in parliamentary elections and his conservative opponent, Andrew Peacock, conceded a Labor victory was likely.
Mr. Hawke said he expected a one-seat majority in the 148-seat House of Representatives. He said a ''worst case scenario'' would give Labor 73 seats, and the conservative coalition 73, with 2 independents. 
The Prime Minister, clearly surprised by the tight outcome of the elections on Saturday, said that when final results are in, ''I hope it may be a bit better than that.''
''It will give a sense of discipline for sure and we can do it.''
 
Calculating the Odds
Mr. Peacock, 51 years old, the leader of the Liberal and National Party coalition, would not concede defeat. But today he acknowledged that Labor had a better chance of taking the election.
''If you are setting a book I suggest the shortest odds would be regrettably on a hung Parliament, followed then by a Labor government just ahead of a possibility of a coalition government,'' Mr. Peacock said in Melbourne. Mr. Peacock, who made his second bid for the prime ministership, emphasized that the outcome of six or seven seats in the states of Western Australia and Queensland had not been decided.
Vote counting, routinely suspended on Sunday, was to resume on Monday. Political leaders said the official results would not be known until Thursday, when mail-in ballots are counted.
 
A Small Party Gains
Forty of 70 Senate seats were also contested on Saturday, and early results showed the small Democratic Party made strong gains. The House, the more powerful chamber, chooses the Prime Minister.
Communities with undecided races included the small town of Kennedy in northern Queensland, where several thousand voters were unable to cast their ballots because polling booths were cut off by floodwaters.
Mr. Hawke, 60, has governed for seven years. He campaigned on his record of economic management, despite dissatisfaction over record home mortgage interest rates and a $100 billion foreign debt.
The Prime Minister said the 1990 election would set the course for Australian politics into the 21st century.
Australia has 10.6 million eligible voters among its 16.5 million people, and voting is compulsory.
 
Independents Win 2
When vote counting closed on Saturday night, Labor appeared to have won 73 seats, the coalition 70 and the independents 2.
The independents, the first elected in 24 years, could hold the balance of power in the House. Labor, which had 85 seats in the previous lower house, needs 75 seats for a working majority.
Australia is a close United States ally, and President Bush said he hoped to visit the country before the year's end.
Mr. Hawke came to power in 1983, was re-elected the following year and again in 1987. He has said that if re-elected in this race he will seek a fifth term before retiring.

HEADLINE: Liberian President Leads the Good Life While His Country Grows Poorer

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia

 BODY:
The delivery of a new luxury plane for the personal use of the Liberian President made front-page headlines in January in this impoverished West African country.
The 60-seater Boeing 707, which diplomats here say was purchased for nearly $20 million, is ''yet another cost-saving measure adopted by the Government,'' the state-owned newspaper said, because ''it will minimize the high cost of chartering private planes.''
What news reports did not mention, however, is that only two runways in this small country are long enough to accommodate the new aircraft, and both are near Monrovia, the capital. As for foreign travel, the President, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, has not flown overseas since he visited Romania nearly three years ago.
''It's an immense waste of money,'' a Liberian businessman said, ''especially in a country that is nearly bankrupt.'' 
 
Rich Yet Poor Land
In its way, the new plane may be an apt metaphor for Liberia, which often gives the impression of forward motion, while it is rolling steadily toward financial and political collapse. Liberia is rich in minerals and has one of West Africa's most skilled and educated work forces. It also has a reputation as one of the African continent's most egregious examples of economic mismanagement.
The timing of the plane's arrival was especially striking, Western and Liberian analysts said, because it came during the visit of a delegation from the International Monetary Fund.
''To acquire that plane right now, with everyone watching so closely, is either an act of incredible arrogance or incredible incompetence,'' a longtime Western resident said.
Three years ago Liberia, which was founded in the mid-19th century as a republic for freed American slaves, became the only country in Africa ever suspended from I.M.F. and World Bank borrowing.
The lenders and the Government are in the midst of negotiations over the next disciplinary step - whether Liberia should be formally declared in default and unlikely to repay $1.2 billion in debt owed to them and other foreign creditors. Later this year, in the third and final step of the sanctions process, Liberia could become the first country ever expelled from the international lending agency.
At the same time the United States, Liberia's largest trading partner and foreign investor, is also cutting back. From 1980 to 1985, the United States gave this country of 2.3 million people nearly $500 million in aid and loans, making Liberia the largest per-capita recipient of American aid in sub-Saharan Africa. But charging mismanagement and misappropriation, the United States Congress has steadily slashed aid levels, to $19.5 million last year and about $10 million in 1990.
 
Leader Lives Well
The sense of economic disarray is compounded, Western donors and bankers say, by President Doe's growing appetite for government-subsidized extravagance. He owns a small fleet of luxury automobiles and is said to spend lavishly on clothes and jewelry. And while no reliable estimate has ever been made, rumors run through the capital that General Doe and his wife, Nancy, and other family members have accumulated extensive real-estate holdings.
One telling detail about Mr. Doe's changing values, Liberian political analysts say, is his insistence on being called ''Dr. Doe,'' the consequence of a visit to South Korea several years ago in which he received an honorary doctorate. By law, the President's image appears ubiquitiously in public places and many people hang his picture in private offices as a display of fealty.
''He is definitely encouraging a cult of personality,'' a Liberian businessman said, ''and you don't dare suggest that there's anything wrong with it.''
Well-connnected senior Government workers have also grown wealthy through lucrative business opportunities obtained through the executive mansion. And despite the Government's deteriorating fiscal condition, in recent months at least a dozen West German limousines were purchased for the small group of political cronies who surround the President.
Nonetheless, when confronted with accusations of corruption, the 39-year old General Doe has said he is a victim of disinformation and has blamed his political opponents for such reports. The President's aides said he was too busy to be interviewed.
 
Rebellion in the Northeast
Of late, however, the most immediate threat to the Doe leadership is an armed one. Since late December, Government forces have been trying to crush an invasion by guerrillas opposed to the President's rule.
The rebels, led by Charles Taylor, a former Doe Cabinet minister who is remembered here mostly for fleeing the country in 1986 after being accused of embezzlement, invaded Nimba County, about 300 miles northeast of Monrovia. The Liberian Government sent troops and provincial policemen to oust them.
In interviews on the Ivory Coast side of the border, refugees reported that the soldiers indiscriminately engaged in vicious and mostly arbitary reprisals, killing hundreds of unarmed civilians - people they apparently believed were sympathetic to the rebel cause.
Amnesty International and Africa Watch, human rights groups, as well as the United States Embassy in Monrovia, have also said that soldiers attacked unarmed civilians.
So far, at least 140,000 Liberians are believed to have fled across the eastern frontiers to escape the bloodshed, most of them settling in the heavily forested hills of the Ivory Coast and Guinea.
Diplomats say that about half of Nimba County - its northern and eastern portions - is still contested. Guerrilla activity in these areas remains strong, and the army has been unable, despite a variety of tactics, to bring them under control.
 
Food a Sensitive Issue
The Nimba invasion also has potentially far-reaching implications for Liberia's economy because about 30 percent of agricultural production comes from the region.
By the accounting of Western economists, the sudden flight of tens of thousands of farmers has already clouded the prospects for this year's rice harvest, and there is talk of potential food shortages and other hardships.
''If there is anything people react to here, it is food shortages and price increases; that combination could be explosive,'' said a Western relief worker who recalled that it was nearly a decade ago that proposals to increase the price of rice set off a wave of protest that eventually led to the overthrow of President William R. Tolbert.
In 1980, General Doe, an 11th-grade dropout and a 28-year-old master sergeant, came to power after he and other army noncommissioned officers shot and bayoneted President Tolbert and took over the Government.
Ten days later, the foreign press was invited to record the sight of 13 senior Government officials, including most of the former Cabinet, marched nearly naked through the streets of Monrovia, tied to seaside posts and then executed at point-blank range.
President Doe's international reputation has never fully recovered from that moment. Leaders of neighboring West African countries, particularly the President of the Ivory Coast, Felix Houphouet Boigny, have maintained diplomatically correct but nonetheless strained relations with the Liberian leader.
 
State Department Criticism
General Doe's image here and abroad has also suffered from persistent accusations of human rights abuses. The State Department's 1989 human rights report said, ''Brutality by police and other security officials during the arrest and questioning of individuals is fairly common, and there has been no evident government effort to halt this practice.''
Liberia's tightly controlled press rarely touches on such subjects and those who do can be expected to be dealt with ruthlessly. Dozens of journalists have been detained in recent years, often without charges, and several newspapers have been closed. The Daily Observer, Monrovia's leading independent paper, has been ordered shut five times since 1982, once for almost 20 months.
Perhaps the greatest source of internal tension in recent years is the widespread impression here that a Krahn tribal elite has begun to replace the American-Liberian elite that virtually ran the country until the 1980 coup.
Unlike most countries in West Africa, until recently Liberia has been relatively free of ethnic strife.
This began to change with the ascendancy of President Doe, a Krahn. Since then, the Krahn, though they make up only about 4 percent of the population, are disproportionately represented in the executive mansion, senior government positions, and the leadership of the armed forces.
Most significant, senior military soldiers directing government forces in Nimba County reportedly engaged in bullying tactics and even murder. Most of the officers were Krahn, and the civilians attacked, members of the Gio and Mandingo tribes.

HEADLINE: Clash of Cultures Grows Amid American Dream

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ENCINITAS, Calif.

 BODY:
Marjorie Gaines and Cirillo Guerrero are neighbors, after a fashion, in this slice of Southern California where two very different visions of America have come into conflict.
Mrs. Gaines, a local Councilwoman with a pleasant ranch-style home, enjoys a relaxed suburban way of life almost within sound of the Pacific surf.
Mr. Guerrero an undocumented immigrant who lives just over the hill from her under a piece of plastic sheeting, was drawn here by a more elemental dream: a job and food for his family in Mexico.
In the past few years, as communities of expensive homes have spread rapidly across the rolling hills of San Diego County, the first stop for immigrants from across the Mexican border, a clash of cultures that sometimes flares into violence has become increasingly acute.
 
An Unsettling Reminder
It is a clash that resonates through California, where immigration is changing the demographics and the character of the state. With the local economy dependent on their labor, people like Mr. Guerrero are an unsettling reminder to residents of the social forces that are at work. 
Homeowners like Mrs. Gaines complain that the migrants, who line the roadsides seeking jobs and who camp out at night within shouting distance of their homes, bring crime, unsanitary conditions and a breath of the third world to their carefully tended communities.
The migrants say they are routinely abused by people who shout and throw garbage at them, destroy their campsites, cheat them at work and sometimes attack them physically.
''The housing developments are growing pretty much in proportion to the number of undocumented people coming into the country,'' said Roberto Martinez, a social worker with the American Friends Service Committee. ''What I've observed is that as the developments have encroached into migrant areas, we are seeing more tension and more incidents.''
 
Crime and Violence
Last month, a 19-year-old man named Kenneth Kovzelove, who said he hated Mexicans, was sentenced to 50 years to life in prison for shooting to death two Hispanic men, one of them a United States citizen, on a rutted lane that snakes through the hills where many immigrants camp.
In what appears to be a more common occurrence, immigrant-aid groups say migrant workers in the hills around the nearby town of Poway have in recent months been shot with paint-pellet guns, which are used in mock warfare. Mr. Martinez said migrant workers were sometimes run down by vehicles on the back roads near their campsites, in what appear to be deliberate acts of violence.
Most attention is now focused on the coming trial of a grocer and a butcher at the Country Store in Carlsbad, a town where migrant workers play an essential role in the flower, strawberry and citrus industries.
As the immigrant flow has continued, large groups of Hispanic men have begun gathering every day in the store's parking lot, seeking odd jobs, in a scene that is repeated increasingly throughout Southern California.
The two men from the Country Store, charged with kidpnapping and assault, are accused of seizing one of those workers in January, binding his hands and feet and taping a bag over his head. A sign attached to the man read, ''No mas aqui,'' or roughly: ''Don't come back.''
Law enforcement officials say the rate of violence and crime are also high among the migrants themselves. They are often attacked and robbed both by other migrants and by non-Hispanic residents.
 
Migrants as 'Perfect Victims'
''The migrant workers here are what I describe as perfect victims,'' said Lieut. Bill Flores, commander of the Fallbrook substation for the county sheriff's office. They are in a foreign land where they do not speak the language, they sleep in the open without access to telephones, they often fear the authorities who could help them, and they generally carry with them all the money they have.
At the heart of the cultural clash, said Gene Louden, a spokesman for United Way of San Diego County, is an unusual demographic fact. Only 10 percent of the people who live in the county were born here, most having come in search of one of the life styles exemplified by Mrs. Gaines and Mr. Guerrero.
The population of the county, which now stands at 2.4 million, has been growing, even though the number of births is dropping sharply. Mr. Louden said this was another indication that the county's growth continued to be based on migration both from within and outside the United States.
At the same time, the county's ethnic balance is shifting from 73.7 percent Caucasian and 14.8 percent Hispanic in 1980, to a projected mix of 60 percent Caucasian and 23 percent or more Hispanic by the end of the decade. The other fast-growing segment of the population is the Asian minority.
An immigration amnesty law enacted in 1986 may have heightened the sense of invasion that local residents have. Under the law, some of the migrant workers who camp out on the hillsides now have the legal right to live and work in the United States alongside their more established neighbors.
''In the last three years, particularly in the last two years, it's become intolerable,'' Mrs. Gaines said. ''People call to complain. They say, 'This isn't the community I bought into 8 years or 10 years or 5 years ago.' ''
Back then, she said, ''We did not have the great numbers of people using our backyards and our little canyons for campgrounds. We did not have people lining our streets waiting for work. We did not have people publicly defecating and urinating, and we did not have business people complaining that their businesses were being ruined because of all the people hanging around.''
Residents say they fear the spread of tropical diseases and are concerned about strains on social services, including hospitals and the police.
These complaints come even though much of the local economy, particularly with the building boom, depends on the labor of these migrant workers.
''Whether they like it or not, there's a symbiosis going on between the workers who live in the mountains and the yuppies who live in the valleys,'' said Tom Burgess, an aide to Representative Jim Bates, Democrat of San Diego.
 
Impact of Immigration Law
Claudia Smith, a lawyer with California Rural Legal Assistance, a private group, said that since some of the Hispanic population had been granted legal documentation, residents no longer called the Immigration and Naturalization Service to remove their unwanted neighbors.
''Now it's nuisance abatement,'' she said. ''They go to the health department or they consider bans on street solicitation. You have cities hounding workers from encampment to encampment. There's a real attempt to depopulate the coastal communities, which I call yuppiedom, of migrant workers.''
If there is such a policy, it does not seem to be succeeding.
Standing amid the litter of his makeshift home, as hummingbirds flitted past, Mr. Guerrero said he had been forced to move repeatedly to new campsites as housing developments have spread across the hillsides. ''We have been raided and bulldozed and moved,'' he said.
Jobs are scarce, and when he does find work in the fields or in construction, he said he is often cheated of his pay.
But he still looks forward to the day when he can bring his wife and children from Mexico to live with him.

HEADLINE: Clean Air Debate: Odd Allies and Formidable Foes

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Senator Robert C. Byrd, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, former leader of the Democratic majority and longtime power on Capitol Hill, walked through the corridors of Senate office buildings last Tuesday dropping off handwritten notes asking his colleagues for help.
The white-haired warrior was seeking support for an amendment to the clean air bill that would help his coal-mining constituents in West Virginia. The proposal, to provide financial relief to miners who lose their jobs as a result of the bill's provisions, is opposed by Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine.
Mr. Mitchell, who succeeded Mr. Byrd as majority leader, believes the Byrd amendment would jeopardize the bill by breaking the compromise reached by Senate leaders and the White House. 
The two formidable Senators have been using their considerable influence to win votes in the hotly contested debate over the legislation.
 
Politics as Unusual
The day after Senator Byrd worked the hallways, Evelyn Dubrow, a veteran labor lobbyist, stopped Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, as he was coming out of the chamber. She asked him why he was not supporting the Byrd amendment.
Mr. Dodd leaned toward the diminutive Ms. Dubrow and, in a whisper loud enough for those standing nearby to hear, said, ''I'll tell you in one word: child care.'' Then, as the elevator door was closing, he held up his hands in a what-can-I-do gesture and said, ''George is being very tough on this one.''
For the record, an aide to Mr. Dodd said later that the Senator had not yet decided what he would do about the Byrd amendment, yet the message was clear: Senator Dodd was convinced that if he wanted his pet child care bill acted on by the Senate, he would have to stand with the majority leader.
The clean air legislation, which Senate leaders have called the most important bill before Congress this year, is producing both politics as usual and politics as unusual.
As usual, promises are being made, unspoken warnings are being issued and chits for favors performed over the years are being called in. Industries are spending millions of dollars in a lobbying effort to persuade senators to ease the requirements of the bill, and environmental groups are urging lawmakers to take the moral high ground by adopting stronger protections for clean air.
But the usual partisan lines have been largely erased. Divisions over the bill, which would impose new controls on acid rain, urban smog and toxic chemicals in the air, are shaped instead by unusually sharp regional differences over who gains from the bill, who loses, who pays, who doesn't. States with dirty coal-fired power plants want financial help to pay for cleanup costs; states that have already cleaned up insist that the polluters must pay themselves.
 
Filibuster Seemed Certain
Western states with clean air are demanding the right to dirty it a bit in the future for the sake of economic growth. States with large numbers of chemical plants and refineries are objecting to the high costs of controlling chemicals in the air.
Senator Mitchell has said he entered into a compromise with the White House because he could not defeat a filibuster that was almost certain to develop over the bill without President Bush's support. As a result, the Senate is now considering legislation that is weaker in some respects than the bill approved by its own Environment and Public Works Committee. But the measure is stronger in some respects than the clean air proposal made by Mr. Bush last June.
Senator Mitchell is struggling to make the compromise stand up against opposition both from environmentalists and their allies who want to strengthen the bill and from industrial interests who want to weaken it.
The result has been some unlikely alliances. For example, some senators who consistently oppose environmental legislation voted for an amendment offered last week by Tim Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, and Pete Wilson, Republican of California, that would require stricter controls on pollution from automobiles.
Among those who voted for the amendment, which was strongly backed by environmental groups, were Senators Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming, Jesse Helms of North Carolina and James McClure and Steve Symms of Idaho, all of them Republicans who have scored zero or nearly so on the voting assessments of the League of Conservation Voters, the chief political arm of the environmentalists.
To Senator Mitchell, their motive was transparent. ''There are a substantial number of senators who don't want a bill,'' he said. ''They are voting for amendments that are not part of the compromise hoping they will kill the bill.''
 
Criticized by Old Allies
Mr. Mitchell said he is finding the process of guiding clean air legislation through the Senate ''the most difficult and demanding thing I have ever been involved in.'' Coming from Maine, where there is a strong interest in air quality, he has been a leading Senate champion of clean air for 10 years and he has come under heavy and, he believes, unfair criticism from his old environmental allies.
The majority leader is also uncomfortable about twisting the arms of his fellow Democrats to support the compromise with the Republican-controlled White House. He did not warn Senator Dodd on the child care bill, Senator Mitchell said, adding, ''I care very deeply about that bill, and there is not a chance I would do anything to block it.''
The most dramatic moment in the clean air debate so far came late Wednesday night, when Senator Byrd took the floor to plead for his amendment. The Senate chamber is usually empty when a member makes a speech, even during the middle of the business day. But one by one, senators filed in and sat silently while Mr. Byrd made an emotional appeal for his proposal to aid coal miners. Mr. Mitchell, exhausted and suffering from a bad cold, sat nearby, for a time with his head buried in his hands.
 
Old Foes Enter the Fray
One after another, senators, including old legislative foes of Senator Byrd like the Republican minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, and Strom Thurmond, the conservative Republican from South Carolina, rose to challenge Senator Byrd.
Mr. Byrd answered them with a plea for the miners. They are specifically ''targeted'' by the legislation, he said, because it would encourage power companies to switch from the coal with high sulfur content that is mined mainly in the East to the low-sulfur coal that is mined in the West. This would reduce the pollution that causes acid rain.
Mr. Byrd won that night's round, getting the Senate's support for alterations in his amendment. But he has not been able to bring the amendment itself to a vote because the Senate leadership is hoping to avoid a test of strength on the issue.
