LENGTH: 606 words

HEADLINE: A Bad Bill Where a Fix Would Do

 BODY:
An impartial auditor examines the books of a corporate pension plan and determines that it is overfunded. Money, therefore, can be withdrawn without jeopardizing promised payments to current or future retirees. So the corporate managers remove the excess money and give it to shareholders. 
Are such withdrawals - known as reversions - lawful theft? Or fiscal prudence? The Senate Labor Committee implies theft, so it has approved a bill, sponsored by Senators Howard Metzenbaum and Nancy Kassebaum, that would effectively bar reversions. Employers yell foul: they argue that since they're legally required to fork over more money if the plan runs low, they should be able to reclaim excess money they mistakenly put in.
The truth is that both sides are exaggerating. Some employers are abusing the tax-free status of pension contributions. But the Senators exaggerate the problem and propose a draconian - and potentially crippling - solution. A modest revision of the tax code is all that's needed.
The controversy concerns so-called defined benefit plans. These plans pay a retirement benefit that, typically, depends on the worker's salary at retirement. Employers are required to put enough money into the plan to cover future outlays. But that requires guessing the future level of salaries and rates of return on invested pension contributions. Unforeseen events in stock, bond and real estate markets can lead to underfunding or overfunding.
The fight is over companies that wind up with overfunded plans and decide to make a lump-sum withdrawal. In many cases, the law now requires that they first terminate the plan. That can hurt workers because a terminated plan, if not reinstated, pays a retirement benefit keyed to the worker's salary at termination, rather than the higher salary at the time of retirement. Senators Metzenbaum and Kassebaum would eliminate this threat by essentially forbidding reversions unless the company builds in cost-of-living adjustments. That may sound noble. But the bill, if passed, would backfire.
The type of inflation protection the Senators envision is virtually nonexistent in the private sector. The risk is too great. If Congress makes it mandatory, employers might just decide to scrap defined-benefit plans. Or companies will avoid excess buildup by contributing the legal minimum. Then, if the plan slips into insolvency, taxpayers are at risk. Because of Federal guarantees, they pay the retirement bills of a company whose plan goes bankrupt.
Bellicose rhetoric has served to divert attention from a real but fixable flaw in pension regulations. Companies have discovered a clever way to turn pension plans into tax shelters. First, they make excess contributions - tax free - into the plan. Then they withdraw the excess money, say, 10 years later. In the interim, the company has earned interest on money that otherwise would have been paid to the Internal Revenue Service. This amounts to an interest-free loan, a glaring loophole in the tax code.
Congress closed part of this loophole with a 15-percent penalty on pension reversions. But a recent Government study shows that the penalty is too low. Raising the penalty would not end terminations; but it would eliminate the unfair tax incentive for them.
Fixing a technical flaw in the tax code is not the stuff of political fanfare and voter appreciation. Too bad, because if Congress ventures any further - as the Senate bill proposes - it risks doing real harm. Burdensome restrictions will discourage use of defined-benefit plans or encourage dumping unfunded retirement liabilities into the lap of taxpayers.

HEADLINE: No Decade for Movies Like 'Driving Miss Daisy';
'Roger and Me'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
So encouraging to read the rational voice of David Bensman discussing the film ''Roger and Me'' (Op-Ed, March 2). As one who grew up in Flint, Mich., who was a little acquainted with Michael Moore and who has watched the city's decay over the last 20 years - along with that of my adopted home, Pittsburgh - I found his film exceedingly unfunny. I heard a few laughs from the Pittsburgh audience when I saw the film early this year. But not many, certainly not what the early reviewers reported, when this film was touted as rivaling Woody Allen's best. 
I had the sense that Michael Moore was more concerned to get footage that exposed people's absurdities than to depict their troubled socioeconomic situations, which so stressed, even deformed, their lives. Thus, the viewer looks askance at the county officer in charge of evictions; looks down on the ''air-head'' mentality of fluffy Miss Michigan (later Miss U.S.A.); looks with clinical concern at the ''meat or pets'' rabbit woman, who has such obvious disabilities that she can't be counted as an unemployed worker; looks with frustration as the Flint boosters flail away with their failing tourist strategies; looks with disbelief at the socialites locked in the ''Jailhouse Rock.''
But nowhere do the film maker, the viewer and the people captured on celluloid come together. Always there is the sense of Michael Moore waiting for the next opportunity to videotape, to add to the collection of things to ridicule, sometimes to expose or humiliate. For one whose overt message is ''help the people,'' this film conveys the feeling of the elitist film maker, who is as humanly insensitive as the General Motors robber baron he blames for Flint's demise.
Not to say that I don't agree with the message of ''Roger and Me.'' Flint is a mess. Much of Michigan is an economic morass. So too is Pittsburgh filled with parents who are often walk-ing tragedies and growing numbers of children at risk. There is something inherently wrong with our country when workers in Flint can't find jobs while G.M. is hiring thousands of Mexicans for a few pesos in expanding automotive plants just over the border. Or when steelworkers wait for a decade for the plants along the Monongahela to reopen, only slowly realizing that the rusting hulks will remain abandoned while new plants open in the Deep South or overseas.
I agree with Mr. Bensman that many workers and communities have made remarkable adaptations, and ''Roger and Me'' neglects the strength these copers with change show. But my experience is that only about half the population possesses the social and psychological resources to respond and adapt positively. Half are the victimized workers and families who end up in drugs, drink, crime and emotional deviance.
Those who increasingly find themselves at the bottom of the economic heap - hampered with little education and many mouths to feed, sometimes homeless and usually alienated, all too often without hope that their children have a chance for better fates - need our attention and thoughtful concern. They should not be the objects of our laughter. This is the most serious challenge we face as the next century looms.
 
VICTORIA JEAN DIMIDJIAN
 Shippensburg, Pa., March 3, 1990
The writer is an associate professor of teacher education at Shippensburg University.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 4; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Needle Exchange Succeeding in Australia

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was dismayed to learn that in New York City, your Mayor has decided to close the city's only needle and syringe exchange (news article, Feb. 14). Outlets for sterile needles and syringes have been established in almost every country in Western Europe. I understand that Canada has also opened such exchanges. In Australia, outlets for sterile needles and syringes are available almost throughout the country. 
A needle and syringe exchange program was established in the state of New South Wales in Australia in 1986. A recent independent evaluation of the needle and syringe exchange program was commissioned by the state government from a leading research company. This evaluation concluded that the exchange program has been an outstanding success and recommends its further extension.
Similar findings were contained in an independent evaluation commissioned by the Department of Health and Social Security in Britain. Academic research to support the value of needle and syringe exchanges is available from the Netherlands, Britain and Australia. In a study I presented as a poster at the fifth International AIDS Conference held in Montreal last year, it was found that the opening of a needle and syringe exchange adjacent to a methadone maintenance unit did not increase drug taking in the methadone program as assessed by analysis of urine specimens.
Australia has the sixth highest rate of acquired immune deficiency syndrome among countries in the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development. Despite this relatively high rate of AIDS, Australia has a low rate of human immunodeficiency virus infection among intravenous drug users. A national study in 1989 showed that the rate of HIV infection in intravenous drug users in Sydney is about 3.5 percent. In Australia, a ''war on AIDS'' is preferred to ''a war on drugs.''
As more and more countries decide to introduce needle and syringe exchange, and as each of the participating countries opens more and more outlets, the decision to close the only needle and syringe exchange in New York City is both bewildering and dismaying.
 
ALEX WODAK, M.D.
Director, Alcohol and Drug Service
St. Vincent's Hospital
 Darlinghurst, Australia, March 1, 1990

HEADLINE: New York State Relying More on One-Time Revenues

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 25

 BODY:
Faced with bills it cannot pay, New York State is increasingly relying on financial maneuvers that provide quick cash but often cost the state more money in the long run.
So many of these maneuvers, known as one-shots, are expected to be included in the next state budget that analysts say they are becoming a threat to the long-term financial health of the state.
''These patchwork and Scotch-tape solutions just don't make sense,'' said Hyman Grossman, a managing director of Standard & Poor's. ''A really good, credible show would be to do away with one-shots altogether. But New York has gotten used to it, and they do it again and again and again. It's certainly going to be expensive.'' 
Among the moves that the state is expected to make to raise one-time revenues for the coming fiscal year are these:
* Changing payment schedules to put off expenses until nexteaear.
* Refincicing bonisissues tnrfree up thgmcash reserves atat are required under the current terms of t b bonds.
* Usg g complicated transactions to tradlolong-terasassets for oneimime cashayaymentpm including t s sale of the state's leases in the World Trade Center.
The state's growing reliance on complex maneuvers to convert assets into quick cash is, to some officials, reminiscent of the moves that New York City made leading up to the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's.
 
'Less Than Prudent'
''It's important to keep in mind that in the years leading up to 1975, there was an increasing volume and innovativeness in financing to produce short-term gains,'' said Stephen J. Weinstein, executive director of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the agency established during the fiscal crisis to give the city access to credit markets. ''To repeat such a pattern today would certainly be less than prudent.''
One-time revenues come in many forms. The most straightforward is a withdrawal from one of the state's reserve funds, which are maintained as insurance against unexpected costs.
But the state has had such severe financial trouble in recent years that many of its reserves are already depleted. Over the last few years, for example, the state has drawn almost $1 billion from reserves of the State Insurance Fund, which pays workers' compensation claims for the state and some private companies. Lacking ready reserves, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget office has come up with more and more complicated strategies for obtaining cash.
To many analysts, these maneuvers smack of gimmickry.
''None of them passes the smell test,'' said Cindy Green, a senior analyst for the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group. ''And when you add them all up, they smell like Fresh Kills,'' the colossal landfill on Staten Island.
As New York's budget problems have worsened in recent years, the amount of nonrecurring revenues included in the budget has increased steeply. In 1986, the budget included $250 million in nonrecurring revenues, according to a recent report by the Assembly minority. By this year, the total had climbed to more than $1 billion. And for the next fiscal year, which starts next Sunday, the total is expected to grow again, to as much as $1.5 billion.
''The numbers are just too big,'' said Mr. Grossman of Standard & Poor's.
 
Credit Rating at Risk
Standard & Poor's has warned that it may lower the state's credit rating, and the agency has cited New York's increasing reliance on one-shots as a symptom of its inability to deal with its persistent budget problems.
The trouble with one-shots, financial analysts say, is that they mask a deficit that then becomes harder and harder to fill.
The state ends up paying for continuing programs with revenues that are available for only one year. This means that the next year, when inflation drives up the cost of the program, the gap between recurring expenses and recurring revenues will have grown that much wider.
''You are taking a recurring expenditure, but taking a revenue you can't repeat,'' said the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan. ''You just keep escalating the problem and then one day the bubble bursts.''
 
Practice Is Defended
Cuomo administration officials defend their heavy use of one-shots as a logical response to the state's sudden fiscal problems. They liken them to temporary aid that parents might give their children if they have suffered an economic setback.
''In the abstract, people will always complain about one-shots,'' Governor Cuomo's budget director, Dall W. Forsythe, said. ''But what they have to decide is whether in the financial architecture of the budget it makes sense to use these nonrecurring revenues.''
Mr. Forsythe noted that without the money, the $51 billion budget that the Governor proposed in January would have had even more tax increases or spending cuts.
''It would have been more controversial than it already is,'' Mr. Forsythe said. Governor Cuomo proposed suspending the next phase of the state's scheduled income-tax cut. He also proposed raising $800 million in new fees and taxes, including a tax on long-distance telephone calls.
 
Sometimes Money Is Saved
The Governor has argued that suspending the tax cut, a move that would yield more than $1 billion next year, justifies the use of more than $1 billion in one-shots this year.
Some of these one-shots actually save the state money over time. By refinancing bonds that were paying high interest, for example, the state may be able to reduce its debt service costs. Several of the refinancing arrangements the state is planning, however, are intended simply to reduce the requirements for cash reserves.
Many one-shots provide cash for one year that must simply be paid back in the next year. For the coming fiscal year the Governor has, for example, proposed changing the schedule of state payments for the City University of New York's community colleges. This move would push $23 million of costs into the next fiscal year.
Other one-shots carry long-term costs, for often the money that is saved now has to be made up at greater expense later on. Recently, the state raised more than $400 million by refinancing bonds for the State University of New York. But over the next 30 years, it will cost the state $800 million more.
 
Complex Strategies
Some of the one-shot strategies the Cuomo adminstration wants to use to generate cash are so complex that even most budget experts in the Capitol confess they do not understand them.
An example of one of these maneuvers is the sale of the state's World Trade Center leases, which is supposed to yield $200 million in cash. In broad terms, the transaction would work like this:
New York State leases office space in the World Trade Center from its owner, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, at a rate lower than market value. The Port Authority has asked the state to move out of the World Trade Center so that it can lease the space at a higher rate. In return, the authority promised to deposit the profits from its higher rents in a fund that the state would use for capital projects.
Now the Cuomo administration wants to collect all of the money that would have gone into the fund at once. Under the plan, the state's Urban Development Corporation would float a bond issue and hand over the cash from the bond sale to the state. The U.D.C. would use the Port Authority payments to pay back the bonds over the next 25 or 30 years.
''What the state is doing is taking a stream of revenue and spending it in one lump sum,'' said one government economist, who asked not to be identified.
''Think of it like a cabinet where each drawer has cash,'' he continued. ''You may be able to rationalize taking the cash from some of the drawers. But at the point you've cleaned the whole thing out, you're up against the wall. And that's where they are now.''

HEADLINE: Dr. N. S. Fatemi, 79; Directed an Institute For Foreign Studies

 BODY:
Dr. Nasrollah S. Fatemi, director emeritus of the Graduate Institute of International Studies at Fairleigh Dickinson University and the author of books on subjects ranging from international economics to poetry, died of a heart attack on Friday at Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived in Saddle River, N.J.
Dr. Fatemi, who was born in Nain, Persia, was a mayor, governor and member of Parliament after the country became Iran. He came to the United States in 1946 and served as Iran's delegate to the United Nations in 1952 and 1953.
He lectured at Princeton from 1950 to 1955 and then became a professor at Fairleigh Dickinson. He was appointed chairman of the social sciences department in 1960, dean of the graduate school in 1965 and director of the graduate institute, which he founded, in 1971. He retired in 1981.
Among the books he wrote were ''While the United States Slept'' (Cornwall, 1981), ''Diplomatic History of Persia'' (Whittier, 1951), ''Oil Diplomacy'' (Whittier, 1954), ''The Dollar Crisis'' (Fairleigh Dickinson Univeristy Press, 1964) and ''Multinational Corporations: Problems and Prospects'' (A. S. Barnes, 1975). The first volume of his projected four-volume autobiography, ''Reflections on the Time of Disillusion,'' was published recently by Mellioun.
Dr. Fatemi was Mayor of Shiraz from 1939 to 1941, Governor-General of the Fars province from 1941 to 1943 and a member of the Iranian Parliament from 1943 to 1947. He represented Iran at several international conferences after World War II.
He was a graduate of Stuart Memorial College in Iran and received a master's degree from Columbia University and a doctorate from the New School for Social Research.
He is survived by his wife, the former Shayesteh Ostovar; three sons, Faramarz, of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J.; Fairborz, of Washington, and Farivar, of Suffern, N.Y., and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Klaus E. Knorr, 78, Professor; Argued Against Use of Military

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
Dr. Klaus E. Knorr, professor emeritus of public affairs at Princeton University and the director of its Center of International Studies from 1960 to 1968, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 78 years old.
Dr. Knorr, a German-born economist and political scientist, wrote many books developing a thesis that the nuclear age had necessitated a global ascendance of diplomatic and economic policies over military options. The volumes included ''On the Uses of Military Power in the Nuclear Age'' (Princeton University Press, 1966), ''Military Power and Potential'' (Lexington Books, 1970) and ''Power and Wealth: The Political Economy of International Power'' (Basic Books, 1973). 
In mid-1968, while the Johnson Administration was continuing to accelerate American military involvement in South Vietnam, Dr. Knorr and three associates at the Princeton center wrote a detailed proposal for the withdrawal of American and North Vietnamese forces, the introduction of an international peacekeeping force and the formation of a neutral Saigon government. The war continued for seven more years.
Klaus Eugene Knorr was born on May 16, 1911, in Essen, Germany, and earned a law degree at the University of Tubingen. He resisted increasing pressure to join the Nazi party and immigrated to the United States in 1937.
He earned a Ph.D. at the University of Chicago in 1941. He then taught economics at Stanford University and international economics and political science, first at Yale and then at Princeton. He taught at Princeton for 28 years, edited the journal, World Politics, for a decade and was the Tod Professor of Public Affairs from 1964 until he retired in 1979.
Over the years, Dr. Knorr was a consultant to the Department of State, the Department of Defense and the Central Intelligence Agency and was awarded the Government's National Intelligence Distinguished Service Medal.
Surviving are his wife, Marianne; two daughters, Monica, of Washington, and Jean, of Alexandria, Va.; a son, Nicholas, of Glencoe, Ill., and four grandchildren.

INTERNATIONAL
 
Japan's economic policy makers are watching their credibility erode almost daily as, for the first time, market forces loom larger than the powers of bureaucrats. As the huge Japanese capital markets were made more open, they became vastly larger and more powerful, less subject to control and far more volatile. As a result, the Government faces not just the problem of what steps to take to stabilize stock prices and bolster the yen, but how it can rebuild confidence. News analysis. HEADLINE: Japan's Scratch-Pad Computers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 25

 BODY:
More than a decade into the personal computer revolution, tens of millions of people are still far more comfortable scribbling on a pad than typing on a computer keyboard. And few countries are more keyboard-phobic than Japan, where the enormous complexities of entering 7,000 Chinese-based ideographs into a personal computer have left offices shockingly unautomated.
Now, a few computer makers here are beginning to sell computers with a simple solution to the problem: They get rid of keyboards altogether.
In what may be a glimpse of computing's future, the Sony Corporation and Canon Inc. have begun to sell notebook-size machines that allow users to write on a touch-sensitive screen with a pen. Their writing is converted, not quite instantly, into neat rows of glowing computer type, which can be intermingled with careful electronic sketches or digitized doodles, then printed out in type just as is done on an ordinary personal computer. 
 
A New Way to Communicate
The battery-operated machines -some call them ''pen computers,'' others ''stylus systems'' or ''smart paper'' - cost from $500 to $2,300, and so far they are available only in Japan, where makers say the need is greatest. They still have their share of annoying technical glitches, chiefly mistakes in reading handwriting, and a host of Japanese and American companies are scurrying to improve the technology.
But experts say the sudden appearance of the Sony Palmtop and the Canon AI Note in Tokyo's gadget-jammed electronics stores mark the beginning of an entirely new way to communicate with computers - a user interface that may be even less intimidating than the ''mouse'' pointing devices that were invented to make personal computers more inviting. The technology could, in 5 or 10 years, make a computer the size of a writing tablet approachable to people who do not type and who refuse to go near anything that clacks and beeps.
Over time, the development could also rectify a huge technological imbalance: Though Japan's population and economy are half the size of those of the United States, market forecasters predict only 1.6 million personal computers will be sold here this year, compared with 12 million machines in the United States.
 
A Dream Notebook
''This has been a dream for us, because keyboards are so difficult,'' said Shingo Tamura, a leader of the development team at Sony.
Right now Mr. Tamura's dream looks more like a cross between an electronic Filofax and a Post-It Note - a place to keep quick notes, to append a description to an electronic picture, or to update a phone list or a calendar or a schedule. The difference is that the computer can retrieve, organize and combine drawings, notes and names that might be lost in a voluminous notebook.
Sony's machine goes a step further: It can take a handwritten note, convert it into clean type and drawings, dial the phone and send it as a facsimile.
 
Future Uses
In the future, the machines are expected to be used as an architect's sketchpad, a traveling salesman's order and notebook, and a place for musicians to compose and for lawyers to update their electronic files without disturbing the quiet of the courtroom.
Ultimately, the machines will be able to perform virtually all the functions of laptop computers with keyboards, including organizing columns of numbers, reaching powerful data bases and communicating with other computers of all sizes.
And there is a higher purpose: The arrival of computers without keyboards finally brings ''a socially acceptable way to doodle while looking busy during dull meetings,'' said Richard Shaffer, the editor of the Technologic Computer Letter.
 
Contest for Technology
Who will get the upper hand in the technology - American companies building on their strengths in computing or Japanese concerns building on theirs in consumer electronics - is far from clear.
Virtually all of the critical hardware technologies for the new machines are Japanese, including the pressure-sensitive screens that ''read'' handwriting and the high-density circuitry that makes it possible to pack the needed computer power into a tablet that weighs less than two pounds. But the software to make it all work, many believe, will play to the strengths of the American computer industry, and already there are forays into the technology.
The Grid Computer division of the Tandy Corporation already markets an ''electronic clipboard'' useful to people who fill out forms, though far less versatile than what is coming out in Japan. Similar technology has been used on desktop machines by Wang Laboratories, with only modest success so far.
The most promising project is at the GO Corporation, a Silicon Valley start-up. GO's first product is widely expected to be a versatile, pen-based machine that allows easy transfer of data to desktop personal computers.
 
Problems Inherent in Kanji
Anyone familiar with Japanese handwriting would know why the technology is of greater value to the Japanese. In written form, Japanese is a mixture of three ''alphabets'': two phonetic alphabets, called hiragana and katakana, which reproduce 46 sounds each (and a host of variants), and the more complex Chinese ideographs known as kanji. Most Japanese know more than 4,000 kanji.
Kanji have driven computer engineers to distraction. Early efforts to place the characters on keys produced keyboards so unwieldy that they were virtually useless. Most Japanese keyboards now use only the two phonetic alphabets, and software converts them to the appropriate kanji. Though the systems have improved greatly, they are still slow.
In the Sony Palmtop, which costs $1,300 and has optional equipment that can cost up to $1,000 more, the software is programmed to recognize the complex kanjis that are written on its screen - along with kana and the 26-letter Roman alphabet. The current version of the Canon machine, which at $500 is intended more as an electronic notebook, only recognizes the two phonetic alphabets and Roman letters; future versions are expected to include kanji.
 
Similarity to the Macintosh
The 4-by-6-inch liquid-crystal display screen of the Sony machine, which is hard to read except in direct light, draws heavily on the use of the small pictographs or ''icons'' in the Apple Macintosh. With a special pen, a user can open up a clean ''page,'' or touch the picture of a shredder to eliminate a file.
Entries can be written in an agenda, and names or telephone and fax numbers scribbled in an electronic telephone book. Database software in the machine catalogues the information, and it can also record eight seconds of sound, mostly voice messages, that are appended to individual files.
A small $300 disk drive and a $475 modem for connection to a fax machine, which can be used instead of a printer, are essential for anyone who needs to save and transmit data.
 
The Machine's Heart and Heel
But the machine's heart - the handwriting recognition system, which took Sony five years to develop - is also its Achilles heel.
There are two ways for machines to recognize handwriting. One is a ''static'' system that looks at the letter after it is written, much as a person would glance at a written letter. Its success depends on the clarity of the writer's handwriting, because each letter must come close to matching an ideal image of that letter in the computer's memory.
But kanji are incredibly complex, sometimes requiring 20 or more strokes to write. So Sony and Canon chose a second way to recognize handwriting, called dynamic recogition.
 
Relying on Order of Pen Strokes
The computer literally traces the pen strokes used to write a Roman letter, a phonetic letter or a kanji as they are being made, and compares them with a series of pen strokes stored in the computer's memory. This system lends itself to Japanese users, because from their earliest schooling all Japanese are taught a specific stroke order for writing each kana or kanji.
''We are depending on the Japanese being well disciplined,'' said Tomoshi Hirayama, a member of the team that developed the machine. ''And most of them are.'' The problem is that if a writer makes an error forming any character, the result, although clear to the eye, may be unrecognizable to the machine.
In the West, of course, schools do not teach a uniform way of making pen strokes to form letters, so the Japanese machines may prove unworkable.
 
Advantages for Canon
Canon actually beat Sony to the market, but has significantly further to go. Its machine's advantage is that users can write notes anywhere on the screen, while on the Sony Palmtop letters or characters must be placed in a small box. But the Canon computer recognizes only handwritten kana, not kanji. The kana are converted to kanji later, a somewhat laborious process.
Nonetheless, Canon sold 30,000 units of a less-capable version of its machine, far better than expected, when the computer came on the market last year. A new model, available this month, is expected to do better yet; it can easily be connected to a printer.
While the notebook computer is mostly a novelty for now, it could someday become popular enough to help Canon and Sony attack the dominant positions of the NEC Corporation and the Toshiba Corporation in the laptop computer market in both Japan and the United States.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Pressure On the Fed Increasing

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee is probably not going to approve a change in monetary policy when it meets tomorrow in Washington. But a growing number of analysts say the central bank may now be leaning toward its first tightening of policy in nearly a year.
The impetus for tightening is clear, these economists say. Inflation, though restrained from its spurt in January, remains at naggingly high levels. And reports on the economy, though distorted by abnormally warm winter weather, nevertheless suggest that recession has been avoided. 
There are, however, sizable impediments that for now block a policy change that would move the overnight federal funds rate, the market rate the Fed most closely controls, from its current 8 1/4 percent.
The dollar remains very strong, particularly against the yen. Higher American rates would cause the dollar to climb even further, making American exports more expensive and leading to greater trade imbalances with the Japanese and other nations.
In addition, analysts say the Fed cannot afford to ignore the possible fallout from the sharp slide in Japanese stock prices.
 
'Not Open and Shut'
''We think the case for tightening is pretty solid, but it is not open and shut,'' said Richard B. Berner, a vice president and economist at Salomon Brothers. ''At the very least, the Fed has to be dismayed with the latest inflation numbers, which have edged up in spite of special, weather-related factors. But for currency reasons, right now is probably a bad time to think about tightening monetary policy.''
Maria Fiorini Ramirez, president and chief executive of Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants, a subsidiary of John Hancock Freedom Securities, said: ''The main impediment to a Fed tightening is the dollar. If it remains strong against the Japanese yen, it will prevent them from tightening, and may even force an ease in interest rates.''
At the moment, the Fed has no reason to react to the recent steep drop in the Tokyo stock market. But the plunge, which since the start of the year has wiped out close to $1 trillion in wealth, has to be a source of concern.
''The fall in the Tokyo stock market is not something the Fed has to respond to yet,'' said S. Waite Rawls, vice chairman of Continental Bank, ''but it is impossible to think that there will be no ripple effect from what has happened in Tokyo.''
David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International, estimates that $800 billion to $900 billion worth of wealth has been erased in Tokyo's market plunge.
 
'Act of Masochism'
Japan's problems are serious, he said, but the Fed has other reasons to reject an urge to tighten monetary policy.
''For the kind of economy we are now in, one that is teetering on the brink of recession, it would be an act of masochism for the Fed to tighten policy,'' he said. ''We need to have lower interest rates.''
Even if the Fed maintains a neutral stance, market interest rates are likely to remain close to current levels for some time to come, analysts said.
A renewed supply of Treasury securities, starting with this week's auctions of two- and four-year notes, will tend to prevent rates from falling. And uncertainty about the economy is almost certain to linger.
''The market has to wait until it sees the March economic data before it can be satisfied that the numbers are a bit stronger,'' said William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. ''But right now the market doesn't have any conviction as to what it ought to do.''
 
Short-Term vs. Long-Term Yields
Indeed, given the current configuration of the yield curve, with yields on shorter-term notes above those offered on long-term bonds, some money managers say the market may have already anticipated a tightening by the Fed.
''The front end continues to expect that the Fed will tighten,'' said Gail P. Seneca, managing partner at GMG/ Seneca Capital Management, a San Francisco firm that has $200 million in taxable fixed-income securities under management. ''But I can't see a reason for the Fed to do that. As a result, if I were going to be making a bet on the yield curve, I would do it at the short end.''
At the end of last week the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.58 percent. The 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price to yield 8.47 percent.
After weeks of moving higher, interest rates have recently become more stable, causing an increasing number of corporations to issue new debt securities. $2 Billion in Corporate Debt Last week, investment-grade issuance of corporate debt amounted to around $2 billion, according to analysts at Salomon Brothers, well up from an average of $900 million for the first 10 weeks of the year.
This week's calendar of expected offerings looks fairly light, but corporate finance specialists say that appearance could be deceiving. They note that with the implementation of shelf registration, corporations can file a debt prospectus with the Securities and Exchange Commission far ahead of when a deal is actually priced.
''Based on the last couple of weeks, business should be O.K.,'' an investment banker said. ''We are in the last month of the quarter, and people feel like they need to get some things done. And they might be worried that rates are going to go higher.''

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Global Strategies Vs. National Ties

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
FOR many American manufacturers, putting factories abroad - going global - is a top priority. They are learning to be as much at home in Europe and Asia as they are in the United States, and in the process they are redefining the meaning of ''home country.'' Having one is still important, it seems, but not in the old sense of the phrase.
The issue is not patriotism, but whether global companies like International Business Machines or Ford Motor or Motorola, drawing much of their revenue and profits from the sale of products made in their overseas factories, have to concern themselves with the prosperity of the United States. Can an American company be competitive in the world marketplace if the United States is losing ground as a center of skilled workers, research and high-technology industries? 
The final answer is not in yet, but some important hints are emerging in the responses of various executives to a recent article on global companies in The Harvard Business Review. The author, Robert B. Reich, a political economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, argued that global companies, whether Japanese, American or West German, do not greatly concern themselves with national loyalties. Over the long run, their factories go to the countries offering the best conditions for modern production. The United States, therefore, should create those conditions, Mr. Reich wrote, and not worry about the nationalities of the companies lured here. What really counts is the wealth their spending and production bestow on Americans.
Many executives agree in principle with Mr. Reich but say that he misses some subtleties that tie companies and countries together. Few corporations in the world are more global than I.B.M., which has huge operations in Japan and Europe as well as in the United States. But Jack Kuehler, I.B.M.'s president, took exception to Mr. Reich in a letter to The Review. Mr. Kuehler, in his letter, and another I.B.M. official, in an interview, argued, in effect, that I.B.M. has to be concerned with the competitiveness and well-being of any country or region that is a major source of I.B.M. revenue. And the United States accounts for 40 percent of the company's worldwide sales.
Thus, I.B.M. is developing with Siemens A.G. of West Germany a 64-megabyte computer chip that is many times more powerful than the semiconductors now in use. The research is being done in both the United States and Europe. The goal is to have a source of supply in each marketplace by the mid-1990's, for use in I.B.M. computers made and sold here and in Europe. As for Japan, the source of supply for I.B.M.'s operations there might be Japanese companies developing a similar chip. Describing the American, Japanese and European economies as three legs in a stool, the I.B.M. official said, ''We want to balance this game out, so that two legs don't get bigger than the third.'' For I.B.M., then, all three regions are ''home country,'' requiring sophisticated production networks.
Richard W. Heimlich, vice president for international strategy at Motorola Inc., acknowledged that Motorola does sometimes have to ignore its American ties in pursuit of technology and the best manufacturing centers - but it does so unwillingly. ''Any company has a national bias, and to the extent a company can keep its best stuff at home, it will do so,'' Mr. Heimlich said. That bias helps to explain why the United States remains for Motorola the center of its research and its most advanced manufacturing for two major products: cellular telephones, so common now in cars, and the telephone pagers and beepers that people wear on their belts.
Both products originated in the United States, which remains a leader in the field. When it comes to semiconductors for calculators and other consumer devices or advanced electronic systems to control highway traffic, Motorola goes abroad, national bias notwithstanding. Government policies in Europe and East Asia have helped to give those areas an edge in these fields.
''Japan has identified intelligent vehicle highway systems as a priority, while the United States is just talking about this technology,'' he said. ''If the other folks push ahead, then we want to participate, and we've set up an operation abroad to work closely with them.''
So, are American managers concerned about their nation's well-being? Plainly, many are. Will the ties remain strong? No one knows. If China were somehow, someday to become a bigger market for I.B.M. computers than the United States, then I.B.M. executives in the 21st century are not likely to insist on wrapping themselves in the American flag. But as Mr. Heimlich argues, many executives running American companies today, given their druthers, prefer to stay home.

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Fell by 3.4% Last Month

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
New orders for American-made machine tools in February fell by 3.4 percent from January, the third consecutive monthly decline. The drop reflected a slowing of the economy and a stagnancy in the automobile industry.
The Association for Manufacturing Technology, the trade association for the machine tool industry, said in a report released today that machine tool orders declined to $194.5 million, from $201.3 million in January.
The February total was down by 31 percent from the $281.9 million in new orders in February 1989. For the first two months of the year, new orders were down by 22.8 percent, compared with the same period a year ago. 
 
Linked to Economic Growth
''This is an industry that is closely tied to economic growth,'' said Robert F. McCarthy, an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. ''And because the economy is slowing, the machine tool industry is directly affected. Because of uncertainty about the economy, companies are delaying their buying of new machinery. And the auto industry is still in a slowdown, which affects the order rate of new machine tools.''
Machine tools are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts used in products ranging from appliances and vehicles to aircraft and construction materials. The strength of machine tool orders generally reflects the strength in industrial production, and economists consider their sales patterns to be important indicators of capital spending patterns by manufacturers.
The level of orders from foreign customers declined by 11.2 percent in February, and the analysts said that was a sign of a stronger dollar. Compared with the level of orders in February 1989, new foreign orders rose by 11.3 percent. The orders from foreign customers increased by 27.3 percent in the first two months of this year from the levels of the comparable period last year.
''We are seeing a pause in domestic business activity, as manufacturers weigh their investment needs for the 1990's,'' said Albert W. Moore, the president of the association, which is based in McLean, Va. ''There is concern about United States interest rates and the effects of higher rates in Japan and West Germany.''
 
Concern Over Standards
Mr. Moore said American manufacturers were concerned about coming fuel and pollution standards on products and manufacturing. ''But United States manufacturers cannot afford to pause much longer,'' he said. ''World competitive conditions dictate that they must invest to survive.''
Many executives of machine tool companies acknowledge that the industry is in a slow period but predict that conditions will improve dramatically in the second half of the year.
''Things will be slow for another two months or so,'' said Michael J. Murphy, the vice president of sales and marketing with the Danley Machine Corporation, a machine tool subsidiary of Connell & Company. ''But things will pick up in the last half of the year, unless there is a recession. Even though some capital spending programs are on hold, they are programs that will have to eventually proceed.''
Shipments of machine tools were up by 18.4 percent in February, to $268 million, from January's level. Shipments increased by 17.1 percent from February 1989. The level of shipments climbed by 29.8 percent, compared with the 1989 period.
The association's report showed that new orders for metal-cutting tools, which include boring mills and lathes, were down by 17.6 percent from January, to $116.3 million. That segment of the industry typically accounts for about three-quarters of the industry's orders. New orders for metal-forming tools increased by 30.1 percent, to $78.2 million.
The backlog for machine tools was $1.7 billion in February, down from January's $1.77 billion. The February 1989 backlog was $2.32 billion.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The Pressures On Drug Stocks

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
THE robust earnings growth that polished the attractiveness of drug stocks in the 1980's owed much to aggressive increases in drug prices. But pressures to restrain prices are building and that may at least partly explain why pharmaceutical stocks have slipped. This year, pharmaceuticals trail the market by about 5 percent.
Other reasons for the slippage that several analysts cited include profit taking by investors worried about the possibility of a general slide in the stock market and uncertainty about the dollar, which has been strong against the yen. Those pharmaceutical makers that have a large presence in Japan would suffer if the dollar continued to advance against the yen, which would reduce their Japanese profits. 
On the price front, Senator David H. Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas and chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Aging, is preparing legislation to prod the drug makers to bid against each other for state Medicaid business. This business accounts for about 13 percent of American drug sales. The Pryor bill is given little chance this year. Even if passed, it would probably not take effect before 1993. But Mr. Pryor's attack on drug prices, which seems to be gathering support in Washington and among insurers, has upset some investors.
Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, chairman of Merck & Company, acknowledged in a talk with analysts late last year that ''there is tremendous pressure on pricing now.'' He said annual price increases at Merck had been ''targeted on recovering what we lost to inflation'' in the 1970's. Last year, Merck's increases were, on average, at the level of the Consumer Price Index, he said. The index rose 4.6 percent in 1989. ''We believe we have caught up,'' he said. ''That's where we like to be.''
In Japan, which is second only to the United States in pharmaceutical sales, the Government will lower drug prices next month by 9 to 10 percent. Merck and Pfizer Inc. have the biggest exposure in Japan, said Mary Ellen McCarthy, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton. She said drug prices would also be under pressure in Western Europe, where lower trade barriers are planned in 1992. ''Wholesalers will buy in Spain, for example, where prices are lower, and sell in the United Kingdom,'' she predicted.
Nonetheless Ms. McCarthy said she was moderately bullish about drug stocks. She singles out Eli Lilly & Company, whose results have been helped by its Prozac antidepressant drug and strong sales in medical instruments.
Lilly's stock closed unchanged Friday at $61.875 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Merck was at $69.625, up 87.5 cents, and Pfizer at $58.875, up 50 cents.
Ronald Nordmann at Paine Webber said he was more concerned about American prospects than foreign ones. He said that overall corporate earnings were slipping and that the relatively strong drug earnings would shine in the ensuing gloom.
''We think earnings of the Standard & Poor's 400 and 500 will be down 5 to 10 percent in 1990, followed by 10 to 12 percent growth in 1991,'' he said. ''By comparison, drug earnings will be up in aggregate by 19 percent in 1990 and 17 percent in 1991. The relative earnings story will make drug stocks turn around.''
Among the first signs of what lies ahead will be the first-quarter results released in mid-April. Barbara Ryan at Prudential-Bache Securities said she expected 10 percent growth, on average, in drug earnings, compared with about 16 percent in the first quarter of 1989, which was a banner year for the companies. ''We don't think the group will outperform the market this year,'' she said.
Earnings of three companies - Bristol-Myers Squibb, Lilly and Schering-Plough - are accelerating, Ms. Ryan said, adding: ''The rest are all decelerating. Our single best idea is Bristol-Myers.''
She said she was enthusiastic about Bristol-Myers's research potential and the company's ''strong over-the-counter presence.'' The over-the-business is important, she said, because pharmaceutical companies will be coming under pressure from the Government and major insurers to slow the rate of price increases on prescription drugs. ''But the consumer products that you and I buy will continue to be able to raise their prices,'' she said. ''We think Bristol will have consistent 20 percent growth over the next several years.''
Bristol-Myers closed at $52.25, up 25 cents, while Schering-Plough was at $78.75, up $1.
For more aggressive investors, Stuart Z. Levine at Gruntal & Company likes SmithKline Beecham. The company was formed last year by the merger of the British company Beecham and SmithKline Beckman of Philadelphia. He said the stock had been selling at a deep discount compared with the other drug companies, after reports that the recently merged company was having trouble finding a buyer as it tried to sell its cosmetics business to pay down debt.
''We are looking for a lot of benefits coming out of the merger from restructuring during 1990 and co-promoting each other's products,'' Mr. Levine said. He also likes Merck, Warner-Lambert and Schering-Plough.
On Friday, SmithKline closed at $40.75, up $1, while Warner-Lambert was at $103, up $1.875.
Steven M. Kaye, who manages the Fidelity Select Health Care Fund, said, ''SmithKline is clearly the cheapest buy in the drug group.'' His fund recently bought some stock in the company. ''They took it on the chin after they reported their numbers,'' he said. ''I am taking a longer-time view.''
Mr. Kaye is also a contrarian on Pfizer, which he said he bought ''fairly heavily'' when news about problems with a Pfizer heart valve drove the stock down in February. ''Those reports were totally overblown,'' he insisted.

HEADLINE: Judge Permits Wickes Suit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J., March 25

 BODY:
A judge has cleared the way for a union representing employees of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation to sue the Wickes Corporation for damages stemming from a failed 1986 takeover attempt of Owens-Corning by Wickes.
A spokeswoman for Wickes said it would appeal the Friday ruling by Superior Court Judge Raymond F. Drozdowski that denied Wickes's request to dismiss the case. 
The Glass, Molders, Pottery, Plastics and Allied Workers International union, based in Media, Pa., contended in its suit that Wickes had ''interfered with economic expectations'' between union members and Owens-Corning.
In August 1986, Wickes, best known for its home improvement centers and furniture business, abandoned the takeover attempt after its $2.1 billion tender offer apparently lost to a restructuring plan proposed by Owens-Corning, which is based in Toledo, Ohio.
In October 1986, Owens-Corning announced that it would lay off 5,000 workers nationwide, including 500 at its Barrington, N.J., plant, to thwart the takeover attempt. Wickes, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., made a $30 million profit after expenses from the takeover bid.

HEADLINE: Treasury Schedules 2 Note Auctions

 BODY:
Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and auctions of two-year notes tomorrow and four-year notes on Wednesday.
By late Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 7.89 percent, and the six-month issue at 7.83 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 8.54 percent and the four-year note at 8.55 percent. 
Among government agency issues expected this week is a $2.6 billion financing by the Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation that is expected to be priced on Wednesday. The financing will include three separate issues of Federal Farm Credit Banks consolidated systemwide bonds.
Two issues of $1.05 billion each will have maturity dates of July 2 and Sept. 1. For the remaining $500 million of bonds, the maturity date is April 1, 1991. Proceeds from the bond sale will be used along with internally generated funds, to retire about $2.7 billion in bonds maturing on April 2.

HEADLINE: An Aging Nation Grapples With Care for Old and Ill

SERIES: Care of the Elderly; Private Burdens, Public Choices - First of four articles.

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
Care of the frail and chronically ill elderly, long a private burden of families, is fast becoming a public obsession and a volatile political issue as the older population increases and members of the baby boom generation face the aging of their own parents.
The nation's current system of long-term care leaves many elderly people in fear and some destitute and demoralized, in the view of many experts and families who have struggled with the problem.
A shortage of affordable community programs - a visiting aide to watch a wandering Alzheimer's patient or a day center to provide meals and society to the frail and isolated - forces some people into nursing homes unnecessarily. It also means there is too little relief for the millions of relatives, usually wives or daughters, who care for the disabled at home, often at the expense of their own lives.
And haunting most of the elderly is the specter of financial ruin. Accounts abound of people who watched in despair as nursing home bills consumed the savings of a lifetime. Many who need chronic care must spend their assets until they qualify for Medicaid, the Federal-state welfare program for the poor - a process of ''spending down'' that people describe as terrifying and humiliating. 
 
The Spending 'Kills People'
''Spending down is horrendous,'' said Nancy Lombardo, a director of the Alzheimer's Association, who has talked with hundreds of families with a member affected by the irreversible brain disease. ''It kills people.''
The political passions surrounding the health concerns of the aged became abundantly clear last year, as Congress was forced to repeal a major program to cover the medical costs of catastrophic illnesses after adopting it with fanfare the year before. An unexpected outcry about the way of paying for the program incited the opposition that led to the reversal. But the debate also threw a spotlight on what many older people said was their greater worry, long-term care.
So far, there is no agreement on where private responsibility ends and public responsibility begins, on how much money Government should, or could, spend to ease the burdens.
In Washington and in state capitals, well-organized groups are demanding more government support. ''We have insurance for retirement, and we have insurance for acute medical care,'' said John Rother, the chief lobbyist for the American Association of Retired Persons, referring to the Social Security and Medicare programs. ''It doesn't seem logical to leave out the thing that can wipe families out, long-term care.''
Politicians are taking up the cry, but even the most sympathetic shudder at the thought of a major new Government obligation, one for which the cost is certain to rise dramatically in the decades ahead. Officials are only too aware of the strains that programs like Medicare are already placing on the Federal budget.
The numbers are daunting. Those 85 and older, who are most apt to need assistance, are increasing more than three times as fast as the population as a whole. A 1987 Federal study projected that the total number of elderly Americans needing some type of help, then about six and a half million, would climb to 19 million by 2040.
Yet the number of family members able to aid the disabled at home - still the mainstay of the nation's care system - is expected to decline, not only because of the changing demographic structure but also because more women, who have traditionally handled such care, hold jobs and more families are smaller or scattered. Both are especially true of the baby boom generation, whose parents are now reaching old age.
 
Facing Poverty
Surviving Spouses Left With Little
Only a minority of the elderly ever face huge bills for chronic care. People 65 years old have a 44 percent chance of entering a nursing home at some point in their remaining years. Only 13 percent, or about one in seven, can expect to spend a year or more in a nursing home, according to a study by LifePlans, a private consulting group on long-term care in Waltham, Mass.
But a prolonged stay in a nursing home or extensive paid assistance at home often means financial disaster. Nursing homes cost an average of close to $30,000 a year, and the cost is more in some regions like New York. A 1987 study by the House Select Committee on Aging found that two-thirds of single elderly people would have their incomes and assets depleted to the Federal poverty level if they paid for one year in a nursing home. Half of elderly couples would be similarly impoverished in a year.
One who knows what nursing home bills can do is Mabel Crim, a 92-year-old widow in Margate, Fla. She and her husband, Russell, a former plant manager for Standard Oil, had felt secure on their retirement in Florida, given his pension, Social Security benefits and the $35,000 they had saved ''to take care of us when we got old,'' as she put it in a recent interview.
Then, at age 88, Mr. Crim had a heart attack and a series of strokes that left him seriously incapacitated, and he spent his last two years in a nursing home.
''The nursing home took all my savings,'' Mrs. Crim said. ''I was glad I had it and could pay it, but it left me high and dry.'' Once her funds were exhausted, the state's Medicaid program took over.
Now, her husband gone, she maintains herself and her one-bedroom apartment with Social Security benefits and financial help from her daughters. ''I get along,'' she says without bitterness.
But one daughter, Iona Gilbert, is angrier. ''My mother is turning 92 this month, and they left her without a cent,'' she said.
''She had daughters to help her, or she'd be out in the street,'' said Mrs. Gilbert. ''I don't know what happens to those little old ladies down there with nobody.''
 
Facing Distress
Using Welfare Torments Many
While Medicare and private health insurance will usually pay for medical treatment, neither covers custodial care of the type needed by those with chronic physical or mental disorders. Increasingly, private insurance is offered for long-term care, but only a small number of people have bought it so far, and policies, usually costing $100 a month or more, are beyond the financial reach of most elderly people, experts say.
Instead, except for the poor, chronic-care bills must be paid out of pocket. Middle-income people often pay until their assets are so depleted they can qualify for Medicaid.
The Medicaid spend-down has achieved a fearful notoriety among the elderly; spouses of the disabled have sometimes even resorted to divorce so they could preserve their standard of living. For a widowed or single person too, the quick loss of a lifetime's savings and of any chance of passing assets on to children is a wrenching blow.
Recent changes in the law have increased the amount that spouses, like Mabel Crim, can keep before getting Medicaid help. The rules differ by state, but Federal guidelines allow spouses to keep the couple's house and, this year, at least $856 a month in income and at least $12,516 in assets. States may allow as much as $1,565 in income and $62,580 in assets, though most have chosen the lower limits.
While advocates of the elderly cheer these changes, they say the limits still force a real decline in living standards and security on some surviving spouses. And single people are still left with virtually nothing: they can usually keep a small spending allowance and little more than $2,000 in assets. Those who are able to return home after spending time in an institution are often left with little.
The critics also argue that reliance on a welfare program, Medicaid, to meet a basic, predictable need of millions of middle-class Americans is a distortion of that program and a source of humiliation.
''Here's a man who always paid his taxes, who raised four daughters, a World War I veteran, and he ends up on charity,'' Mrs. Gilbert said of her father. ''That's the part that really hurt.''
''Knowing that the only way to get help is to give up your funds and go on welfare only adds to the distress,'' said Mrs. Lombardo of the Alzheimer's Association. ''People are tormented by this.''
Protecting assets has become a fixation for many older people who figure that if they should be incapacitated, they will need to rely on Medicaid but want to preserve their spouse's standard of living or their children's inheritance. The recent improvement in the law should reduce the number of divorces, but still, more than a few widowed older people are avoiding remarriage to avoid putting their assets in jeopardy, said Fernando Torres-Gil, an associate professor of gerontology at the University of Southern California.
Although the Government says it violates the spirit of the law, many people find legal ways to transfer assets to relatives or to use trusts or other devices to shelter funds.
''Financially sophisticated people who are accustomed to dealing with attorneys, accountants, and financial planners can find ways to protect their assets and still qualify for Medicaid,'' writes Stephen A. Moses, a former official the Department of Health and Human Services, in the February issue of The Gerontologist. ''Others, with less financial savvy, often lose what little they have before they learn how the system works.''
This means that fewer families of nursing home patients are bankrupted than would be suggested by income data alone. But it also means that the burdens of care and the benefits of public aid are being apportioned inequitably.
 
Seeking Help
Providing Care Fills the Day
At least Medicaid pays for nursing homes once people have used most of their own money or if they were poor to start. But for everyone, nursing homes are the answer of last resort. A much larger problem is the lack of home services and aid for the family and friends who care for the disabled elderly.
The stereotype of callous children notwithstanding, most of the country's disabled are cared for in their own homes or those of their children.
With the aging of the population, ''increasingly the caregivers are old too,'' notes Stephen McConnell, the director of public affairs with the Alzheimer's Association. ''More and more, it's the 65-year-old woman taking care of 85-year-old parents.''
Relatives often go to extraordinary lengths before they send a loved one to an institution. Social workers say they know of too many daughters working themselves to exhaustion trying to attend to an infirm parent while raising families of their own and too many devoted wives and husbands, frail themselves, struggling for years to provide grueling 24-hour aid to a chronically ill spouse.
Uldene Ditter, 72, of Ferndale, Mich., considers herself among the more fortunate of those caring for a disabled spouse, but her daily strains and especially her financial insecurity have led her to become an outspoken advocate of change.
Her husband of half a century has been in bed for the last five years with advancing Alzheimer's disease. She is determined to keep him out of a nursing home. ''He doesn't have a bedsore,'' she said proudly in an interview. ''I feel like I'm doing the right thing.''
Mrs. Ditter's job is an unpaid one almost without end. She gets away for 4 hours on Tuesdays when a volunteer comes, and another 4 hours on Wednesdays when a hired women comes, but apart from that, she said, ''I'm here, 24 hours a day.'' These brief hours of respite are crucial. ''It just lifts me up to get out,'' she said. ''Sometimes I get real down.'' She also gets help from a nurse who comes three times a week to bathe her husband.
But money, and thus her own future, are constant concerns. ''Just bed pads and diapers cost me $135 a month,'' she said. ''I'm getting into my savings.''
''You think you're doing well, then something falls apart in the house,'' she said. ''And of course, with him here I have to keep the furnace up a little higher.''
Of $15 billion in Federal Medicaid funds to be devoted to long-term care in the 1990 fiscal year, less than 3 percent will pay for home services. Many states and localities are now experimenting with a host of promising programs designed to help disabled people stay in the community. But overall, ''there are very few services available to people caring for older relatives and friends,'' said Bette Mullen, the director of the women's initiative program of the A.A.R.P. ''And there's a lack of knowledge of the services that do exist.''
 
Daunting Prospects
More Will Need Extensive Care
Demographic and social change portend an enormous rise in the need for expensive care. The problem is not just the aging of the population, but also ''the aging of the elderly population,'' observes Kenneth G. Manton, a demographer at Duke University. Those over 85 are rapidly increasing in number.
At the same time, Dr. Manton said, there will be relatively fewer relatives available to provide care at home. And this, he warns, almost inevitably means ''a shift from voluntary, family sources of care to paid care'' like professional home services and nursing homes.
Now, on any given day, about 5 percent of the elderly are in a nursing home, or a total of 1.4 million in 1987, according to Federal data.
Three-fourths of the nursing home residents are women, mostly widows, reflecting the tendency for women to outlive men and the related consequence that they are less likely to have a surviving spouse to care for them at home.
But these numbers mask the enormous differences in the conditions of the younger and older ones among the elderly. Of those age 65 to 74, only about 2 percent are in nursing homes and of those 75 to 84, 6 percent.
But in the 85-plus age group, 23 percent, or more than one in five, are in nursing homes, according to Federal surveys.
Simply because so many more of them suffer severe dementia or physical infirmities, the rapid growth of the group over 85 means that a rising share of the elderly will require nursing homes or other close, expensive care. It also means there will be relatively more infirm elderly people relative to healthy elderly people who could assist them, Dr. Manton said.
At the same time, the tendency of more women to hold jobs and other changes in the family mean that relatively fewer children are likely be available to help. Without a corresponding increase in professional home-care services, there could be ''a deterioration in the ability of the disabled to stay in the community,'' Dr. Manton warned.
For a variety of economic and cultural reasons, blacks, Hispanic people and other minority groups are dramatically under-represented in nursing homes relative to the proportion of the population they make up. Many Hispanic people and Asians, for example, still see nursing homes as ''a strange and unnatural system,'' said Dr. Torres-Gil, and a tradition of extended family ties and care in the home, as well as financial concerns, has meant that the disabled from minority groups were especially likely to be kept in the community.
But now the elderly from minority groups, too, are increasing rapidly, and traditional family ties are often breaking down. This, he asserted, only underscores the desperate need for home-care services and other alternatives tailored especially to minority communities.
 
Planning Ahead
Future Poses A Social Choice
One reason nursing home costs come as such a shock to so many people is simply that they have not planned for them. Saving for retirement is part of the American way, but Americans have not traditionally thought of saving or buying insurance to cover the expenses of long-term care. Yet Government policy explicitly requires people to devote nearly all available resources on such care before receiving aid. Given these clashing assumptions it is not surprising that those who encounter the large expenses of such care feel bitter and betrayed.
''We do not expect people to exhaust their resources or sell their homes when they suffer a heart attack, but we do so for long-term care,'' said the report issued this month by a bipartisan commission on health care known as the Pepper Commission, after the late Representative Claude Pepper. ''There is no intrinsic reason why this is so; it is a matter of social choice.''
Broader government support of long-term care costs could take the form of universal coverage without considering recipients' resources, like Medicare, or remain linked to recipients' ability to pay. Any new program is apt to encourage wider use of private insurance by the more affluent among the elderly. Even the most sympathetic politicians warn, though, that any new Federal aid is unlikely to be generous, given concerns over the budget deficit and competing social needs.
More and more, experts say, planning ahead for the possible expense of chronic care will have to be a customary rite of aging.
Tomorrow: The increasing choices for care in the community.

HEADLINE: Losses at Savings and Loans In 1989 Were the Biggest Ever

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
The savings and loan industry had its worst year ever in 1989, with losses soaring to $19.2 billion, Federal regulators said today.
With the industry's recent troubles, a record loss was expected, but not one of that magnitude. It was far steeper than the biggest previous shortfall, which came in 1988, when savings and loans lost $13.4 billion, and the size of the deficit for the fourth quarter, $6.5 billion, took many by surprise.
In fact, the 485 troubled institutions had losses from operations of $2.6 billion in the quarter. That works out to a loss to taxpayers of $29 million a day for as long as the ailing institutions stayed open in the last three months of 1989. The remaining $3.9 billion loss was a result of the institutions reducing the stated value of some loans and assets, in recognition that they were worthless, at the instructions of regulators. 
Some analysts have noted that both the recent legislation to bail out the industry, which put numerous restraints on surviving savings and loans, and competition from banks and other financial institutions for mortgage business are making it significantly harder for the savings and loans to make money.
 
'New Reason for Insolvency'
''I see a growing viability problem that, in effect, is a whole new reason for insolvency,'' said Bert Ely, a financial consultant in Alexandria, Va. ''I find these numbers troubling.''
There is little disagreement that a year from now the industry will be significantly smaller than it is now, as institutions are sold off by the Government or liquidated.
Some have argued that there are simply too many savings and loans and that the failures, insolvencies and losses will not stop until most of that excess capacity has been eliminated.
Experts pointed out that aggressive regulation by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency that is managing the savings and loan bailout, is forcing institutions to acknowledge accumulated losses by reducing the value of their loans and real estate holdings to market levels for accounting purposes.
The cost of the savings and loan collapse was underscored when L. William Seidman, chairman of Resolution Trust, told Congress that the failure of Florida's largest savings institution, the Centrust Bank of Miami, was likely to cost taxpayers more than $2 billion.
Centrust, which was seized by regulators on Feb. 2, has become the latest institution to come under scrutiny by the House Banking Committee. The committee is investigating the causes of the Centrust failure; with $10 billion in assets, the institution had invested heavily in high-yield ''junk bonds'' and was run, as regulators described it, as ''a private investment banking or trading operation.''
 
Flamboyant Chairman
The committee is also investigating Centrust's chairman, David L. Paul. Known for his flamboyant, high-spending life in Miami, he had Centrust buy a $6 million yacht, called the Bodacious, received more than $16 million in compensation over five years and used his home to display large parts of Centrust's $29 million art collection, including Renoir's painting ''Man as Mars.''
Regulators are now saying privately that the cost of Centrust could be as high as $3 billion, eclipsing the cost of closing the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. That would make Centrust the single costliest failure to date.
The industry's huge deficit capped a year in which regulators and members of Congress tried to confront the tremendous size of the problem created by lax regulations, bad real estate lending, fraud and insider dealing. The landmark legislation passed last summer was intended to close down at least a third of the industry at a cost to taxpayers and healthy institutions over the next decade of at least $159 billion; analysts say the estimate has now risen to more than $200 billion.
The fourth-quarter losses were almost entirely concentrated at the 485 insolvent savings and loans that either had been taken over by the Government or were targets for Government seizure, regulators said.
 
Hopes for the Future
James Freund, the acting chief economist of the Office of Thrift Supervision, the regulatory agency created by the legislation, painted a hopeful picture, saying that ''we are seeing a substantial segment of institutions emerging that are profitable and going about their business successfully.''
Some members of Congress rejected the characterization of the situation as an improvement.
''Not only are the numbers devastating, but once again the O.T.S. attempts to sugar-coat the news, a pattern reminiscent of Danny Wall's era of rosey scenarios,'' said Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee. M. Danny Wall had been the head of the Office Thrift Supervision until he left the agency under pressure earlier this month.
Other analysts also saw ominous signs in the numbers released by regulators today.
They noted that in the fourth quarter alone, 581 institutions that had not been scheduled for Government seizure had a total loss of $1.3 billion, indicating that many of these associations might have a hard time surviving. A group of 1,818 healthy institutions had a total profit of about $1.3 billion in the fourth quarter. There were 88 fewer institutions reporting a profit than in the third quarter.
 
Signs of Trouble
''I have always found that the number of unprofitable institutions is a leading indicator of S.&L.'s on their way to trouble,'' Mr. Ely said.
Since August, the trust corporation has sold or liquidated 52 institutions and just last week Mr. Seidman announced plans to either liquidate or sell 140 more by the end of June.
Regulators have been severely criticized for the slowness of the initial pace in addressing the problem, adding to the ultimate cost to the public. Some experts predicted that examiners from the Resolution Trust corporation will continue to come down hard on institutions to reduce the book value of their assets, to put as much of the problem behind them as quickly as possible.
That could lead to similar high losses in coming months.
 
Board Member Named
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -President Bush said today that he would nominate Philip C. Jackson Jr., an Alabama banker, to the oversight board of the Resolution Trust Corporation.
Mr. Jackson is an adjunct professor at Birmingham Southern College in Birmingham, Ala. He is a former vice chairman of Central Bankshares of the South in Birmingham.

HEADLINE: News Summary

 BODY:

 
International A3-15
 
Armed Soviet troops in Lithuania stormed a psychiatric hospital in Vilnius and arrested about two dozen Lithuanian deserters who had taken refuge there since the republic's proclamation of independence March 11, witnesses said. Page A1
 
News analysis: Lithuanians are on their own. At a time when they desperately need well-placed allies in Moscow, the Lithuanians have little support in the Soviet capital for their claim of statehood. A12
 
Fear for Lithuania has U.S. emigres on the watch A12
 
Hungarian voters split their vote between two newly formed parties from the anti-Communist opposition that are now battling over how quickly the country should complete its transition to a free-market economy. A1 
 
The tally of East German residents moving to the West dropped considerably after the East German election a week ago. But it is too early, officials said, to declare that the heaviest flow is over. A13
