HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
For Lithuania, Few Allies in Moscow

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Thursday, March 27

 BODY:
After two weeks of battling with Moscow over the sovereignty of their tiny republic, the Lithuanians may or may not be independent, but one thing is clear: they are on their own.
At a time when they desperately need well-placed allies in Moscow, the Lithuanians have little support in the Soviet capital for their claim of statehood.
Even opposition groups that advocate full democracy and Western-style economics, as does Lithuania, are divided on the crisis, worried that Lithuania's secession was precipitous and may strengthen the hand of hard-liners.
Members of the Soviet legislature said in interviews on Monday that Lithuania's support there was so thin that if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev decided to use force or impose a state of emergency - measures that few expected but no one ruled out entirely -Parliament would back him up. The interviews were conducted before Soviet troops stormed a Lithuanian psychiatric hospital to arrest army deserters. 
Politicians in Moscow said the Lithuanians themselves had alienated potential allies by their aloofness, their disregard for the fears of other ethnic groups, and their romantic, one-great-leap approach to independence.
 
Moscow's Shrewd Propaganda
But Moscow has compounded the republic's political isolation by the shrewd use of propaganda to raise doubts about whether the independence government is really democratic.
Lithuanians have also been largely disappointed in their hopes of support from the outside world - especially from countries like the United States, which never officially accepted Lithuania's forcible incorporation into the Soviet Union.
Western nations and countries newly liberated from the Soviet bloc have called on Moscow to open a dialogue with Lithuania. But because they have been doubtful of the new government's durability and solicitous of Mr. Gorbachev, they have all stopped short of formally recognizing free Lithuania.
''There are three textbook conditions for recognition: territory, people and control,'' a Scandinavian diplomat said today. ''The new Lithuanian government has the first two, but we cannot yet say that they have control.''
 
Georgians Rally in Support
The Lithuanians have heard muted promises of solidarity from independence campaigners in neighboring Estonia and Latvia, and Georgian separatists rallied in support of the new government in Lithuania on Saturday.
A few members of the Soviet Parliament, such as Yuri N. Afanasyev, a historian, and Yuri Y. Boldyrev, a Leningrad lawmaker, have called for recognition of the republic's proclamation of independence, made March 11.
But most legislators have been hostile or lukewarm to the Lithuanian declaration, including members of the opposition Interregional Deputies Group, which has often been allied with members of Parliament from the Baltic republics in campaigning for greater democracy and economic pluralism.
When the Congress of People's Deputies voted March 15 to declare Lithuania's secession invalid, only 94 of the 1,557 legislators voting dissented. In Parliament on Monday, a day before reports of the seizure of Lithuanian deserters, legislators generally applauded Mr. Gorbachev's handling of the situation, including his decrees tightening security and demanding the surrender of private firearms.
 
Many Disapprove of Tactics
Many who admire Lithuania's non-Communist government said they disapproved of the tactics of separation, accomplished by an act of Parliament rather than a referendum.
The idea of representative democracy is still a novelty in this country, and many Soviet deputies consider anything short of a direct plebiscite undemocratic, although the Lithuanian Parliament was freely elected and voted unanimously for independence.
Other critics say the Lithuanians lost support by not showing greater concern for the members of the Russian and Polish minorities in their republics, many of whom worry about their place in an independent Lithuania.
''The Lithuanian freedom-lovers do not want to give first priority to human rights,'' said Nikolai N. Engver, a legislator of Latvian descent who represents a region of central Russia. He said he had repeatedly queried Lithuanians about plans to make Russians learn Lithuanian or to limit their citizenship rights, and had been given no satisfactory answers.
 
Opposition Divided
The Lithuanian move has divided Soviet opposition groups like the Interregional Deputies Group. ''A lot of deputies in the Interregional Group support Lithuania, but we don't support the form they picked to attain their independence,'' said Anatoly A. Sobchak, a Leningrad lawyer active in the opposition faction.
''They are creating opportunities for conservative forces that would like to say that the disintegration of the country must be stopped, that force must be used,'' he said.
Moscow political insurgents who met over the weekend to organize a protest on the issue next Saturday found that they were not unanimous on framing the rally as an endorsement of Lithuanian independence. Instead, they have billed their protest as a condemnation of Kremlin pressure tactics.
''If we are not united on the policy of Sajudis,'' said Galina Y. Kovalskaya of Moscow Tribune, one of the groups sponsoring the rally, referring to the Lithuanaian pro-independence movement, ''we are at least united against force and pressure. We all agree that there must not be tanks in Lithuania under any circumstances.''
Several deputies said the Lithuanians hurt themselves by failing to practice the old art of legislative logrolling.
''People ask, 'Where were the Lithuanians when our issue was debated?' '' said an Armenian legislator who has championed self-determination for his own people.
The Soviet authorities have also weakened sympathy for Lithuania with propaganda portraying the new Lithuanian leaders as reckless and undemocratic.
Roy A. Medvedev, a leading historian, said many of his fellow members of Parliament were shocked by reports, widely circulated in the Soviet press, that the Lithuanian government was on the verge of enacting a law providing a three-year prison term for activities against the new state.
Lithuanians have said that they are drafting a law outlawing attempts to overthrow the government by force, but that it will not restrict speech or political activities.
Mr. Gryazin, the Estonian deputy, conceded that the Baltic cause was hurt by the lack of support in Moscow, but he said most deputies from that region never counted on it.
''Everything we've gained until today, you've seen it yourself, has come through a very strong battle,'' he said. LAST GRAF CAN BITE

HEADLINE: Suddenly, China Looks Smaller in the World

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 26

 BODY:
If maps were based not on the physical dimensions of nations but on perceptions of their importance, the world would have to be redrawn: China has shrunk dramatically by that standard over the last year.
The result is that China is less important a country now than it used to be, in the view of diplomats, scholars and business executives. In a range of interviews in recent months, they asserted that the changing perceptions have far-reaching implications for both diplomacy and business.
''No one cares about China any more,'' a European diplomat said recently. ''In Europe, it's impossible to get people's attention about China, after what happened here in June and afterward in Eastern Europe. When China says, 'We will not apologize and you must kowtow before us,' they say --.'' He made a rude noise and extended his arm in an obscene gesture. 
Whether or not such a view is warranted, it seems to be widespread. The Bush Administration has continued to court China, and so have some business executives, but the most common view is that China does not matter nearly as much as it used to.
 
Three Factors Cited
''There's no doubt that the pendulum has shifted,'' said Richard Feinberg, the executive vice president of the Overseas Development Council in Washington. Diplomats and scholars cited three principal reasons for the devaluation of China.
The first reason is the disillusionment with business prospects in China, particularly after the upheavals and the rise of the hard-liners last year. No longer is there a widespread faith that China is inexorably proceeding toward an open-market economy that will yield riches to foreign corporations.
Second, in the 1980's China captured the West's imagination as an example of ''cuddly Communism,'' and it was a star pupil of the World Bank and other international agencies. These days it is Eastern Europe that symbolizes the hope for change.
Third, the China card is less useful for the West because of the diminishing strategic threat posed by the Soviet Union. It is striking, for example, that no one is concerned about Prime Minister Li Peng's planned visit to the Soviet Union in late April.
''Their great concern is the evaporation of leverage,'' an American diplomat said of the Chinese leaders. ''What can you do when you can't play the Americans off the Russians? This has been a great game for years, and it's gone, temporarily.''
 
The Power Remains
These analysts do not regard China as unimportant; they simply assert that it is not so important as it used to be. Any nation that is a nuclear power and a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council is powerful, particularly when it has a population of 1.1 billion.
But the fascination with China over the last decade was based on more than population and a nuclear ability. The open-door policy of the 1980's fostered a sense of awe for China that spilled out of the corridors of power and into the boardrooms. Major corporations often felt obliged to do business in China.
All that has changed. Western companies were already becoming disillusioned with China's bureaucracy, high costs and elusive profits when they were hit last year with both a deepening austerity program and the killings and repression in Beijing. Now many still say China has a great deal of potential, but they add that so do a lot of other countries.
''There used to be a missionary aspect to it, with the board of directors having a vision of an enormous consumer market - you know, two billion armpits in need of deodorant,'' said Mats Engstrom, chairman of California Sunshine Inc., a food company that does extensive business with China. ''But since Tiananmen Square, they've realized that it's a long-term prospect, and even then unless you're in the right area you're not going to succeed.''
 
Lending Rates Change
The change in attitudes can best be seen in lending rates. Just a few years ago, when China was blooming in its greatest glory, some Japanese banks were making loans to Beijing at no mark-up from the London Inter-Bank Offered Rate, or Libor, a common benchmark. Now the ''spread'' has risen to about three-quarters of a percentage point above Libor.
China is also hurt by the growing international awareness of Taiwan's financial muscle. It is impossible to regard the tiny island of Taiwan as an international power, but it is difficult not to notice it when its foreign exchange reserves are five times as large as China's and its per capita income is more than 20 times as large.
Executives also note that while Taiwan's population of 20 million is less than 2 percent of China's, Taiwan's total foreign trade is about 6 percent more than the mainland's.
Taiwan's wealth has led to a series of embarrassing diplomatic defeats for the mainland, as one poor country after another responds to economic incentives and recognizes Taiwan as the government of China.

HEADLINE: The U.S. Needs a Domestic Marshall Plan First;
Don't Shift Assistance

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The revolutionary turn of events in Eastern Europe, coupled with dramatic political changes in Central America, have led some in Congress and the Administration to advocate cuts in foreign aid levels to our main allies, such as Israel, Egypt and the Philippines, to provide aid to Eastern Europe and elsewhere (''Congress, Hoping to Aid New Democracies, Finds Itself Shackled by Budget,'' news article, March 8).
I strongly disagree with that approach. What the United States needs is a larger overall foreign assistance level, so that it does not unwisely undermine old friends while trying to help new ones.
It makes no sense to rob the Philippines to pay Poland. Given new political realities, it makes more sense to shift money from military spending to economic aid. In recent years, United States aid to our main allies, such as Israel and Egypt, has declined in real dollars, and I see no reason to squeeze them further.
For our nation's own economic health, the first priority of any peace dividend must be to reduce the Federal budget deficit. After that, our national security interests demand that we do not underestimate the strategic value of economic aid to needy nations in Eastern Europe. It would be counterproductive, however, simultaneously to weaken support for our historical allies.
President Bush's proposal to pay for new economic assistance for Nicaragua and Panama from fiscal year 1990 Defense Department funds is a step in the right direction. This can be a classic case of making swords into plowshares.
 
BILL GREEN
Member of Congress, 15th Dist., N.Y.
 Washington, March 13, 1990

HEADLINE: Dinkins Details Additional Cuts In City Budget

BYLINE: By LEONARD BUDER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday announced details of the city's latest budget cuts for the current fiscal year, a $75 million reduction that he said would cut ''to the very marrow of city services.''
The cuts will mean, the Mayor said, that schools and hospitals will have to further trim spending on supplies, streets will be dirtier, a planned expansion of drug-treatment programs will be delayed until the start of the next fiscal year, and there will be further reductions in subsidies to libraries and cultural institutions.
The Sanitation Department Clean Team, a group that uses push brooms to sweep streets, will be reduced, from 505 employees to 282. The Mayor said the staff would ''be less than one-fourth the size it was just a few years ago.'' 
Acknowledging that ''none of these actions will be popular,'' Mr. Dinkins said at a news conference that the reductions ''are the regrettable but inevitable steps we must take to maintain this city's fiscal integrity.''
 
'That's Where the Money Is'
On Feb. 28, Mr. Dinkins announced that because of new shortfalls in tax revenues, city agencies would be asked by April 1 to make $75 million in budget cuts on top of other cuts and actions taken since last fall to close a gap of more than $1 billion for the fiscal year that ends on June 30.
Last week the Mayor said that New York City faced an additional budget gap of at least $700 million for the next fiscal year.
That is on top of the $1.1 billion gap expected when Mr. Dinkins announced his $27.8 billion preliminary budget for 1990-91 on Feb. 1.
Among the 1989-90 budget reductions announced yesterday were the Board of Education, $16.7 million; Health and Hospitals Corporation, 13.7 million; Social Services Department, $6.7 million; Housing Preservation and Development Department, $6.1 million; Police Department, $3.2 million, and Sanitation Department, $3.7 million. There was no new reduction for the Fire Department.
Asked why schools and hospitals were cut the most, the Mayor said both had very large budgets. ''That's where the money is,'' he said.
About half the Health and Hospitals Corporation's new cuts will be from unspent money. The rest will be from a $1 million reduction in overtime and a $6 million decrease in supplies and materials and contractual costs. The Board of Education, which has already reduced its budget by $50 million in the last several months, will have to cut further on computers, typewriters, science equipment and other supplies.
The cut for the Police Department will force a delay in hiring 81 civilians, but will not affect the scheduled hiring next month of 750 officers who will begin training at the Police Academy.
Mr. Dinkins said he would go to Albany today to ask the state ''for help that will permit us to help ourselves,'' including approval to enact new and higher taxes previously proposed.
''If there is a political risk,'' the Mayor said, referring to the taxes, ''I will bear it, for I know that there is a far greater risk in further service reductions.''
 
Advisers to Review Spending
Earlier in the day, Mr. Dinkins announced the appointment of a 17-member Council of Economic Advisers, drawn from business and city governnment, to help the city develop long-range economic policy.
He said that the group would annually review budget policies, including expenses, revenues and labor contracts, and that it would help the city try to obtain additional state and Federal aid for economic development. These are the members of the council:
 
Carol O'Cleireacain, Commissioner of Finance.
Joseph Flom, partner, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.
Earl G. Graves, president and chief executive, Earl G. Graves Ltd.
Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development.
Reginald Lewis, chairman and chief executive, the TLC Group.
Philip R. Michael, director of the Office of Management and Budget.
G. G. Michelson, senior vice president for external affairs, R. H. Macy & Company.
James D. Robinson 3d, president and chief executive, the American Express Company.
Joyce M. Roche, vice president of brand marketing, Avon Products Inc.
David Rockefeller, chairman, Rockefeller Group Inc.
Felix G. Rohatyn, senior partner, Lazard Freres & Company.
Lewis Rudin, president, Rudin Management Company, and chairman, Association for a Better New York.
Norman Steisel, First Deputy Mayor.
Ellen Sulzberger Straus, president, Executive Service Strategies.
Elgardo Vasquez, former senior vice president, United States operations, Banco Popular.
Clifton R. Wharton Jr., chief executive officer, Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund.

HEADLINE: FIRE IN THE BRONX;
Koch Bill Cracking Down On Clubs Died in Council

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
A centerpiece of the Koch administration's promised crackdown on New York City social clubs - a bill to require owners of clubs closed for safety violations to post a large bond before re-opening - died in a City Council committee last year after members said it might penalize innocent landlords.
The measure would have provided for civil penalties of up to $1 million for safety violations that resulted in death or serious injury and would have forced clubs closed for safety violations to carry $1 million in liability insurance before reopening.
The bill's fate was part of a city initiative that has dwindled since it was announced with fanfare by Mayor Edward I. Koch in August 1988, after a fire at another Bronx social club killed six people. The effort also included an interagency task force to conduct inspections of clubs, which officials said yesterday had shrunk from a dozen four-member teams of building and fire inspectors and police officers to two teams before Sunday's fire. 
 
Cooperating 'With Relish'
Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would propose new legislation, probably with some of the same elements, to toughen penalties for clubs found to have violated fire and safety laws. The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said that he would cooperate with the administration ''with relish'' and had scheduled a hearing for Thursday.
But last year, aides to Mr. Dinkins and to former Mayor Koch said, Councilman Jerry L. Crispino, who was then chairman of the Public Safety Committee and now head of the Land Use Committee, blocked the bill as too broad. Mr. Crispino acknowledged yesterday that he had believed the bill might hurt landlords, but he said it was not acted on because the Koch adminstration failed to resolve questions about it.
It is by no means clear that the proposed law could have prevented the fire at the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx that killed 87 people on Sunday. In that case, the city had already posted an order that it be vacated. Officials said yesterday that inspectors had visited it several times and found it closed.
 
Happy Land Didn't Even Try
The proposed law would have required owners of clubs closed for violations to post a bond of $10,000 or $10 per square foot, whichever was higher, before they could re-open as legal establishments. Happy Land apparently re-opened without making any efforts to become legal.
But Gabriel Taussig, chief of the administrative law division of the city's Law Department, said another provision of the bill would have allowed the city to seek a court order to lock and seal for up to a year any club with a vacate order pending against it. Even then, he said, ''it would have depended on us going to court.''
Mr. Crispino introduced the bill in November 1988, at the request of Mr. Koch, and held one hearing on it the following January. Aides to Mr. Koch said Mr. Crispino had expressed reluctance to act on the bill, and at a meeting in April with Robert Esnard, then the deputy mayor heading the social club task force, had said he would oppose it.
Yesterday, Mr. Crispino denied meeting with Koch aides on the bill. ''I never had a formal meeting with anybody in the administration on this legislation,'' he said.
 
Might Hurt Fishermen
Mr. Crispino, who as a lawyer has handled real estate transactions, said he worried that the bill could have been used against owners of small businesses or legitimate ''hunting or fishing clubs.'' Asked whether he thought it likely that such clubs would be the subject of vacate orders, which are issued for serious fire and safety violations, he said, ''They could possibly.''
Mr. Vallone said yesterday that the bill applied to ''everybody.''
But it applied only to places used for eating, drinking, dancing or entertainment, and its preamble said the Council intended the maximum penalties to apply only ''in the case of the most egregious and flagrant violations.''
Mr. Esnard said yesterday that the bill was to be an economic weapon. ''The people running these social clubs were not running church socials,'' he said. ''You had to take that economic benefit away.''
 
Little Pressure for Passage
Of the Council, Mr. Esnard said: ''They said they weren't going to pass it. They knew that I would have negotiated. They didn't want to negotiate. If they had wanted to do it, it would have gotten done.''
On the other hand, Mr. Koch acknowledged in an interview yesterday that he did not recall personally pressing Mr. Vallone or Mr. Crispino to get the bill passed.
Mr. Vallone said he believed the Council should consider legislation to cut off utility services to clubs operating with safety violations, and that he would not be opposed to a bill that required the posting of a bond, as long as it was narrowly drafted.
As for the inspection effort that Mr. Koch began, which made more than 2,000 inspections in 1989 and more than 300 so far this year, First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said they had dwindled because, ''I think there was a slackening of effort.''

SECTION: Section B; Page 4, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 636 words

HEADLINE: Cuomo May Be Blamed, But Ratings Aren't Votes

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 26

 BODY:
Republican leaders predicted today that they will be able to pin the downgrading of the state's credit rating on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo like a badge of fiscal dishonor. But Democratic officials and political consultants, both in New York and in Washington, said that credit ratings are too abstruse a subject to make for potent political symbolism.
Wall Street's two major rating agencies, Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service, both dropped New York's credit rating on short-term bonds today. Standard & Poor's took the unexpected step of lowering the rating on New York's long-term credit by two notches, from AA- to A, and said the state's budget impasse contributed to its decision. 
A lower rating translates into higher interest payments on the millions of dollars worth of bonds sold by the state each year.
''The Governor has been the chief executive of this state for the last seven and a half years so I think a lot of it rubs off on him,'' said J. Patrick Barrett, the state Republican Party chairman, who has been seeking a challenger to Mr. Cuomo for this year's gubernatorial race. ''It happened on his watch.''
 
Should Get Out of Albany
Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island borough president and a former Republican Congressman, said he does not think a credit-rating drop alone could cost Mr. Cuomo an election. But he said the image of a Governor who has prided himself on his fiscal management would be tarnished.
''He's got to take draconian measures so I think you'll see his popularity drop,'' he said.
Mr. Molinari suggested that if Mr. Cuomo has serious ambitions to run for President in 1992, he should consider leaving office this year rather than facing the fiscal demons that may haunt Albany for the next few.
The strong step taken by Standard & Poor's suggested that the rating agency had passed judgment on the state's fiscal condition even before the Governor and the Legislature settled on a way to close a projected $1.5 billion deficit in the 1990-91 budget. But Democratic officials said voters will judge Mr. Cuomo more on his ability to handle the fiscal crisis.
 
'Not In My Tax Bill'
''The average person is going to make a decision on how it affects him or her or the person around him rather than what rating agencies say,'' said John A. Marino, the state Democratic Party chairman.
Joseph F. Crangle, a member of the Democratic National Committee and a former chairman of the Erie County Democratic Committee, added: ''The average guy on the street doesn't understand it. It doesn't show up in his tax bill.''
Mr. Crangle also said Mr. Cuomo may find a silver lining in today's announcements because the news may pressure the Republicans who control the state Senate to adopt some of Mr. Cuomo's measures for closing the budget gap.
The Governor has proposed closing most of the deficit with new taxes and ''one-shot'' revenue measures, but Senate leaders have refused to consider many of his initiatives.
 
No Candidate in Offing
Any talk of political damage to Mr. Cuomo on the state level may be abstract since Mr. Barrett has been unable to find a gubernatorial opponent.
And some national political analysts said they doubted Mr. Cuomo's Presidential chances would be hurt unless he fails to cure the state's problems. New York is not Massachusetts, where a plummeting credit rating came to symbolize the decline of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, because Mr. Cuomo has not staked his political future solely on his fiscal prowess.
''Dukakis's problem was that he ran a Presidential campaign on the 'Massachusetts Miracle' and it turned out to be the 'Massachusetts Mirage,' '' said Alvin From, executive director of the Democratic Leadership Council. ''When you run as an economic genius and the bottom falls out, then you've got troubles.''

HEADLINE: Dire Regan Predictions Finally Gaining Respect

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan's dire warnings about New York State's finances, an annual rite in Albany, took on new urgency yesterday with the reduction of the state's credit rating.
Even before the drop in the rating, which will force the state to pay millions of dollars more in interest, Mr. Regan had been sounding his fiscal siren more loudly than usual.
He had threatened to refuse to certify the state budget for the new fiscal year, a move that would further alarm the financial community. Such certification is required for the state to borrow money. 
Mr. Regan, a Republican who rarely tangles with the Democratic Governor, has said he will not certify the budget unless it is ''demonstratively conservatively balanced'' - meaning it has conservative estimates of revenues and expenditures, requires no raids on the state pension funds and calls for tax increases only if they are accompanied by substantial spending reductions.
 
Budgetary Brinksmanship
The threat has opened a game of budgetary brinksmanship.
Many legislators and aides to Governor Cuomo said they expected Mr. Regan to back down in the final budget talks this weekend. The new fiscal year begins on Sunday.
But Mr. Regan said last week, ''Let's see who blinks first.''
Still, his aides concede that Mr. Regan, who faces a potentially difficult re-election campaign this year, is trying to walk a fine line between stopping state practices he considers profligate and alarming the financial community so much that it shuts down all credit -a budget disaster. If credit is cut off, the Governor might be able to blame him for all the state's problems.
''That what this game of chicken is all about,'' said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private group, ''If that happens, that's Armageddon.'' He said a credit shutdown would have ''an instant spillover to the city'' because the state pays much of the city budget.
 
Why He Certified Last Two
In calmer times, state officials often ignored Mr. Regan's audits and warnings. This year is different.
''I think he's perfectly serious and he's very justified,'' said Manfred Ohrenstein, the State Senate minority leader. ''We've run a deficit for two years.'' He also said Mr. Regan ''joined in the consensus'' by certifying the budgets.
Asked why Mr. Regan had certified the last two, his spokesman, Marvin Nailor, said the budgets ''became imbalanced after they were enacted because of the erosion of revenues.''
Mr. Regan said the state's budget problem ''is the worst crisis we've ever had, worse than the mid-70's'' when the State Urban Development Corporation threatened default on its bonds, shocking New York and other cities.
This year, the state faces at least $1.5 billion in deficits not only for the new fiscal year but for the current year. Republicans, like State Senator Roy M. Goodman of Manhattan, contend that the budget has been in the red in seven of the last nine years, with a cumulative deficit of at least $5 billion, despite a state constitutional requirement that the budget be balanced.
 
May Face Carol Bellamy
Mr. Regan, 59, is seeking a fourth term this year and his aides anticipate a strong challenge, possibly from Carol Bellamy, the former City Council President.
This time he could be hobbled by criticism of his campaign financing by the State Government Integrity Commission and an investigation of it by the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau.
He has also angered other Republicans by privately blaming State Senate Republicans as well as the Governor for the state's problems and by saying Nelson A. Rockefeller, a Republican Governor, was a bigger spender than Mr. Cuomo.
He has also argued that New York City, with its serious fiscal problems, ''is in better shape than New York State,'' largely because of restraints imposed on it by the State Financial Control Board.
Republicans hope to portray Mr. Cuomo as a liberal big spender and taxer in the gubernatorial campaign, adopting the image hung on a neighboring Democratic Governor, Michael Dukakis of Massachusettts, in the 1988 Presidential campaign.
 
Pork Barrel Campuses
In the meantime, Mr. Regan has been talking tough - even before yesterday's fiscal blow.
''You borrow and you pay back with one-shot revenues, that's what New York State has been doing for the last two and a half years,'' Mr. Regan said. ''The state has historically spent two and three times the rate of inflation, to the point that it has run out of all of its options.''
Tackling a sensitive subject, he described the State University system as ''pork barrel - a campus for every assembly district.'' There are 84 campuses in 51 cities.
He said he would not allow Governor Cuomo to raid the state pension system. ''He's not getting the money,'' he said.

HEADLINE: A Lower Betting Tax Could Help New York

 BODY:
Last Friday morning at a hearing room in downtown Manhattan, the chairmen of two New York State Assembly committees demanded to know why the operators of Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga did not have more money in the kitty at the end of last year.
It was as if a whale had drained a swimming pool in one gulp and then asked its owners where all the water went.
To say this is no slap at Ivan Lafayette, the Queens Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly's Standing Committee on Racing and Wagering, or Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat who chairs the Standing Committee on Oversight, Analysis and Investigation. Unlike most of their colleagues, these legislators have taken an active interest in New York racing, and that alone is cause to hope for improvement. 
But the biggest problem with racing in New York State is New York State.
Officials of the New York Racing Association, which operates the state's three major tracks, defended their finances Friday by taking the offensive. While much of their presentation was self-serving, the facts they presented were indisputable:
The 5.3 percent tax extracted by New York State from the parimutuel handle is badly out of line with other racing states. The state's share is only 1.9 percent in Pennsylvania, 0.9 percent in Maryland and 0.7 percent in New Jersey.
Nationwide, New York attracts 26.6 percent of all parimutuel betting, but pays 40.2 percent of all parimutuel taxes.
Over the last decade, New York on-track betting has declined 6.5 percent despite inflation, while operating expenses have increased by 20 percent. rrIs it any wonder that the N.Y.R.A., after handing over more than $42 million to the state last year, had nothing left over?
Despite the frequent characterization of New York racing as an industry in crisis, and the pining of old-timers for the good old days that never were, overall business has never been better. Purses are climbing steadily, and were nearly 50 percent higher at Aqueduct this winter than they were amid better weather, more soothing surroundings and classier horses at Gulfstream near Miami.
Betting is booming as well. The handle on Saturday's nine races at Aqueduct was $9.96 million. The same day, 11 Gulfstream races drew $2.61 million in bets.
The problem is that only $4.1 million of that $9.96 million in New York was bet at Aqueduct, with the rest being wagered at Offtrack Betting and simulcast outlets. The N.Y.R.A. retains 9.3 cents of every dollar wagered on track for its operations, but only 1.9 to 2.5 cents of every dollar wagered at OTB. In 1981, 47 percent of the statewide handle was bet at the track. Last year, only 37 percent was.
OTB hurts rather than helps New York racing because of its inane structure. A generation ago, misguided N.Y.R.A. executives turned down the chance to operate OTB as an arm of the tracks, and the sport has paid for it ever since.
Legislators created six redundant regional OTB corporations whose primary function has been to drain money from the sport in order to support a bureaucracy. New York OTB has become a nationwide laughing stock and model of what not to do. Every other state has linked OTB with the tracks. rrThe N.Y.R.A. argues that it supplies a product, and that OTB should be the marketing arm for that product rather than a competitor. At the same time, the N.Y.R.A. has got to do a much better job of marketing its own product.
While many of the N.Y.R.A.'s problems stem from lack of funds, it has failed in a more basic way. With the exception of the 24-day Saratoga phenomenon, the N.Y.R.A. has not made going to the races a sufficiently attractive proposition to stem the departure of patrons to OTB shops or other forms of amusement. A new paint job every few years and new flavors of fast food are not enough. The game needs truly new ideas and promotions to attract new players.
It also needs relief to keep the old ones. The parimutuel takeout of 17 to 25 percent, coupled with punitive Federal and state withholding taxes on bettors' gross proceeds rather than their net profits, have made winning more difficult and losing more expensive than ever.
Every experiment and study in reducing takeout and taxes has shown that business will increase in the long run. Legislators, however, are always unwilling to sacrifice any short-term revenue.
The same is true with reducing the state's piece of the action. The resurgence of Maryland racing was due in part to the late Frank DeFrancis's superior management, but he never would have had the chance had the state not reduced its cut to 0.9 percent of the handle. That freed up operating money so that he could improve the facilities, install attractive high-tech handicapping aids and make Laurel and Pimlico places where people wanted to spend an afternoon.
The N.Y.R.A. could be doing a better job with its current resources, and it probably does deserve closer outside scrutiny than it has gotten in the past. Its shortcomings, though, pale next to the state's taxation rate and the current structure of OTB. The legislators only need to turn the mirror on themselves to find the game's most serious problems, and the solution to them.

HEADLINE: Patient's Marrow Emerges as Key Cancer Tool

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
DOCTORS have long suspected that colossal doses of chemotherapy and radiation could triumph over a number of otherwise fatal cancers. The only hitch was that doses large enough to overcome the tumor frequently killed the patient as well, generally by destroying the bone marrow, the body's crucial factory for making cells for the blood and immune system.
Now cancer specialists are sidestepping that problem using a dangerous but ingenious technique: they remove and treat some of the patient's own marrow, give the patient previously unthinkable doses of chemotherapy and radiation and then return the purged marrow to the patient, where it gradually resumes its vital function.
Although such autologous bone marrow transplants were first used experimentally over a decade ago as heroic treatments for hopeless cases, researchers have only recently accumulated enough data to prove definitively that they work. Some of the initial patients have long outlived the time they were expected to survive with their fatal diseases. And, although the risk of dying in the procedure is still 5 to 15 percent, autologous transplants have taken off. 
Further, experts say the recent isolation and production of several naturally occurring molecules called growth factors, which dramatically hasten the recovery of a transplanted marrow, promise to make the procedure safer and cheaper.
''These transplants have moved from the world of evangelical religion to the world of science,'' said Dr. Peter H. Wiernik, the chairman of the Department of Oncology at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. ''We are just now at the point where we can look people in the eye and say this is the treatment for your disease.''
Based on these impressive results, autologous transplant has become the treatment of choice for certain tumors of the immune system, or lymphomas, and a few tumors of the blood, or leukemias, with cure rates of over 50 percent. Researchers hope the technique might eventually help save many patients with widespread breast cancer, ovarian cancer and melanoma as well.
''We are about to see an exponential rise in the number of autologous transplants,'' said Dr. Richard O'Reilly, the head of the bone marrow transplant program at Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York. ''Particularly as we find new diseases that respond to the technique.'' An estimated 2,000 autologous transplants were performed in 1989, about double the number two years before.
Since autologous transplants require over a month in the hospital and cost over $75,000, insurers and health care economists look to this boom with some apprehension. Because most uses of the treatment are still in the experimental stage, insurance companies may refuse to pay. And while the procedure is not technically demanding, few hospitals can accommodate more than a handful of marrow transplant patients at one time.
Also, experts caution that for patients the month without functioning bone marrow, called the nadir period, is a harrowing, painful ordeal with almost daily bouts of fevers from infection and sometimes bleeding. These ensue because the bone marrow, about a quart of which is usually taken from the patient, makes red cells to carry oxygen, white cells to fight disease and platelets to promote clotting.
Heart, lung and kidney tests before a transplant disqualify many patients as not healthy enough to survive the ordeal.
''It was the worst experience of a lifetime,'' said Donna Rossi, 37 years old, of New Jersey, who had an experimental autologous transplant in 1983 for lymphoma, then generally considered incurable. ''During the transplant you're at such a low point that you can't see the light at the end of the tunnel. I gave up a year of my life, because nothing else held out hope of a cure.''
 
Not a Traditional Transplant
The new procedures are different than true transplants when a patient's diseased marrow is destroyed and then replaced with marrow from a donor who must be genetically matched to prevent rejection of the foreign tissue. These transplants were initially developed to treat patients with inherently defective marrows, although they have since been use successfully on cancer patients as well.
Only 30 to 40 percent of patients waiting for conventional transplants find compatible donors. The procedure is generally considered too risky for patients older than 30 because of a devastating reaction in which the immune cells of the donated marrow attack the host and which becomes more deadly with age. But autologous transplants are performed on people into the 60's.
When the autologous method is used to treat patients whose cancers, like leukemia, involve the marrow, before the marrow is reinfused it must be cleansed in a laboratory.
Since the autologous transplants theoretically can be applied to any tumor for which more chemotherapy is considered better, ''the question everyone is asking is: who can benefit?'' said Dr. Jerome Ritz, associate professor of medicine at Harvard University's Dana-Farber Cancer Center. Patients with advanced metastatic breast and ovarian cancer have already shown dramatic responses.
''The next bastion for autologous transplants is breast cancer,'' said Dr. Hillard Lazarus, director of the bone marrow transplant program at Case Western Reserve University's Ireland Cancer Center. ''The technique is still investigational, but the results are pretty compelling.'' Although metastatic breast cancer is generally first treated with surgery and chemotherapy, over 50 percent of women will relapse and the recurrent disease is uniformly fatal.
In one study of women with breast cancer that had spread to the bones or lungs, as well as the bone marrow, 60 percent showed no sign of disease after an autologous transplant and a fraction have already survived more than five years. In another of study of 14 women with relapsed ovarian cancer, more than a third were alive and free of disease more than three years after the transplant.
Buoyed by these successes, a number of research teams are now studying the use of autologous transplants to treat some early cancers that are likely to be incurable with traditional therapy.
 
Use for Earlier Cancers
''There is now lots of data to indicate that the earlier and more aggressively you treat these tumors, the better the chance for cure,'' said Dr. C. Dean Buckner, director of the autologous bone marrow transplant program at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center of the University of Washington in Seattle.
Although the basic autologous transplant is now fairly standardized, scientists are experimenting with modifications which promise to improve the technique.
At the University of Nebraska, Dr. James Armitage and his colleagues are stockpiling bone marrow cells collected from patients' bloodstreams and using it in autologous transplants. Scientists have long known that a small number of bone marrow, or progenitor, cells circulate, but the technology to filter out the vagrants has been developed only in the last few years, Dr. Armitage said. Scientists say these so-called peripheral progenitors mature more quickly into functioning red and white blood cells than cells harvested from within bone, leading to faster recovery after the transplant.
 
Growth Factors Hold Promise
But the biggest boon to the transplant world seems most likely to come from a class of naturally occurring molecules, called growth factors, which were isolated in the mid-1980's and can now be produced in large quantities using recombinant DNA technology. ''Growth factors have been the major advance in the last couple of years,'' said Dr. Buckner.
The compounds, more than a dozen of which have been identified, speed the development of the undifferentiated marrow cells into working red cells, whites cells and platelets. A growth factor for red cells, called erythropoietin, and several for white cells, including granulocyte macrophage colony stimulating factor, are currently available for investigational use.
Several centers around the country are now giving patients white cell growth factors at the time of transplant in the hopes of speeding the return of immune function. Patients whose blood contains low levels of white cells are vulnerable to life threatening infections.
Transplant patients generally spend three weeks in isolation with perilously low counts. They usually fall ill with infections anyway, stricken by the bacteria that inhabit their own skins and intestines.
When transplant patients have been treated with growth factors in clinical trials, their marrows have rebounded more quickly and effectively. White cell growth factors proved capable of shortening the nadir period to about 10 days, reducing the number of infections by half and hastening discharges by two weeks or more.
Experts say they hope to utilize combinations of growth factors and the quickly developing peripheral blood progenitor cells to further shorten the nadir period and, maybe, to eradicate it altogether.
In a field ringing with scientific optimism, the most troubling issues involve money and logistics. Most insurers, including Medicaid and Medicare, will now pay for the procedure for lymphomas and some leukemias. But what if transplant proves the treatment of choice for all women with newly diagnosed metastatic breast or ovarian cancer, for example? Tens of thousands of women fall into these categories each year. The largest transplant center in the United States, the Hutchinson Center at the University of Washington, performs 400 transplants annually; only 4 or 5 of those can be covered by grant funds. ''Who will pay?'' said Dr. Buckner. ''Who will fill the gap?''
Experts say that if growth factors prove successful they may ameliorate the problem. ''If you can keep people out of the hospital and decrease the number of infections and transfusions, that will lower costs,'' said Dr. Lazarus. ''Hospital charges run $1,000 a day and $5,000 a day in the intensive care unit.
If growth factors reduce the costs, some of the savings will be spent on the growth factors themselves, but even so, studies indicate that for properly selected patients the big investment is cost effective in the long run, especially for patients treated early in their disease, said Dr. Buckner. ''If you transplant a patient early and cure his disease, it's much cheaper than multiple hospital admissions and 10 rounds of chemotherapy spread over years,'' he said. ''You may also save his life.''
 
BEFORE HOSPITALIZATION
Storing the marrow
Some bone marrow is harvested from the breast bone and pelvis through hollow needles, treated if necessary, and refrigerated. Then the patient is hospitalized for the cancer treatment.
 
TREATMENT
High-dose radiation and chemotherapy
During treatment, marrow dies. The patient loses red blood cells, which carry oxygen; white cells, which fight infection, and platelets needed for clotting. Even with isolation and frequent transfusions, side effects are severe.
 
REPLACEMENT
Replenishing marrow
Re-injected into the bloodstream, marrow migrates to the bone and starts making cells again. Growth factor infusions may shorten the time needed to resume production of white blood cells. In clinical trials, injecting marrow progenitor cells filtered from the patient's blood makes the recovery period even shorter.

HEADLINE: Coral Reefs Off 20 Countries Face Assaults From Man and Nature

 BODY:
CORAL reefs off the coasts of more than 20 countries are suffering from increasingly severe human and natural assaults, new research shows.
Overfishing, coral harvesting and vessel groundings, widespread pollution caused by chemicals, sewage and deforestation, and such natural phenonomena as sharp swings in water temperature have threatened the corals, scientists say.
The problem affects the coasts of Australia, China, Japan, Panama, Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, India, Indonesia and Kenya, as well as the Red Sea and many reefs in the Caribbean and the Atlantic.
Off the Florida coast, more than 100 square miles of the only barrier reef in North America are being threatened by toxic pollutants and vessel groundings. In the last few months, groundings in the Florida Keys have caused $20 million in damage and pulverized thousands of square feet of coral, according to the Center for Marine Conservation in Washington. In many cases, the damage has been irreparable. 
In the South China Sea, widespread coral harvesting for aquariums has wiped out all but 20 of 110 coral species recorded in 1960, according to a United Nations report, ''Human Induced Damage to Coral Reefs.'' In Indonesia, blasting of coral and fishing with traps has damaged corals. In Bali and the Maldives, coral mining, spear-fishing, dredging and pollution are killing corals.
''Virtually every reef system in the world is suffering,'' said John Ogden, director of the Florida Institute of Oceanography, a consortium of nine Florida universities studying the problem. ''We have reached the point where coral reefs are being turned into wastelands.''
 
Tiny Tentacled Animals
The tropical reefs are the handiwork of minute, tentacled coral animals. They range in size from a half an inch to eight inches and live in large, tightly knit colonies, attached permanently to the limestone skeleton that the colony builds as it grows.
For reef-reliant economies, the continued loss of corals could be devastating. Living coral reefs form the basis of a delicate ecosystem that shelters thousands of marine organisms, including fish, crabs and other seafood. Their loss would be most severely felt in underdeveloped nations because coral reefs are a crucial source of food and provide jobs for thousands of fishermen.
Brian Lapointe of the Florida Keys Land and Sea Trust estimated that 30 percent of all coral cover in the Keys has been lost since 1970.
In one study, James W. Porter, a zoologist at the University of Georgia, and fellow researchers have documented the disappearance of 8 percent of corals on several large reefs in only a two-year period. Dr. Porter, who used time-lapse photography in the study, said he was worried that the loss would continue. ''We saw a significant loss of coral,'' he said. ''But the exact cause seem to be elusive.''
''It's a very complicated problem which has many causes,'' said Jeremy B. C. Jackson, chief scientist at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama. ''Some would like to say it's because of human activity, but there's also a natural component.''
 
Nature Joins in Conspiracy
Hurricanes, radical swings in water temperature and El Ninos, the warm ocean currents that periodically cause climate disturbances, are among the natural causes.
On many reefs the shortage of fish as a result of overharvesting and the loss of coral-protecting sea urchins has stripped away two major natural protections of corals. In many places the urchins have been replaced by a venomous, coral-eating starfish known as the Crown of Thorns.
The Crown of Thorns is abundant in a dozen countries, including Japan, where teams of divers working together are injecting them with lethal poison and putting up underwater fences to halt their migration.
Since 1987, Caribbean corals have suffered from widespread bleaching, a blight that impairs or kills corals. Scientists blame rising water temperatures, which sensitive corals cannot withstand. The bleaching occurs when the algae that coral organisms depend on die. Because the algae give corals their coloration, their death causes the reef to turn ghostly pale.
 
Oil Spills and Chemicals
Scientists say that the human impact on reefs, such as freighter groundings, oil spills and chemical pollution are now the main threat to coral survival.
In an ecological study on spills in tropical waters, Dr. Jackson reported last year that such damage to coral is not only immediate and severe but can leave them susceptible to disease and blight for years.
Scientists say reef-killing algae can proliferate as a result of human pollution. This occurs when groundwater and streams carry nutrients from treated sewage and agricultural chemicals from crops and golf courses into the ocean. The nutrients travel miles offshore to pristine reefs where they fertilize the algae. The algae outcompete corals for living space, effectively killing them.
But scientists say the most long-term damage occurs when stands of coral are leveled by freighters or knocked down by objects like boat anchors. They say the branching elkhorn coral, which take 400 years to grow and are the most common of 1,000 coral species, can take up to 50 years to grow back.
 
Concern in Congress
Some Federal lawmakers have voiced concern about what is happening. Last fall Congress ordered the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to study three Florida sites for inclusion in the National Marine Sanctuary Program.
Then within three weeks, four major vessel groundings in the Keys flattened thousands of square feet of coral and prompted further Congressional action. Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, introduced a bill to create a Florida Keys Marine Sanctuary that would extend 122 miles from the coast of Key Largo to the Dry Tortugas near Key West out to the 300-foot depth. If passed, the law would give teeth to current enforcement, allotting additional Federal funds for more enforcement agents and mooring buoys.
A Senate bill introduced on March 7 by Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, would make most marine sanctuaries off-limits to freighter traffic. The Coast Guard, meanwhile, has been holding hearings on a proposal to ask the International Maritime Organization to create ''areas to be avoided'' by international freighters off the Florida coast.
In less developed countries, corals have suffered decades of abuse directly related to slash-and-burn deforestation, which consumes thousands of acres of trees each year. Heavy nutrient runoff from clear-cutting has led to sediment-filled waters, which spur algae growth and choke corals. ''The Caribbean reefs seem to be in an advance state of decline,'' Mr. Lapointe said.
 
Aiding Third World Countries
In an effort to halt the decline of coral reefs in the third world, the Bush Administration has drafted guidelines for the United States representative to the World Bank to follow in considering the financing of projects that might adversely affect rain forests and coral reefs.
Scientists are urging that Federal and state governments continue to reorganize their environmental priorities toward coastal resources, imposing tougher penalties on freighters that run aground, imposing bans on some agricultural chemicals and installing mooring buoys along reefs.
They warn that unless further steps are taken, corals could become endangered within decades. ''We still don't know if we're dealing with long-term variations,'' said Mr. Ogden of the oceanography institute. ''There are natural cycles we know little about.''

HEADLINE: Multi-Use Credit Card Is Offered by A.T.&T.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday introduced a combination telephone-calling card and general-purpose credit card affiliated with Visa and Mastercard International.
In doing so, A.T.& T. decided not to issue a card on its own, as did Sears, Roebuck & Company when it introduced the Discover card in 1986. Although the Discover card has posted small profits in the last two years, it has not yet reached the targets set for it by Sears.
The new cards bear A.T.& T.'s name and corporate logotype but will be issued by the Universal Bank of Columbus, Ga., and will be called the A.T.& T. Universal card. The card is a so-called affinity card, which carries the name of a company or organization that helps promote its use in return for a share of the profits earned by the issuing bank. The banks say such cards offer new marketing niches in an industry that is quite profitable, but which analysts say is approaching the saturation point. 
Banks already issue similar cards on behalf of many airlines, university alumni associations, professional athletic teams, charitable groups and other organizations.
A.T.& T. officials said the company was sponsoring the card to strengthen its position in the long-distance telephone market and to meet a perceived desire among consumers to carry fewer credit cards. The U S Sprint Communications Company, a rival of A.T.& T.'s in the long-distance market, started offering a combination calling card and Visa credit card last November. Another rival, the MCI Communications Corporation, reached agreements in the last few months with a dozen banks to allow the billing of long-distance MCI calls to Visa accounts at these banks.
A.T.& T. attached a variety of services to the new card to make it competitive with so-called gold credit cards.
Those who apply for the card this year will pay no annual fee if they use the card for at least one purchase a year.
Customers who charge telephone calls to the A.T.& T. Universal card will receive a 10 percent discount off regular calling-card rates.
Charges for long-distance calls will appear on the same bill as regular purchases, but must be paid in full each month.
The card includes free collision-damage insurance coverage on rental cars paid for with the card and a free extension of the manufacturer's warranty on products purchased with the card.
 
Adjustable Interest Rate
The card's intitial annual interest rate will be 18.9 percent, which was higher than most analysts had expected. The interest rate is equal to the prime rate plus 8.9 percentage points, and will be adjusted automatically every three months.
Most of the 70 million American households that have A.T.& T. long-distance service will be offered the card, said Paul Kahn, the president of A.T.& T.'s new credit card division. The first applications have already been sent out, he said.
A three-year research program by A.T.& T. found that consumers were abandoning single-purpose oil company and department store cards in favor of general purpose cards, and this also gave A.T.& T. an incentive to replace some of its 40 million calling cards, Mr. Kahn said. ''More and more people don't want their wallets bulging with cards,'' he said.
A.T.& T. intends for the Universal card to replace existing Visa and Mastercard credit cards issued by other banks, Mr. Kahn said.
 
Partners in Venture
A.T.& T.'s partners for the new card are the Synovus Financial Corporation, the Columbus, Ga., holding company that recently set up the Universal Bank to handle the new card, and Total Systems Services Inc., a large credit-card processing services company that will keep track of billing for the Universal card.
A.T.& T. will share in the revenues from the Universal card. Mr. Kahn and James H. Blanchard, the chairman of Synovus, declined to discuss the details on the arrangement.
In addition, A.T.& T. received the right to buy an 8.6 percent stake in Total Systems. Synovus owns 82 percent of Total Systems.
A.T.& T. had considered creating its own card, but its market research found that customers wanted a card that was already widely accepted, Mr. Kahn said. Visa and Mastercard are accepted at seven million locations worldwide.
The Universal card's high interest rate reflects a belief among A.T.& T. officials that the company's well-known name and other features offered would attract enough customers to make a lower rate unnecessary, said Gregory R. Sawers, a securities analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York.
He estimated that the card would cost A.T.& T. from $100 million to $150 million for the next two or three years, and that the new card would attract five million customers in each of its first two years.
Depending on creditworthiness, customers will be offered a regular or gold Universal card affiliated with Visa or a regular Universal card affiliated with Mastercard.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The savings industry had its worst year ever in 1989, with losses soaring to $19.2 billion, regulators said. Although a record loss had been expected, the amount surprised experts. Indeed, losses from operations for 485 troubled institutions amounted to $2.6 billion in the fourth quarter, equivalent to a taxpayer loss of $29 million a day as long as the institutions stayed open in that period. [Page A1.]
 
Federal examiners are suggesting that problems with real estate loans are far more serious than bankers have admitted. The examiners are recommending sharp increases in the reserves set aside to cover bad loans. News analysis. [D1.] 
 
Japan has given President Bush a few ideas about how the U.S. economy could be tightened up, including limits on how many credit cards Americans carry. [D1.]
 
Janney Montgomery Scott dismissed an analyst who refused to retract comments about the prospects of Donald Trump's Taj Mahal casino. Many analysts expressed concern at the action. [D2.]
 
Harvard's second-highest administrator was named the next dean of the Stanford University Graduate School of Business. [D5.]
 
MARKETS
 
Gold prices plunged in near-panic selling on reports of unexpectedly large sales by Middle Eastern interests. Statisticians at the Comex in New York said the decline, of more than $23 an ounce, was the biggest one-day drop since Feb. 28, 1983. European news reports attributed the bulk of the selling to the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority, which was said to have used much of the proceeds to buy British pounds. [D1.] The dollar retreated against the pound, but rose against the yen. [D24.]
 
Standard & Poor's lowered New York State's credit rating by two notches, leaving it with the nation's third-lowest rating. Officials said the downgrading would raise interest payments by tens of millions of dollars. [A1.] S.&P. downgraded ratings for about $2.9 billion in Bankers Trust New York Corporation securities. [D22.]
 
The Dow Jones industrials eked out a gain of 3.38 points, to close at 2,707.66. It was the second-slowest trading day of the year. [D12.]
 
The N.A.S.D. reported a 6.1 percent rise in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities. [D21.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities moved modestly higher in listless trading, pushed up by continued strength in the dollar. [D22.]
 
COMPANIES
 
A.T.&T. entered the credit card business with a combination telephone-calling card and general-purpose credit card affiliated with Visa and Mastercard International. [D1.]
 
The auto industry is watching a dispute between Mazda and the United Automobile Workers over temporary employees. [D1.]
 
Avon agreed to include two Chartwell directors on its board, ending the threat of a proxy fight by the investor group. [D1.]
 
Gillette and the Justice Department announced an agreement to settle an antitrust lawsuit challenging Gillette's purchase of a large portion of Wilkinson Sword. The accord would bar Gillette from buying Wilkinson's U.S. operations. [D5.]
 
The Administration is considering legal action against Occidental and Mobay because they refused to sell to the Army an ingredient needed to make poison gas, Pentagon officials say. [A24.]
 
The Netherlands' two largest commercial banks are discussing a merger aimed at creating the world's 20th-largest bank. [D5.]

Insurers in several states are testing new types of coverage for at least some of the 31 million Americans who lack health insurance. Business and Health. [D2.]
 
Nordstrom's fame and profits soared in the 1980's, but the specialty-apparel retailer is suffering from some unusual setbacks that began as the decade drew to a close. Market Place. [D12.]
 
American Health's founder says the magazine's sale was a bellwether event in publishing, signaling the end of a go-go time built on huge debts. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D25.]

HEADLINE: U.A.W. Faces Test at Mazda Plant

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLAT ROCK, Mich.

 BODY:
The auto industry is closely watching a dispute between the Mazda Motor Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union over the use of temporary employees.
When Mazda came to this community just south of Detroit to build cars three years ago, it agreed to recognize the U.A.W. and promised not to lay off regular hourly workers except as a last resort. And the Japanese car maker has so far kept its promise despite the weak auto market, which has forced production slowdowns at the plant.
But there's a catch. Local U.A.W. officials complain that Mazda has been able to stand by its no-layoff pledge by jettisoning scores of temporary assembly-line employees, who work side by side with regular hourly workers and pay union dues but lack the job security. 
Although they are paid the same hourly wage as regular workers, the temporaries at Mazda have a limited health-care and disability package, no access to unemployment benefits financed by the company and the union, and no guarantee that they will be hired back first when production picks up again - provisions enjoyed by regular workers in the industry.
While the union agreed to accept some temporary workers at the plant here in a three-year contract signed in 1988, it is now putting pressure on the company to cut back on the hiring of such employees, which is common in Japan. Union officials accuse the company of using temporary workers in far greater numbers and for longer periods than the contract stipulates, which company officials deny.
Other auto companies are watching to see whether Mazda can keep the union at bay. Executives for the Big Three view Mazda's use of temporaries as a competitive edge, enabling the Japanese car maker to keep its costs lower and lay off workers with impunity.
With job security likely to become the central issue in national bargaining talks scheduled before contracts expire in September, analysts say the American auto companies may seek to exploit the situation at Mazda, by pressing for expanded use of temporary workers in their own plants.
''Anything that gives a cost advantage to a competitor needs to be examined in contract negotiations,'' said a labor relations executive at one of the American car makers.
The cutbacks in Mazda's temporary work force also foreshadow a major problem facing the U.A.W. in the coming contract negotiations, said Harry Katz, professor of labor and industrial relations at Cornell University.
''The U.A.W. would like to have it both ways: employment security and no temporaries,'' Mr. Katz said. ''But that is not the way the world works. The union must live with the consequences if they demand tighter job security.''
The consequences of such demands will be a separation of auto workers into two groups, Mr. Katz predicted, one with guaranteed jobs and the other with no employment guarantees and leaner benefits.
 
A Violation of Principles
Allowing two classes of workers goes against longstanding U.A.W. principles aimed at creating union solidarity and protecting jobs. When the General Motors Corporation sought a two-tier wage structure at its components plants in 1987, the union was bitterly opposed.
''It creates a lot of political problems within the union to make these explicit distinctions,'' he said. ''A burning question for the U.A.W. is how far it should head down this road.''
Solving its problem with Mazda would help the U.A.W. prove it can find common ground with the Japanese auto makers. So far, the union has been able to organize only those Japanese plants engaged in partnerships with unionized domestic auto makers, like Mazda's Flat Rock plant, which makes Probes for the Ford Motor Company, and New United Motor Manufacturing Inc., the joint venture of the Toyota Motor Corporation and General Motors. The union has not had success in organizing the Honda Motor Company plant in Marysville, Ohio, or the Nissan Motor Corporation plant in Smyrna, Tenn.
 
Abuse of Provision Seen
While the U.A.W. did agree in its contract to allow temporary workers to fill assembly-line jobs, local union officials say the company has abused the provision.
''When the original contract was negotiated, the assumption was that these would be primarily people to fill in as casual replacements, when people got sick or were on vacation, not that they would be used by the hundreds for six, eight or twelve months,'' said Phillip Keeling, president of U.A.W. Local 3000.
Although the temporary workers are dues-paying union members, officials at the U.A.W. local said they were unable to provide firm figures on the number in the plant before and after the production slowdown. One union official estimated that the number had fallen to fewer than 100 from a peak of 400; the plant has 2,900 regular hourly workers. None of the temporary workers remaining on the job perform assembly-line tasks, the offical said.
The union leaders say the second-class status of Mazda's temporary employees represents the dark side of Japanese employment practices, exported to Flat Rock along with a workplace philosophy of teamwork and mutual sacrifice in hard times.
 
'Throwaway People'
''It don't give us much of a life, working on the edge as a temporary employee,'' said a 24-year-old worker who was afraid that using his name would hurt his chances of being hired as a regular. ''They think of us as throwaway people.''
Mazda officials say they have abided by the contract, which allows temporary workers to fill in for absent regular employees. Masahiro Uchida, president of the Mazda Motor Manufacturing (USA) Corporation, said the company uses temporary workers ''to keep our regular hourly employees in the plant, to avoid laying them off.'' He added, ''In our discussions with the union, we never said we would use a certain number of temporary workers.''
Some local union officials at the Mazda plant criticize the international union for negotiating away the job security of temporary workers in their eagerness to plant the U.A.W. flag in a Japanese plant.
The Big Three have for several years used small numbers of temporary hourly employees with the union's blessing on Mondays and Fridays, when assembly-line absenteeism is high. Mazda insisted on the same provision.
The U.A.W. has tried to contain the practice at Mazda by pushing it to hire more temporary workers as regular employees.
 
'They Lay You Off'
But the company is dragging its feet, union officials say. ''They lay you off before you can get your 90 days in,'' one temporary worker said, referring to the contract provision granting regular hourly status to temporary workers after 90 days of continuous work. ''It happened to me twice.''
All of the ''transplants,'' as Japanese auto manufacturers in the United States are called, hire contract laborers, or temporary workers, to perform housekeeping chores; Mazda and Toyota are the only Japanese auto makers in the United States that use them for production jobs.
Mazda has also responded to the auto industry slowdown by eliminating overtime, combining some jobs and shuffling regular hourly workers into new roles.
Mazda has slowed production of the two-door sports coupes and sedans made in Flat Rock, and ''rebalanced'' workers' duties instead of shutting down its assembly line for a week or two and instituting layoffs - which is the standard approach of the Big Three to bloated inventories.
Because the assembly line is running more slowly, each ''team'' of half a dozen or so workers is expected to accomplish its assigned tasks with fewer people. The pool of hourly employees freed as a result serve as quality inspectors, undergo additional training or help plan the introduction later this year of Mazda's new 626 model.
So far, only 70 of the plant's 2,900 hourly workers have been reassigned.
 
'There Was Some Confusion'
Mazda executives acknowledge that the quality of cars coming off the assembly line has deteriorated during the reassignments. ''Many people were not accustomed to their new job, and there was some confusion,'' Mr. Uchida said.
If quality has suffered, the loyalty of many regular employees appears to have soared as a result of Mazda's effort to keep its core work force employed during the downturn, interviews with plant workers show.
''So far, Mazda has lived up to their promise of not laying people off,'' said Derek Greer, 22, a regular hourly worker who was reassigned when the line slowed down. ''All the extra training we've been getting is useful. We're no use to Mazda out in the street.''
But the recent reduction of temporary workers has strained already fragile relations between the union and Mazda, which was only the second Japanese manufacturer to welcome the U.A.W.
Three years after the opening embrace, Mazda has been stung by absenteeism of 10 percent, unusually high for a Japanese transplant, where the figure is normally less than 5 percent. At Honda, it is below 2 percent.

HEADLINE: Japan to U.S.: Tighten Up. U.S. to Japan: Loosen Up.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 26

 BODY:
Japan has a few ideas how President Bush can move quickly to tighten up the American economy. To start with, he should strictly limit every American to just a couple of credit cards. Then he should build a network of bullet trains across America, impose a stiff gasoline tax and get rid of low-interest car loans, all to get gas-guzzlers off the road. And he should ban the tax write-off for many types of home mortgages because it subsidizes consumption, not savings.
That is a sampling of 80 very concrete ideas that the Japanese Government presented the Bush Administration several weeks ago, part of the broad critiques that Japan and the United States are making of each other's economies. The list was leaked to the Japanese newspapers over the weekend and confirmed by officials on both sides today. 
''Is this a recipe for political suicide?'' a senior Japanese official said after he was asked whether Japan actually expected the President - or other American politicians - to embrace reforms that would likely cost most American voters thousands of dollars. ''Maybe it is. But you should see America's ideas for Japan.''
There are 240 of those - the Japanese press termed them demands when they leaked late last week - including a suggestion that the leaders of Japan's biggest and most secretive business conglomerates make public the minutes of their monthly meetings. The Japanese business community has scarcely rushed to voice its support of the idea.
For months, both countries have broadly criticized each other's economies. But the two recently exchanged lists make up the most specific plans either side has ever put together to close Japan's trade surpluses and open the country's markets, or to end America's budget deficits and restore United States industrial competitiveness.
From the start, both sides say, the plan was to put together the best suggestions they could come up with, paying no heed to political realities on either side. ''We don't expect every suggestion to be adopted,'' said a senior official of the American Embassy here, ''and neither do they.''
The result is what Makoto Kuroda, a former high official of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, calls ''a bunch of very crazy ideas.''
 
Giving as Well as Getting
''But as long as you gave us your crazy ideas,'' Mr. Kuroda told an American tonight, ''we thought we would give you a few of ours.''
Some Japanese suggestions are familiar to anyone who has followed the often-repetitive trade dialogue of the countries. For example, the Japanese said American companies should report earnings, and pay dividends, only twice a year, rather than quarterly. That is the system Japan uses, and the proposal grows from the ritual argument here that American companies are too shortsighted.
Some American ideas are also familiar. A draft of the United States' proposals calls for raising Japan's public spending to about 10 percent of gross national product from the current 6 percent. It wants to ''abolish the distinction between areas for urban development'' and areas where such development is regulated, like farmlands. It calls for a repeal of the law that makes it difficult to establish large department stores, American or Japanese, anywhere it might hurt small shops.
It is Japan's ideas, however, that have attracted much of the curiosity here. The ideas were presented to Washington a few weeks after American negotiators dropped off their list.
 
On 'Junk Bonds'
Japan suggests legislation or regulations against ''junk bonds,'' the high-yield, high-risk debt financing tactic that has brought down several companies.
In the past, Japan has made only general criticisms about the American educational system, saying that it has to work harder to produce an educated, highly skilled work force. In the documents made public over the weekend, Japan suggested that business school curriculums should stress corporate management and manufacturing and educate students in the Japanese language and ''Japanese business customs.''
The proposed limit on the number of credit cards that consumers could hold appears to be a new idea, but one that stems from talks over how to raise the United States savings rate, which is several times below Japan's. Japan is still largely a cash society, and officials here say they have a hard time understanding why Americans would fill a wallet with plastic.
Japanese officials say that despite Mr. Bush's commitment to stop any tax increases, Japan suggested several - including a Federal value-added tax and the gas tax. The Japanese know about high gas taxes: It often costs $35 to fill the tank of a compact car. Japan's solution is to build bullet trains, a mode of transport that works wonderfully along the narrow, jam-packed Japanese coast but seems ill suited for much of the United States. It may also be unsuited for closing the trade deficit: Bullet trains are made in Japan and Europe, but not in the United States.
