HEADLINE: Quicksand For Banks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Bankers knew their problems with real estate loans were mounting, but Federal examiners now suggest that the problems are far more serious than the bankers have admitted.
At bank after bank, groups made up of 150 or more examiners are sifting through records on construction and commercial real estate loans. In most cases, the result has been a recommendation for a sharp increase in the reserves that banks set aside to cover bad loans. And those increased reserves cut into profits, making bankers more wary about making new real estate loans. 
Last week, large losses from real estate lending led the Shawmut National Corporation in Hartford to announce a $128.9 million loss for 1989 and the Southeast Banking Corporation in Miami to announce a first-quarter loss of $53 million to $57 million. A week earlier, Barnett Banks Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla., and the Hibernia Corporation of New Orleans announced real estate losses after visits from examiners.
 
'Credit Crunch' Seen
Indeed, some real estate experts assert that the tougher examinations are aggravating the downturn in real estate prices by causing bankers to cut off the supply of credit for new projects, even those that are creditworthy. Charles Cranmer, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton, said a general cutback in lending was already noticeable. If continued, he warned, it ''could mean slower economic growth - in effect, a credit crunch induced by regulatory pressures.''
And Andrew J. Singer, president of Ackman Brothers & Singer, a specialist in arranging financing for commercial real estate projects, said, ''Bankers who committed themselves to lend a year or so ago are now finding ways to not go through with the commitment, because they know it would automatically result in a loan that runs afoul of the new policies.''
 
Loans Continue to Rise
So far evidence of a squeeze on credit for business borrowers is scanty. A Federal Reserve survey of bankers taken early this year showed that the bankers said they were becoming more cautious, but other Fed data show that both real estate loans and business loans have continued to increase this year among large banks that report data weekly.
Karen J. Wilson, deputy comptroller at the Northeastern district office, disputed the suggestion that examiners were causing credit to be curbed. In markets with office vacancy rates of 20 and 30 percent, and with many bank loans already troubled, ''is it any wonder that banks are not taking on significant new risks,'' she said in a speech to analysts last week.
Officials at the Comptroller of the Currency's office say their standards have not changed. ''We are not holding banks up to a new list of commandments,'' Ms. Wilson said, ''we're simply applying our old standards to a changed environment.''
 
Fleet/Norstar Exposure
One of the banks thought to be most exposed to real estate losses is Fleet/ Norstar Financial Group Inc. in Providence, R.I., where an examination is now under way. The Midlantic Corporation, the Summit Bancorporation and the UJB Financial Corporation, all of New Jersey, are thought to be vulnerable. The Michigan National Corporation is another heavy real estate lender whose debt ratings are under downward pressure.
Other banks in the Southeast and Middle Atlantic States have rapidly increased their real estate lending in recent years, including the Citizens and Southern Corporation of Atlanta, where an examination started last week. A few days before that, Moody's Investors Service said its ratings for Citizens and the Sovran Financial Corporation were no longer under consideration for upgrading. The two have agreed to merge.
 
Views at Citicorp and Chase
Larger banks with national lending operations are also warning that they expect rising losses. Executives at Citicorp and the Chase Manhattan Corporation told analysts last week that real estate losses would increase in 1990.
John S. Reed, Citicorp's chairman, noted that many purchasers of real estate loans, such as Japanese banks, had stopped buying in the last few months. During 1990, he said, commercial real estate lending will earn a profit for Citibank, a Citicorp subsidiary, but nowhere near the $1.50 it usually earned on each $100 of loans.
Officials at the office of the Comptroller of the Currency, an arm of the Treasury that regulates national banks, say they are aiming their examinations at banks with rapid increases in real estate loans and in areas where prices are weakening.
Based on experience with failed banks in Texas, and the experience of other regulators with savings and loan associations, the Federal examiners are more experienced in gauging how badly a bank can be hurt by falling real estate prices. In Texas, for example, they learned that personal guarantees by developers did not provide as much protection as some bankers expected.
It is widely assumed by bankers and analysts that regulators are taking a tough line now to avoid blame for any new debacle such as the one that put banks in Texas out of business in the mid-1980's and resulted in billions in losses for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
Joel B. Alvord, chairman of Shawmut, said last week that estimating the quality of loans had always been an imprecise business, with much room for disagreement. But there is no doubt, he added, that examiners were judging bank loans more harshly than he expected.
One new practice by examiners that raises the hackles of bankers is the labeling as ''nonperforming'' loans on which interest and principal payments are still up to date. Normally the nonperforming label was reserved for loans that were 90 days delinquent. The harsh judgments of the examiners have led to the introduction of a new term in banking jargon, the ''performing nonperforming loan.'' At Shawmut, about a third of the $1.045 billion of the nonperforming loans were loans on which payments are up to date.
Even if the borrower is paying interest when due, Mr. Alvord said, examiners might assume that the developer of a particular project might not be able to continue drawing on personal funds or profits of other projects in order to keep making payments on a troubled project.
Other bankers say that examiners are overriding recent appraisals and applying lower values to properties backing bank loans, based on their knowledge of overall real estate market conditions.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Falls As Mideast Sales Jump

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Gold prices plunged yesterday in New York in near-panic selling on reports of unexpectedly large sales by Middle Eastern interests. Statisticians at the Commodity Exchange in New York said the decline of more than $23 an ounce was the biggest one-day drop since Feb. 28, 1983, when bullion plunged by $42.50, to $400.50.
''The weakness in gold was no surprise, given the continued strength of the dollar and the relatively low level of inflation, said Peter I. Cardillo, metals analyst at Josephthal & Company. ''What did shock the market was the source and magnitude of the selling. It was largely from the Mideast and came in lots of a million ounces. While European bullion dealers absorbed much of the sales at ever-decreasing prices, the full import of the sales was not realized'' until the markets opened in New York. 
 
British Pounds Bought
News reports from Europe attributed the bulk of the selling to the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority, which used much of the proceeds to buy British pounds, causing that currency to rise sharply against the dollar, West German mark and other key currencies.
At the time of the earlier big loss, the winter of 1983, oil prices were falling, which caused some Middle East oil-exporting countries to either reduce or halt their purchases of bullion. In the week before Feb. 28, 1983, gold tumbled by $105 an ounce. Until then, the oil exporters had preferred bullion to the inflation-riddled dollar and other paper investments. Indeed, it was the rampant inflation of the late 1970's that caused the cash price of gold in New York to reach a record high of $850 on Jan. 21, 1980.
Gold and other precious metals lost much of their attractiveness as investments or hedges against declining currency values as inflation declined since then.
At the close of the Commodity Exchange in New York, the spot March gold contract, which expires tomorrow, settled at $365.80, down $23.10 on the day. The more active April delivery dropped by $23.20, to $366.20. Comex volume was uncommonly high at more than 90,000 contracts of 100 ounces each.
Other precious metals declined in sympathy, with the expiring March silver contract down 8.8 cents an ounce, at $4.955, and the April platinum delivery down $10.20 an ounce, at $483.60, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The failure of oil prices to keep pace with the rising cost of Saudi Arabia's development and social programs has prompted its monetary authority to sell bullion from time to time, according to several dealers.
Moreover, Saudis and other Middle East oil exporters have been diversifying their investments and reducing their traditional interest in gold. In recent years, Japan, Taiwan and South Korea have been the major buyers of precious metals. The central banks of Taiwan and South Korea in particular have bought huge amounts of bullion as a means of reducing the soaring volume of dollars created by their favorable trade balances with the United States and other countries.
 
Decline in Reserves
While Saudi gold and hard-currency reserves have been estimated at between $40 billion and $60 billion they are well below those of several years ago.
Bette Raptopoulos, metals specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities, said that ''while the OPEC lands of the Mideast have been net sellers of bullion from time to time, the already weakened market did not expect to be hit by sales of three to four million ounces in one day. The Mideasterners are usually very astute gold traders and don't plunge into a soft market. Another mystery is why they would sell gold for British pounds.''
In a move aimed at calming its metals market, the Comex raised both speculative and trade margins, effective this morning. The new speculative initial cash margin for gold was raised to $2,100 from $1,700 for a 100-ounce contract. The initial margin for gold hedgers and others in the trade was raised to $1,400 from $1,000.
The initial margin for Comex silver was increased to $1,400 for a 5,000-ounce contract from $1,000 for both speculators and the trade. The Comex also raised margins for its copper and aluminum futures contracts. While these are the exchange's minimum margins, most brokerage houses require somewhat more cash from their clients.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Insurers Testing Basic Coverage

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
WITHOUT waiting for Congress, which seems reluctant to act on important health insurance issues in an election year, insurers in a number of states are testing new types of coverage for at least some of the 31 million Americans who lack health insurance.
Insurers expect the Governors of Virginia and Washington to sign legislation that exempts small businesses from many required types of coverage. When the bills are signed, the Virginia and Washington Blue Cross plans will offer relatively inexpensive basic coverage to small employers, who often cannot afford coverage with many expensive benefits.
The Virginia program would cover uninsured workers earning $10,000 to $25,000 a year at companies with no more than 50 employees. It would cost $98 a month, half of which would be paid by the employer. ''We did not price it to make money,'' said Donna DeWitt, a product manager with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Virginia. ''It will be a break-even product.'' 
Eric J. Rohlman, a vice president with the Blue Cross of Washington and Alaska plan, said employees of Washington businesses with 25 or fewer uninsured workers would be eligible after a 12-month waiting period. Both the Virginia and Washington plans would encourage prenatal and preventive care. ''Everybody is scrambling to provide access to care for small groups,'' Mr. Rohlman said. ''It's a huge problem and a political issue.'' Programs for the uninsured are also going into effect in Oregon, Oklahoma, Hawaii and Massachusetts. In Connecticut, most of the influential Hartford-based insurance companies are supporting a similar program, which is considered likely to be approved by the Legislature.
In California, which is considering far-reaching legislative proposals, Blue Cross of California has jumped ahead with an offer to insure all but the riskiest of high-risk small groups at rates only 30 percent above those for groups without many health problems. Leonard D. Schaeffer, chairman of California Blue Cross, said his plan could not wait for the state to act.
Massachusetts hopes to cover 100,000 of the state's 600,000 uninsured by summer. The state has awarded contracts to five insurance companies that will offer lower-cost coverage to a pool of small businesses. The state will help with subsidies (which were reduced because of state budget problems to $6 million, from a planned $30 million). Massachusetts employers will have to contribute to coverage for people who receive unemployment compensation; disabled people will be able to buy into the state Medicaid program, and college students will be required to have health insurance.
Oregon is offering a tax credit to employers who offer a basic coverage; it emphasizes primary health care but would not cover expensive procedures like heart transplants. In Oklahoma, which does not require health insurance coverage, Blue Cross is offering a basic, lower-cost plan. Hawaii, which has long required all employers to provide health benefits, has just enacted a voluntary ''bare bones'' program for part-time, seasonal and agricultural workers and their dependents, said Greg Scandlen, state research director with the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association.
At the national level, the Health Insurance Association of America, an insurers group, is working on a proposal that would set limits on renewal rate increases for small groups and provide a privately financed reinsurance pool for high-risk people with a history of expensive health problems. Linda Jenckes, an association vice president, said insurers would lobby for the plan in all states. They also want Congress to exempt small employers from the 800 or so state-mandated types of coverage.
Insurers welcomed many of the recommendations to Congress for ''insurance market reform'' by the Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care. But the insurers association strongly objects to the commission's call for Federally standardized health insurance benefits and regulations that would ban the exclusion of individuals or groups because of pre-existing health conditions.
The House Ways and Means Committee's health subcommittee plans to hold hearings on the commission's package on Tuesday. The subcommittee's chairman, Representative Pete Stark, a California Democrat and a member of the commission, said the bipartisan panel was nearly unanimous in its support for the market-reform proposals.
But both Mr. Stark and Representative Bill Gradison of Ohio, the subcommittee's ranking Republican, said they did not expect Congress to act this year. Representative Henry Waxman, the California Democrat who is chairman of the health subcommittee of the Energy and Commerce Committee and a member of the bipartisan commission, said it was already ''late in the session'' for action on controversial health-care proposals.

HEADLINE: Harvard Administrator to Head Stanford Business School

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 26

 BODY:
A. Michael Spence, a renowned economist and the second-highest administrator at Harvard University, today was named the next dean of the Stanford University Graduate School of Business.
The appointment was considered a coup at Stanford. As dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences at Harvard, Mr. Spence held one of the nation's most prestigious academic posts, with a rank equivalent to that of provost at many other universities.
Mr. Spence said today that he realized many people would view his new position as a step down. But he said the more manageable size of the Stanford job would eventually allow him to return to teaching and research while remaining an administrator. 
''I think it's a real chance for me to get to where I came from and still do the job I'm doing,'' he said.
 
Other Considerations
Mr. Spence also said the move would allow his wife, Ann, to spend more time with her parents, who live in Northern California and are in poor health. Moreover, he said, it made sense for him to step down now before Harvard begins a major fund-raising effort, because it would be difficult to remain as dean for the seven to eight years it would take to complete the campaign.
At Stanford, in Palo Alto, Calif., in Mr. Spence will replace Robert K. Jaedicke, an accounting expert who has been dean since 1983 and who said last year that he would return to teaching.
''I can't think of anybody who could generate such enthusiastic support from people ranging from theoretical faculty to hard-headed practical businessmen to eager students,'' said Charles T. Horngren, a professor of accounting at the business school and vice chairman of the search committee that chose Mr. Spence.
 
Degrees From Oxford
Mr. Spence, who is 46 years old, was born in Montclair, N.J., and reared in Toronto. He earned a bachelor's degree in philosophy at Princeton University and received bachelor's and master's degrees as a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University.
He earned a doctorate in economics at Harvard, where he later taught in the economics department and at the business school. His specialty had been how markets communicated information through prices and other mechanisms, and how companies and individuals made decisions based on that information. In 1981, he received the John Bates Clark Medal, given by the American Economics Association to outstanding economists under age 40.
Mr. Spence became the dean of arts and sciences in 1984, a job that put him in charge of 9,000 students and 700 faculty members in Harvard College and the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, though not in the professional schools. He became best known for a plan that encouraged the university to promote more of its junior faculty rather than hire senior professors from outside.
''All of Harvard owes Mike Spence a great debt of gratitude for the skillful and imaginative way in which he has led the Faculty of Arts and Sciences during the past six years,'' said Derek C. Bok, Harvard's president. ''Though I regret Mike's departure deeply, all of us can understand and respect the personal considerations that have led him to this decision.''
 
To Oversee 800 Students
At Stanford, where he will start this fall, Mr. Spence will be in charge of fewer than 800 students and 120 faculty members. Mr. Spence had taught economics at the university for two years in the mid-1970's, as his wife earned a degree from the business school.
Stanford is perennially ranked as one of the nation's best business schools. A survey by U.S. News & World Report recently ranked it No. 1. But it is not without problems.
Students have complained in recent years about inadequate teaching and an emphasis on research, and some notable faculty members have left. But Stanford officials say that faculty departures are to be expected and that the teaching complaints focused on some visiting faculty members who are no longer there.
Mr. Spence said he had some ideas on what he wanted to do at Stanford, mentioning as an example the need to emphasize manufacturing. But he said he would not set an agenda before meeting with students and faculty members.
''There's not going to be any dramatic change,'' said James N. Rosse, the Stanford provost who was chairman of the 18-member search committee. The panel had considered more than 100 people.

HEADLINE: Stocks in Tokyo Decline Slightly

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, March 27

 BODY:
Stock prices declined slightly today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The United States dollar opened higher against the Japanese yen.
The Nikkei index of 225 stocks, which had gained 1,468.33 points, or 4.83 percent, on Monday, rose and fell in volatile trading throughout the day, and by the end of the session stood at 31,825.96 down 14.53 points. Volume was at the 700 million level, or fairly active.
Dealers attributed the loss to the yen's continued weakness against the dollar.
The dollar started trading at 156.90 yen, up 0.50 yen from the Monday close in Tokyo.
''Because of the yen's decline, issues sensitive to interest-rate movements are being sold,'' a Nomura Securities dealer said.
Monday's gain was second only to the 2,037.32-point rise on Oct. 21, 1987, when share prices rebounded from the worldwide market crash.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved modestly higher yesterday in listless trading, pushed upward by continued strength in the dollar.
Much of the session's gains were recorded during overnight trading, when the dollar rose strongly against the Japanese yen.
But dealers said there was no follow-through once trading shifted to Europe and then to the United States.
With the Federal Reserve Board unlikely to approve a change in monetary policy at the meeting today of its policy-making Open Market Committee, traders and analysts said coming auctions of two-year and four-year notes may be the only events that will spark much interest this week. 
''The Fed has to be quite happy at this point,'' said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''Short-term interest rates have moved up, and they aren't going to fight that. I think they are going to sit back and watch.''
Because of the rise in short-term rates, Mr. Held and others said demand for the new Treasury notes should be strong.
''Retail participation should be very aggressive at the auctions,'' Mr. Held said. ''The yields are there.''
 
Ten-Year Note Auction
The Treasury will auction $10 billion of new two-year notes today. Late yesterday, the notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.55 percent.
Good demand from small investors for short-term securities was also in evidence at the weekly Treasury bill auction yesterday.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.85 percent, down from an average rate of 7.97 percent at last week's sale.
Meanwhile, bids on new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 7.83 percent, compared with an average rate of 7.92 percent a week ago.
Non-competitive bids, a good indication of demand from retail investors, totaled $1.5 billion for the $8 billion of three-month bills that were sold. Investors placed $1.2 billion worth of non-competitive bids for the $8 billion of six-month bills that were auctioned.
The strength of the dollar, and a big drop in gold prices, provided modest support for prices in the secondary market for Treasury securities.
By late in the day, the 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at 100 14/ 32, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.45 percent.
Among note issues, 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 31/32, up 2/32, to yield 8.50 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 7/8, up 2/32, to yield 8.51 percent.
 
Tax-Free Municipal Bonds
Participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market said prices were little affected yesterday by a sweeping ratings downgrade by the Standard & Poor's Corporation on more than $13 billion worth of outstanding New York State debt obligations.
Included in the downgrade was a lowering of Standard & Poor's rating on $3.9 billion of general obligation bonds to A, from AA-minus.
In addition, Moody's Investors Service lowered its ratings on the state's auction today of $775 million of tax and revenue-anticipation notes. The notes were downgraded to MIG-2. The notes, which are issued annually, were rated MIG-1 last year.
''The downgrade will affect the pricing of the notes, but it hasn't had much of an impact on the bonds,'' one municipal bond trader said. ''New York's problems have been well known for some time, so these steps were not unanticipated.''
New-issue activity in the tax-exempt market was dominated by a $492 million offering of bonds issued by O'Hare Airport in Chicago.
The issue, which is subject to provisions of the alternative minimum tax, consisted of serial and term bonds.
The largest part of the issue consists of $199 million of 7.5 percent term bonds due in 2017. The bonds were preliminarily priced at $96.6245, to yield 7.80 percent.
Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company acted as lead manager for the negotiated sale. The issue is rated A by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
In the new-issue corporate bond market, the Carolina Power and Light Company offered $75 million of first-mortgage bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The 9.14 percent bonds, which mature on April 1, 1995, were priced at 100, which was 67 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated A-2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
Activity in the secondary markets for tax-exempt municipal bonds and investment-grade corporate bonds was light, dealers said.
Prices of most tax-exempt issues were unchanged to a 1/8 point higher. Prices of actively traded corporate bonds posted similar results.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Climbs Against Yen, But Loses Ground to Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against the Japanese yen yesterday, stoking the bearish attitude toward gold that has been building for weeks. But the dollar retreated against the British pound.
The Saudia Arabian Monetary Agency is said to have been a big seller of gold - an estimated 3 million ounces - and to have bought pounds with the proceeds. The agency acts as the country's central bank and is the main repository of hard currencies and gold reserves. 
The dollar has been bid up on speculation that American interest rates will remain at current levels or will climb. There is a perception that the Federal Reserve will not nudge rates down because economic growth appears adequate while inflationary pressures persist.
Tension in the Soviet Union over the Lithuanian independence movement and forecasts of further weakness in the Japanese yen have also driven up the dollar.
The dollar rose to 156.70 yen in New York, from 154.30 yen late Friday. In Tokyo yesterday, the dollar rose by 1.33 yen, to 156.40 yen, its highest close since Jan. 13, 1987. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 156.35 yen.
The British pound, benefiting from the reported Saudi sterling purchase, strengthened to $1.6185 in New York, from $1.6010 on Friday. Sterling traded late in London at $1.6135, up from $1.6040 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, were: 1.7075 West German marks, down from 1.7135; 1.5205 Swiss francs, up from 1.5200; 5.7480 French francs, down from 5.7720; 1,256.00 Italian lire, down from 1,260.25, and 1.17595 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17505.
Late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared with late Friday's levels, were: 1.7155 West German marks, up from 1.7100; 1.5275 Swiss francs, up from 1.5179; 5.7745 French francs, up from 5.7645; 1.9267 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9249; 1,261.50 Italian lire, up from 1,258.50, and 1.1748 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1751.

HEADLINE: Strategies to Let Elderly Keep Some Control

SERIES: CARE OF THE ELDERLY; PRIVATE BURDENS, PUBLIC CHOICES - SECOND OF FOUR ARTICLES.

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
Home care services, adult day care and a host of other programs to aid the disabled elderly are proliferating as more people search for alternatives to traditional nursing homes.
Over the last decade, public and private agencies have begun to respond to the near-universal desire of frail or chronically ill people to remain in familiar surroundings, with control over their lives, whenever possible.
Innovative programs are providing help with daily activities to frail or chronically ill people who do not want, or need to live in a nursing home. The new approaches include home-repair services, day centers, foster homes for the elderly and apartment buildings where residents can get more care as they need it.
 
Need for New Services
Nonetheless, experts say, the need for new services is far from met. Most of the disabled elderly are still cared for by relatives at home. But many elderly people are placed in nursing homes simply because they lack help with dressing and bathing. And many wives, husbands and children still strain to care for the disabled at home without any assistance or relief. 
''There's no question that the experiments and alternatives are out there, but they're serving only a small proportion of those who need them,'' said Dr. Carroll Estes, director of the Institute for Health and Aging at the University of California at San Francisco.
For elderly people who want to stay in the community, she said, the biggest need is in-home help with bathing, dressing and homemaking.
 
States Try New Strategies
''While there are a lot more of those programs than there were 10 years ago, very few deal with large numbers of people,'' she said.
To be sure, nursing homes may be the best alternative for the frailest people, the most disabled, the severely demented or violent, those with complex medical needs and those with no family or friends to lend a hand.
But states are trying out many new strategies as they face ever-higher nursing home costs, and growing concern about the sense of confinement and lack of personal control that so many nursing home residents feel.
''Wisconsin, Oregon, Washington State and Illinois have been among the leaders,'' said Diane Justice, deputy director of the National Association of State Units on Aging. ''And where programs aren't being developed, it's usually due to a lack of state dollars, not a lack of interest.''
In Wisconsin, the $35 million annual Community Options Program assists 7,700 people needing long-term care, half of them elderly and half younger disabled people. The program will arrange almost any service needed to keep a resident at home, whether it is paying the next-door neighbor to cook dinner twice a week or finding a nurse to come every day. The services are provided free to the poor and on a sliding scale to others.
Oregon is trying a different approach, creating a network of foster homes for the elderly. The state is also encouraging developers to build ''assisted living'' apartments, where residents can get the same level of nursing care available in a nursing home, along with housekeeping services and meals in a group dining room, without forfeiting the chance to live in a private apartment with their own furnishings, carpeted floors and a door that can lock. New Approaches Sorting Out What Works Many community programs, some public, some private, have developed across the country. There are now about 2,200 day centers for the elderly, compared with a dozen 20 years ago. Hundreds of new respite programs provide a companion or nurse to look after an elderly person while the person who usually provides the care takes a break.
There are also telephone reassurance programs, in which frail people get daily calls to make sure they are well. Technology can also play a part. Some elderly people get a sense of security by wearing an electronic alarm they can set off if they fall or need help.
Many cities also have housekeeping, gardening or home repair programs for the elderly, to help prevent people from retreating to a nursing home simply because they cannot manage the chores of daily life.
 
New Role: Care Manager
The proliferation of programs has spawned a new profession: the private care manager, who coordinates and monitors an elderly person's care, signing up for the meal programs, checking the performance of the home health aide, scheduling doctor's visits and arranging transportation.
Such services are appealing to the growing population of adult children whose aging parents live far away. Rather than making weekly trips to check on a parent, many choose to hire a local care manager, at $50 to $120 an hour. Some care managers work with their own nurses and aides, while others contract out the work. And while one client may need only a monthly check-in call, another may require daily visits. The National Association of Private Geriatric Care Managers, in Dayton, Ohio, is creating a national referral network.
Many public and nonprofit agencies use case managers to screen clients and help them find their way to the most appropriate programs available locally.
Some nursing homes have created their own services for elderly people in the community.
 
An Array of Services
Since 1980, for example, the Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged in New York City has started a ''nursing home without walls'' home care program; two day centers, one of them for the blind and visually impaired; an in-home Alzheimer's emergency respite program; outpatient rehabilitation that offers therapy, nursing and counseling, and an at-home recovery program, which cares for patients newly released from the hospital and helps train the family to take over. The Jewish Home has also started a telephone Guideline, (212) 663-4663, to help clients decide which services they need and qualify for.
''Most of the things that are likely to help solve the long-term care problem are being tried in some pilot project somewhere, but we're really still at the very beginning,'' said Dr. Burton Reifler of the Bowman Gray School of Medicine in Winston-Salem, N.C., who directs a pilot program that finances several day centers. ''It's going to take 15 or 20 years to sort out what works, what people want, what they will pay for, what the government will pay for, and then to see that the services we need are widely available.'' Home Living Someone to Take Care of Things Most health policy experts agree that too many people live in nursing homes not because they need much medical attention but because that is the most widely available option. Also, for those who have used up their resources, it is the one that Medicaid, the joint Federal-state health program for the poor, is most likely to pay for.
The National Center for Health Statistics reports that 5 percent of Americans over 65 now live in nursing homes, more than double the percentage of the early 1960's. Most of the increase came shortly after the 1965 creation of Medicare and Medicaid, which helped nudge long-term care into a medical model, with the disabled and elderly seen as patients, rather than a social model, with programs designed around daily living needs, and medical services added as needed.
''The field of long-term care has been too medicalized, because programs are driven so much by the funding mechanisms available to pay for them,'' said Jeffrey Mitchell of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, which supports many experimental long-term care programs. ''We did some research to find out what the elderly want, and we found that services like home repair, shopping and housecleaning may contribute more to the elderly's being able to stay in the community than traditional medical services.''
 
Help With Home Repairs
One such program is the home repair service that the New York Foundation for Senior Citizens operates for elderly people with limited incomes. It has helped Rose and Michael Katz stay in the Brooklyn home they have owned since the 1950's.
''We thought about leaving because we weren't sure we would be able to manage the upkeep,'' said Mrs. Katz, 76 years old. ''They've probably come 30 times and fixed the locks on our doors, the washers on the faucets, taken care of the washing machine and cleared the drains. The house would have fallen apart without them.''
In Dallas, the Visiting Nurse Association offers a program called Independence Plus, which arranges $10-an-hour housekeeping, and yard maintenance for the elderly.
''We get a lot of widows who can't take care of the yard, or need help with shopping, and a lot of men who don't know how to take care of the house and need heavy cleaning, shopping and meal preparation,'' said Sue Seifert, the director of the program.
 
Nine Visits a Week
With more than 10,000 public and private home health agencies nationwide, even people who need a great deal of nursing care can often remain in their homes.
Margaret Pawley, 78, of Brookside, Del., has had several disabling strokes and a colostomy. She is bedridden, diabetic and catheterized, with a bedsore and a surgical incision that still need dressing. She gets three visits a week from a nurse who checks her blood and her dressings, three visits from a physical therapist who helps her with upper-arm exercises and three visits from an aide, who changes her bed and bathes her.
''It's hard and I did think about a nursing home,'' said Mrs. Pawley's daughter, Mary Lucille Walstrum. ''But when Mom was in the hospital, she only said two things to me: ''I love you' and 'When am I going home?' So I thought I would try it,'' Mrs. Walstrum has moved her family into her mother's house and hired her husband's sister to care for her mother while Mrs. Walstrum is at work. Assisted Living Varied Strategies Succeed in Oregon Richard Ladd, the administrator of Oregon's Senior and Disabled Services Division, estimates that only about 5 percent of the state's 20,000 Medicaid recipients receiving long-term care have complex medical needs.
''Most of them just can't do what they need to do, whether it's getting dressed or taking their medicine,'' he said. ''Long-term care is not a medical problem, but too often we put them in nursing homes where they have less control over their lives and less freedom than the average prison inmate.''
One of Mr. Ladd's alternatives to nursing homes is a network of foster homes, each caring for up to five elderly people.
''I've got a lady who's 95, three in their 80's and a 67-year-old Alzheimer's patient, and they're all confused in their minds,'' said Geraldine Maurig, 62, who runs a foster home near Portland. ''It's no different than having five children at home to look after. You become their mother, the one they turn to. I cook and do their hair, and take care of their whiskers, and even when I have incontinent people you don't smell anything when you walk in my door.''
Mrs. Maurig, who trained her granddaughter to open a foster home of her own, charges $1,000 to $1,400 a month, depending on the level of care. The state pays an average of $1,700 a month for nursing home care.
Oregon also emphasises assisted-living apartments, in which the elderly and disabled live in a building where meals and housekeeping are provided, with other services, like nursing, added as needed. Mr. Ladd estimates that half the state's nursing home residents could be cared for in such apartments.
 
A Couple Stays Together
Gladys and John Chaffin moved from California to the Regency Park assisted-living complex in Portland two years ago, when Mr. Chaffin began needing care for Alzheimer's disease.
''We had looked at a lot of nursing homes,'' said Mrs. Chaffin, who is 81, ''but to tell the truth, I wouldn't have moved into a nursing home with him, and when you've been married 60 years, it seems sad to be separated.'' She said the assisted-living arrangement ''is wonderful for us because I can go and play bridge twice a week and there's someone to take care of him.'' In the future, she added, ''when he starts needing more care, they'll be able to handle that, too.''
Assisted-living often becomes sensible when home care proves too difficult, and many profit-making companies, including hotel chains like the Marriott Corporation and the Hyatt Corporation, are entering the field, expecting that, as the population ages, there will be a large market for care.
''It's not always practical to keep people at home,'' said Keren Brown Wilson, a consultant who helped develop Regency Park.''It's very expensive and very tough to manage home care for someone who needs care round the clock, or needslike someone to help whenever they have to use the bathroom. If you design it carefully, assisted living gives you the economies of scale and a lot of the feeling of a home.''
Regency Park, with costs starting at $1,500 a month for a studio apartment, has about 20 residents receiving state assistance, but most of the residents pay privately.
 
Expected Savings Not Realized
Rosalie A. Kane, an expert on long-term care at the University of Minnesota, is optimistic about assisted living. ''I think the most promising model for people with heavy long-term care needs is housing where lots of different services can be added on,'' she said. ''If you can separate the idea of housing from the idea of care, you can break through the rigidity of nursing home life.''
Dr. Kane and others said that most of the alternatives to nursing homes were started with idea of saving money. But often, the cost savings are illusory: indeed, round-the-clock home care is apt to be more expensive than care in a nursing home, because it requires a caretaker for each patient.
''For the most part, the initial glowing reports about how much money these programs save, and how long they delay nursing home admission, have not panned out,'' she said. ''Cost aside, most people do not want to enter a nursing home. Quality of life can be just as important a factor as cost.'' Helping the Helpers Day Centers Give Needed Relief Much of America's long-term care is still provided informally, most often by wives, daughters, daughters-in-law and neighbors. And increasingly, policy makers are trying to find ways to support them.
Day centers and respite programs, which can help those caring for disabled people as much as the disabled, are mushrooming, and becoming increasingly specialized, with programs especially for Alzheimer's patients, the visually impaired, AIDS patients and other groups.
''It's a godsend to be able to take my husband to the day center every morning,'' said Gloria Lowe, whose husband, Martin, 80, has had Alzheimer's disease for 17 years and now attends an Alzheimer's center in Delaware. ''When he's home, he needs constant attention, so this is my only chance to catch up on shopping and cleaning. I would have run out of money if he had been in a nursing home all this time and this is better for him.''
Alzheimer's patients, who make up about half the population of nursing homes nationally, pose the most troubling long-term care problems as their dementia progresses.
 
Benefits of Music
Some programs are finding new ways to engage them and lessen their distress. The Sunshine Terrace day center in Logan, Utah, uses extensive music therapy, having found that it helps to soothe demented older people.
''We have patients who can no longer say five words, but who can still sing the lyrics to 20 or 30 songs from their childhood,'' said Bonnie Smith, the program director. ''We sing a lot of 'Let Me Call You Sweetheart' and 'Springtime in the Rockies.' ''
The center even has a choral group, whose conductor, Viola Israelsen, an 84-year-old Alzheimer's patient who lives with her son, has a wandering problem and can no longer quite remember her age or how many children she has. But singing is second nature to her, and she sound utterly lucid at rehearsal.
''I was trained by mother and dad to like and originate music, to make it sing in my heart,'' she said.
NEXT: The politics of long-term care, and the policy choices.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: March 28, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1190 words

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS AGREE NEW YORK IS FACING BIGGER BUDGET GAP

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 27

 BODY:
Apparently chastened by a downgrading of the state's credit rating on Monday, Senate Republicans agreed today that the gap in Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed 1990-91 budget had grown to $1.5 billion.
The accord between Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders included an agreement to reduce spending by $500 million, but none of of the officials involved would disclose details of the cuts. The accord was reached during long negotiations that ended early this morning. Though the leaders have yet to decide how to solve the fiscal quandary, it was the first time they had agreed on how severe it was.
The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., had resisted an agreement even though the Governor and the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, both Democrats, and Comptroller Edward V. Regan, a Republican, concurred on the number more than two weeks ago. 
 
Now the Talk Is of Taxes
A smaller budget gap might have enabled Mr. Marino to avoid supporting some of the tax increases Mr. Cuomo proposed.
Mr. Marino's concession on the size of the budget gap, coupled with the accord on spending cuts, seemed to signal that the Senate, with a Republican majority, might now be willing to discuss a smorgasbord of new and increased taxes that Mr. Cuomo has proposed to fill much of the budget gap. But Mr. Marino stopped short of saying so.
''We have not accepted the need for revenues,'' Mr. Marino said at a news conference today. ''We are discussing revenues, however. We're not going to tax the people of this state one cent more unless it's absolutely necessary, and we can't see any other way of getting this budget done.'' #2 Targets: Retirement Funds While continuing to argue over how to cut spending and where to raise taxes, Mr. Cuomo and the legislative leaders did appear to agree on one facet of a plan to close the budget gap. All three want to save at least $400 million by simply reducing the state's contribution to two huge retirement funds for public employees and teachers.
Similar changes last year saved $600 million, but custodians of the funds, including the State Comptroller, are resisting the new proposals. They say further cuts in state contributions could impair their ability to meet obligations to more than a million pensioners, but Mr. Cuomo has insisted that the pensions are now overfunded and that a reduction is warranted.
Officials with Standard & Poor's, one of two major credit rating agencies that lowered New York's rating on Monday, said their decision was influenced by the inability of state leaders to agree on even the magnitude of the gap - the difference between how much the government plans to spend and how much it expects to take in.
Standard & Poor's took the unexpected step of lowering the state's credit rating on longterm bonds by two steps, from AA- to A, making New York's credit rating the third lowest of all states that are rated.
 
'A Breakthrough'
In a fiscal landscape that darkened from gloomy to bleak with the drop in the credit rating, the leaders portrayed the agreement on the size of the budget gap as a ray of good news.
''After three months, we finally agreed there is a deficit, so I suppose it was a major victory,'' Mr. Miller said.
Calling the accord ''an extraordinary breakthrough,'' Mr. Cuomo said it was crucial to negotiate a budget by April 1, when the fiscal year starts. ''We made a mistake,'' he said. ''We didn't agree fast enough that there was a problem.
O.K., that's behind us. Now we want to be constructive and get this done.''
After meeting for more than five hours Monday night, a session that ended at 12:30 A.M. yesterday, the Governor and legislative leaders also said they had agreed on $500 million in spending cuts, leaving them to find $1 billion through other means.
They have consistently refused to disclose which items they plan to cut from Mr. Cuomo's $51 billion proposed budget, fearing that such an announcement would mobilize opposition that could paralyze an already delicate budget process.
 
An Ever-Widening Gap
The projected gap in Mr. Cuomo's 1990-91 budget has grown since the Governor proposed it in mid-January. When fiscal analysts saw that state tax collections in January and February were far lower than anticipated, they revised their estimates for tax collections in the coming fiscal year.
That created the budget gap that the leaders now agree is $1.5 billion. That gap exists in addition to a $2 billion gap that would have occurred in the 1990-91 budget if Mr. Cuomo had maintained state spending at the previous year's level plus inflation.
State law requires the Governor to present a balanced budget, so he has proposed filling that gap by suspending the final year of a four-year cut in the personal income tax, by levying a series of other taxes, by taking a number of so-called one-shot revenue measures, and by making spending cuts.
There is another gap in the existing budget, passed last April for the 1989-90 fiscal year. That gap has been estimated at more than $1 billion and has been reduced through spending cuts and raids on reserve funds and by selling $775 million in short-term bonds.
The credit rating drop was already felt today with the sale of those bonds, which mature at the end of the year. Marvin G. Nailor, a spokesman for the State Comptroller, said the lower credit rating caused the bonds to trade at an interest rate that is one-tenth of 1 percent higher than it would have been had the credit rating not fallen. That means the state will have to pay $580,000 in additional interest.
 
Even Lower Rating Feared
Although the start of the fiscal year, and thus the state's budget deadline, is April 1, the Legislature has not met that deadline since 1984. Mr. Cuomo, who had warned previously that missing the deadline could mean lower ratings, said today that the state credit rating could be threatened further if a budget was not negotiated quickly.
''If we don't do this budget right we could make this a junk bond state,'' Mr. Cuomo said at a news conference.
He expressed concern about ''rumors'' that some Senate Republicans believed that the lowering of the credit rating on Monday alleviated the pressure to pass a budget on time.
Mr. Marino insisted that he and his colleagues were indeed working toward an April 1 deadline, but several Republican senators conceded that the early drop in credit rates made it less likely that they will meet that date.
Mr. Marino threw one new item on the negotiating table today by proposing a mandatory cap on state spending. The Republican proposal, which was rejected by a spokesman for Mr. Miller, would restrict the annual growth in state spending more than a similar cap long supported by Mr. Cuomo.
Mr. Cuomo's spending cap would limit the annual growth in spending to the average growth in state personal income over the previous three years.
Mr. Marino's plan would limit spending growth to either 80 percent of the average rise in personal income over three years or to the previous year's increase in inflation adjusted for population growth, whichever figure is less.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (94%); 

CITY: ALBANY, NY, USA (65%); 

COMPANY: STANDARD & POOR'S CORP (90%);

HEADLINE: Accord on Control of Nicaraguan Army

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 27

 BODY:
Representatives of the Sandinista leadership today recognized the right of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro to exercise full authority over the country's Sandinista-dominated army and security forces.
That provision, part of an agreement signed after four weeks of talks, is the first concrete effort to determine the role of the powerful Sandinista military apparatus under an incoming Government that has defined itself in opposition to Sandinista rule. It appears to address broad concerns that the Sandinistas would attempt to retain military power despite their defeat by a wide margin in national elections on Feb. 25.
The document declares that serving soldiers and officers, who now receive intensive political instruction, will be prohibited from holding leadership positions of any political party. It notes explicitly that the size and structure of the armed forces, which now include 65,000 troops on active duty, may be adjusted ''in accordance with the economic capacity and social necessities of the country.'' 
But the agreement, described as a ''protocol on procedure for the transfer of presidential authority,'' also declares that a respect for the ''integrity and professionalism'' of the armed forces will be a crucial element in an orderly transfer of power. And it commits Mrs. Chamorro to respect a number of cherished Sandinista projects, ranging from grants of land to the rural and urban poor to maintenance of monuments to Sandinistas who died in the 1979 revolution and on the Government side of the country's long war against the United States-supported rebels known as contras.
 
Other Agreements Expected
The document, released at a press conference late today, is the first and broadest of what is expected to be a series of agreements between the Sandinistas and Mrs. Chamorro's nascent administration as the two sides attempt to work out the practical aspects of Nicaragua's first democratic change of government, scheduled for April 25.
''The nation's defense forces and forces of public order will be subordinated to the civil power of the President of the republic, in accordance with the Constitution and the laws of the republic,'' the agreement declares. ''The armed forces will have a professional character and will not belong to any political party.''
Although Sandinista leaders have issued harsh and frequent warnings that Mrs. Chamorro's Government must not tamper with the ''integrity'' of the army or the security forces, today's announcement was reinforced by a passionate, conciliatory speech by the chief negotiator of the Sandinista transition team, Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra, who is the younger brother of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra and a key strategist of the Sandinista Government.
 
Goal of National Reconciliation
Declaring that Nicaraguans ''voted for peace'' in last month's elections, Mr. Ortega urged them all to work together to work for national reconciliation. He underscored the document's demand for the carrying out of recent agreements to disband the contra army, which both sides have described as the most important remaining obstacle to a smooth transition.
In a passage clearly aimed at responding to Sandinista fears of a wholesale turnover in the Government after Mrs. Chamorro takes power, the agreement declares that both sides support ''a guarantee of job stability for Government functionaries and employees, on the basis of their efficiency, administrative honesty and years of service.''
But the document also takes aim at widespread evidence that the Sandinistas have handed out automatic weapons to their military and civilian supporters in the weeks since the election, directly underscoring ''the need to insure that arms and combat equipment be kept exclusively in the hands of the armed institutions of the republic.''
The agreement was signed by Humberto Ortega and by Mrs. Chamorro's chief negotiator, Antonio Lacayo Oyanguren, her son-in-law and former campaign manager. It was witnessed by Nicaragua's Roman Catholic primate, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo.

HEADLINE: Colleague Denounces Comments By Illinois Congressman as Bigoted

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
Remarks made by Representative Gus Savage of Illinois in the closing days of his successful Democratic primary campaign have been condemned as ''divisive and bigoted'' by the House Democratic whip, Representative William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania.
Mr. Gray, the third-ranking Democrat in the House, gave that assessment in a statement Monday after reviewing a videotape of Mr. Savage's comments, which have been denounced by Jewish groups as anti-Semitic.
Mr. Savage made his remarks at a Chicago campaign rally the weekend before the March 20 election. The rally was attended by his fellow black Congressmen Mr. Gray and Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan. 
After his two colleagues had left the rally, Mr. Savage charged that his opponent, Mel Reynolds, a black former university administrator, had received much of his campaign money from what Mr. Savage termed ''pro-Israeli Jewish lobbies.'' Mr. Savage suggested that pro-Israel groups wanted him defeated because he favored a shift in foreign aid from Israel to sub-Saharan African nations.
 
A Colleague Was 'Shocked'
Mr. Rangel issued a statement last Friday saying he was ''shocked'' by reports of Mr. Savage's remarks. At that time, Mr. Gray, in New Orleans to attend a Democratic conference, said that ''if anti-Semitic, bigoted statements were made,'' he condemned them and that he wanted to review a videotape of the event when he returned to Washington.
In his statement Monday, Mr. Gray said: ''After reviewing the videotape of Mr. Savage's speech before the Illinois primary, I find much of his language and remarks unacceptable, divisive and bigoted. Such language I reject and condemn.''
Repeated efforts today and tonight to reach Mr. Savage or a spokesman for comment were unsuccessful.
Mr. Savage is known for his extravagant use of language. Last month, when the House ethics committee was about to rebuke him for improper sexual advances toward a female Peace Corps worker on a trip to Zaire, he attacked his accusers as ''white liberals'' and ''self-appointed guardians of public morality.''
Aides to Mr. Gray said he had just returned from a trip to South Africa when he was invited by Mr. Savage to appear at the campaign rally and speak of the candidate's help in passage of a bill to impose economic sanctions against Pretoria. The aides said that by appearing at the rally Mr. Gray had in essence been repaying Mr. Savage for his support on South Africa sanctions and that Mr. Gray had no idea what Mr. Savage would say there.

GRAPHIC: photo: William H. Gray 3d, the House Democratic whip, who condemned Representative Gus Savage for making ''divisive and bigoted''comments at a rally. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;
Ribbs Out of Indy 500

 BODY:
Willy T. Ribbs, who enlisted the support of Bill Cosby last November in his attempt to become the first black driver to compete in the Indianapolis 500, has abandoned his plans to drive in that race in 1990.
Jim Dinsmore, a spokesman for the Raynor-Cosby Racing Team, said yesterday that the team still planned to enter Ribbs in the 11 road-racing events on the 16-race Indy-car schedule this year. 
Ribbs abandoned an attempt at Indy this year, Dinsmore said, because the team could not get a 1990 model chassis in time for the May 27 race.
The team started searching for a major sponsor relatively late, Dinsmore said, and that fact, combined with the weakening economy and the Porsche Indy-car team's unexpected entry into the sponsorship hunt, was too much to overcome.
More than one Indy-car team so far has complained that the 1989 cars, when updated to meet the new rules taking effect this year, are very skittish.
Ribbs hit the wall while testing a 1989 chassis last month at the mile oval in Phoenix.

HEADLINE: Fiscal Fire Alarms, and Fire, in Albany

 BODY:
As threatened, the top bond rating agencies have now downgraded New York State's credit rating, leaving no doubt that the state is in serious financial trouble. With the legal deadline for approving the next budget now just four days away, leaders in Albany can no longer afford political games at public expense.
The task confronting Gov. Mario Cuomo and Senate Republicans is to close a $1.5 billion gap for the fiscal year that begins Sunday. There's one hopeful sign: Ralph Marino, the Senate majority leader, after weeks of irresponsibly shrugging off warnings even from his fellow Republican Edward Regan, the State Comptroller, finally acknowledges that a problem exists. 
But that's hardly enough. New Yorkers need a plan that would not merely solve this year's problem but restore the state's long-term financial stability.
The decision by Standard & Poor's and Moody's to downgrade the state's credit rating could cost taxpayers dearly in higher interest on state bonds. The higher debt service could also make new initiatives, like Mr. Cuomo's proposed Environmental Bond Act, unaffordable.
Part of the problem is the downturn in the economy that has cut tax revenues throughout the Northeast. But part of it is also the way Governor Cuomo and the Legislature have been managing the state's money. They have cut taxes without reducing spending and engaged in fiscal gimmicks that dismay the rating agencies.
Only in recent days has Mr. Cuomo shown signs of strong leadership. He's gone along with the tax cuts and high spending, he's given his blessing to the questionable use of one-time revenues like raiding reserve funds, and - except for a few tantalizing hints, like his welcome call for higher gasoline taxes - has yet to let the public in on his proposed solution to the current mess.
But the Senate Republicans remain the biggest obstacle. Even now, Mr. Marino won't agree to defer the next phase of the state's income tax cut, vaguely holding out for unrealistic spending cuts.
Posturing is inevitable at state budget time, especially in an election year. But as the siren from the rating agencies now makes clear, this year the rules have changed. Mr. Marino and his colleagues appear intent on dragging out the process in an effort to hurt Mr. Cuomo. It's a destructive, possibly self-destructive strategy and it's already costing New York millions.

HEADLINE: Not-So-Crazy Talk From Japan

 BODY:
Just who do the Japanese think they are? Tokyo's negotiators and Washington's have been talking jargon to each other for seven months about ''structural impediments'' to trade. Now the Japanese have found a way to show America how it feels to be patronized.
Their device is a list of 80 specific ideas for improving the U.S. economy. The Japanese say that consumption-mad Americans have too many credit cards. They argue that U.S. corporations should take a longer view, reporting earnings and paying dividends twice a year, like the Japanese, instead of quarterly. They say gasoline taxes are too low and that the tax deduction for interest on home mortgages should be abolished. 
The forum is a bilateral discussion called the ''Structural Impediments Initiative.'' Washington initiated the talks in hopes of persuading the Japanese to change their ways, and eventually import more and export less. But Japan insisted on discussing what's wrong with America, too.
Now, in a stroke, the Japanese have shown how preposterous it is to think that national norms can be reordered by negotiation. Japan's list of ideas for making the American economy more efficient and competitive has not been made public, but a sampling found its way into the Japanese press. The published examples are suggestions that responsible critics have made many times. By and large, they make sense - and they don't stand a chance of being adopted.
Knowing that Washington politicians would sooner take poison than accept these unpopular suggestions, one Japanese authority called the list ''a bunch of very crazy ideas.'' But, he went on, ''as long as you gave us your crazy ideas, we thought we would give you a few of ours.''
Indeed, the U.S.'s own list of what's wrong with Japan spells out two hundred forty things that Washington says need fixing. It suggests that Japan raise public spending to 10 percent of its gross national product, from the current 6 percent. It calls for repeal of a law that protects shopkeepers by making it hard to open department stores. Another suggestion, smacking of fantasy, proposes that Japan's giant conglomerates make public the minutes of their monthly meetings.
Washington's 240 ideas for Japan are no less valid than Tokyo's 80 for America, and no more likely to be swallowed whole.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 465 words

HEADLINE: Proposed New York State Budget Would Hurt Farm Families

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New York State needs to corral state spending. The proposed $50 billion budget is 8 percent higher than last year's - twice the inflation rate. State spending has risen nearly 25 percent in just four years. 
Agriculture is New York's largest industry and could be a growth industry for the 1990's and beyond. However, the state's excessive tax burden is suffocating New York's $3 billion agricultural industry. New York's 39,000 family farmers work long, hard hours and are highly productive. However, their overall tax burden places them at a competitive disadvantage with farmers in other states and countries.
New York Farm Bureau, the state's largest farm advocacy organization, believes state spending must be put on ice. Spending should increase no faster than what current revenue rates can handle. In addition, we believe no new revenue sources should be created.
The proposed executive budget contains revenue-raising plans that can best be characterized as budgetary hocus-pocus. For example, transfering $230 million from the State Insurance Fund to the general fund ultimately contributes to higher worker compensation premiums for New York farmers and other business people. This money was paid by hard-working business people and is a reserve to protect them, not a budget-balancing mechanism.
Since 1986, special revenues, such as fees, have increased state spending dramatically. This shift of general fund programs to special revenue programs has increased about 150 percent, with a negative impact on agriculture.
The $1.9 billion proposed environmental bond is another revenue raiser that will hurt family farmers. The state holds a collective debt of about $49 billion. Adding another bond act will jeopardize future generations, farm and nonfarm alike.
New York family farmers own about nine million acres, some one-third of the state's total acreage, and pay more than $150 million in property taxes. A big share of the land taxes farmers pay goes toward school taxes.
Adjusting the school aid formula to reflect both enrollment and attendance will hurt rural school districts. Since New York farm families bear much of the school tax burden for rural areas, altering the formula will hurt those who produce our food. An excessive property tax burden for New York's food producers jeopardizes the state's biggest industry.
The Governor and the Legislature need to practice tougher fiscal management. New York State agriculture will remain competitive if spending is controlled and taxation inflation is stopped. New York State must not become a miniature version of the Federal quagmire. This state needs true economic growth, not budgetary expansion.
 
CHARLES WILLE
President, New York Farm Bureau
 Glenmont, N.Y., March 7, 1990

HEADLINE: Fire in the Bronx;
Bronx Social Club's Sublease: How a Firetrap Skirted the Line

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
A lease for the Bronx social club where 87 people died in an arson fire early Sunday shows that the building's landlord was aware that the club was to be used as ''a bar and game room.'' But responsibility for making sure the club complied with the law was left to the club's owner, Elias Colon, who was killed in the fire.
Court records also show that while the Happy Land Social Club's landlord tried to evict the club for nonpayment of rent, the landlord never informed Housing Court that it had been ordered closed for serious fire and and building code violations.
Legal experts said the landlord, Little Peach Realty, a large concern whose principals are Jay Weiss and Morris Jaffee, is unlikely to face any criminal liability.
 
Skirting the Rules
The role of the landlord in a property that is operated illegally was illustrated in a review of court records and city documents that show how Happy Land and dozens of other social clubs carefully skirt the limits of government regulations and the fine print of the real estate establishment. 
Alan Vogeler, a lawyer who represents Little Peach, which holds a 30-year lease on the property, said last night that Mr. Weiss had never been inside the social club and had not visited the property since April 1989 at the latest.
He said Mr. Jaffe regularly visited their properties to collect rent, but that to the best of his knowledge Mr. Jaffe had also never been inside. He said he had not been able to reach Mr. Jaffe to confirm this. Asked if either man ever knew of illegal activities in their property, Mr. Vogeler said, ''We're not making any statement on that.''
 
Open Despite Orders
Under the eyes of enforcement agents, who cited it time after time, the club was able to remain open, buy and sell liquor illegally, and apparently build an illegal second floor without any city approvals and without fire alarms, sprinklers or emergency exits.
At the same time, the club's owner obtained a lease that treated the club as if it were to be operated as a legal tavern, even though residents of the neighborhood knew it was an illegal social club.
The records and interviews with neighborhors and city officials provide the following picture of the club's operation:
* Despite a series of law enforcement actions, including the arrests of three men at the club on charges of selling liquor without a license on Sept. 11, 1988, the club remained in business.
* Seven months after the club was ordered shut by a team of inspectors in November 1988 for building and fire code violations, a police report showed that both the Fire Department and Building Department were notified that it was still in business.
* Although it appears to be a business that charged admission and was open to the public, Happy Land was incorporated in 1988 as a not-for-profit corporation for ''the purpose of providing for members entertainment, sport, recreation and amusement of all kinds.'' The incorporation papers, tax officials said, appeared to enable Mr. Colon to avoid filing state and city income tax forms.
The first official record of Happy Land, a bright red storefront on Southern Boulevard at East Tremont Avenue with a smiling ''happy face'' on its sign, is the seven-year lease between Mr. Colon and Little Peach in October, 1987.
Rafael Camacho, who is listed as an initial director of the Happy Land Social Club corporation, said that he was unaware that he was.
''It was without my consent,'' he said. ''At no time have I signed any papers or anything.'' He said he once put up some wallpaper at the club.
 
Nestled in a Strip
The club is nestled in a strip of 13 stores and medical offices purchased in 1985 by Alex DiLorenzo 3d, a real estate developer whose father was once one of the largest property owners in the city.
Mr. DiLorenzo, real estate officials said, has bought commercial property in good locations in low-income neighborhoods in the past few years. He paid $885,000 for the strip of stores in June 1985.
While these stores are not as profitable as stores in middle class locations, they provide a stream of customers with a steady source of income - public assistance - that is less subject to swings in the economy than middle-class salaries.
Within a few months, Mr. DiLorenzo leased the entire strip to Little Peach for 30 years. Mr. DiLorenzo and Mr. Weiss, whose wife is the actress Kathleen Turner, are in deals involving at least 16 properties in Manhattan, city records show.
 
Combined Two Storefronts
In September, 1987, Queens Apple Realty, an agent for One Peach Associates, an entity related to Little Peach Realty, leased the site to Mr. Colon for seven years.
Local storeowners said Little Peach combined two ten-foot-wide storefronts to accommodate Mr. Colon's club. One of them had once been used for a much smaller social club.
Under the terms of the lease, Mr. Colon's rent went from $1,500 a month the first year to $2,700 the seventh year, plus payments for insurance and taxes.
The lease specifies that the store was to be used as a ''bar and game room'' and specifies that ''the tenant shall not be permitted, under any circumstances to allow any person under the age of 21 years to enter.''
Many of the victims of the fire were less than 21 years old.
In the event that ''any governmental authority,'' complained about the club, the lease gave the landlord the right to evict the club, if it could not quickly correct the problem.
The arrests for illegal liquor sales were made in September, 1988.
Two months later, on Nov. 21, the building was ordered closed for ''imminent danger to safety and life of the occupants.'' The order said the building had no second exit, no fire alarm or sprinkler system, and no emergency lighting.
In May 1989, the landlord sought to evict Mr. Colon because he owed more than $3,000 in back payments. At no time was the question of an emergency vacate order or serious health or safety violations raised.
 
DiLorenzo Told of Violations
A landlord would not normally have been informed of the arrests, city officials said.
The New York City Building Commisioner, Charles D. Smith Jr., said yesterday that notice of the violations was sent to Mr. DiLorenzo, who was on the city's records as the owner of the property. Real estate operators say the building owner would typically pass such notices along to the next leaseholder, who would take them up with the tenant.
Mr. Weiss's attorneys said they never received a formal notice of the violations, but would not say whether they knew about them.
Carlos Negron, the owner of Neighborhood Video, around the corner from the social club, said that last May, at a time when the club was supposed to have been closed, he paid $500 to hold a party at the club.
During the party, he said, the second floor shook and partly fell.
He said Mr. Colon subsequently replaced the entire second floor, redid the dance floor and put in new lights.
No second floor for that building seems to appear on the certificate of occupancy for the strip.
But the owners of the club may never bear liability for the deaths. To prove criminal liability, state legal officials said, a prosecutor would have to show that a landlord knew firsthand about illegal conditions and either helped create them or deliberately allowed them to continue.
Civil liability is easier to show, they said. A jury in a negligence lawsuit might find, for example, that a landlord had reason to know of dangerous conditions and failed to act.
New details also surfaced yesterday showing how the efforts of a city task force to shut down dangerous social clubs faltered.
The Sept. 11, 1988 arrests for illegal liquor sales were the fourth time the task force took action against the club.
On Nov. 21, the building was ordered closed because it was unsafe.
On July 24 1989, seven months after the club was ordered shut, a bartender was arrested by a police officer of the Public Morals Division on charges of selling liquor without a license.
The police report, which was sent to the Fire Buildings Departments, noted that the club was operating in violation of the earlier vacate order.
 
Opened Only for Parties
Yet no further action appears to have been taken. The club was inspected again on Nov 1, 1989, a weekday, and police found it closed. But neighborhood residents said it often closed, or open only for private parties.
Mr. Smith, the Building Commissioner, said that his department responded at all hours to reports of building emergencies, but not to complaints about social clubs.
He said building inspectors only went to social clubs as part of the Koch administration-era task force administered by the Police Department, because inspectors feared for their safety.
The bartender arrested last July, Santos Batiz, a 48-year-old buildling superintendent, said yesterday that he had not been a regular employee and was helping out during a celebration following a soccer game.
''The owner told me one time he was going to get a license,'' he said.
