HEADLINE: Fire in the Bronx;
Hondurans Lack Place to Grieve Over Fire

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
Honduran authorities were told yesterday that more than 60 of the 87 people killed by the fire in a cramped Bronx social club were their countrymen, and in Tegucigalpa the President declared a day of national mourning.
But for the tens of thousands of Hondurans who live in New York, there was no suitable place to share their grief.
Unlike more established groups in the city like Dominicans and Puerto Ricans, hundreds of thousands of Colombians or even the relatively few Argentines, the Hondurans have established no landmarks of their presence - no bars, no prominent Honduran restaurants, no predominantly Honduran churches.
Over the years, they have often gathered in small civic groups, but those have tended to dissolve more quickly and easily than they have formed. Amid the bands and dancers and floats of different countries at last year's Columbus Day parade the Honduran representatives were a flag-bearer and four older men who walked alongside. 
Young Honduran men were something of an exception: they came together every Sunday, in soccer clubs that bear the names of towns and favorite teams from their homeland's especially poor Caribbean coast.
Last year, the Happy Land Social Club sponsored one of the teams, and Honduran players from around the league based at Van Cortland Park in the Bronx lavished the club with business. It became their place, the players said, and the salsa, merengue and calypso music played to their tastes.
When leaders of the teams met last night to plan some sort of memorial for the at least 17 players who were killed in the fire, they had to borrow a room from the Cuban Interamerican Club.
''There are many of us, but we are all scattered,'' said Juan Ramon Cisneros, a Honduran journalist who came to the United States 20 years ago from San Pedro Sula, the country's second city. ''And a lot of us get together in each others' houses because there's no place that's decent.''
Like many older Honduran immigrants, Mr. Cisneros said he did not consider the Happy Land a place for ''good people.'' The younger generations, both young and more newly arrived, strongly disagreed.
''It was a very pleasant place,'' said a 23-year-old Honduran man who identified himself only as Mario, and he told detectives he had left the club on Sunday morning not long before the fire started. ''Maybe somebody might punch somebody else, but it would start and end right there.''
What generally kept the Happy Land under control, many of its patrons insisted, was the fact that it tended to fill each weekend with natives of the same stretches of the same impoverished country.
They have come since the turn of the century, when the well-to-do arrived on business with the American banana companies that dominated their republic, and the more desperate sought a share of the wealth that seemed so much more abundant here.
In the last decade their flow has quickened, as mismanagement, corruption and the neighboring wars of Nicaragua and El Salvador have drained the Honduran economy more quickly than $1.1 billion in United States economic aid could shore it up.
Salvador Rodezno, minister-counselor of the Honduran Embassy in Washington, said he believed that about 50,000 Hondurans of varying immigration status now live in the greater New York area. A spokeswoman for the city's Planning Commission, Martha Ritter, said about 25,000 Hondurans believed to reside legally in the city, most in the East New York section of Brooklyn and the Bronx.
''More than anything, they have come looking for a better life, better standards of living, a better education,'' said Arturo Flores, a former president of the Honduras-New York Society, one of the civic associations that have come and gone.
Almost since its independence in 1838, Honduras has been the hardest spot on a hard-luck isthmus. While tiny El Salvador to the south and Nicaragua to the southeast grew more valuable coffee and cotton, Honduras grew bananas. And it exported them at the prices that all-powerful American fruit companies cared to pay.
 
Struggling Economy
When Honduras has been able to afford finer things, it has generally had to import them, to what its few artists and intellectuals complain has been the detriment of an already meager national culture.
Honduras still jostles Haiti and Bolivia to avoid distinction as the hemisphere's poorest nation. But in a region that has always struggled under the weight of American commercial culture, Tegucigalpa has perhaps the highest distribution of Dunkin' Donuts shops per capita in Central America.
The Happy Land, its patrons said, was like many of the attractions that draw young Hondurans here. It might not have seemed like much to those better off or to those who have been in the United States longer. Still, most of the young Honduran patrons said that by the standards of the crumbling brick nightclubs that dot the north coast of Honduras, where they came from, it was quite a place.
Occasionally, the club's owners would get a few cases of Nacional or Salvavida, two of Honduras's four brands of beer. But most of its Hondurans visitors were happy to drink Budweiser and Heineken, several regular patrons said.
 
'He Grabbed Life Here Too Fast'
Jose Diaz, a 29-year-old Bronx factory worker whose father grows bananas near the small northern town of Potrerillo, said that he had tried on Saturday night to convince his nephew, Jose Alexis Diaz, 19, that the Happy Land was not only not so great, it was probably dangerous.
''He grabbed life here too fast,'' the uncle said. ''In Honduras he didn't make enough money to do all these things you do here.''
Standing nearby, outside a schoolhouse adopted by the American Red Cross as a disaster relief headquarters, the Honduran Consul, Norma Mejia, was telling reporters that the newly inaugurated Honduran President, Rafael Leonardo Callejas, on Monday declared a day of national mourning. With some help from donors, she was saying, Honduras would fly the bodies of its dead home for burial.
From the crowd around her, the unsteady hand of an older man thrust forward a $10 bill.
''Diez pesos de un puertorriqueno,'' Jose Suco, 66, told the aristocratic-looking diplomat, meaning ''Ten bucks from a Puerto Rican.''
Then Mr. Suco walked away, as quickly as he could, it seemed. An onlooker stopped him as he approached his car and asked about the donation.
''I live on a pension and Social Security,'' he said. ''But for these things there is always enough. And God always pays you back.''

HEADLINE: Job Hoppers Take Losses On Housing

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CONVENT STATION, N.J.

 BODY:
Just as housing prices here rose in step with the metropolitan region's economy through the mid-1980's, they are stumbling now that the economy has slowed and businesses are trimming back.
As long as the economy remains in a slump, housing experts say, demand will remain comparatively soft, keeping a lid on prices. Lower mortgage interest rates might help, but not much. In the meantime, they say, home sellers will be hurt the most, particularly corporate employees whose relocations here, a wealthy suburban neighborhood near Morristown, in the last decade helped drive up the prices. 
Housing and the economy have always been related, but experts say the 1980's were extraordinary. When the economy in the metropolitan region was churning out new jobs at rates much higher than the long-term average, so many more people with so much more money were chasing after homes that prices rose at a startling 2 to 3 percent a month.
But now that fewer jobs are being created, demand has slackened throughout the region and brokers say prices have flattened or, in some instances, dropped as much as 30 percent.
 
On the Market Longer
While that may be good news for potential buyers, a lack of optimism that values will rise soon prompts them to keep their price ranges conservative. Houses stay on the market months longer than before, and inventories of unsold homes have swelled.
''The scale and growth of jobs after the 1981-1982 recession, and the scale of corporate in-migration of employees, essentially drove the surge in housing prices,'' said James W. Hughes, a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University who has studied the region's housing prices.
''They were extremely powerful forces in the housing market because they tended to erode any market discipline,'' he said.
Now, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, ''Economic growth is the vital missing ingredient in these areas. The absence of growth is enough to create a shakeout in the real-estate market.''
Besides the connection between job growth and house prices, there is a belief among some in the industry that corporate relocations were at the leading edge of the price strides of the 1980's. In real estate, as in horse racing, they say, the pace is set by the leaders.
Real-estate brokers throughout the region have concluded that transferred executives are the most motivated of buyers: They shop with substantial benefits from their corporate employers, who are eager to satisfy prized workers and get them back behind their desks as quickly as possible.
When there were many new jobs but few available houses in the mid-1980's, transferees paid top dollar for the house of their dreams. That tended to pump up the price of housing because one high-priced sale became the comparable basis for others in the same neighborhood.
''Then the sky was the limit,'' said Marion J. Beatty, corporate relocation coordinator with Weichert Relocation Company in Morristown. ''Relocating buyers would do the maximum; they would buy more house, go to the higher price range. It was a gangbuster market.''
 
Paying for Generosity
But analysts say the corporations may have shot themselves in the foot by being so generous. Prices soared so high that recent surveys show that employees do not want to come into the region, citing housing costs.
Anyone trying to sell a house in today's market feels pinched, but some of those hurting the most are the same workers who were transferred here at the peak of the market.
In 1982 David J. Romeiko was transferred from BellSouth in Atlanta to A.T.&T. in New Jersey and bought a house in Morristown for $152,000. When he decided to move to a condominium in 1988, he sold the house for $350,000.
In February 1988 Mr. Romeiko, who is now 42 years old, bought a three-bedroom town house in the Liberty Greens complex in Convent Station for $224,000. Six months later a similar home in the same complex sold for $259,000.
 
Loss on Condominium
Late last year Mr. Romeiko learned he was being transferred back to Atlanta. He listed his condominium at $229,000, $5,000 more than he had paid.
After a month, not a single offer had come in. He has reduced the price to $205,000 but is not optimistic. He said he may take the price the company offers, which, based on independent appraisals, will be less than $205,000.
''I hate to think I lost $60,000, but if you look at the potential, that was probably the case,'' Mr. Romeiko said.
Geoffrey A. Gardner of Glen Rock, N.J., also will be hurt. Mr. Gardner, an engineering manager in the marine and power division of the Alfa Laval Company in Fort Lee, N.J., relocated to New Jersey in 1981. Now he is being transferred to Warminster, Pa. He thought he could sell his four-bedroom colonial for about $350,000, but his real-estate agent convinced him it would not sell for more than $299,000, the price at which it is now listed.
 
'You Just Don't Have Control'
''Our house was worth more a couple of years ago, I'm sure,'' said Mr. Gardner, who is 40. ''You just don't have control over these things.''
Some of the larger relocation companies in the metropolitan region report that the number of transferees coming in has dropped by 30 percent since the mid-1980's. PHH Homequity of Wilton, Conn., fell 26 percent, to 903 last year from 1,225 in 1985. RELO, the International Relocation Network, which covers 1,400 real-estate companies across the country, showed decreases of 21 percent in New Jersey, 30 percent in New York and 37 percent in Connecticut from 1985 to 1989.
However, some smaller companies have increased their relocation business. William Pitt Real Estate Limited Partnership in Stamford, Conn., showed a 30 percent increase in incoming business from 1986 to 1989. The Julia B. Fee Real Estate Company in Scarsdale has grown by about half in the same period.
It is impossible to tell which set more accurately represents the current picture because there are no figures available on the number of job relocations throughout the region.
 
A.T.&T. Still Relocates Many
Corporations generally are reluctant to discuss personnel matters. But based on the experience of one of the largest private employers in the region, A.T.&T., relocations continue no matter what the state of the economy might be.
Relocation figures from A.T.&T. in New Jersey, where the corporation has 51,500 employees, show that in 1987 1,416 employees were brought into the state. Last year the total was almost the same, 1,366. So far in 1990, 970 relocations have been undertaken.
''The needs of business more than anything else dictate any moves,'' said Lynn M. Newman, a spokeswoman for A.T.&T.

HEADLINE: New York's Budget Squeeze;
Ratings Given by Agencies to Shape Interest Rates for Years

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
When rating agencies assess state and local governments with a letter grade, they are doing more than just issuing an opinion. They are shaping the interest rates governments will pay for years, even decades into the future.
In the case of New York State, which seemed to shun repeated warnings by executives at Standard & Poor's Corporation to bring its budget closer to balance, the rating reduction announced Monday by Standard & Poor's is certain to result in higher interest payments for state bonds and the myriad of state agencies that sell bonds with state backing. 
Higher interest rates on bonds the state sells to pay for long-term projects such as roads, office buildings and environmental projects mean there will be less money available for day-to-day expenses like workers' salaries or education aid payments to hundreds of school districts around the state.
 
Rates Still Rising
Exactly how much interest payments will increase is not known. But early reports from traders on Wall Street are that interest rates for state bonds are still rising after substantial increases earlier this year when the state's budget problems became apparent.
In the first full day of trading after Standard & Poor's cut the state rating to A from AA-, yields on long-term bonds have increased about five-hundredths to seven-hundredths of a percentage point, and prices fell about $6 per $1,000 bond. For state agency bonds, prices fell roughly $7.50. One typical long-term issue, the 7.2 percent issue due in 2020, was offered to small individual investors yesterday at $994.50 per $1,000 bond to yield about 7.25 percent, down from about $1,000 a day earlier.
For 10-year state bonds, yields of 7.10 percent were barely lower than the 7.31 percent yield for a widely watched index of 20 municipal bonds compiled by The Bond Buyer, a trade publication. In June 1988, 10-year state bonds were 6.70 percent, compared with 7.73 percent for the Bond Buyer Index.
 
Significance Assessed
James F. Lynch, president of Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, a newsletter, said, ''The rating cut is more significant for the state agencies whose ratings fell to the triple-B category than for the state.'' He noted that many municipal bond funds do not invest in bonds rated in the triple-B category but do buy bonds in the slightly higher-quality single-A category. State agency bonds typically carry slightly lower ratings than the state's.
Mr. Lynch said yields of 10-year state bonds have risen in the last year by about 35-hundredths of a percentage point relative to 10-year bonds of top-rated states with triple-A ratings. Assuming New York State sells $500 million of bonds this year with an average life of about 10 years, the extra 35-hundredths of a percentage point would raise its interest payments by about $17.5 million over the life of the bonds. But the cost is likely to be far higher because other state agencies will also be paying higher interest rates.
So far, the additional expense of higher interest rates does not loom large in the $51 billion state budget proposed for the coming year.
Assuming that the state and its tax-supported agencies sell $6.6 billion of bonds over the next four years as planned, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said, an increase of 20-hundredths of a percentage point in the state's borrowing costs would increase the interest payments by $180 million over the 25-year life of the bonds.

HEADLINE: New York's Budget Squeeze;
Bond Rating: A Censure of Bickering

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 27

 BODY:
More than just an indictment of the state's finances, the lowering of New York's credit rating on Monday was a censure of its political process.
Two years of procrastination and bickering in Albany, financial analysts say, have allowed what were once manageable problems to approach a fiscal crisis.
Over the last few weeks, when the need to stem the crisis was becoming increasingly clear, instead of coming up with a concerted plan, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the state's legislative leaders reacted with partial solutions and partisan debate.
''What the rating agencies look at is: Is there a rational plan to deal with the problem and is there a mood within the executive and the legislature to solve it?'' Gerald H. Miller, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers, said. Among New York lawmakers, he said, ''there doesn't seem to be any willingness to deal with things.'' 
 
Lowered by Two Notches
On Monday, one of the nation's two leading credit-rating agencies, Standard & Poor's, signaled that it had effectively given up hope on state leaders' ability to produce a sound financial plan. The agency lowered New York's long-term bond rating two notches even as budget negotiations for the fiscal year that starts on Sunday were still in progress.
The new rating, an A, is the lowest in the state's history.
In a statement explaining the rating, analysts at Standard & Poor's said they were distressed by the state's recurring deficits and the failure of state leaders to agree even on the size of the problem. The analysts cited the ''absence of a credible plan'' to address the problem as another reason for the downgrading.
Hyman Grossman, a managing director at Standard & Poor's, said Governor Cuomo had called him after the new rating was announced and accused him of changing the rating in response to newspaper editorials.
''I said, 'You told us last year you would fix things, and you did not,' '' Mr. Grossman said. ''The problem's just gotten worse.''
 
An Operating Deficit
New York's current financial fix had its beginnings in 1988, when a month after a new state budget had been approved, Mr. Cuomo announced that tax collections were falling hundreds of millions of dollars short of expectations. The Governor lowered his revenue estimates twice more that year, and the state ended the fiscal year with a $1.1 billion operating deficit.
At that time, Cuomo administration officials attributed the shortfall to changes in the Federal tax code, which, they said, had produced an unexpectedly sharp drop in tax revenues from capital gains.
But in 1989 the pattern began all over again. The administration lowered its revenue estimates every few months, this time linking the problem to an unexpected downturn in the economy. The Governor proposed a plan for making up only a small part of the revenue shortfall through spending cuts, and the state is expected to end the 1989-90 fiscal year, which closes March 31, with an operating deficit of at least $600 million.
The state's accumulated deficit, which it rolls over from year to year, is expected to grow to $5 billion, a rise of 50 percent over the last three years.
Even as the state was running up larger and larger deficits over the last three years, the Republicans who control the State Senate were accusing Governor Cuomo of exaggerating New York's fiscal problems. They loudly condemned his proposals to raise new tax revenues (although they voted for many of them) and they seemed almost to relish the state's troubles as a way to embarrass Mr. Cuomo.
In January of this year, when Mr. Cuomo proposed his budget for the fiscal year that starts Sunday, financial analysts were already skeptical about Albany's capacity to put aside partisan differences and impose fiscal balance. The events since then, as Monday's lowering of the credit rating shows, has only reinforced that skepticism.
By February, Mr. Cuomo's proposed $51 billion spending plan had developed a hole, which was the result, administration officials said, of yet another unexpected drop in tax collections. But many financial analysts, including Mr. Grossman of Standard & Poor's, say they believe the Governor's proposed budget never was really balanced.
''We said back in January the revenue projections were too optimistic,'' Mr. Grossman said. By mid-March, the hole in the Governor's budget had grown by most estimates to $1.5 billion. Mr. Cuomo never presented a detailed plan to close the gap, saying it would be easier to move the recalcitrant Senate Republicans by negotiating the plan in private.
That tactic, however, met with only limited success. Until early this morning, the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, refused even to acknowledge the size of the budget gap. And now that he has agreed on the size of the gap, he is still reluctant to discuss the new taxes that both the Governor and the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, say will be needed to close the hole.
As the Governor and legislative leaders continue to wrangle, the state's April 1 budget deadline is drawing nearer. Despite repeated assurances from Mr. Cuomo and the legislators, it now appears that a new budget will not be approved in time.
''My assumption is that Standard & Poor's watched patiently for the state to put its fiscal house in order,'' said Cindy Green, a senior analyst at the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group. ''And while the state leaders said they would put the house in order, they did not, and their doing so is not in sight.''

HEADLINE: Fire in the Bronx;
Unlawful Clubs Posing Hazards In Other Cities

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 27

 BODY:
From seedy speakeasies called ''blind pigs'' in Detroit to chic underground clubs in Los Angeles, unlicensed nightclubs pop up in cities around the country, local officials say.
Interviews with fire officials across the nation after the fire that killed 87 people at the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx on Sunday indicate that the problem probably is worse in New York than in other cities. Outside of New York there are more possibilities for informal social gatherings in homes or backyards.
Officials in some cities say their enforcement is vigorous enough so they do not have a problem with illegal clubs. But others say that, especially for the poor, there is always some incentive to bypass the letter of the law and the safety standards that go with it. 
 
Activity Hard to Gauge
''In any large city with a culturally diverse population that includes many immigrants, you will have an illegal club problem,'' said Garry Briese, executive director of the International Association of Fire Chiefs.
By definition, the extent of illegal club activity is impossible to gauge. Some communities that would seem vulnerable, like Miami and Houston, say they are not aware of any problems.
''I don't think it's a problem here,'' said Robert Crossman, deputy fire marshal for the City of Miami, where there was only one fatal fire in the entire city last year. ''One difference between here and New York is that people have backyards, they have more options for socializing than up there, where people have to do something inside.''
But in other cities officials admit informal clubs are a part of life.
In Chicago's predominantly Puerto Rican Humboldt Park community, there are more than 50 social clubs, of which nearly half operate without liquor licenses, said Alderman Luis Gutierrez. Most are in ground-floor storefronts of apartment buildings and have a small bar, a band and room for socializing and games, like dominoes.
 
Safety a Standard Concern
''We should check them out for fire safety,'' Mr. Gutierrez said. ''The exits on these places don't conform to regulations, and in most places in this neighborhood, there are a lot of bars on the doors and back gates.''
But he added that he did not see the potential for a disaster like the one in New York. ''There is no establishment where 150 people go,'' he said.
In Detroit, officials say they wage an unrelenting battle to contain small, unlicensed drinking spots known as blind pigs.
''We constantly close down those type of facilities as often as they open,'' said Christopher Buck, a spokesman for the Detroit police. ''Sometimes that proves to be fruitless, because there are more of them than their are of us.''
In Los Angeles the illegal club business flourishes at the upper end of the economic spectrum. Promoters complain that tough occupancy standards and regulations have led some people to operate clubs illegally in warehouses or vacant buildings.
 
'I Needed the Money'
''I myself have always been very concerned with the number of exits in a space we plan to use for a club,'' said Keith Merryman, a 25-year-old entrepreneur who has organized and managed unlicensed spots, commonly known as underground clubs, in Los Angeles. ''But there are clubs I've worked that I know are potential fire hazards, but I needed the money, so I worked regardless. The fire in New York definitely has stimulated some thought.''
The fire in New York has prompted some responses in other communities. In Miami, Mr. Crossman said officials planned to increase random inspections at nightclubs instead of just responding to complaints. In Chicago, Mayor Richard M. Dailey said he planned to intensify the pace of inspections and begin inspections on weekends, when many of the clubs are open.
Still, the National Fire Protection Association says only a small portion of the fire deaths annually in the United States occur in clubs.

HEADLINE: Using Self-Esteem To Fix Society's Ills

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
IT is being called a vaccine against drug abuse, teen-age pregnancy, welfare dependency and other social ills. But some experts are calling it little more than yet another ''feel good'' approach to life's travails.
At issue is the age-old concept of self-esteem, defined by the Second College Edition of Webster's New World Dictionary as ''belief or pride in oneself.'' But the California Task Force to Promote Self-Esteem and Personal and Social Responsibility reported recently that there's a lot more to it than that.
Make people feel better about themselves and the whole nation will benefit: that is the message of the task force, a 25-member commission of unpaid volunteers formed in 1986 to explore self-esteem among Californians. Employees will then become more productive, teen-agers will be less destructive, crime will decrease and welfare recipients will move toward financial self-sufficiency. 
There are few scientific data to buttress this view, nor is there agreement on how self-esteem is nurtured, harmed or rehabilitated. Skeptics are also concerned that the emphasis on self-esteem glosses over deep social problems and the necessity for more complex solutions. Nonetheless, the self-esteem movement is taking hold across the country.
Hundreds of school districts have added self-esteem motivational materials to their curriculums. American employers have turned increasingly to consultants who say they can raise employees' morale and work performance through self-esteem techniques. New companies have formed, devoted to teaching on self-esteem themes, and hundreds of books on self-esteem and self-enhancement have been published.
At a recent daylong self-esteem seminar in Sacramento run by Jack Canfield, a former schoolteacher and the founder of Self-Esteem Seminars in Los Angeles, 30 teachers were led through a series of motivational exercises that began with the students massaging their classmates' shoulders, to relax the group and create a bond.
Then, in small groups, they did ''E.R.O.'' exercises: they made up events (E), demonstrated their responses (R) and explained the outcomes (O) that would arise from their responses. They were also encouraged to recall successes in their lives dating from childhood or to describe the highlights of their lives in five minutes. The teachers attending the seminar use the techniques with their own students.
''It's pretty intense,'' said Mr. Canfield. Each seminar runs about seven hours and includes video and audiotapes as well as kinesthetics. ''All of these exercises are the foundations of raising self-esteem and building strength.'' In addition to California, 10 states are considering establishing self-esteem task forces.
''It's been a remarkable shift in this movement since I first got involved in 1984,'' said John Vasconcellos, the California Assemblyman who sponsored the bill to establish the task force. He attributed the growing interest to widespread frustration. ''People are exasperated,'' he said. ''Nothing else has worked, so they're willing to listen to new proposals.''
The things done in the name of self-esteem can take many forms:
* Students in social studies and English in San Antonio are being graded not only on subject matter, but also honesty, truthfulness, kindness, courage and conviction.
* Recovering alcoholics and drug users in Philadelphia are practicing breathing techniques said to ease stress, depression and anxiety, which can badly damage self-esteem.
* Welfare mothers in Cumberland County in New Jersey are consulting I.A.L.A.C. flashcards (the acronym stands for I Am Lovable and Capable). The cards were developed by Mr. Canfield.
* Selected prisoners in California are mapping out productive incarcerations with ''facilitators'' and videotaped lectures on goals.
In his self-esteem course at Apollo High School in Simi Valley, Calif., Geoff Schofield was taught such maxims as, ''It doesn't matter what you do, but who you are.''
''It helped me a great deal,'' said Mr. Schofield, who is 21 years old now and is an apprentice plumber. He is not upset that his friends are swapping campus-life stories while he is fixing sinks. ''I'm learning a skill and I'm earning money,'' he said.
But many researchers and social scientists say self-esteem is being oversold. ''There is among academics a lack of consensus about how to define it and how to measure it,'' said Martin Ford, an associate professor of education at Stanford University who has done extensive research on self-esteem and confidence. ''Therefore, it's difficult to make strong statements about techniques or interventions to enhance self-esteem.''
Most skeptics say the principles of self-esteem can do no harm, but they add that they worry that supporters are promoting it at the expense of other social goals.
''We certainly are for self-esteem; it's a good thing for kids, particularly, to have confidence in themselves,'' said Gary Bauer, the president of the Family Research Council in Washington and a leading voice for conservative family values. ''We do feel, however, that there are a lot of odd things going on out there in the name of self-esteem. And in some cases, self-esteem degenerates into just another form of almost selfishness.''
Roger Wilkins, a professor of American history and culture at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., expressed another concern: ''For those born into or living in situations where there is no stability, or where the only successful people are criminals, self-esteem isn't going to do it for them.''
There is also a sense that the haste with which the idea is taking hold has spawned a gold-rush atmosphere in which people with dubious credentials - former convicts, say, or fashion models - are hanging out shingles as self-esteem specialists.
''It's not necessarily bad,'' said Dr. Ford of Stanford, who is a developmental and educational psychologist. ''The more nurturing and helpful people you have in life the better.
''But often those who do the best self-esteem promotion in this society are not those with specialized credentials, but those who are caring, concerned and competent parents, teachers and employers of society.''
Another concern is that self-esteem programs are papering over the friction that occurs in an increasingly diverse population with conflicting views, and even infringing on personal liberties.
When several California companies tried three years ago to motivate employees through meditation, self-hypnosis, inducements to trancelike states or instructions to visualize certain events, they were met with union resistance and threatened with lawsuits from employees who said the techniques were alien to their religious views.
''The new-age philosophy may have been contrary to an employee's own religious views or personal philosophies,'' said Curtis E. Plott, the executive vice president of the Society for Training and Development, an association of training professionals in Alexandria, Va. ''Employers are discovering, however, that self-esteem training that assists employees in recognizing their skills, dealing with their own limitations and understanding their emotional abilities to cope with stress, change and criticism is necessary because they are hiring from a limited professional labor pool, women, minorities and new immigrants, who may need help in enhancing their self-esteem.''
A survey of 200 companies among the Fortune 500 that was conducted last year by Mr. Plott's organization found that 42 were offering self-esteem training.
Black Americans, who many sociologists and psychologists say are more likely to suffer from low self-esteem because of racism, give self-esteem programs mixed reviews.
''I'm all for self-esteem,'' said Charles Joyner, 22, a student at Fordham University. Mr. Joyner, who is black, has written a paper on self-esteem among black men.
''But I'm concerned that some of the self-esteemers are imposing mainstream American values on our kids without stressing the African culture. So you end up with kids who don't think they are worth anything, unless they have a fancy car or gold jewelry.''
Some analysts connect the quest for self-esteem with economic and social trends that have seemed to make life in the United States both harsher and more materialistic.
''The materialism of the 1980's stemmed from a terrible vacuum of identity,'' said Laurence Shames, the author of ''The Hunger for More: Searching for Values in an Age of Greed'' (Times Books, 1989). ''Possessions can't provide meaning, a sense of identity,'' he said. ''And they certainly can't provide a solid base for self-esteem.''
Self-esteem grabbed headlines in 1986, when the California task force was alloted $735,000 in state money. At the time, many people dismissed it as a California fad. Garry Trudeau lampooned the group in his ''Doonesbury'' comic strip.
The concept, however, had played an important social role years before. In the Brown v. Board of Education case, which struck down segregation in public schools in 1954, the Supreme Court cited the ''dolls tests'' conducted by Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the black sociologist and psychologist.
In the tests, young black children were shown both black and white dolls and asked which they preferred. A majority chose the white dolls. In its opinion, the Court said the children had ''definitely been harmed in the development of their personalities.''
For scholars, the self-esteem movement has roots that reach back more than a century. Dr. Donald Meyer, a professor of American history at Wesleyan University, traced the tradition of positive thinking to a period of psychological malaise after the Civil War and found its seeds in American Protestantism. Among the figures he included in his book ''The Positive Thinkers'' (Pantheon, 1965) are Mary Baker Eddy, Dale Carnegie and the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale.
Today, some self-esteem exercises seem to echo the drills, complete with yoga techniques, prescribed in the ''success'' handbooks popular just after the turn of the century. In 1922, Dr. Emile Coue began national fads in England and the United States with his motto ''Day by day, in every way I get better and better.'' His work regained popularity in 1961, at the dawn of the current ''human potential'' movement. But for many the self-esteem concept remains a riddle. Were ninth graders at Grant Union High School in Sacramento, Calif., reading at a fifth-grade level because they had low self-esteem, or were their reading problems contributing to their poor self-image?
''I don't know the answer,'' said Richard Owen, the principal at Grant Union. ''But don't just say, 'They don't like themselves,' and that's it. Teach them how to read and write properly, and they'll feel better about themselves.''

HEADLINE: DE GUSTIBUS;
Winter Strawberry: Its Life and Its King

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

DATELINE: PLANT CITY, Fla.

 BODY:
PLANT CITY calls itself the ''Winter Strawberry Capital of the World,'' and Robert E. (Roy) Parke is its undisputed king.
Of the 5,000 acres of strawberries under cultivation in this town 15 miles east of Tampa, 250 belong to Mr. Parke. For the last 25 years, his strawberries have been the Grand Champion of the Florida Strawberry Festival, held in Plant City during the first two weeks of March. Even his competitors say the 69-year-old grower knows everything there is to know about the strawberries that brighten winter produce counters across the United States and in Europe. 
Mr. Parke has built a life of winter berries. He has studied and cultivated enough strawberries to know how to grow the size, shape color and taste that please him and thrill ''the housewife up north.'' Along the way his erudition became the strawberry esthetic by which he lives.
His prizes are different from the thimble-sized, purple-red strawberries that grow wild during the summer in the north. The wild summer berries return year after year, even if untended, producing successively smaller and more intensely flavored fruit. The strawberries from Mr. Parke's Parkesdale Farms are generally closer in size to a golf ball and are scarlet. ''You want something smaller than a baseball and bigger than a pea,'' Mr. Parke said.
He also wants a high yield, so he sets new seedlings every fall and relies primarily on three varieties. Selva, which ripens before Christmas, is tart and has very little in common with its wild cousins. Pajaro, a slightly sweeter berry, begins to ripen in January. The Osso Grande variety that Mr. Parke describes as ''the sweetest berry we know, the Cadillac of your winter berry,'' begins to ripen in December, is at its peak now and will remain in grocery stores until mid-April, when the California crop begins to appear.
The three varieties look alike: fat, red and beautiful. But berry to berry, they seldom taste the same. Their flavor ranges from bitter to jam-sweet. In texture, they can be as taut as well-developed biceps, or as tender as a sunburned cheek. As soon as a connoisseur pledges never again to fall for the chubby red charms of a winter strawberry, when he swears that he cannot bear the betrayal of their ungiving flesh or punishingly tart taste, he will happen upon another in the same pint that is soft and sweet. This sends him off in frenzied pursuit of just one more plump, sweet promise of summer.
The lure of blue skies on a gray day makes lucrative business. Between October and April of last year ''strawberries pumped $162 million into Florida's economy,'' said Mr. Parke, who is a member of the Florida Strawberry Growers Association and was the first inductee into that organization's Hall of Fame. Although he has been the leading exporter of the berries since 1956, the one who first successfully air-freighted winter strawberries to Europe and followed that with regular shipments to New York City, Boston and Philadelphia, Mr. Parke is still confounded by the variation in their flavor. There are, of course, subtle differences among the three varieties. The sugar content of each berry rises and falls with the temperature of the nights and the burn of the Florida sun.
The sugar that ripens and sweetens a berry can also be its demise, Mr. Parke said. A very sweet berry rots faster and, he said, ''won't ship, won't keep.'' Mr. Parke and his wife, Helen, two sons Bobby and Gary and three daughters Cheryl Meeks, Sandee Sytsma and Colleen Fulton do their best bringing up the mercurial berry.
''You have to be a tough breed of cat to be a good strawberry grower in Florida,'' he said. Because the Plant City terrain is so flat, the rows of strawberries are raised to promote drainage and wrapped in black plastic to keep moisture and fertilizers in the sandy soil. Stretching for acres and acres from his ranch-style house, Mr. Parke's fields look like wide-wale corduroy. A sprinkling system helps protect against freezes. The handpicked berries are packed and weighed in mobile sheds which are immediately driven to a packing station, parked in a garage-sized cooling chamber, and cooled to 34 degrees.
''Slows down the sugar,'' Mr. Parke said. But it's no guarantee. ''Some'll be sweeter than others,'' he added. He claims there is no such thing as a perfect berry, even though every single one is ''a beautiful thing to see.''
He maintains a strawberry esthetic in most aspects of his life. He drives a red tractor, frequently wears a red shirt and green cap and has strawberries stenciled on the door of his white pickup truck. Tours of his home begin with the garage, where strawberry prizes and memorabilia and pictures of great moments in strawberry history are all on display.
Inside, every inch of the three-bedroom home is carpeted with thick, strawberry red carpet. There are strawberry pillows and cookie jars and ash trays, needlepoint pictures, place mats and pitchers and all of the wallpaper is strawberries. There is a walk-in closet full of Mrs. Parke's red clothes; her strawberry jewelry is arranged neatly on a dish in the bathroom. There, a few years back, Mr. Parke posed for a magazine photograph in his pink bathtub, covered with strawberries. He looked like the Frank Perdue of strawberries.
Yet his romance with the fruit has an abiding gratitude. Parkesdale Farms started as a 10-acre patch in 1956. Today, it is the largest family-run strawberry farm in the country, Mr. Parke said. He and his family also own Parkesdale Motel (''Gateway to Strawberry Country'') and Parkesdale Farm Market; both are on Route 92. People line up 10 hours a day for bowls of the Parke family's strawberry shortcake at the market.
No one complains about the wait. No one fusses about the difference in taste from berry to berry. Mashed with sugar, ladled on butter-rich cake and crowned with a rococo tower of whipped cream, the berries are part of an irresistible tableau.
Those who understand the nature of winter strawberries know better than to expect them to stand alone. The winning recipes at the festival use strawberries in a celery and yogurt soup; as a counterpoint to a spinach salad; in an omelet with cheese; steamed in pudding; layered in a black bottom pie, or as fondue.
Mr. Parke is intrigued by these uses of his berries. He imagines the dishes taste good: ''I breed for flavor before shipping and keeping,'' but he doesn't know for sure.
''I don't eat strawberries,'' he said with a hint of the Hindu's respect for the holy cow in his voice, as he led a visitor to his backyard to show off his strawberry-shaped swimming pool. ''The berry,'' he said, ''built it all.''

GRAPHIC: photo: For Robert E. (Roy) Parke, strawberries are a way of life. (The New York Times/Susan Greenwood)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Fed vs. Treasury On Dollar's Value

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
EARLIER this month, at a conference in Tokyo, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Manuel H. Johnson, said he was ''not uncomfortable with the current level of exchange rates.'' Hidden in that off-the-cuff comment may be a growing rift between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury Department over the dollar.
Although Mr. Johnson's remarks seemed entirely consistent with those he had uttered in the past, this time the foreign exchange markets reacted by sending the dollar to three-year highs against the yen. Since then, the dollar has climbed even higher, although other factors, like the drop in the Tokyo stock market, have also had an effect. 
The most elementary reading of Mr. Johnson's remarks was that the Federal Reserve was content to hold interest rates firm and would refrain from intervening in the foreign exchange markets. But given the uncertainty in Japan's stock market, a non-interventionist policy would almost certainly drive the dollar higher against the yen, something the Treasury, which is concerned about exports, almost certainly does not want.
Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics in New York, found Mr. Johnson's comments so important that ''I devoted two issues of my newsletter to them.'' Normally, the Fed does not take a position on the value of the dollar. ''It does what it is told by the Treasury,'' Mr. Weinberg said. ''But this remark signals a potential shift in the way the Fed sees itself.''
When the Plaza Hotel accords were negotiated in 1985 to bring down the value of the dollar and stimulate exports, it was the Treasury that worked out the agreement while the Fed sat silent. ''But now it is very explicit that the Fed has a view,'' Mr. Weinberg said.
Policy regarding the dollar is set by the Treasury but executed by the Federal Reserve when it buys or sells foreign currencies in the open market. By law, the Fed must follow the Treasury's instructions even if it disagrees with them. Changes in interest rates, which are the domain of the Federal Reserve, also affect the value of the dollar by making dollar-denominated financial investments more or less attractive to foreign investors. But changes in interest rates have much more of an effect on the domestic economy than operations in foreign exchange markets.
Francis Schott, chief economist at the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and a former economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, also sensed tension between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury hidden in the Johnson remarks. He said that while the Treasury wanted a lower dollar, the Federal Reserve was more concerned about a lower dollar's effect on inflation. ''From the Fed's point of view, a falling dollar raises the prices of imports and adds to inflation,'' he said. ''This means the objectives of the Fed and the Treasury are now at odds with each other. That is why Manny Johnson's remarks are so significant.''
There are other reasons why the Fed is troubled by intervening in foreign exchange markets at the Treasury's behest: ''If the Treasury instructs the Federal Reserve to buy yen, it is the same as the Treasury telling the Fed to create money,'' Mr. Schott said. ''The Fed doesn't like this because it means the Treasury is instructing it to do something that may go against its own policy objectives.''
Conflict between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury may hinge on another element as well. ''I have yet to see a study that shows that sterilized intervention, the most common type of intervention used by the Fed in the foreign exchange markets, has any effect on the value of the dollar at all,'' said Allan H. Meltzer, an economist at Carnegie-Mellon University and co-founder of the Shadow Open Market Committee, which monitors the Federal Reserve's policy decisions. ''But it costs the taxpayers money.''
The Federal Reserve, with holdings of foreign currencies worth only $20 billion, does not have the resources to move the foreign exchange markets, which can trade $500 billion in a single day. ''Of course Mr. Johnson knows this,'' Mr. Meltzer said. ''But the Treasury's position is that it doesn't care if its policy doesn't work. It is intervening in the markets for other reasons.''
Where will the conflict lead? While not every analyst sees the dispute widening, others are clearly worried. Mr. Schott of Equitable said: ''Manny Johnson may be saying that the Fed does not want to buy yen for the Treasury. If he is saying this, it could lead all the way to Congress before it is sorted out. The issue of who controls the dollar must be resolved.''

HEADLINE: Brazilian Loans Decline In International Trading

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The price of Brazilian debt has fallen since the country's new President, Fernando Collor de Mello, announced his tough economic program 12 days ago. But traders in the highly specialized market that deals with such debt say the decline is not a reflection of unhappiness with Mr. Collor's program.
Traders say the declines are a response to the provision in the Brazilian program that freezes more than $100 billion in bank accounts for 18 months, prohibiting various swaps and other kinds of transactions that had been supporting the price of the debt.
''It is more supply and demand than a judgment,'' said Paul A. Masco, a trader with Salomon Brothers in New York. 
''The demand for Brazilian paper is gone,'' added Manuel Mejia, a debt trader at Merrill Lynch.
 
Vulnerable Market
Another debt trader said the decline showed that this small $70 billion market was sometimes more vulnerable to temporary and technical forces than to significant changes in a country's domestic economic policy. It is not easily moved, like the foreign exchange market, by politics and promises.
These traders said the price of Brazilian debt could stay in a very narrow range for some time, perhaps $20 to $25 for each $100 of face value. Getting the price to rise again will require action that directly affects the foreign debt, like a renewal of interest payments by Brazil, they said.
Since the beginning of March, just before Mr. Collor's inauguration, Brazilian debt has fallen from 32.50 cents to the dollar to as low as 19.75 cents last week. Yesterday it was 23.75 cents for each dollar.
Before the freeze was announced there had been some activity in what are called swaps of debt for debt. In effect, the Brazilian central bank would buy existing debt from lenders at a discount and the lenders would use the money to make new loans.
 
'The Ultimate Buyer'
''The central bank was the ultimate buyer of the loans and was holding the price up,'' said a trader who asked not to be identified.
Both Mr. Masco and Mr. Mejia said the announcement last week that Brazil would not resume making interest payments on its debt did not have a big impact on the market because it was expected. Brazil stopped payments on its debt to banks last September. Its total debt is $114 billion, the largest in the developing world.
The fact that a renewal of interest payments and a renegotiation of Brazil's $65 billion in loans with commercial banks could be delayed into next year is helping keep the price down. Another negative is the widespread expectation that Brazil will insist that a large amount of the debt must be reduced in the negotiations.
The debt of two other large Latin American debtors - Mexico and Venezuela - is trading at a much higher level, with Venezuela at 39.75 cents yesterday and Mexico at $39.50 cents. This reflects, in part, the fact that each country has reached an agreement with its commercial bankers to reduce and reorganize its debt.
 
Creating a Demand
In addition, these countries hold out some promise of swaps of existing loans for shares of stock in domestic companies, and this prospect provides a demand for the loans in the secondary market.
''The real demand for the debt is not long-term investment or because an investor thinks Brazilian debt makes sense at 25 cents on the dollar,'' said Mr. Mejia of Merrill Lynch. ''The demand comes when the debt can be used in a project.''
The debt of Argentina, another troubled debtor, is priced even lower than Brazil's and has fallen since the hope of economic reform under the new President, Carlos Saul Menem, evaporated last fall.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees Rapid Movement On Mexican Trade Talks

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
The United States and Mexico are moving more rapidly than expected toward opening negotiations on a free-trade agreement, Administration officials said today.
The decision on starting such talks is likely to be announced in early June when Mexico's President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, visits President Bush in Washington, the Administration officials said.
Such a pact, similar to one already in place with Canada, could lead to a North American common market from the Arctic to the Yucatan, embracing 350 million people.
 
Acceleration of Schedules
An early June announcement would represent a sharp acceleration of earlier schedules for the elimination of Mexican-American trade barriers, an idea that has been discussed on the American side since the early 1980's. 
Deferring to Mexican political sensitivities about closer links with the giant to the north, Washington had not pressed for negotiations.
A statement issued by the Mexican Embassy today said a Mexican team was now ''analyzing possibilities'' to permit Mexican exports to ''reach the stable and growing U.S. market.''
''Once this analysis is concluded,'' it added, ''the governments of both nations will decide the best way to continue deepening their trade relationships.''
The statement followed a report in The Wall Street Journal that Mexican and American leaders had already agreed to negotiate such a pact. ''It cannot be confirmed that a free-trade agreement will be established between both countries, as the above mentioned article affirms,'' the statement added.
 
Younger Leaders a Factor
Now, however, Mexico has younger business and Government leaders who, according to American officials and other analysts, see increased trade, investment and technology flows as essential to strengthening competitiveness and general well-being.
''There is more confidence, more a sense of common interest with the United States and more a feeling that Mexico can be a beneficiary of trade with the United States,'' said Robert E. Herzstein, a former Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade.
Last year Mexico enjoyed a $2 billion trade surplus with the United States and ranks after Canada and Japan as the third-biggest American trading partner.
Also contributing to greater interest in free trade by Mexico is the democratization of Eastern Europe, placing it in competition for the multinational investment capital that Mexico hopes to get through closer economic ties with the United States.
''A free-trade agreement would buy security of access to the American market that would galvanize investment in Mexico,'' said Guy F. Erb, a Washington consultant specializing in Mexican business.
 
Rise in Canadian Spending
The free-trade agreement with Canada, which went into effect Jan. 1, 1989, has led to a robust increase in capital spending in Canada. There has also been agreement to accelerate some tariff cuts that were to be made over a 10-year period.
A Canadian Embassy spokesman, Malcolm McKechnie, said his Government would follow Mexican-American negotiations ''with interest'' and seek ''assurances Canadian interests were safeguarded.''
During his Washington visit, President Salinas will address the June l1 annual meeting of the Business Roundtable, a group of 200 chief executives of the biggest American companies. A Business Roundtable working group, headed by Colby H. Chandler, chief executive of the Eastman Kodak Company, is preparing a report on economic relations with Mexico that is expected to be published between now and June.
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today that no agreement existed at this time to negotiate a free-trade agreement, and declined to speculate on what might happen in June. But she insisted that whatever occurred would not affect the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations, which is expected to be concluded next December, well before any free-trade talks would actually begin between Mexico and the United States.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeking Trade Pact

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BONN, March 27

 BODY:
The United States wants the Soviet Union and all participants at a 35-nation economic conference being held here to sign a declaration committing themselves to Western-style free-market principles, United States officials said today.
Among other things, the declaration, called the ''Bonn Principles for Economic Cooperation,'' says the 35 nations recognize the importance of ''international policies which support the expansion of free, open trade, investment and capital flows'' and ''full recognition and protection of rights of citizens to hold and use private property.'' 
A high-ranking Soviet official at the conference, Sergei Zotov, said he supports the idea of setting out principles for East-West economic cooperation, but that the document ''presents more a code of behavior'' for East bloc countries rather than concerning itself with ''purely principles of economic cooperation.'' Mr. Zotov is the deputy head of the Soviet Foreign Ministry's Department of Security and Cooperation in Europe.
The meeting of government officials and business executives began last week and will run through April 11. The 35-nation group includes the United States, Canada and all Eastern and Western European nations except Albania.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Drop Sharply After Comex Limits Buying

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Copper prices plunged yesterday even though there is a growing global shortage of the important industrial metal.
This contradiction of the usual relationship between supply and demand is caused in part by moves taken by the Commodity Exchange in New York to prevent a ''squeeze'' from developing in its spot March copper futures contract, which expires today.
A squeeze develops in a commodity market when the amount of the commodity represented by the number of outstanding contracts exceeds the stockpile of the commodity registered with the exchange. At the close yesterday, 891 March copper contracts were still outstanding, representing about 11,137 tons. But the Comex copper stocks total roughly 3,000 tons. 
To discourage speculation and dampen buying, the Comex began yesterday requiring traders to pay all cash for the March contracts. At yesterday's close, the expiring March copper delivery settled at $1.2165 a pound, down 4.55 cents, which means that the 25,000-pound contract sold for $30,412.50. On its other copper futures contracts, the exchange's margin standard remains unchanged and a trader is required to put up only $1,800 to control a contract.
The March contract set a contract high of $1.33 a pound last Wednesday, after soaring from a low of 95 cents on Jan. 24, as the supply situation became more severe.
''Copper supplies have been falling dramatically since the end of 1989,'' said Frederick R. Demler, minerals economist at Paine Webber Inc. ''For example, Comex copper stocks have dropped to 3,000 tons from 16,000 since Dec. 31. Those on the London Metal Exchange have dwindled to 72,000 tons from 108,000. Copper stocks in the hands of domestic producers are down 37 percent; consumer stocks down 20 percent, and worldwide stocks of the metal are down 70,000 tons since the year began.''
One reason for the tight supplies, Mr. Demler said, is that the domestic economy is stronger than statistics indicate, while foreign industrial activity remains fairly strong. But many industrial copper fabricators were persuaded by forecasts of an economy downturn to reduce their inventories of the metal during the last year or so.
''Meanwhile,'' he noted, ''global supplies have been shrunk by a number of factors such as strikes in Peru, technical problems in Chile, and mines in Papua New Guinea, which promises to be another major copper source, have been shut for almost a year because of terrorist activities.''
Another indication of tightening copper supplies is the rising cost of high-grade No. 1 scrap. Mr. Demler said this grade of scrap copper was no longer selling at discounts to Comex prices. This is a most unusual peacetime situation.
On other futures markets, petroleum futures finished mostly higher on the New York Merc on buying in advance of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventories report. The report, released after the close, showed a larger-than expected increase in United States stocks of crude oil, a greater-than-expected decline in gasoline supplies and drop in heating oil stocks that was within market expectations.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, pork futures fell in reaction to weaker cash markets. Cattle futures retreated slightly in sympathy with the pork price movement.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Gold Prices Recover a Bit As Dollar Continues to Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices rebounded slightly yesterday after a tumultuous plunge Monday that strategists traced to the dollar's strength and abnormally large gold sales from the Middle East.
The late price at the Republic National Bank in New York was $368.85 an ounce, up $2.10 from the previous session.
The dollar finished higher against most major currencies except the British pound yesterday, extending a rally that reflected fears of growing political and economic instability abroad. 
The shaken gold market appeared to stabilize somewhat from its severe beating Monday, when bullion prices plunged as much as $30 an ounce and nearly erased a rally that began six months ago. Some traders said the Monday decline was the worst rout they had seen in years.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose $2.90 a troy ounce, to $368.70. Earlier, gold rose 75 cents an ounce, to $369.25 in London, and rose $6.25 an ounce, to $369.25 in Zurich. It fell $13.10 a troy ounce in Hong Kong, to $370.65.
 
Questions Over Japan
Currency dealers attributed the dollar's rise largely to questions over Japan's ability to manage the country's unwieldy financial markets and other economic problems. They also said the Soviet Union's resolve to suppress Lithuanian independence was unsettling European markets and raising demand for dollars.
''I'm basically a dollar bull, just based on a fundamental assessment of the world situation,'' said Zlatko Glamuzina, chief trader at the Banco di Sicilia's New York branch. ''As a safe haven, I don't think anybody can beat the United States right now.''
The dollar strengthened in Tokyo to 156.96 yen, up from 156.40 Monday. In London, the dollar traded at 157.35 yen and in New York it fetched 157.74 yen, up from 156.70 yen late Monday. The dollar was at the highest level against the yen in more than three years.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Fall in Quiet Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers placed bids on $10 billion worth of new two-year notes - the only real activity of the day.
''We thought the two-year would spark some interest, but even though the auction went well, it wasn't enough,'' said Joe Liro, a vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc. ''We believe there is a lot of money on the sidelines, but at this juncture there is no reason for that money to come in.''
At the auction, the notes were sold at an average yield of 8.59 percent, up from the 8.50 percent average yield at the last two-year note sale on Feb. 21, and the highest yield on a two-year note since the auction last May 24.
As expected, the attractive yields generated strong demand from investors. 
Non-competitive bids for the notes, a good barometer of retail demand, amounted to $1.56 billion for the new notes. It was the largest non-competitive bid since the two-year auction held on April 26. $8 Billion Sale Today Today the Treasury is expected to sell $8 billion worth of new four-year notes. That auction will be followed tomorrow with the sale of $13 billion of 16-day cash management bills.
Late yesterday the four-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.57 percent.
But away from the auction, little was going on.
''There is a general malaise throughout the whole government market, and I don't know what is going to shake us out of it,'' one bond trader said. ''The Fed is on hold, and we are going to have to wait and see what the direction of the economy is, and how the dollar will do against the yen and the mark.''
Yesterday, members of the Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee met in Washington, but Mr. Liro and other analysts said that the central bank gave the market no sign that it had altered its current stance on monetary policy.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered in late trading at a price of 100 3/8, down 3/32, to yield 8.46 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 31/ 32, down 1/32, to yield 8.50 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 26/32, down 1/8 point, to yield 8.53 percent.
 
Three-Month Bills Rise
Treasury bill rates edged higher. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.88 percent, up five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.85 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by three basis points, to a late rate of 7.75 percent.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, prices of outstanding general obligation New York State bonds that were downgraded by Standard & Poor's on Monday fell by 3/4 point to 7/8 point in fairly light trading.
The downgrade, announced late Monday, did not surprise most participants in the municipal bond market, because S.&P. had been issuing progressively negative reports on New York's fiscal prospects since November.
 
New York City Pricing
An indication of how the downgrade might affect debt offerings by New York City will come today, when the city is expected to price a $648 million bond offering.
In advance of the auction, traders said that yields were likely to be well above the securities that the city sold at competitive bid in mid-February.
For example, preliminary price talk was that the five-year bonds to be sold today would yield 7.60 percent. By contrast, in February five-year securities were sold at a yield of 6.80 percent.
A good part of today's offering -roughly $150 million - is likely to be insured, market participants said.
''On the face of it, it would seem that the ratings downgrade won't help the city,'' said one municipal bond trader, who asked not to be identified. ''But yields on city paper have backed up a lot over the last six months, and the Mayor has been coming out and addressing the city's budgetary problems, something that a lot of people were worried he wouldn't do after he was elected. Right now city yields seem extremely attractive.''
Municipal market participants said that away from the New York State sector, prices of most issues in the secondary market were unchanged on the day.
 
Philip Morris Offering
In the new-issue market for investment-grade corporate bonds, the Philip Morris Companies offered $200 million of five-year senior notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The 9.45 percent notes, which are noncallable for three years, were priced at $99.877, to yield 9.481 percent, 95 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/2 percent five-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The notes are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate issues prices of actively traded bonds dipped by about 1/8 point, market participants said.

HEADLINE: Edward Cristy Welsh, Economist And Space Program Pioneer, 81

BYLINE: By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ

 BODY:
Edward Cristy Welsh, an educator and economist who played a leading role in developing the nation's space program, died of a stroke on Sunday at the Charter House nursing home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 81 years old and had lived at the nursing home for two years.
Mr. Welsh was the executive secretary of the National Aeronautics and Space Council, a White House advisory group, from 1961 until his retirement in 1969. He then remained active as a consultant to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. 
As chief staff officer of the space council, Mr. Welsh was principal adviser to the White House and was a strong advocate of increased spending to overcome the early Soviet lead in space. He also helped draft legislation creating the Communications Satellite Corporation.
Earlier, as a legislative aide to Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, he helped draft the legislation that created NASA and the space council in 1958.
 
An Aide to MacArthur
He began his government service in 1937 as an economist with the National Resources Committee and moved to the Temporary National Economic Committee in 1940. In 1942 he became head of the Office of Price Administration's regional office in Cleveland and in 1945 became director of price operations for the agency in Washington.
In 1947 Gen. Douglas MacArthur summoned him to become chief of the antitrust division at Occupation headquarters in Japan. There he broke up the major cartels and reorganized Japan's largest companies.
He returned to Washington in 1950 and served as assistant to Mr. Symington, then as chairman of the National Security Resources Board and later chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. After Mr. Symington was elected to the Senate, Mr. Welsh served as his legislative aide from 1953 until 1961, when he was appointed by President John F. Kennedy to head the Space Council.
Born on March 20, 1909, in Long Valley, N.J., Mr. Welsh earned a Ph.D. in economics in 1940 from Ohio State University, where he taught for eight years.
He is survived by two sisters, Eleanor Jones of Chambersburg, Pa., and Dorothy Vernon of Dunedin, Fla.

HEADLINE: FREE-TRADE TALKS WITH U.S. SET OFF DEBATE IN MEXICO

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 28

 BODY:
In a break with the policy of economic nationalism that has prevailed here since the Mexican Revolution of 1910, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has agreed to consider negotiations for a free-trade agreement with the United States.
The move represents a huge political gamble and has prompted a spirited public debate.
The Bush Administration said Tuesday that the two Governments had begun ''preliminary discussions'' that could lead to a pact similar to one that last year eliminated major trade barriers between the United States and Canada.
But such an agreement, which could pave the way for a North American common market, is extremely controversial here and would also force other Latin American governments to rethink their place in the world. 
 
Elimination of Barriers
Free-trade agreements are intended to eliminate barriers to the flow of goods between the countries involved. These restrictions include quotas limiting the import of goods and services or duties on product shipments. For example, the United States-Canadian free-trade agreement, which went into effect on Jan. 1, 1989, calls for duties to be reduced or eliminated on 8,000 categories of products over the next 10 years. The pact also makes it easier for Americans and Canadians to work in each other's markets.
Since coming to power in 1929, the Institutional Revolutionary Party has emphasized development of the Mexican economy by keeping foreign competition out and subsidizing domestic producers. That model was developed in large part to prevent Mexico and its economy from being swallowed by United States interests, whose extensive acquisition of mines, railroads, oil companies and ranches helped detonate the revolution that the party still claims to defend.
 
Suspicion Still a Force
Over the last decade, a period of crisis marked by stagnation and inflation, Mexico has given up some of its traditional economic isolation by moves like joining the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in 1986. But suspicion of American intentions remains a potent force in Mexican politics, and no candidate for office ever gives a speech without promising to protect the country's ''sovereignty'' and ''independence.''
There is no timetable for talks about formal economic integration between the two countries, Mexican and American officials said, and the obstacles that must be overcome are likely to be formidable. Among the most politically sensitive issues are the immigration of Mexican labor to the United States and American ownership and exploitation of natural resources in Mexico.
In a statement issued Tuesday, the Mexican Embassy in Washington said ''it cannot be confirmed that a free-trade agreement will be established between both countries.'' Nevertheless, the mere fact that such a possibility is now under consideration has generated immediate alarm and concern here.
''Our way of life is at stake,'' a political analyst, Lorenzo Meyer, wrote this morning in Excelsior, Mexico's leading newspaper. ''We should take decisions knowing, as much as is possible, what we will gain and lose by integrating ourselves with the economy of a great power, one from which we previously considered it our historic and patriotic duty to protect and separate ourselves.''
Political parties on both the left, which emerged as the country's second-largest political force in the 1988 elections, and the right have already accused the Salinas administration of rushing too eagerly into Washington's economic embrace and said the North American common market would be a major issue in next year's midterm elections. A columnist, Gaston Garcia Cantu, a fervent nationalist who generally supports Mr. Salinas, recently suggested that what was really at stake was not economic integration but an ''annexation'' similar to that of Texas in 1836 and a betrayal of the rest of Latin America.
 
'Tied to Latin America'
Most Latin American countries appear to believe that the destiny of Mexico lies to its north, not to its south, and that the willingness of Mr. Salinas to consider a free-trade agreement with the United States and Canada left them out in the cold.
''Mexico has always talked about the economic integration of Latin America,'' a South American diplomat here said, ''but they are at the gate of the largest market in the world, and whether they like it or not, economic logic dictates that they associate themselves more closely with that market. It appears they have now reached the same conclusion.''
Like his predecessors, Mr. Salinas, a 41-year-old Harvard-educated economist, initially shunned too close an economic relationship with the United States and sought trade and investment links elsewhere. In an interview in January 1988 after being named the presidential candidate of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, he said that ''I am not in favor'' of any free-trade or common market plan because ''there is such a different economic level between the United States and Mexico.''
But Mexican officials and foreign diplomats here said that since taking office in December 1988, Mr. Salinas had come to question whether Mexico could realistically hope to use Western Europe and Japan as an economic counterbalance to the United States. They say he has been profoundly influenced by recent events in Europe, especially the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe and the decision of the European Community to eliminate all trade barriers in 1992.
 
European 'Fascination' Cited
In late January, Mr. Salinas visited Europe and complained that Western Europe's ''fascination'' with events in the Eastern bloc was resulting in ''a relative lack of attention to other parts of the world.'' A Mexican official said Mr. Salinas was particularly sobered by his meetings with Prime Ministers Helmut Kohl of West Germany and Margaret Thatcher of Britain and his discussions with business executives in both countries.
Mexican officials and foreign diplomats said Mr. Salinas emerged from those contacts with the belief that Mexico could not hope for large flows of European investment during the next few years.
Late in February, the Minister of Commerce and Industry, Jaime Serra, and Mr. Salinas's chief economic adviser, Jose Cordoba, agreed to discuss a unified North American market further while in Washington for talks on other matters.
 
Bank Debt Converted
Approximately $44 billion of Mexico's commercial bank debt was converted into bonds yesterday, the Mexican Government and Citibank announced. William R. Rhodes, Citibank's senior executive-international, said the transaction was the largest long-term bond issue ever.
Also yesterday, Mexico received $370 million in its first drawdown of some $1.1 billion in new money provided by the agreement.
The 30-year bonds were issued as part of an agreement Mexico worked out with its bank lenders last year and signed earlier this year.
The agreement covered virtually all of the $48.5 billion in medium- and long-term debt that Mexico owes to 470 banks worldwide. Under the plan, the banks chose between making new loans to Mexico or exchanging their debt for bonds on terms that reduce Mexico's debt burden by 35 percent.
