HEADLINE: ATOM BOMB PARTS SEIZED IN BRITAIN EN ROUTE TO IRAQ

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
Six people were arrested in Britain today in what American and British officials said was an attempt to smuggle electronic devices used to trigger nuclear weapons to Iraq.
Triggering devices that had been disarmed and other electronic equipment that has military uses were seized in the raids in Britain today, the officials said.
The officials said the moves capped an 18-month undercover investigation that has already produced a sealed indictment, returned by a Federal grand jury in San Diego, describing a scheme in which several foreign nationals tried to smuggle out of the United States through England small electronic devices that were said to be required by Iraqi officials for building nuclear weapons.
 
Some Are Charged
Some of the six people arrested in London have been charged in the indictment while others have not, officials said. They identified one of those arrested, Ali Ashour Daghir, as the leader of the smuggling ring. The names and nationalities of the others were not divulged, but officials said they included citizens of Iraq, Britain and Lebanon. 
American officials said the investigation began after a CSI Technologies, a California company, informed the United States Customs Service that a British company had been inquiring about obtaining devices called capacitors. The devices, not much larger than a matchbox, have many uses in industry, but the British company, called Euromac, was seeking a type of capacitor that clearly was for military use, most probably to detonate a nuclear warhead.
The British and American authorities said what followed was a long and complex charade as they lured the British company's officials - Mr. Daghir among them - into a trap, promising delivery of the devices while gathering evidence on the company and its connections to Iraq. [Page A14.] The case adds fuel to the debate over Iraq's weapons programs, including a suspected program to build a nuclear bomb. But because of the secrecy surrounding the case, many questions remain unanswered, including details of the criminal charges and the exact status of Iraq's weapons programs.
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today: ''This issue raises once again our concern for the nuclear proliferation in the Middle East. It continues to pose a serious risk to U.S. interests, and it continues to exacerbate regional problems.''
Abdul Rahmen Jamril, the press attache at the Iraqi Embassy here, said that he knew nothing about the case but that Iraq was ''not developing nor does it intend to develop any nuclear capacity.''
One complication is that law officials who know the details of the case have not shared a lot of their information with intelligence and nuclear experts who are more familiar with Iraq's weapons programs.
 
A Puzzling Factor
Some of the devices sought by the Iraqis, capacitors, are particularly well suited for triggering nuclear explosions. This puzzles some intelligence experts who believe that Iraq's program lacks crucial supplies of plutonium and enriched uranium that would be needed to make nuclear weapons.
One intelligence expert pointed out that capacitors are also used in separating the stages of missiles and rockets. Officials said Iraq also has a missile program that is far more advanced than the nuclear program.
But law enforcement officials, relying to some extent on statements made to an undercover agent by principals in the case, said they believed the multi-pronged Iraqi effort was for use in the nuclear program.
At Heathrow Airport near London today, British officials seized 40 electrical devices that were being shipped from the United States to Baghdad by way of London. Officials in Britain had switched the shipment, which arrived in London a few days ago, and substituted inoperable devices.
The devices seized were krytrons, high-speed capacitors that can be used to trigger nuclear explosions but that also have commercial applications. There are few manufacturers of these specialized devices, which have figured in smuggling cases in the past involving foreign nationals accused of trying to circumvent the United States' export laws.
E. G. & G., a Massachusetts company that makes krytrons, said today that it had cooperated with the Customs Service and supplied more than 40 inoperable trigger switches, including krytrons.
Ed Kittredge, a Customs spokesman, said that the British authorities had searched sites in Scotland and Cheshire today in connection with the attempted shipment of ''naval equipment to Iraq.'' He also said that an office in Surrey was searched in connection with the export of certain restricted ''electronic devices'' from the United States to Iraq by way of England.
Though the operation was undercover, the Customs Service permitted television crews unusual access. In advance of the arrests, NBC News television crews were allowed to film the preparation of the capacitors and loading in California and their arrival in London, as well as the comings and goings of Mr. Daghir, the alleged leader of the ring. They were also on hand for the arrests and the raid on Mr. Daghir's office in the London suburb of Surrey.
Mr. Kittredge said ''the Brits have asked us to soft-pedal the case because of the British citizens living in Iraq and we have deferred to them.''
The case comes at a sensitive time in British-Iraqi relations. The British Ambassador in Baghdad was recalled this month after the Iraqi hanging of an Iranian-born journalist working for a British publication. The reporter, Farzad Bazoft, was accused of spying.
There have been cases in the past of other countries trying to obtain krytrons, including Israel and Pakistan. Israel sent its warplanes to destroy an experimental nuclear reactor south of Baghdad in 1981.
A United States Government expert said he believed that Iraq was more than a decade away from developing nuclear weapons. But the official noted that Iraq had been trying to obtain technology and equipment that could used in a future plant to enrich uranium to nuclear weapons grade.
Other Government officials have described the Iraqi program in more alarming terms.
Rear Adm. Thomas A. Brooks, the director of naval intelligence, recently told Congress that the Iraqi program was ''well advanced.''
 
International Pressure Urged
Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project, which studies nuclear proliferation issues, said that the Iraqi effort ''is part of a worldwide, well financed, dedicated effort to get nuclear weapons.''
''It appears to be the first open violation of the nuclear nonproliferation treaty by a non-nuclear weapons state,'' Mr. Milhollin added.
Leonard S. Spector, an expert on nuclear proliferation at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said that he believed that Iraq was 5 to 10 years away from acquiring nuclear weapons, but added that the Iraqi case was nonetheless very worrisome.
''It demonstrates a clear intention to acquire nuclear weapons,'' Mr. Spector said. ''Now is the time for international pressure to be brought on Iraq, especially from countries like France and the Soviet Union that are supplying arms to Iraq and from various Western states that are extending economic credits.''

HEADLINE: Paying for Long-Term Care: The Struggle for Lawmakers

SERIES: Care of the Elderly; Private Burdens, Public Choices - Third of four articles.

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
Senator Max Baucus fed Gladys Foote, a 97-year-old stroke victim in Helena, Mont., who was his kindergarten teacher. Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th assisted an 82-year-old Alzheimer's victim in South Charleston, W.Va., while Representative Charles E. Bennett held a 4-year-old mentally disabled child on his lap at a center in Jacksonville, Fla.
They were among 75 lawmakers who spent a day feeding, dressing and caring for the severely disabled last year in a program sponsored by the Long Term Care Campaign, a coalition of 138 organizations including groups of the elderly, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the United Way. The coalition is pressing for more Government assistance for long-term care of the frail and the disabled, whether they are in nursing homes or being cared for at home. And increasingly, the nation's lawmakers are listening.
After a decade in the legislative shadows, the national debate over long-term care is moving toward center stage, propelled by the rising costs faced by growing numbers of disabled elderly Americans. 
It is an emotional debate involving morality and politics, fueled by different visions of what is right and what is feasible. It is a debate about government responsibility and family obligations, the roles of the public and private sectors, and whether the disabled elderly have as strong a claim on limited Federal resources as other groups like children and the poor.
''Sometime in the not-too-distant future we will get a major national program protecting families against the cost of long-term care,'' Robert M. Ball predicted in a recent interview. Mr. Ball was Commissioner of Social Security in the Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon Administrations and is now chairman of the National Academy of Social Insurance, a nonprofit research organization in Washington. He went on: ''I expect it to come, not primarily because of the political power of the elderly - although this is important - but because of pressure from those of middle age, the sons and daughters of the elderly. They are the ones most at risk.''
But few expect such legislation in the next two or three years. ''The public isn't willing to pay more taxes,'' said Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who is chairman of the Subcommittee on Health of the Ways and Means Committee. ''Unless the President is willing to spend some of his popularity, we'll never have it.''
 
The Issues
Who Benefits? Who Will Pay?
The debate over a new national policy turns on basic issues of philosophy and practicality:
* To what extent should middle-class people be expected to save funds for possible long-term care, or buy private insurance?
* Should Government programs be universal, like Social Security, with everyone paying and everyone getting a benefit? Or should they be aimed only at the needy, as programs like Medicaid are now?
* If eligibility for benefits is based on need, how poor should people be before getting aid? Should spouses of the disabled be able to maintain their former standard of living? Do people have a right to keep assets to pass on to their children?
* How much support should the Government give to care in the home, which many say is the greatest need but others fear could be an endless drain on the Treasury?
* How should any new program be financed? Through payroll taxes, personal or corporate income taxes, estate taxes or others?
Some people cast the debate as an intergenerational conflict, contending that the major beneficiaries will be the elderly, who are already benefiting from immenseGovernment programs like Social Security and Medicare. But others, like Mr. Ball, say aid to the elderly helps an entire family, especially the middle-aged, who he said face ''the poignant choice of spending time and money on their parents at the sacrifice of their own children.''
 
The Politics
Nightmare, Now or Later?
The debate is complicated by a national ambivalence. Public opinion polls show overwhelming support for Government protection against the financial nightmare so many families fear. But many politicians doubt that the public would support the new taxes needed to pay for these benefits.
Still, with the elderly growing in number and more families confronting the problems of the soaring costs of long-term care, there is a widespread feeling that something needs to be done. ''This could be a campaign issue in 1990 and 1992,'' said Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health and the Environment. He added that ''there is very strong public support'' for more Government aid for long-term care.
The Democrats, who championed Social Security and Medicare, have sought to portray themselves as protectors of the aged, and are the strongest supporters of such coverage. Republicans have taken the major role in questioning whether the middle-class elderly and their families, who would be the major beneficiaries of a new Federal benefit program, should receive more Federal money from tight budgets at a time when more than 31 million people lack health insurance and poor pregnant women and children need better health care. Republicans also tend to give more stress to the potential for private insurance to meet the care needs of many.
 
The Budget Squeeze
Representative Bill Gradison of Ohio, ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said, ''If we assume that there's some limit on how much taxes people are willing to pay, a major new middle-class program means that other parts of the budget are going to get squeezed.''
Nor is long-term-care legislation expected to become law without the support of the Bush Administration, which has resisted major new social programs, especially those that provide benefits to the middle class.
The poor already receive coverage for nursing homes, and occasionally home care, under Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for the poor. Many middle-class people rely on Medicaid to cover their expenses in nursing homes, but can do so only after spending most of their assets, a process many call humiliating and unfair. Others find legal ways to shelter assets and obtain Medicaid.
Medicare, the Federal health program for the elderly and the disabled, covers acute rather than chronic illness, so it provides relatively little support for nursing homes or home care.
The policy debate accelerated earlier this month because of the recommendations of the United States Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, called the Pepper commission for the late Representative Claude Pepper, a Florida Democrat who championed long-term coverage. The commission, created by Congress, is composed of 12 members of Congress and three private experts appointed by President Ronald Reagan. By a vote of 11 to 4, it called for a $42.8-billion-a-year plan for long-term care, with a majority of the money going to home health care, despite objections by the Bush Administration.
''The White House message was, 'Don't let the Democrats have an issue,' '' said Senator Rockefeller, who is chairman of the commission. ''The White House said, 'Don't do anything until after the November elections.' ''
But Republicans have insisted that their opposition was based on substance, not politics, including the commission's failure to fulfill one task assigned by Congress: proposing a way to finance the program. The $42.8 billion would be in addition to the $19.4 billion projected in the fiscal year 1990 for long-term care under Medicare and Medicaid, of which only $424 million is projected for home health care and the remainder for nursing homes.
''Before the Pepper commission, long-term care was a concept,'' said Ronald F. Pollack, executive director of the Families USA Foundation, which promotes the concerns of the elderly poor. ''Now, it's a concrete package.''
 
Wary of Another Debacle
But Deborah Steelman, who was George Bush's health policy expert in the 1988 Presidential campaign and now heads an independent Government commission studying health and social policy, balked at the Pepper commission's price tag. ''Why do we stick to ideas that are bigger than we have any reasonable expectation of paying for?'' she asked.
The Pepper commission sought to defuse the intergenerational debate by recommending long-term care for the severely disabled of all ages. About 40 percent of the severely disabled are under the age of 65. Of this younger group, a vast majority are cared for at home.
Under the Pepper plan, the Government would pay for the first three months of care in both skilled nursing homes and intermediate care centers. Thereafter, additional coverage would be provided to individuals with assets of $30,000 or less (not counting a home and some other essentials), and to couples with assets of $60,000 or less. The commission estimated that such institutional care would cost $18.8 billion, in addition to the $15 billion that Medicaid now pays for nursing homes.
Under the Pepper plan, the Government would also pay 80 percent of the costs of home and community-based care for up to 400 hours a year. The commission projected that this and other home health care benefits would cost $24 billion.
But members of Congress appear reluctant to endorse any new benefits package since last year's demise of the year-old Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act, which was repealed after vociferous objections to a new surtax paid by elderly people with higher incomes. Lawmakers appear to have learned several painful lessons from the episode: People do not like to be singled out for special taxes; health legislation is complicated and costly, and complicated legislation is hard to explain and justify to angry taxpayers. ''There are some real hangover feelings from the catastrophic coverage experience,'' Senator Rockefeller said. Instead of recommending specific financing measures, the Pepper commission offered a list of possible ways to meet the $42.8 billion cost. For instance, this amount could be raised by making all wages subject to the Social Security tax, rather than just the first $51,300, or it could be raised by increasing income tax rates 1 or 2 percent and taxing the highest incomes at a rate of 33 percent.
 
The Outlook
Responsibility And Coverage
A major issue in the debate involves whether the middle class as well as the poor should receive Government coverage for long-term care.
''I think we need some form of social insurance approach,'' said Alice Rivlin, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office, who is now a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. ''You get better programs if everybody pays and everybody benefits, as they do in Social Security and Medicare, instead of programs financed out of general revenues and specifically targeted at the poor, as in Medicaid.''
But others ask why the Government should provide coverage for the David Rockefellers and Donald Trumps.
''The question is, Can we afford to expand Government coverage on an entitlement basis, with benefits regardless of income?'' asked Gail Wilensky, administrator of the Health Care Financing Administration, which administers Medicare and Medicaid.
Another issue involves the role of private insurance. Mr. Ball, the former Social Security Commissioner, says only 20 percent of elderly couples could afford private insurance, those with incomes of $40,000 a year or more. ''Private insurance is for people who are relatively well off, and have some assets to protect,'' Mr. Ball said.
But Carl J. Schramm, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, says 40 percent of the elderly have enough income or assets to pay an average premium of $1,100 to $1,400 a year, at the age of 65, for private long-term-care insurance, or to pay directly for their care needs. Is Insurance the Answer? Representative Gradison said that although only about one and a half million million people have private long-term-care insurance, these policies were first offered only five years ago.
''It's way too early to throw up our hands and say the insurance industry can't do the job,'' Mr. Gradison said. ''They're just getting started.'' Thirty-two million Americans are 65 or older.
Health experts disagree on whether a Government program should pay at the outset of long-term care, or after a period of months or years. The two approaches help different groups.
The Pepper commission would have the Government pay for the first three months, and then provide coverage for those whose assets fall below $30,000 ($60,000 for couples). But Paul Willging, executive vice president of the American Health Care Association, which represents 10,000 nursing homes, said that when it comes to his own elderly parents, ''I can handle the first three months, at an average cost of $2,000 a month, but not the five to seven years of late-stage Alzheimer's.''
George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, the Senate majority leader, has proposed providing Government coverage only after two years in a nursing home, as well as home health services and respite care. His program would cost $25 billion a year.
But critics say the Mitchell approach favors the more affluent, those who still have assets after two years.
Mr. Ball said people who return to the community after nursing home stays ''will need their resources.''
Judith Feder, a health economist and the Pepper commission's staff director, said, ''The fundamental premise of our plan is that the program should focus on those at home and those likely to return home.'' Half of those in nursing homes for three months return home, Dr. Feder said, and two-thirds of all those who ultimately return home do so in three months.
 
'Flexibility Is the Key'
Another plan, developed by the staff of Ms. Steelman's commission, would give Medicare beneficiaries the option of paying a substantial deductible, ranging perhaps from $20,000 to $40,000, and then having the Government pay all the costs for long-term care, as well as all the costs of prescription drugs, hospitals and doctors. The commission is expected to make its recommendations early next year.
''Flexibility is the key,'' Ms. Steelman said. ''The question is whether we can modify Medicare to provide long-term care benefits.''
Home health care poses a policy problem. It is both more prevalent and usually less expensive than nursing home care. But some question whether the Government should pay for services that are now often provided without charge by relatives and friends. In addition, they say, home care coverage could easily be overused.
Dr. Warren Greenberg, professor of health services administration at George Washington University, said: ''Most elderly people can use such care as assistance in dressing, eating, shopping and other aspects of daily living. Once you pay this up, and say that we will pay for this as a nation, many people would qualify, and there would be no end to it.''
But others emphasize that many families badly need outside aid to keep providing the care they want to give and that home services can sometimes keep people out of nursing homes.
Whatever the form, Government aid for long-term care will be a major issue in this year's Congressional elections and in the 1992 Presidential election, if its supporters have their way.
''The '92 election is our friend,'' Senator Rockefeller said. ''The political pressure for long-term care is very substantial. The problem is mobilizing the will that exists out there, and getting the President to take the lead.''
NEXT: How to plan for long-term care needs.

LENGTH: 1665 words

HEADLINE: Rise in Minimum Wage Offers Minimum Joy

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EUFAULA, Ala., March 25

 BODY:
''I sew front pockets,'' Filena Craft says of her work at the Reltoc Manufacturing Company here, where she is among 100 workers who make men's cotton pants. Ms. Craft, who is 27 years old, earns the Federal minimum wage of $3.35 an hour and takes less than $100 a week home to the trailer where she lives with her two young daughters.
On Sunday, April 1, Ms. Craft and about 3.2 million other workers at the bottom of the wage scale will see a big change in their earnings. In November, Congress voted a 25 percent increase in the minimum wage, the first since 1981. Half the increase, to $3.80, takes effect next week and the second half, to $4.25, in April 1991.
But because these workers will see an increase in income, those who receive food stamps will lose some of their allotment. For example, Ms. Craft, who now takes home $85.89 a week, will take home about $97 a week after Sunday. She said her food stamps for the month of March were worth $200; food stamp officials, while declining to discuss individual cases, said the reduction in food stamps in a case like hers would probably be about $40 a month. The result: virtually a wash. 
So there is not much rejoicing in Eufaula. Not from Ms. Craft, not from her co-workers at Reltoc, Pamela Akins and Geanette Tennille; not from Annie Ruth Scott, who works at the Hardee's fast-food restaurant here and has a son with diabetes but has no health insurance, and not from Christine Dennis, who has a temporary job at Southern Plastics Inc., a maker of soft plastic fishing lures.
All are single mothers with young children and representative of the two-thirds of the nation's minimum-wage workers who are women. Such families, even with a full-time wage earner, fall below the poverty line, making them eligible for food stamps.
''When a woman maintains a family and her earning potential is at or near the minimum wage, she generally cannot keep out of poverty,'' the Labor Department's Monthly Labor Review said last October in a study of 6.4 million people whose family incomes were below the official poverty level in 1987 even though they worked or looked for work at least half the year.
''There's not much you can do with the minimum wage,'' said Ms. Akins, the mother of 4- and 6-year-old girls.
 
Costs Paid by Employer
The immediate costs of the wage increase, of course, are borne by the employers - retailers, service establishments, a sprinkling of light manufacturing companies - and their customers.
The families that will end up with more money from the wage increase are those that already have a bit more than the Crafts or the Akinses. Youths who live with their parents and work will gain. So will members of two-worker families, who earn too much to qualify for public assistance.
The Bush Administration and some leading Democrats are now considering enhancing another device, the earned income tax credit, which is meant for the working poor and in effect pays them a subsidy for working.
Under the credit, familes with incomes up to $6,500 get a maximum benefit of about $910, usually as a tax refund or as a check if they owe no taxes, according to Robert J. Shapiro, an economist at the Progressive Policy Institute in Washington. At incomes of $9,000 or so, the credit starts phasing out and stops at about $19,000.
Democrats and the White House support a higher benefit level. In addition, as part of child care legislation, the Administration would extend the benefit to mothers who stay home with their children, while Democrats would use it as an incentive to encourage work.
In the South, particularly, the minimum wage increase has a wide effect - at least on paper. The Bureau of Labor Statistics says 1.5 million workers - 7.2 percent of the region's work force - receive no more than the minimum wage. The bureau defines the South as 16 states and the District of Columbia.
 
Life on the Chattahoochee
Eufaula (pronounced you-FAH-lah) is a tranquil city of 15,500 people and a per capita income of a little over $9,000 a year, putting it among the nation's poorest communities. Its north end is a living museum of antebellum and Victorian mansions. Like many rural Southern communities, Eufaula is surrounded by forests, pastures and the shacks and mobile homes of the poor.
Eufaula has an unusually diversified, low-wage but also low-cost economy, with about 40 old and new industries. A sizable minority of workers are paid the minimum wage or a little more, among them some of the women at Reltoc, the maids at the motels, the help at the many fast-food shops, the beginner clerks at the K Mart discount store.
Some of these people say they started their jobs four or five years ago at $3.35 an hour and have yet to see even a penny raise. Some say they hold two jobs. At the Barbour County seat, 20 miles from here in Clayton, Ala., the supervisor of the food stamp program, Jean Teal, said 1,500 households, mostly in and around Eufala, get food stamps. ''Most people on the program work,'' she said. But at the Store. . . .? Ben and Rosalyn Turner, both 28, are among those who stand to gain from the wage increase because they are already above the poverty line. They earn a total of around $19,000 a year, he as a $7-an-hour janitor at a union-organized lighting fixture plant, she as a minimum-wage worker at Reltoc. With daughters 9 and 5 years of age, they live 30 miles away in a mobile home on land that Mr. Turner's mother gave them. Their cars are a 10-year-old Toyota and a nine-year-old Toyota. ''I'll be able to give my older daughter an allowance,'' Mrs. Turner said.
But it is hard to know how much these people will really benefit as the higher wage filters through the economy. Some retailers say they will raise prices to offset the higher wages they will have to pay - offsetting the workers' gains as well. Some employers might lay people off and postpone hiring new people.
Frank Comer, executive director of the Eufaula Chamber of Commerce, said that if he were a local businessman, he would look a little more closely for ways to cope with the higher wages.
''I would look at the productivity of that person,'' he said. ''Can he do more? If not, I would look for other things I can cut. But I might have to let that person go.''
Terry Spence, vice president and co-owner of Southern Plastics, said: ''We started tightening our belt two or three months ago. We're paying a lot more attention to who's producing and who's not.'' Even with better productivity, he added, ''We're going to have to have some price increases this year.''
Howard Cotler, chief executive of the H. Cotler Company in Manhattan, owner of Reltoc (Cotler spelled backwards), said his company, too, expected to impose price increases.
That is the sort of thing that makes some economists in Washington wince. Fast-food restaurants that can find workers to hire at the minimum wage ''will pass it on in the price of hamburgers,'' said Isabel Sawhill, economist at the Urban Institute there. ''That's what we should worry about if we worry about anything - the inflationary effects.''
But speculation about the national economy bears little relation to the world of Reltoc's women. Reltoc has become the flashpoint of industry's efforts in Eufaula to hold down costs to preserve profits and meet foreign competition.
 
Clothing Workers in Drive
This is anti-union country. Only three or four companies here have unions. But Reltoc is the target of an organizing drive by two women from the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers: Hilda Parker and Karen Hart, who have opened an office at the Holiday Inn.
The Cotler family, which operates two other plants in Alabama and two in Arkansas, all unionized, was warmly welcomed by the Eufaula business establishment about a year ago. Cotler bought a sewing plant that had closed the previous Christmas season, putting about 120 people out of work; Cotler rehired many of them. ''They are seen as a savior,'' Mr. Comer said.
But women at the plant who are leading the union organization drive say Reltoc pays less than the previous owners or other textile and apparel plants in the area. The women complain less about the minimum wage, which is all the company assures them, than about the company's requirements for earning more than the minimum.
By working fast and reaching a quota, called ''production,'' of completed pockets and other tasks, they can earn $4 to $5 an hour, and many do.
Even that is not enough to bring the workers up to the $1,090 level of monthly income that Mrs. Teal at the food stamp office says is the cutoff for a mother with two children. Ms. Tennille, who has children 16 and 9 years old, gets $24 a month in food stamps. ''I push myself,'' she said. ''You've got to have speed to make production.''
 
Running, Just to Stay Even
But Ms. Tennille said she was afraid that after April 1, the company would raise its production quotas so that she would have to work harder to stay even. The manager of the plant, Hern Bennett, declined repeated requests for comment and called the police when a photographer started taking pictures outside the plant.
Ms. Craft's prospects for escaping poverty and depending on food stamps are bleaker than Ms. Tennille's. For a week of stitching pockets, her paycheck stubs show that she takes home $70 to $90 a week after deductions of about $12 for taxes and Social Security and $39.73 for health insurance - a benefit many workers decline because of its unusually high cost.
She said she rarely meets her production quota - completing the pockets on 824 trousers a day. ''The majority of us can only do 500,'' she said. ''We're complaining that production is too high to make money.'' When Ms. Craft signed up for the health insurance a few months ago, she said the Government raised her food stamp allotment from $131 a month to $200. It could be years, she said, before further wage increases could free her from the need for food stamps.

PUB-DATE: March 29, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1736 words

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Bush's Adviser on Domestic Policy: The Perfect Person to Win the Point

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
Roger Porter has a theory that you can learn a lot about people by watching them on the tennis court.
Take Mr. Porter himself, an expert player who often plays doubles with President Bush.
The court strategy of the Assistant to the President for Economic and Domestic Policy is patient, steady, cerebral. He is scrupulous about line calls and he is willing to rally eight or nine times while he decides exactly which shot to set up for a put-away.
''A lot of players play impatiently,'' he says, talking about tennis and about life. ''And it is not easy in tennis, unless you're much better than your opponent, to score a lot of outright winners. My point is to win the point, but not to do it in any particular time frame.'' 
 
An Emphasis on Details
Because of his amiable, meticulous and tenacious nature, Mr. Porter is regarded as the perfect person to run the domestic policy shop at a time when the President is focusing on the more heady foreign policy agenda, earmarking the first part of the peace dividend for aid to Panama and Nicaragua, while domestic policy is found more in details than in grand schemes.
Some wags wonder what Mr. Porter does all day, arguing that Mr. Bush's domestic policy, as George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, drily observes, ''is notable primarily for its absence.''
This month Senator Mitchell noticed Mr. Porter's presence. The paradigm of the team player so celebrated in the Bush Adminstration, Mr. Porter was not very visible in his first year. He gained a higher profile as indefatigable point man for the Administration's Clean Air Act, winning from Mr. Mitchell a compromise measure that is tougher in some respects than the White House wanted but is still weaker than a Senate committee version - weaker enough that some of his colleagues think the majority leader is giving away too much.
 
Domestic Approach Disputed
Democrats hope the White House strategy is a vulnerability, that American anxiety about trying to make America work better at home and so compete better abroad will lead to dissatisfaction with the President's domestic approach.
Mr. Porter argues that within the constraints of fiscal responsibility the President has advanced a bold domestic and economic agenda on clean air, child care, education, capital gains, and drugs and crime.
''I do not agree with the notion that the President has failed to put forward dramatic initiatives,'' Mr. Porter said. ''Quite the contrary, his initiatives are dominating the agenda. He is also building bridges to governors, to Congress and to the country. His domestic policy is not dependent on heavy-handed Government mandates, but on market-oriented approaches. The rest of the world is now following our lead on this.''
 
A Black Belt in White Paper
Even in a city of policy wonks, Mr. Porter is an acknowledged black belt in white paper, a voluminous note-taker and voracious document-reader who spends long hours brokering complex programs with a host of bickering agencies and interest groups.
''Policy is his bag,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. ''He's one of those guys who reads the Federal Register and notices the fine print. He can tell you how much carbon monoxide amounts to how much global warming.''
Told that on the subject of policy he often utters pedantic sentences, Mr. Porter replies with self-deprecating humor, ''But I am a walking textbook, you know that.''
Methodical? He is so methodical that he tears out the advertisements from news magazines before he reads them so that they can be stored in smaller stacks afterward.
Hard-working? Mr. Porter, who eats warmed-over dinners when he gets home past 9 P.M. and who has been known to spend the night on his office couch, processes so much paper that he needs six in-boxes, occasionally using his closet as a seventh.
 
Asleep at a Rock Concert
On weekends and evenings he sometimes brings his three children into the office; his wife, Ann, says the brood has grown up helping him type memos. The hours sometimes catch up with him. He once took his son to a Michael Jackson concert and managed to sleep through it.
Disciplined? Raised in a studious, ordered Mormon household, where his mother read books to the children at the dinner table and his father taught them the art of arranging books neatly in a bookcase, the 43-year-old Utah native does not drink, smoke, swear, guzzle coffee, leave messes or lose his temper.
Mr. Porter says he never thought about rebelling as a teen-ager because he was ''too busy.'' His A average in high school and at Brigham Young University was marred by a handful of A-minuses, including one he says he didn't deserve in physics because the final exam was on the day President John F. Kennedy was assassinated and the teacher refused to postpone the exam.
Mr. Porter, who started college at 16, took two years off to work in England as a Mormon missionary. ''My family gave me a legacy of an approach to life that is structured but not rigid,'' he said.
 
Two Kinds of Advisers
Mr. Bush, who first met Mr. Porter in 1976 when President Gerald R. Ford asked him to join in a game of doubles, likes two kinds of advisers. His barbed wire side, developed in his years in Texas politics, likes realpolitik tough guys like Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff. His more genteel side is attracted to moderate, progressive, noblesse oblige advisers like Mr. Porter and William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.
Asked to offer a list of public officials to call for a profile of his first year, Mr. Porter named as many Democrats as Republicans.
Mrs. Porter says that even when her husband chides the children about chores, he sets up a gentle ''win-win situation,'' adding: ''If a room needs to be cleaned, he might offer to clean it with them. He operates very much from a base of trust.''
In the days of sweeping influence exercised by predecessors in the domestic policy post like John D. Ehrlichman in the Nixon Administration and Stuart E. Eizenstat in the Carter Administration, gentle compromise was not a necessary building block for operations in that post. Nor is the office the petri dish for conservative ideological debate that it was in the Reagan years. Under Mr. Porter, the let's-cut-them-off-at-the-knees attitude that sometimes prevailed in the past has given way to a let-us-reason-together-without-spending-money attitude.
Once the domestic policy office could dictate terms to the Office of Management and Budget. Now Richard G. Darman, Mr. Bush's budget director, as brainy and strong-willed as his close ally Mr. Sununu, dictates the terms to the domestic policy office.
 
A Technician, Not a Strategist
''Porter becomes less a principal and more a staffer for Sununu,'' said one White House insider. ''He's more a technician than a strategist.'' But in George Bush's White House, the likes of Mr. Porter and Mr. Reilly can be comfortable - even when others seem to be dominating their fields.
''I do not sense a contest or competition there,'' Mr. Porter says of Mr. Darman, with whom he shared teaching duties a decade ago at Harvard's Kennedy School for courses like managing Federal policy development.
Mr. Darman had the brazen dash in the classroom, Mr. Porter the quiet charm. Those who know both men say their talents are still complementary.
Mr. Porter is skilled at taking the issue of the moment, finding out where everyone stands, clarifying and organizing their positions, and presenting them to the President in a fair way.
''He was born to process,'' a colleague said of Mr. Porter.
Mr. Darman has a rare ability for taking the issue of the moment and developing a strategy on how it will play three years hence.
 
Complaints Over Bush Policy
The Administration has astutely tried to co-opt some Democratic issues, like child care and the environment, but complaints are growing noisier that, on domestic policy, Mr. Bush speaks loudly but carries a small stick.
The Administration's transportation policy, in which the budget office removed or changed references to Federal spending, ''crystallizes why this Administration's domestic agenda is devoid of policy,'' Senator Mitchell said. ''Essentially, the transportation policy is a catalogue of what's wrong in the country, trying to dump the responsibility off on states and local government. It's the opposite of Federal policy.''
Mr. Porter demurs. ''It is wrong to equate Federal leadership with Federal spending,'' he said.
Mr. Porter played point for the Administration's at the February education summit conference, where the President and the governors agreed on objectives to improve results in education. But educators were dubious that the goals, including making American students the first in the world in mathematics and science by the turn of the century, could be achieved.
 
Compromise on Clean Air Law
As to the first revision of the nation's clean air laws since 1977, though environmentalists agree that Mr. Bush is more sensitive to their cause than Ronald Reagan was, they complain that the compromise catered too much to business interests.
But Administration officials were surprised and thrilled that Mr. Porter pulled a compromise together. Even Democrats like Senator Michell, who day by day is forced to beat off challenges to the compromise by fellow Democrats, came away praising the domestic policy adviser as even-tempered, open-minded and candid.
Mr. Porter says this patient style will work. ''As Gorbachev has learned, you can't turn around a country from the top,'' Mr. Porter said. ''It has to come from the bottom.''

HEADLINE: The Health Cost Explosion, Evaded

 BODY:
America's tattered health insurance system cries out for reform. Congress turned for guidance to a bipartisan commission that now offers some useful ideas. But it evades the central issue. The commission boldly proposes an $86 billion-a-year plan to provide universal health insurance. But it doesn't say where the Federal share, $66 billion, would come from. 
Worse, it doesn't say how to keep medical costs from continuing to skyrocket. Ducking the question of which taxes to raise is forgivable. Ducking how to contain the ruinous inflation of medical costs is not.
Millions of Americans, unable to afford basic medical insurance, are terrorized by the prospect of costly illness. Even people of means face bankruptcy should they need long-term nursing care. That's why in 1988 Congress created the 15-member commission, named in honor of the late Representative Claude Pepper and headed by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, to propose reform.
The commission has now released a set of recommendations, notably to extend health insurance, including coverage for long-term nursing care. Under the plan, large employers would offer affordable basic insurance to employees or else pay into a public health plan. The public insurance would cover people otherwise uninsured, with subsidized rates for the poor.
In general, these ideas are sound. Rather than creating a Federal behemoth, the commission would graft universal coverage onto the existing structure of employer-based insurance. But successful reform of medical insurance requires more than general outlines.
Medical costs are soaring in large part because the nation relies on fee-for-service plans, under which patients pick their own doctors and receive insurance reimbursement for most costs. Doctors, hospitals and patients don't much care how much treatment costs because an insurance company winds up paying most of the bill. The system encourages unnecessary tests and exotic procedures.
To control costs, the commission calls for modest deductibles and co-insurance. But health finance experts - most notably Alain Enthoven of Stanford University - have shown that deductibles and co-insurance are an insufficient brake. Among the many reforms they recommend, two are essential:
Consumers must be made aware of costs. This requires limiting tax deductions for health insurance premiums to a fixed amount, enough for adequate coverage. A consumer would be free to buy a more expensive plan, but at his own expense, not that of the taxpayer.
This one change would make consumers sensitive to costs and open up the market to fierce competition from Health Maintenance Organizations and other alternatives to fee-for-service plans.
Health insurance must be ''managed.'' Individuals lack the expertise or time to shop intelligently for medical insurance. Professor Enthoven would rely upon corporate sponsors - or a public sponsor for those without employer-based coverage - to formulate options and monitor quality.
By ignoring details like tax subsidies and managed care, the Pepper Commission renders many of its recommendations unenforceable. For example, the commission would require that private insurers enroll the sick as well as the healthy. But without careful scrutiny by knowledgeable corporate sponsors, this provision would be easily evaded.
Congress had the right to expect its commission, after a year of study, to face up to the complexities of health insurance. Instead, Congress got a wish list that skirts the central problem of cost control. America has lost a year.

HEADLINE: Retooling for Peace Will Take Some Planning;
No Windfall

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your March 8 and 9 editorials join the bandwagon for the ''peace dividend,'' determining its magnitude and suggesting where it can be spent. But the dividend comes from reducing the size of the armed forces and from cutting the procurement of weapons. Have you given serious thought to what these steps mean? 
Troops removed from Europe will have to be demobilized; there are not sufficient bases to house them domestically. What will be the effect of dumping several hundred thousand young men and women into the economy? These are reasonably well screened and motivated young people. They will shove the current population off the bottom rungs of the economic ladder. This will lead to increased welfare costs and more money into the war on drugs, which are the palliative of the forlorn and hopeless.
And what about the weapons programs? The money spent goes into the economy. It pays for engineers, scientists, mechanics and secretaries. What will these people do? If the last slowdown in the aerospace industry is any example, they too will push people off the bottom of the economic ladder. Aerospace engineers have demonstrated that they can drive taxicabs. The barely English-literate drivers who make up a great deal of the driver force will be consigned to the welfare rolls. So much for the ''peace dividend.'' It will be spent on the same people it is being spent on today, only less effectively and with a poorer outcome.
The oft-touted solution of converting defense industries to civilian industries is not an answer. If there were demand for civilian products that defense contractors could produce, they would be in the business already.
The reason there will be no peace dividend is that in the long run the money is being spent on people, and they will not go away. We may restructure our society, but we will not reap any windfall to squander on social excess.
 
CORMAC P. WALSH
Glen Rock, N.J., March 9, 1990

HEADLINE: All Apartment Dwellers Would Feel Co-op Crash

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Dan Hurley may look forward to New York City's economic collapse (''Co-op Crash: Just Fine With Me,'' Op-Ed March 11), but he might not be so happy with the result.
The lawyers, dentists and financial analysts he derogates, along with nurses, police officers, teachers, auto mechanics and others, have invested hundreds of millions in co-op apartments. Building owners have spent some $250 million on improvements to buildings being converted.
No public funds were used to save and restore this housing. More minorities live in co-op buildings than were renters in those buildings before. While rent regulation helped destroy housing for the poor, co-op conversion salvaged buildings for working families.
The recent downturn in real estate values has many causes - the national economy and New York's overreliance on the financial services industry are just two. But Federal and local tax policies clearly make things worse. Real estate is not the favored investment it once was in America. Locally, increases in assessments and tax rates are squeezing all apartment owners, whether they own just their own apartment or an entire building. Renters are feeling pressure too, as taxes become a big factor in legal rent increases and some building owners have to defer maintenance expenses to pay tax bills.
If Mr. Hurley looks forward to a day when the co-op owners are forced out and he can find a nice home near the city cheap, I hope he likes living alone.
 
WILLIAM A. MOSES
New York, March 14, 1990
 The writer is chairman of Community Housing Improvement Program, which represents owners of 400,000 apartments.

HEADLINE: Rostenkowski Is Half Right

BYLINE: By Dave Durenberger; Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, is a member of the Senate Finance Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
''Adopt my plan to fix the budget deficit - or come up with a better one.'' That's the challenge issued by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, should be applauded for his courage in urging Washington to meet the budget deficit head on. But there are any number of ways to broaden the tax base and raise revenues that would be more equitable than his proposals. 
The gaping pothole standing in Mr. Rostenkowski's way is his proposal to increase Federal taxes by nearly $200 billion during the next five years. Not user fees, not ''loophole closers'' -just clean, straight, new taxes.
President Bush's 1988 ''no new taxes'' pledge has yet to be etched in marble on a monument overlooking the Potomac. So, if we're going to raise taxes, let's do it in an effective and fair way.
I don't think Mr. Rostenkowski does that. He discards several important principles while disposing of President Bush's pledge.
First, Mr. Rostenkowski would suspend indexing of the tax rates for individuals for one year - a $50 billion tax increase. This would be seriously misguided.
Taxpayers are protected from paying higher taxes when inflation drives them into higher tax brackets by the practice of indexing the personal exemption, the standard deduction and the dollar level of each bracket. Middle class and working-poor families benefit the most from the personal exemption and the standard deduction. Suspending indexing would hit these groups the hardest, not the high-income taxpayers who itemize deductions and cannot claim personal exemptions.
Second, Mr. Rostenkowski wants to increase excise taxes. These are the most regressive form of taxation.
Excise taxes are the third largest source of revenue for financing state and local government operations. With the hundreds of mandates passed to them from Washington over the past 10 years, states cannot afford to lose these revenues to the Federal Government. For example, the gasoline tax is used for construction and maintenance of highways. Increasing that tax to reduce the deficit deprives states of a potential source of revenue for expanding efforts to stop the deterioration of the highway system.
Third, Mr. Rostenkowski proposes to raise the top tax rate for individuals to 33 percent from 28 percent. This is as unnecessary as it is unfair. A top tax rate of 33 percent would in effect levy a higher tax on capital income than was levied when Jimmy Carter was President. In the past 10 years, Congress has striven to bring down tax rates while broadening the base of taxable income.
If we are going to open up the tax code to raise revenue, let's begin where we left off in the 1986 tax reform bill: taxing income that escapes all Federal taxation. For example, $33 billion in employer contributions to finance employee health benefits is tax free. And corporations are allowed to deduct 100 percent of the cost of employees' health insurance. If we taxed a small portion of employer-paid health insurance, we could raise almost $47 billion over five years.
There are other employer-paid fringe benefits that escape taxation: $50,000 worth of life insurance, assistance to care for dependents and educational assistance. If Congress imposed a 3 percent excise tax on the value of all nonretirement fringe benefits, including health insurance, it could raise more than $20 billion over five years.
And if Congress lowered the ceiling for tax-deductible contributions to private retirement plans, it could raise $16 billion over five years.
There are other options that ought to be considered before we raise income tax rates. For example, a 5 percent tax on the investment income of pension and other retirement plans would raise $37 billion. Taxing capital gains at death could raise $10 billion. A securities transfer tax of one-half of 1 percent would raise more than $57 billion over the next five years.
Yes, let's throw out the political timidity with which we handled the deficit in the 80's. But let's maintain some of the wise tax principles we established over the last decade.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
The U.S. Intervenes

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Once again, and for the second time in a year, the United States has allowed Communist governments to dictate American foreign policy.
Both times Washington turned on its word and acted against the interests of an oppressed people seeking freedom. Soon that may not even be news.
Both times the Bush Administration justified its actions by arguing that the rulers had to be placated, helped and bolstered to avoid chaos. 
In China the Bush Administration promised that, as payoff for the secret missions and economic benefits, Beijing would loosen its tyranny.
The American desertion of the young people murdered in the streets of Beijing won their survivors nothing. The dictatorship is as stifling and brutal as ever.
At least now the United States is not promising the Lithuanian people that things will get better if they do not press for independence. They are spared that.
For a half-century, ever since the Hitler-Stalin pact turned the three Baltic nations over to Soviet imprisonment, the United States has proudly said it would never accept their captivity. George Bush ran as Vice President on Republican platforms saying that kind of thing.
So much for that. Now at the moment of decision, the United States is telling the Lithuanians, ''Sorry but something just came up: Our interests and the interests of the Soviet Government happen to coincide.''
Washington tells them that we do not want any threat to the power of Mikhail Gorbachev and that since he feels Lithuanian independence is a threat, obviously we have to back off from it - and so should you.
Other nationalities that feel trapped in the Soviet Union are meant to hear and take notice.
The argument that Mr. Gorbachev is important to the United States is true. But insisting he is so vital to us and the world that peace and progress will perish if he feels threatened in any way has made the Government of the United States his prisoner.
This is a position that diminishes honor and sacrifices logic.
The U.S. did not bring Mr. Gorbachev to power and cannot keep him in power. The Soviet Politburo brought Mr. Gorbachev to power. Its members were desperate for a man of change who could save their collapsing system from being wiped out entirely by internal explosion. Mr. Gorbachev stunned them and the world with his imagination and flexibility.
But if his hold is really so tenuous that he cannot deal with the Baltic independence movements without the force he already has used in Lithuania, and the plain threat of more in reserve, nothing can save him. Lithuania was the first to strike out for freedom; it will not be the last, despite Washington.
For all the years of its existence, the Soviet Union was for many of the nationalities not a country of their choice but a fence preventing their escape. Massive Soviet military power made the world forget that -until the whole society began cracking apart.
But if force and fear continue to be the only way Mr. Gorbachev can deal with the problem, built into the very structure of the Soviet Union, then the explosion will indeed come.
Even before that, the political and intellectual openness he has helped bring to his country will wither.
Already, in its first real test, glasnost was thrown out the Gorbachev window. Foreigners were ordered out of Lithuania. The Soviet press, radio and TV resumed submissive posi-tions as apologists and provocateurs for the Government.
This brought no loud protest from abroad. The Western world, particularly the United States, is once again making the mistake of putting all its hopes in one man. This over-personalization of politics blinds us to his weaknesses and often to his destiny - remember the Shah, Marcos, Khrushchev.
The United States should not damage Mr. Gorbachev if it decently can avoid doing so. But neither should we obediently follow him or intervene on his side against those dreaming of escaping the Soviet Union, individually or as a nationality.
And we are intervening. Going back on our word, keeping silence about the force and psychological warfare being used against the Lithuanians -that is intervention against Lithuania.
Once more Washington is depriving a struggling people of the one powerful asset they thought they had - the moral and political backing of the United States.
Once more American power reached to help Communist power. How long will that be news?

LENGTH: 522 words

HEADLINE: Defendant Silent as Defense Rests in L.I. Slaying

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., March 28

 BODY:
The defense in the Robert Golub murder trial rested its case today without calling Mr. Golub to the stand, insuring that the jury's verdict will depend almost entirely on circumstantial evidence.
Mr. Golub, who is 22 years old and unemployed, is charged with killing Kelly Ann Tinyes, 13, a neighbor from Valley Stream. Kelly disappeared on March 3, 1989. Her beaten, slashed and strangled body was found the next day in a closet in the basement of the Golub family's house on Horton Road. 
There was no confession and no witnesses to the crime, so the prosecutor, Daniel Cotter, based his case on physical evidence, focusing on a bloody palm print and smears of blood found at the scene. The defense's burden, then, was to call experts to raise doubts about the prosecution's witnesses. And the jury will decide whose experts were more credible.
The defense lawyer, Salvatore Marinello, has said repeatedly that the law requires him only to raise reasonable doubt of guilt. ''This is a scientific case,'' he said today. ''And we did what the defense needed to do.''
The case was puzzling from the start because the defendent had no criminal record and no known history of violence. Nor did he know Kelly Tinyes except by sight; she was an acquaintance of his brother John, 14.
 
Prosecution Works Backwards
So Mr. Cotter, presenting the prosecution's case in Nassau County Court, worked backwards. First he established that the Golub house had limited access and that only Robert Golub, his parents, brother, and two of his brother's friends were known to have been there the afternoon Kelly disappeared.
Then, using experts in the analysis of blood, fingerprints, bite marks and hair, Mr. Cotter tried to show that physical evidence at the scene proved that only Robert Golub could have killed her.
Mr. Marinello's strongest rebuttal testimony came from dentists who said that wounds on Kelly's neck and left buttock were not bite marks inflicted by Mr. Golub, as the prosecution contended. Three witnesses, including the chief forensic dentist for the New York City Medical Examiner's Office, said the marks could not have been made by Mr. Golub's teeth.
Today, however, Dr. Neal R. Riesner, chief forensic dentist for Westchester County, testified on rebuttal for the prosecution that the buttock wound was a bite mark inflicted by Mr. Golub. Further, he said, one of the defense's witnesses, Dr. Norman D. Sperber, had misnumbered the teeth in testimony earlier this week.
Dr. Riesner's testimony left the impression that Dr. Sperber had based his conclusions on this misnumbering. But in testifying earlier on his analysis, Dr. Sperber did not make this mistake.
The crux of the prosecution's case is that stains on Kelly's clothing and on three attache cases in which the clothing was found showed genetic markers consistent with Mr. Golub's blood. One witness, Lorah McNally of the Lifecodes Corporation, a genetics-testing laboratory, said blood found smeared on the top of two of the cases matched the DNA ''fingerprint'' of Mr. Golub so closely that only one in 707 million people had such a pattern.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: State, or Labor Market, May Set Higher Minimum

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 28

 BODY:
Even before it goes into effect Sunday, the new national minimum wage of $3.80 an hour is out of date here.
California has already established state minimum wages of $4.25 an hour, as have Connecticut, Rhode Island, Washington and Oregon. In Alaska, the minimum wage will increase to $4.30 from $3.85 the same day the new Federal minimum wage takes effect. 
And in places where the economy is generally healthy and the demand for workers is strong, it does not matter what the statute says. Employers must offer a premium or they will not find anyone to hire.
When it hires janitors, the Atrium Club, a private social and fitness club in Manhattan, must pay $5 to $6 an hour, said Joseph Roland, the club's manager. He said the New York labor market was too tight for him to consider offering anyone the minimum wage.
 
Supply and Demand in New York
''It's just supply and demand,'' Mr. Roland said. ''If you have a qualified person, you're not going to be able to pay them minimum wage.''
At Urban Outfitters in Philadelphia, a store that sells clothing and housewares for younger people, the manager, Lara Goldstein, said she could not possibly offer any employee the minimum wage.
''Most retail stores in this area pay between $4 and $5 an hour,'' she said. ''If we only paid minimum wage, they would find a better job somewhere else.''
The same is true in Los Angeles. ''To work in a restaurant, I'd expect to earn at least $6 an hour,'' said Michelle Breslow, who lives in La Canada, an affluent suburb north of downtown Los Angeles, and works part time in the catering business.
A variety of economic and political factors explain why some states impose a minimum wage higher than the Federal one, as is their right, said Richard B. McKenzie, a University of Mississippi professor who has written extensively on the subject.
Generally, he said, the wage goes up, often beyond the official minimum, wherever the job market is tight, because of either economic expansion or a worker shortage.
 
'Market Ahead of Politicians'
''The labor market is ahead of the politicians in this issue here,'' said Jeff Hannum, an economist with Oregon's Employment Division of the State Department of Human Resources. ''In Oregon, anybody paying less than $4.50 an hour is probably having quite a bit of difficulty finding people.''
Jim Glasgow, vice president of operations at Trans Pacific Restaurants Inc. of Irvine, Calif., which operates 16 restaurants in the state, said his dishwashers earned $4.75 to $6.50 an hour.
In California, the Industrial Welfare Commission raised the state's minimum hourly wage to $4.25 from $3.35 in 1987 after studying economic data and holding public hearings. Employer groups opposed any increase because they said it would hurt the economy; citizen groups argued that a higher minimum was necessary to make a living.
In Oregon, the State Legislature raised the minimum wage in several steps to $4.25. Next January, it will increase again to $4.75.
The current mimimum rate is often too low. ''I can still hire some of the younger kids at $4.25,'' said David Butters, general manager of an El Pollo Loco fast food restaurant in Hillsboro, Ore., near Portland. ''But if I want to look for full-time or day help I have to pay anywhere form $4.50 to $6 to generate any interest.''

HEADLINE: Electronics: It's Not Home Without It

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
FOR generations of Americans, setting up a home meant buying furniture, bedspreads, china and cutlery. But to a generation raised on omnipresent audio and video gadgets, the hope chest is electronic.
Videocassette recorders, compact disk players, cordless telephones and other electronic equipment represent an increasing chunk of the budget, a good indicator of the priorities of the American family today.
Since 1980, personal spending on electronics has grown by 45 percent, from 1.1 percent annually to 1.6 percent, said Clint McCully, chief of the consumption branch of the Bureau of Economic Analysis in the Commerce Department. In 1989, spending on electronics amounted to $54.6 billion. By comparison, spending on furniture did not change at all during the 80's; it remains at 5 percent of annual personal consumption. 
The money for electronics could be coming from a number of places. The percentage of the budget devoted to clothing and shoes has dropped from 6.3 percent to 5.7 percent; to food, from 20.2 percent to 17.1 percent; and to gasoline, from 4.8 percent to 2.4 percent.
Personal spending for entertainment outside the home - on movies, plays, concerts and spectator sports - also dropped during the decade, from four-tenths of 1 percent to three-tenths of 1 percent. Personal consumption data include all expenditures except taxes, interest payments and savings.
The last 10 years have brought a revolution in the relationship between Americans and home electronics. Much of what many Americans have come to regard as standard equipment for the home was virtually unavailable 10 years ago: the portable cassette player, the videocassette recorder, the telephone answering machine, the home computer, cordless phones, CD players. This was, after all, the decade that made the LP obsolete.
Witold Rybczynski, an architecture professor at McGill University in Montreal who wrote ''Home: A Short History of an Idea,'' said in an interview that electronics has taken over roles servants used to play. He cited the answering machine as an example. And electronic devices ''seem almost foolproof,'' he added.
''They almost never break down. It's a painless kind of ownership, compared to, say, a lawn mower.''
Whether they are passionate consumers who study the newest products or indifferent ones who buy only the basics, people no longer view electronic devices as luxuries. The equipment has become so familiar in just a decade that it has become unremarkable, like a stove or a refrigerator. Percy Quartey, who lives in Brooklyn in a two-bedroom apartment with his wife and two children, has two televisions, a VCR, two telephones, a stereo system with a tape deck and CD player, and an answering machine. ''This is like a necessity,'' he said.
Mitchell Blank, a 29-year-old New Yorker, lives with his wife in a one-bedroom apartment where they have two color television sets, two CD players, a tape recorder, three telephones and two VCR's. When it comes to more traditional home furnishings, though, he has ''just a couple of couches and a bedroom set.'' Even if he had a sudden windfall, he said he would not go out and buy furniture. ''It totally has to do with my value system,'' he said.
Mr. Blank, who went to law school and worked in commercial real estate before turning to selling baseball cards, said most consumers are looking for psychological benefits when they buy electronic equipment. ''People identify the technology with being up, being current with social change,'' he said.
Some, though, seem to have accumulated the equipment in spite of themselves. Alan Zweibel, a TV producer who lives in Los Angeles with his wife and three children, admitted, with chagrin, that they have five televisions, three VCR's and nine telephones. ''I don't know why,'' he said. ''I had a very happy childhood, and we never had a phone in the garage.''
Many people don't seem aware of how much equipment they have. Hughes Torres, who was shopping for computer software in New York earlier this week, at first said he did not have much electronic equipment. But on questioning, it turned out that he owned two TV sets, two VCR's, a video camera, a stereo and a computerized watch.
Gerry Gerrard, who was buying a second VCR for business reasons, said he did not have a lot of equipment in his home, just a VCR, two televisions and ''the usual CD and cassette.'' He and his wife, Olga, who run their business from their living room, don't even have a sofa.
''We sit on office chairs or on cushions on the floor,'' he said. Despite that, he thinks that the electronic devices make the quality of home entertainment so much better that ''we're more likely to stay home.''
Barbra Green, who lives in a studio apartment in New York, said she has a television, VCR, answering machine and stereo, but considers them her least important household possessions. But she said she uses the VCR every day to tape ''Days of Our Lives.'' By bringing work and entertainment into the home, the profusion of electronic devices has made the entire concept of home more fluid: it is a terminal, and a surprisingly mobile one. Danny Louie said that when he and his wife go out, their three children can reach them through his pager. Mr. Louie, who lives in Cranford, N.J., said he plans to buy a high-definition TV set when it becomes available.
The technology, he said, ''only gets better.'' When he updates, he puts the old equipment in the basement. ''After it's rusting,'' he said, ''you throw it out.''
The industry happily obliges such hunger. Indeed, the newer products experience the fastest rate of increase: sales of cellular telephones are expected to grow 37 percent this year, and those of compact disk players 15 percent.
Although richer households obviously spend more on electronics, this is not a yuppie phenomenon: even people who don't have projection TV's in their homes are buying a lot of electronic equipment. Sales of color TV's were a record 22 million sets last year, according to the Electronic Industries Association, a trade group based in Washington.
Many of those sets were the second and third in a household. More than 75 percent of color TV sets are still in use after 10 years, according to a 1985 study by Market Facts, a Chicago-based market research company that surveyed more than 12,000 households.
A Gallup Organization study in June 1988 for the Electronic Industries Association found that the presence of children in a household is the most likely indicator that electronic equipment will be purchased. ''Even households with income under $20,000 are buying camcorders,'' said Tom Lauterback, a spokesman for the association.
''People are willing to forego some of the other things to capture the baby's first steps on video.''
The products don't cost much more than they did 10 years ago, and in some cases less, so the dollars spent don't reflect their increasing importance. More telling are the numbers, which show that once-unusual devices are now common. For instance, 17 percent of households had VCR's in 1985, but now 68 percent do, the Electronic Industries Association says.
The American house has yet to catch up with the changes. Cords snake under rugs and along walls, getting tangled in one another. Remote control devices pile up on the coffee table.
With no startling new products in sight that promise to become mandatory in every household, the industry is focusing on ways to make existing products more useful. By the end of this year, the Electronic Industries Association expects to develop standards for manufacturers to make equipment that will tie together all the electronic devices in a household.
''I think the 90's is going to be the home automation decade,'' Mr. Lauterback said.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Weighing The Rights And Wrongs Of Welfare

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Tonight's edition of ''48 Hours,'' at 8 o'clock on CBS, digs into America's welfare system, which Dan Rather too accurately calls ''the helping hand that almost everyone hates.''
Concentrating on Wisconsin, where welfare payments are among the highest in the nation, the strongly reported hour focuses on a 35-year-old woman with five children and no husband; Caseworker No. 1479 in Milwaukee who has to handle 293 families; a young woman trying to earn a diploma; a 38-year-old family man, formerly on welfare, who works 100 hours a week at menial jobs to make sure he stays off it, and a cop assigned to hunting down fugitive fathers.
The reporting is sympathetic without being soppy. Learning from the first woman that her children all have different fathers, Bernard Goldberg exclaims, ''You picked all these guys!'' When she replies, yes, she made a mistake, he says, ''You made five mistakes.'' The issue, of course, is how much responsibility the state should bear for such mistakes. 
Even for those who seem better able to take advantage of what Wisconsin offers, the program shows, the difficulties are daunting. Under the state's ''learnfare'' program, which is being copied around the country, Wisconsin will help people get training and then pay medical insurance and child support for their first year on the job. But after that they are on their own, and as one 28-year-old single parent discovers, when that happens, even with a job, she will be in the red. Doug Tunnell, a correspondent, puts her predicament to Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, who can provide little comfort. Indeed, the Governor is under pressure to toughen residency requirements to block the flow of jobless people drawn to Wisconsin by its relatively high benefits.
Untypically for television documentaries, the bureaucrats are seen to be as human as their clients. ''I wasn't hired to make moral judgments,'' says the case worker. But state officials have learned that the threat of a cut in benefits may be the only effective means of compelling a young mother to go to school.
The father-hunting cop is anything but punitive. He knows that putting feckless fathers in jail is politically popular, but he also knows that few of these men have any job skills.
The most heartening story here is also the most heart-rending. A father of seven, who holds down both a night job as a health aide and a day job helping a handicapped man, manages to attend classes and find time to play with his children. He catches naps along the way. Together, he and his wife earn $26,000 a year. ''I don't like feeling small,'' he says.

WITH: Bernard Goldberg, Jacqueline Adams, Eric Engberg and Doug Tunnell, correspondents.
