HEADLINE: Doubts Raised Over Bush's Tax Plan for Savings

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is counting on its proposed Family Savings Plan to generate more revenue than it would cost, but the Senate's chief tax writer is skeptical.
''That carries me back to 1981,'' when the Reagan Administration predicted that huge tax cuts would pay for themselves, Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said on Tuesday. ''Now we have these enormous deficits that in part were brought about by that 'magic,' '' the Texas Democrat said.
The Family Savings Plan is part of a package proposed by President Bush as an incentive to increase saving and investment. Under the plan, a person with an income of less than $60,000 could deposit up to $2,500 a year and pay no tax on the interest if the account was maintained for at least seven years. A couple earning less than $120,000 could deposit up to $5,000. 
 
Billions in Savings Seen
Sidney L. Jones, the Assistant Treasury Secretary for economic policy, told the Finance Committee that the proposal would generate $40 billion in new personal savings over the next five years.
He said the White House Council of Economic Advisers estimated that the plan would increase saving and economic growth so much that it would lead ''to an increase in Government revenues as well as personal saving in the longer run.''
The Administration makes the same argument on behalf of the biggest part of the President's savings and investment package: a proposal to cut the tax on capital gains from sales of investments.
Some economists quarrel with the Administration's basic argument that a tax incentive will increase savings. They cite Individual Retirement Accounts as an example, saying that most of the money going into such accounts is simply transferred from existing accounts.
 
Conflicting Advice
The Finance Committee on Tuesday received conflicting advice on that point from two analysts associated with the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private group.
Jonathan Skinner of the University of Virginia said an I.R.A. - which provides a tax deduction for some taxpayers at the time a deposit is made - can increase savings by locking up an account until retirement. He predicted that Mr. Bush's plan, which would allow accounts to be cashed in after seven years, would lead to shuffling money between taxable and nontaxable accounts.
But Lawrence J. Kotlikoff of Boston University said, ''It is clear that saving policies of the last decade, such as expansion of I.R.A.'s, failed to promote national saving.'' He said a tax on consumption, like a national sales tax, would encourage saving.
The one point on which the economists, Administration witnesses and committee members agreed is that Americans save too little of their income, far less than Japanese and West Germans. The United States saving rate last year was 3.6 percent of net national income, compared with an average of 8.9 percent during the 1950's, 1960's and 1970's.
 
Benefits of Higher Savings
''Increased savings would lower the cost of capital for our nation's business, enhance the ability of American companies to compete in a global market and lower the cost of most goods and services we consume,'' said Kenneth W. Gideon, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for tax policy.
The National Association of Counties complained that the savings plan would force up the cost of borrowing for highways, schools and other state and local building projects. Mary O. Boyle, a member of the Cuyahoga County, Ohio, Commission, said the accounts would compete for the same savings dollars as the tax-exempt bonds on which states, cities and counties rely.
''Local governments would be forced to pay higher borrowing costs just to compete - an ultimate cost shift to all taxpayers,'' Ms. Boyle said. That would endanger the nation's system of highways, bridges and sewers, she said.
But Mr. Gideon said the new accounts ''will have at most a small impact on the tax-exempt bond market.''

HEADLINE: Company Profits Down; G.N.P. Growth at 1.1%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
Profits of American companies fell by 3.2 percent in the final three months of 1989 mainly because of rising labor costs, the Commerce Department reported today.
For the full year, corporate profits from current production dropped by 8.3 percent; in 1988 they rose by 10 percent. The decline was the first significant drop since a 20.2 percent decrease in 1982, the most recent recession year.
While profits from current production are the purest gauge, the Commerce Department reports other measures of profits. Current-production cash flow - the internal funds available for investment - fell by three-tenths of 1 percent after rising by 1.9 percent in the third quarter. Profits before taxes eased by five-tenths of 1 percent after a 7.1 percent decline, and profits after taxes rose by 2.8 percent, the first quarterly gain in a year. 
 
Calculation of Growth
The profits report accompanied the department's latest calculation of the pace of economic growth in the fourth quarter, now put at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.1 percent.
This suggested that the economy was slightly firmer than shown in last month's estimate of nine-tenths of 1 percent. The first estimate, in January, had said the gross national product expanded at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the quarter.
The figures on corporate profits, although not unexpected, reinforced the worries of some analysts that corporations would not have the means or the incentive to invest in new plant and equipment during 1990.
 
Not a 'Painless Landing'
''This shows that a 'soft landing' is by no means synonymous with a painless landing,'' said Robert G. Dederick, a former Commerce Department official who is now chief economist for the Northern Trust Company of Chicago. ''One of the key questions now is whether this year is going to be dragged down by businesses responding to last year.''
A ''soft landing'' refers to the effort of policy makers, so far fairly successful, to restrain the economy enough to keep inflation under control without tipping the economy into a recession.
Profits are a principal source of money for expansion, the other being loans. Many lending institutions have, however, been tightening credit standards recently, with lending to smaller companies seeming to be the most seriously affected.
 
Higher Final Sales
The latest revision of the G.N.P. growth figure reflects higher final sales for most major components partly offset by a $4 billion downward adjustment in the growth of inventories. The gross national product measures the output of goods and services, and production adds to the G.N.P. even if the goods pile up on dealers' shelves. The latest data were considered something of a plus for the business outlook because it means inventories are under good control and production will not need to be scaled back to bring them into balance with sales.
The rise in the G.N.P. fixed-weighted price index, a measure of inflation, remained at 3.6 percent, up from 2.9 percent in the third quarter.
The 3.2 percent quarterly decline in profits reflected a fall-off of $9.5 billion, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $285.7 billion. Profits would have been far worse had it not been for a sharp increase in earnings abroad.
The foreign component jumped $9.7 billion, up from $2.1 billion in the third quarter. This represents the amount by which dividends paid to United States residents and reinvested earnings of foreign affiliates of American companies exceed corresponding amounts paid to foreign residents.
 
Domestic Profits Down
Domestic profits of nonfinancial corporations skidded by $13.9 billion, far more than the $3.8 billion decline in the preceding three months. Gross corporate product rose while profits per unit of real product fell; lower unit profits reflected difficulty in raising prices combined with higher costs.
Kenneth A. Petrick, a Commerce Department specialist, said much of the narrowing of profit margins reflected higher labor costs as companies appeared to hold on to workers in hopes that the economy would regain momentum.
Mr. Petrick also said the net interest costs of nonfinancial corporations seemed to have leveled off, suggesting diminishing pressure on profit margins this year. He acknowledged, however, that some of the interest reduction figure could be a reflection of defaults on debt.
Domestic profits of financial corporations fell by $5.2 billion during the quarter, less than half the third-quarter drop of $10.8 billion, which reflected large costs incurred by casualty insurers because of hurricane and earthquake damage. The fourth-quarter decline reflected the problems of banks and savings and loan associations.

HEADLINE: Home Sales Rose by 3.1% In February

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
High interest rates and declining consumer confidence depressed sales of new homes in February, although they bounced back slightly from steep declines in the previous two months, the Commerce Department said today.
New single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 607,000 units in February after plummeting by 6.8 percent in January and a revised 8 percent in December.
But the February rate, though rising by 3.1 percent from January, was still below the 649,000 homes sold in 1989 and, except for January, the lowest since 556,000 homes were sold on an annual basis last March. Sales totaled 589,000 in January. 
 
Risk of Higher Rates
''The housing industry has been adversely affected by the increase in mortgage rates in January and February,'' said Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association. ''I don't see much of a decline in rates in the months ahead, and there's a substantial risk that they will go higher in the second half.''
David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, also pointed to weakness in the economy, including slower job growth, as contributing to a decline in consumer confidence and thus softer sales.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said interest on fixed-rate mortgages rose from 10.17 percent at the beginning of February to 10.31 percent, before falling to 10.23 percent at the end of the month.
 
Psychological Barrier
Mark Obrinsky, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, called the 10 percent level a psychological barrier that was keeping the housing market a little weaker than at the end of 1989, when rates dropped into single digits.
John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, also blamed high mortgage rates for a 2.3 percent decline in the sales of existing homes last month. The association said the February pace was the slowest in seven months.
Many analysts had expected sales to surge with the unusually warm weather in January and February after the fourth-coldest December on record. But Mr. Obrinsky said the median time to find a house was about seven weeks, ''so that some that sat on the sidelines in December may still be looking but haven't found their house yet.'' He added, ''It's possible we could see some further increases in March and April.''
Sales were up 21.3 percent, to 256,000 units at an annual rate, in the South, more than rebounding from a 16.3 percent decline in January. But sales fell elsewhere in the nation.
They were down 18 percent, to 82,000 units, in the Northeast, 6.4 percent, to 88,000 units, in the Midwest, and 1.6 percent, to 181,000 units, in the West.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Post Slight Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were slightly higher for the week that ended yesterday.
Analysts at Donoghue's do not expect yields to change much until a clearer picture of the economy, free of the distortions in the winter statistics, emerges from economic data to come in the next few months.
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund increased 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.98 percent, while the 30-day average yield increased a basis point, to 7.95 percent. 
 
Increase in Consumer Funds
Assets of taxable funds rose $821 million for the week, to a total of $385.2 billion, with institutional assets down $94 million, to $80.3 billion, and consumer assets up $915 million, to $304.9 billion. There was a noticeable increase in the flow of money into consumer funds this week.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios increased to 45 days, from 44. Fund managers are now holding securities in their portfolios longer than usual, because they are not concerned with the Federal Reserve's tightening of credit, which stands to raise short-term rates.
Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million surveyed by IBC/ Donoghue's, the Dreyfus Worldwide Dollar Money Market Fund, distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation of Garden City, L.I., had the highest yield for the sixth consecutive week. The fund reported a return of 8.86 percent, up from 8.83 percent last week.
 
Tax-Exempt Yields Rise
Yields of tax-exempt funds were also up for the week.
Assets decreased $41 million in the week, to $77.4 billion, with the average seven-day compounded yield up 6 basis points, to 5.48 percent. The increase was only half as large as that of a week before.
The taxable equivalent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket is 7.61 percent, and about 8.18 percent for investors in a 33 percent bracket.
Donoghue's said the top spot among tax-free funds was shared by the Evergreen Tax-Exempt Money Market Fund, distributed by the Fidelity Distributors Corporation of Boston, and the Calvert Tax-Free Reserves Money Market Fund, distributed by the Calvert Group of Washington. Each posted a 6.06 percent return, about 58 basis points points better than the seven-day average.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 30, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about money market funds misidentified the distributor of Evergreen Tax-Exempt Fund. It is the Evergreen Asset Management Corporation.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Allure of Spain's Phone Company

BYLINE: By Keith Bradsher

 BODY:
THE national telephone monopoly of Spain, Telefonica de Espana S.A., is most popular with investors and stock analysts who use its services least.
American investors, who see growth potential in the earnings of the company and are not familiar with its poor service, have been buying the stock heavily for the last three years. Spanish investors, who use Telefonica's lines every time they pick up a phone, have been sellers. As a result, control over nearly $1.3 billion worth of Telefonica stock, or 17.4 percent, has crossed the Atlantic. The Spanish Government holds 35 percent of the shares. 
Buying stock when the locals are selling is always risky, and so far the Spanish seem to have had the best of the deal. American depository receipts, each representing three shares of Telefonica stock, have climbed modestly since they began trading at $20.875 on the New York Stock Exchange on June 12, 1987. They closed 12.5 cents higher yesterday, at $23.625.
Telefonica's shares have underperformed broader stock market indexes in both countries, and have done poorly compared with most large American long-distance and local telephone companies. Now some previously bullish American stock analysts are beginning to echo the concerns of European analysts.
But so far the trans-Atlantic flows of Telefonica stock continue to be westbound. Demand for the A.D.R.'s in New York has been so strong that American investment banks have been buying shares in Madrid and depositing them with the Banco de Santander and J. P. Morgan & Company to create new depository receipts for sale in New York. Since the initial sale of 18 million in 1987, 53.5 million more worth $1.264 billion have been created by this process, said Angel Garcia, a spokesman for Telefonica.
Several American analysts have recommended the stock because its price-earnings ratio is low using American accounting standards, the Spanish economy is growing and many Spaniards still need telephone service. Using American accounting standards, Telefonica trades at only five times earnings, the lowest ratio of any leading international telephone company.
Telefonica has been especially popular with American mutual fund managers. Fidelity Group mutual funds, led by Fidelity Equity Income, have accumulated eight million depository receipts worth $189 million.
Yet as fast as American institutions buy up the stock, more has come over from Spain. The 71.5 million depository receipts outstanding now represent a fifth of Telefonica's outstanding stock. Leonard S. Hyman, a foreign-telecommunications analyst at Merrill Lynch, has recommended Telefonica's stock since it was first offered in New York and continues to do so.
Spanish and other European analysts have been less enthusiastic about Telefonica. The stock's price-earnings ratio is nearly 10 using Spanish accounting standards, which require much faster depreciation than American standards, and many other Spanish companies have comparable ratios.
More important, Telefonica has begun a huge investment program to bring its network, the ninth largest in the world, up to international standards. Last month the company predicted that it would increase its investment again this year, by 20 percent, to $6.2 billion. The spending will nearly equal Telefonica's entire 1989 sales.
Telefonica is borrowing almost half the cost of its investment program. Efforts by Spanish monetary authorities to curb growth in foreign borrowing have obliged Telefonica to raise money mostly in Spain, where the interest rate on one-year Spanish Treasury bills now stands at 13.5 percent.
High interest costs are likely to prevent Telefonica from showing appreciable growth in earnings per share or raise its dividend until 1993 at the earliest, said Ignacio Gomez Montejo, the research director at FG Inversiones Bursatiles S.A., a Madrid brokerage.
After-tax earnings grew 8.9 percent last year, to $628 million. ''The earnings just weren't coming through,'' said James M. McCabe, a telecommunications analyst in the New York office of Nomura Securities who downgraded Telefonica a month ago from a short-term buy to a neutral rating.
Yet the investment is badly needed, because Spain's rapid economic growth in the late 1980's outpaced the expansion of Telefonica's operations, and the waiting times for new lines in Spain stretched to a year and a half in rural areas. Telefonica says that new investment is improving service, but there has been a deluge of complaints.
Huge American purchases of Telef'onica may have actually become an additional drag on the company's stock. Unlike European institutions, American institutions have bought very few shares in Madrid, preferring the convenience and faster settlement periods of trading Telef'onica's depository receipts in New York.
Some Spanish money managers now fret that American investors may someday decide to reduce their Telefonica holdings and start buying other Spanish stocks, so that their results would more closely reflect the performance of the Spanish stock market as a whole, Mr. Gomez Montejo said. If that happens, he added, Telef'onica's share price would be likely to fall sharply.

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 6.75 Points in Slow Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks went nowhere yesterday in slow trading, plodding ahead by 6.75 points, to 2,743.69, in the Dow Jones industrial average.
Heavy buying and selling in computerized program trading almost canceled each other out, traders said.
Volume rose to 142.3 million shares, from 131.6 million the previous day, with 724 issues advancing and 731 declining. 
The Dow rose for the third time this week, but traders said many people were waiting for March employment figures, due on April 6, before committing more money to the market.
Traders said they were also waiting for the new Japanese fiscal year, which starts on Sunday, to see how heavily the Japanese moved into the American bond market. Big Japanese bond buying would bring down interest rates here - and help American stocks.
Others said they were particularly concerned yesterday about what they called disappointing earnings by Oracle Systems, a high-flying computer company. Oracle headed the Nasdaq's most-active list, sliding by 7 7/8, to 17 1/2, with a record 20.61 million shares, or 16 percent of the company, changing hands.
Wall Street professionals contented themselves with what seemed to be a slow, steady return to takeover fever.
Apple Bancorp, the New York-based savings bank, jumped by 9 1/8, or 28.3 percent to 41 3/8, in the wake of a $38-a-share offer to shareholders from Stanley Stahl, a New York developer who is a large stockholder.
American General, the insurer, headed the Big Board's active list, soaring by 8 1/8, to 40 1/8, on 4.26 million shares after Torchmark, another insurer, offered $50 a share for half the stock and $50 in Torchmark stock for the rest. American called the offer ''unsolicited.''
Amax, the mining company, jumped by 2 5/8, to 28 5/8, on 2.18 million shares, on rumors that it would soon get an offer of $42 a share. The financial columnist Dan Dorfman had said in USA Today 10 days ago that a group headed by Peter Kiewit Sons and a Norwegian company were working on a deal.
Chemicals, utilities, paper, drugs, oil and metals were all strong, while computer issues were weak - except for I.B.M., which rose 1 3/8, to 105 7/8. The Nasdaq index fell 2.81 points, to 436.69, while the Amex market-value index fell 0.65 point, to 361.23, and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.50 point, to 342.00.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Cocoa Hits 7-Month Highs On Concern Over Exporters

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Cocoa futures prices surged to seven-month highs yesterday amid fears that political and economic crises could disrupt exports from the Ivory Coast and Brazil, the world's two largest cocoa producers.
Uncertainty about Brazil's changing economic policies also supported gains in futures prices of sugar and coffee.
On other commodity markets, soybean futures tumbled, copper futures rose sharply, precious metals were mixed, petroleum futures were mixed, and livestock and meat futures advanced. 
Cocoa futures settled $39 to $47 higher on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, with the contract for delivery in May at $1,164 a ton, the highest settlement price of a near-month contract since Aug. 18.
''It was an explosive move, one of the biggest moves I've seen in a long, long time,'' said Arthur Stevenson, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
 
Producer Near Bankruptcy
Civil unrest in the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer, has kept the market on edge for the last six weeks after austerity measures aimed at saving the once-prosperous West African nation from bankruptcy were put into effect.
The market was further supported by rumors that the Brazilian Government had suspended all commodity exports while it untangled bureacratic problems created by economic changes announced two weeks ago.
After the markets closed, the Brazilian Government said that coffee and sugar exports were in effect suspended because of the abolition of two Government agencies that had been responsible for authorizing such shipments.
The Government said cocoa exports were not affected, but that cocoa shipments had been moving slowly because of seasonal factors.
Soybean futures fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade amid heavy selling fueled by reports of ideal harvesting weather for the South American crop and forecasts for rain in the Midwest and northern Great Plains.
Copper futures soared on New York's Commodity Exchange, partly reflecting a resumption of Japanese buying in the physical market. Copper settled 1.9 cents to 4.25 cents higher, with April at $1.205 a pound. The March contract expired at $1.225.
In petroleum trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 40 cents lower to 12 cents higher, with May at $20.08 a barrel; heating oil was 0.50 cent lower to 0.40 cent higher, with April at 55.73 cents a gallon.
Strong cash markets and bullish chart signals helped raise livestock and meat futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: Study Rejects View That Decontrol Cut Air Fares

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
The first study of United States airline fares to account for changes in jet-fuel costs has found that contrary to the Government's recent findings, inflation-adjusted fares have risen since the industry was deregulated in 1979.
The study was released today by the Economic Policy Institute, a nonprofit Washington research institution generally identified with liberals. It also found that airline service has declined since deregulation. 
The study, the latest of several completed in recent years by study groups and government agencies, is likely to fuel the debate on whether airline deregulation has fulfilled its promise of providing lower fares and better service.
 
'Nothing to Do With Deregulation'
Other studies have not taken into account that the price of jet fuel fell 50 percent during the 1980's and that airplanes became more fuel-efficient. ''These changes had nothing to do with deregulation,'' said the author of the new study, Paul Stephen Dempsey, a professor at the University of Denver. Recently, jet fuel prices have begun to rise again, and some airlines have raised fares as a result.
The new study challenges a comprehensive review by the Department of Transportation released in February. The Government study found that air fares were, on average, lower than in 1979, when the airlines' routes, fares and finances were deregulated. The studies of both the Transportation Department and the Economic Policy Institute adjusted their figures for inflation.
Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner is expected to arm himself with the department's study in an effort to ward off attempts to re-regulate the industry.
The Economic Policy Institute found that prices for the average traveler, adjusted for fuel costs, had risen 2.6 percent per mile since deregulation. What is more, the study said that because deregulation has spawned a hub-and-spoke system that has led to more circuitous routing, the cost per trip had risen by 8 percent to 33 percent, depending on the route.
Mr. Dempsey, a former lawyer for the now-defunct Civil Aeronautics Board who once argued in favor of deregulation, proposed that airlines be limited to one domestic hub, that ceilings be set on fares and that a Federal commission be established to regulate transportation. ''The time has come to roll back deregulation,'' the study said.
The study pointed to the consolidation of the industry as a reason for higher fares. The number of large carriers has shrunk to 29 from 39 in 1984, and 8 carriers now control more than 90 percent of the traffic.
 
'Competing Vigorously'
But the airlines say competition is as fierce as ever. ''We may have fewer carriers but those carriers are competing vigorously,'' said David Swierenga, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association, the industry trade group.
Officials at the Transportation Department had not yet reviewed the study, a spokesman said.
The Transportation Department study had found that consumers enjoy more service to more cities, at lower fares, than they did before deregulation. Between 1984 and 1988, fares fell 15 percent on average, that study found. But the Government study also found that in eight cities where one carrier controlled most of the traffic, fares were on average 18.7 percent higher than at other cities.
The new study added that deregulation had also resulted in more flight delays, poorer service and, in the case of some rural communities, no airline service at all.

HEADLINE: For a Comfortable Old Age, Plan for Care, Experts Advise

SERIES: CARE OF THE ELDERLY: PRIVATE BURDENS, PUBLIC CHOICES - LAST OF FOUR ARTICLES.

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
As the average cost of a nursing-home stay climbs to nearly $30,000 a year, experts agree on one main piece of advice for those concerned about preparing for their old age: plan early for long-term care.
The experts say people should not rely solely on their physicians for advice because doctors are often not familiar with the alternatives to nursing homes that are springing up and with the sometimes complicated financial planning that is necessary for a comfortable old age.
In general, the experts say, even people now middle-aged should begin to familiarize themselves with Government and private programs, like those providing at-home care for the elderly, and begin reading the consumer guides on long-term care that are increasingly available.
 
'Make Decisions Early'
''Often, people don't have access to enough information to make intelligent decisions about long-term care,'' said Monika White, associate director of the Senior Care Network of Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena, Calif. The key, she said, ''is to make decisions early, before a crisis hits.'' 
Specialists in the field of long-term care say advice and guidance are widely available on the major points, from purchasing private long-term care insurance and determining Medicaid eligibility to coordinating care in the home. The problem is where to obtain the information.
More than a fifth of all elderly people require some form of long-term care at any given time, whether it is skilled attention in a nursing home or help at home with bathing and meals. Many receive assistance from their family members or friends but many need to rely on volunteers, community programs or paid help.
 
Savings Can Be Jeopardized
Only about one in seven 65-year-olds will ever spend a year or more in a nursing home, but lifetime savings can quickly disappear with the rising cost of those stays as well as the cost of professional care at home.
Typically, the elderly individual is forced to turn to Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for the poor and the only Government program covering long-term care. ''The common expression is that you almost have to go broke to get long-term care in this country,'' said Michio Suzuki, the Acting Deputy Commissioner of the Federal Administration on Aging.
Being caught by the Medicaid safety net is usually a last resort, but gaining an understanding of the complex eligibility requirements can help impart a sense of control, social workers say. And that knowledge could aid in important decisions, like whether to buy private long-term care insurance or whether to pay off a mortgage early.
''There's a lot of planning a person can do, rich or poor,'' Dr. White said. ''There are programs and people you can turn to in most communities to help you make decisions for the future.''
That is not to say the choices are simple or easy. ''My friends always ask me what they should be doing,'' Mr. Suzuki said, ''and, frankly, it's a very hard question to answer.'' The Search Tenacity Pays Off In many parts of the country, support for the struggling elderly person living at home is just beyond the front door. Tenacity is the key to tracking it down.
''There's more to long-term care than stowing away money,'' said Jane A. Tilly, a senior analyst with the American Association of Retired Persons' Public Policy Institute in Washington. ''Are there volunteers out there? Are there public programs?''
This year, more than $1 billion allotted by Congress under the Older Americans Act will trickle down through state governments to the nation's 660 Area Agencies on Aging and, finally, to more than 10,000 centers for the elderly. Both the agencies, financed primarily by Federal funds, and the centers can be vital sources of information and aid.
Established in the early 1970's, the Area Agencies on Aging are charged with administering an array of non-medical services: home-delivered meals, health programs, adult day care, free transportation to doctors' offices, weekly trips to the supermarket and social activities.
The agencies use the ubiquitous senior center to reach the elderly in many towns and cities. Most services are free, but not necessarily widely offered because of constraints on staffing and local financing. ''Our primary goal is keeping the older person in the home and in the community for as long as possible,'' said Jonathan D. Linkous, the executive director of the National Association of Area Agencies on Aging.
 
Specific Individual Plans
To coordinate the range of available health and support services, as well as helping individuals devise a way to pay for them, many agencies and organizations dealing with the elderly offer what they call case management, or service coordination. More than a third of the Area Agencies on Aging offer this service, as do many private home-care agencies, hospitals, insurance companies, senior centers and state and county offices, either free of charge or for a fee.
The Area Agencies on Aging can also steer an elderly person to companies that provide professional home care, with the cost usually ranging from $20 to $50 a day, depending on the number of hours the help is needed and the nature of the help.
One new source of money is available in some areas for the elderly who have significant equity in their homes. Some lenders are marketing what is known in the business as ''reverse mortgages'' in which the lender pays the homeowner. Under the terms of these mortgages, the homeowner is guaranteed monthly payments based on the equity they have in their homes until the day they die or move. When the house is sold, the lender is repaid through the proceeds. Government Help Sorting Out The Benefits Confusion abounds over the two major Government health care programs, Medicaid and Medicare, the Federal health insurance for the elderly, and their provisions for nursing home care.
Medicare pays for very limited long-term care. The plan pays for up to 100 days of skilled care in a nursing home after discharge from a hospital where the stay was at least three days, and in some cases it pays for skilled nursing care in the home for up to 38 days.
Medicaid covers long-term care, but only for those with relatively low assets or income. In many states it provides little support for home care. New York, a notable exception, will spend about $1.6 billion in state, Federal and local Medicaid funds this year to support about 80,000 people in their own homes. In addition, the state will spend $3.3 billion in Medicaid money to support an equal amount of patients in nursing homes.
By the Government's own admission, the system of requirements for Medicaid eligibility is bewildering. An outline of the requirements prepared by the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, the agency overseeing Medicaid, called it ''among the most complicated of any program administered by the Federal Government.''
One problem is that eligibility requirements vary greatly from state to state. Essentially, Medicaid requires that assets not exceed a certain level, usually about $2,000, for an individual, and that income be low or squeezed by medical bills. For elderly people with savings who are facing long-term care in an institution, this means they must spend nearly all of it on that care before they can qualify for Medicaid.
Once on Medicaid, the person must use all income on the nursing home costs, except for a monthly personal allowance, ranging from $30 to $50. Medicaid covers the remaining costs of care. The nursing home must be willing to accept Medicaid's relatively low rates, a requirement that serves to exclude the more expensive institutions.
 
Welcome Asset Change
A widely welcomed change in Medicaid came in 1988 with the passage of the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act. Although Congress repealed most parts of that act last December, provisions protecting the spouse of a Medicaid patient in a nursing home from impoverishment were kept.
Before passage of the new provisions, the spouse at home in some states could keep no more than $2,250 in assets and monthly income of only a few hundred dollars a month. In other states, the spouse living outside the nursing home could keep whatever assets and income were in their names, a situation that was usually a boon to the husband but a burden to the wife.
Now, the wife or husband whose spouse enters a nursing home on Medicaid is allowed to keep at least $12,516 in assets or half of their combined assets, whichever is greater, as long as her half does not exceed $62,580. Some states have simply allowed the elderly to keep up to $62,580, eliminating the formula. In addition, states must allow the wife to retain a minimum monthly income of $856; states can raise that limit to $1,565.
 
Home and Auto Exempt
Because a home is often a person's largest investment, its fate is of particular interest to Medicaid recipients. The home is considered an exempt asset, along with automobile, furnishings and personal belongings, and the elderly person does not have to sell it and ''spend down'' the proceeds to qualify for Medicaid.
If the house was owned jointly and it is clear that the nursing home patient will never return home, most states will end the nursing home patient's Medicaid benefits once the spouse in the community dies. The patient would then have to sell the house and spend the proceeds on nursing home care until the assets were again below the eligibility ceiling.
But if the nursing home patient dies first or if the spouse in the community dies first, and the house had been tranferred to that spouse's name, the house is off-limits for calculating Medicaid benefits.
Out of pride or civic responsibility, some people would prefer to spend all of their own money on their care before going on Medicaid. Others want to protect as much of their assets and savings as possible and try to gain eligibility at the earliest moment.
 
Finding Loopholes in Law
That approach is a subject of controversy. The concern is that the middle-class are finding loopholes in the law, often with the help of lawyers specializing in laws affecting the elderly, and are able to get on Medicaid while retaining their money.
''In the extreme,'' said Nancy M. Coleman, the director of the American Bar Association's Commission on Legal Problems of the Elderly, the question is, ''Why should people who have millions of dollars be able to give it away, go on the public dole, and have you and I pay for it?''
Lawyers specializing in the field maintain that their counsel is aboveboard. 'It's no different than a tax attorney suggesting to invest in tax-free municipal bonds,'' said Daniel G. Fish, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Freedman & Fish. ''What's unfair is that Medicare doesn't cover custodial care.''
The law was toughened in response to the practice of giving assets to heirs before applying for Medicaid. All states are now required to look at a Medicaid applicant's financial transactions over the past 30 months, and if money was given away or assets were tranferred at less than fair-market value, then eligibility is delayed until the individual has paid the nursing home roughly the same amount that had been given away. It is still legal, though, to pay off a home mortgage any time before applying for Medicaid. Also, a house may be transferred to the spouse and in some cases to a child or sibling any time before applying for Medicaid.
Many experts in long-term care caution that it is usually preferable to be a nursing home resident who pays privately than a resident on Medicaid.
''There is a grand illusion that if you get poor, you don't have to worry, that the Government will take care of you,'' said Lynn Goldis, the assistant director of the Senior Care Network in Pasadena. ''But what being on Medicaid means is that you have virtually no choices. You can't shop around, and Medicaid patients are placed in semiprivate rooms.'' Private Insurance Tips for Buying Protection In the mid-1980's, the insurance industry began offering policies to protect people from the potentially devastating financial impact of long-term care. These have been controversial, both because they are expensive and because many of them have provided very incomplete coverage.
Considering whether to buy a private policy ought to begin in people are in their 50's, the experts said. The younger the person, the less costly the premiums, and many companies will reject an applicant in ill health.
Consumer advocates have written reams about the practice in which an insurance agent fails to explore an applicant's medical history thoroughly, only to deny a later claim for nursing home coverage because of a ''newly discovered'' condition that existed at the time the policy was purchased, like heart disease or diabetes.
 
'Very Much Buyer Beware'
But the policies have improved, and some people who work with the elderly say that as long as there is no public insurance, private insurance is the best shield for assets for those who enter long-term care. ''It's very much buyer beware,'' said Mr. Linkous of the National Association of Area Agencies on Aging, ''but it's the only option until this country gets its act together.''
Other experts are opposed to private insurance for long-term care. Robert M. Ball, 75 years old, who was Social Security Commissioner under Presidents John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard M. Nixon, said he would rather rely on his own resources. ''The risk is slight enough and the premiums are high,'' he said. ''If anything happened, I could sell my house.''
The policies are recommended primarily for those people who have a lot to protect. ''It's more for the person with some significant assets and an income of at least $20,000 a year,'' said Gary Claxton, a senior analyst with the American Association of Retired Persons.
 
'A Very Personal Choice'
Even the industry's representatives agree. ''It's a very personal choice,'' said Susan Van Gelder, the associate director for policy development and research at the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade organization.
''Married couples may feel they don't need it now that the spouse in the community can retain a much higher asset level,'' she said. ''Likewise, if Medicaid is within someone's reach, we wouldn't want that person wasting money on private insurance.''
To date, 1.5 million policies for long-term care have been sold, a vast majority of them to people over 65. About 120 companies now offer the policies. While institutional care is stressed, coverage of home care is increasingly available as well. In addition, a few companies are making long-term care insurance available to employees, usually through payroll deductions.
 
Insurers Want an Investigation
But only about 4 percent of elderly Americans now carry private insurance for long-term care. Insurance industry officials believe that far more elderly people would buy it if it were not for the bad publicity. In fact, the Health Insurance Association of America has joined consumer watchdog groups that have documented abuses of policy sellers in calling for a Federal investigation. ''We don't want this market ruined by a few bad apples,'' Ms. Van Gelder said.
The Health Insurance Association of America said a policy offering four years of coverage with a daily benefit of $80 for nursing home care, a 20-day deductible and no protection against inflation, has an average annual premium of $483, if purchased at the age of 50; $1,135 at 65 and $3,800 at 79.
The association said the same policy, but with inflation protection, has an average annual premium of $658 if purchased at 50; $1,400 at 65 and $4,200 at 79. ''Generally, the rate you come in on is the rate you pay for the rest of your life,'' Ms. Van Gelder said.
 
What Policies Should Include
Consumer experts say the best policies do not require prior hospitalization before covering nursing home care; cover both skilled and non-skilled nursing care; provide at least three to five years of coverage; pay for home care; guarantee protection against inflation, and include patients with Alzheimer's disease and other degenerative or dementing illnesses.
The answers on the application should be as detailed as possible to guard against later charges that a debilitating condition predated the signing of the policy.
''It's not for everyone,'' said Alan D. Bogutz, a partner in the law firm of Bogutz & Gordon in Tucson, Ariz., and the founder of the 650-member National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys. ''The very poor are going to qualify for Medicaid and the very rich will foot their own long-term care bills. It's the people in the nebulous middle who need to protect what they have who should consider it.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Survey in Moscow Sees a High Level of Anti-Jewish Feeling

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

 BODY:
A survey of tolerance in the Soviet Union has reported ''disturbingly high levels of anti-Jewish feeling,'' according to the American Jewish Committee, which helped finance the project.
Asked to rate whether they liked Jews, on a scale of one to 11, 18 percent said they disliked them. Another 18 percent said they liked Jews, and 65 percent said they were neutral.
Asked about the anti-Semitism of others, 17 percent said ''most people in the Soviet Union are anti-Jewish,'' 60 percent said ''only some people are anti-Jewish,'' and 19 per cent said ''very few people are anti-Jewish.'' 
The study, based on face-to-face interviews in the Moscow area with a random sample of 506 Soviet adults between Feb. 16 and March 4, found that 8 percent of those questioned agreed with the statement, ''More than any other group in society, it is the Jews who are responsible for the problems the Soviet Union is experiencing today.'' Seventy-nine per cent disagreed, and 13 percent were uncertain.
Thirty-three percent agreed that ''when it comes to choosing between people and money, Jews will choose money,'' and 23 cent agreed that ''Jews have too much influence over Russian culture.''
 
Negative Figures Seen as High
The study was financed by the American Jewish Committee, the National Science Foundation and the University of Houston, and conducted under the auspices of the Institute of Sociology of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. The study directors were two political scientists from the University of Houston, Prof. James Gibson and Asst. Prof. Raymond Duch. Interviewed by telephone yesterday, Dr. Duch said the figures for anti-Semitism in the study were significantly higher than similar figures for the United States. ''Most research in this country indicates a level of hard-core anti-Semitism equal to about 5 percent of the population,'' he said.
He acknowledged that the Soviet study, which comes at the time of an increased Jewish exodus from the Soviet Union under the more liberal emigration policies of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, was confined to Moscow. Attitudes toward Jews in the capital were expected to be relatively liberal compared with the rest of the Soviet Union. Jews make up only about 2.5 percent of Moscow's population, but there are more Jews in Moscow than in any other Soviet city, Dr. Duch said.
The survey questionnaire consisted of 350 questions, and the margin of sampling error was plus or minus 5 percentage points. Eighty-eight percent of the respondents said they were of Russian descent, 3 percent said they were Ukrainian, 2 percent said they were Armenian and 2 percent said they were Jewish.
The question of anti-Semitism was only a part of the overall survey, which had a broad theme of political tolerance in the Soviet Union.
 
Skepticism on Perestroika
On general issues, the survey found increasing skepticism about perestroika, Mr. Gorbachev's program of political and economic restructuring, and concern over insufficient glasnost, or the new increased openness in the press. It recorded a decline in Mr. Gorbachev's popularity and a serious lack of political tolerance.
The high number of negative responses to Jewish-related questions early in the survey prompted the directors to expand that part of their work. But not all the responses to Jewish-related questions were negative.
Of those queried, 91 percent said that ''Jews should be free to decide for themselves whether they want to remain in the Soviet Union or emigrate.'' Ninety percent agreed that ''the Government should make every effort to see that the rights of Jews to equal educational opportunity are respected.'' And 88 percent said the Government should see ''that the rights of Jews to equal employment opportunities are respected throughout the Soviet union.''

HEADLINE: Senate Rejects Plan on Aid to Miners

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29

 BODY:
The Senate, upholding the President and its own leadership by the slenderest of margins, rejected a proposal today for special aid to coal miners who would lose their jobs if clean air legislation was passed by Congress.
The $500 million special assistance package was rejected by a vote of 50 to 49.
At least two Senators who said they planned to vote for the proposal reversed themselves after they were told by the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, that President Bush would veto the clean air bill if the proposal was included.
A veto would have killed the compromise bill negotiated between the White House and Senate leaders and probably would have ended the prospects for clean air legislation this session. The White House said the provision for financial help for miners would make the clean air legislation too costly. 
 
Quick Action Seen on Bill
The defeat of the amendment, which was offered by Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, the former majority leader, removes the last major obstacle to Senate passage of the legislation to strengthen the Clean Air Act of 1970. Final action in the Senate is expected by Tuesday.
The House is still drafting its clean air bill and has not yet addressed the acid rain issue and the problem of miners or other workers who might lose jobs. The miners' jobs would be in jeopardy because the provisions dealing with acid rain would encourage utilities to shift to a type of coal that would reduce pollution.
 
Biden Changes His Mind
At first, Mr. Byrd appeared to have the necessary votes to carry his amendment. But Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. a Delaware Democrat who supported the proposal to assist the miners, voted against it after he left the floor during the vote to take a call from Mr. Sununu.
Mr. Biden reported after the vote that the White House chief of staff warned him that the amendment would break the compromise agreement between the White House and Senate leaders and ''guaranteed the President would veto the bill.''
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, said in a telephone interview that he decided to vote against the amendment after Mr. Sununu had told him its passage would compel a Presidential veto. ''That wouldn't have been in the interest of my state, which is suffering from air pollution,'' Mr. D'Amato said.
Senator J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana, who Mr. Byrd said would have voted to help the miners, was attending a funeral and did not vote.
Thirty-seven Democrats and 12 Republicans voted for the amendment, while 16 Democrats and 34 Republicans voted against it.
The Byrd amendment was opposed by the majority leader, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, and the minority leader, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, who both argued that providing special assistance to the coal miners would set a bad precedent and that workers in other industries would demand the same relief.
Mr. Byrd, who remains one of the most influential members of the Senate, made an extraordinary personal effort to win passage of his amendment. After he lost, he told reporters: ''I made the supreme effort. I did everything I could and, therefore, I don't feel badly about it.''
The Senate bill, as well as legislation being prepared in the House, would require require a reduction in sulfur dioxide emissions of 10 million tons a year, which, along with nitrogen oxides, is the chief component of acid rain. All the reductions would be made by coal-fired power plants, most of whuch are in nine Midwestern states.
The reductions could be made by installing devices on smokestacks to remove sulfur. But a less expensive approach likely to be adopted by many utilities is to shift from coal with a high sulfur content to low-sulfur coal. Such a shift is expected to result in the closing of a number of high-sulfur coal mines, particularly in West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Illinois and Indiana.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 31, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday about Senator Robert C. Byrd misidentified him. He is the former Senate majority leader; Senator George J. Mitchell now holds the post.

HEADLINE: Veto of Idaho Abortion Bill Is Possible

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho, March 29

 BODY:
Faced with one of the most difficult decisions in his long political career, Gov. Cecil D. Andrus, today offered the first hint that he might veto a restrictive abortion bill passed by the Idaho Legislature last week.
Governor Andrus, a longtime opponent of abortion and a Democrat in a state dominated by Republicans, said he had not yet reached a final decision about the bill. But he said he was particularly troubled by provisions that could, in some instances, prevent a victim of rape or incest from obtaining an abortion in the state.
He insisted that he would not be influenced by aggressive lobbying campaigns by those on both sides of the abortion question that have taken aim at the heart of Idaho's economy: its potato industry and tourism. 
''I am concerned that this bill may narrow it to the point where a woman who has suffered rape, incest or a threat to her life might be unable to receive an abortion,'' he said. ''Basically, that's what I'm agonizing over.''
 
Decision Expected Soon
The Governor, who is expected to decide soon, has three options. He could sign the bill, veto it or let it become law without his signature.
The last option is unlikely, said Marc Johnson, the Governor's press secretary. ''I know of only one instance where he's let something become law without his signature,'' he said. ''That's not his preferred way of doing business.''
The bill at the center of the battle was designed to give the Supreme Court of the United States a way to challenge its landmark decision in the 1973 Roe v. Wade case that legalized abortion.
The Governor's office, normally a quiet reception center for schoolchildren and curious visitors, has received more than 2,000 phone calls a day on the measure. #10,000 Pounds of Potatoes Today, supporters of abortion rights, who have threatened to boycott Idaho's No. 1 crop, dumped 10,000 pounds of potatoes on the Capitol steps. On Wednesday abortion opponents were out in force at the same place, many of them carrying signs reading, ''Pro-life, pro-spud.''
Idaho produces 10 billion pounds of potatoes every year, worth $650 million to the state's farmers. That represents nearly one of every three potatoes grown in America.
''I can't ignore that threat, but it will not have anything to do with my decision,'' Governor Andrus has said. ''I will not be pressured by one group or another.''
Ever since Molly Yard, the president of the National Organization for Women, first raised the boycott threat earlier this week, groups favoring the bill have pledged to eat three times as many Idaho potatoes as before if the measure becomes law.
''We are calling for the massive increase of purchases of Idaho potatoes,'' said Beverly LaHaye, the president of the Concerned Women for America.
 
'I Had No Idea'
Mark Ricks, a state senator who opposes abortion and is also a potato farmer, said the boycott calls caught him by surprise.
''I had no idea these kinds of repercussions would result,'' he said. ''I think it's unjust and narrow minded.''
Business leaders, too, said they are dismayed by the events.
''It's inappropriate and unfortunate that the potato industry has become involved with abortion politics,'' said Fred Zerza, a spokesman for the J. R. Simplot Company, a concern that provides french fries for McDonald's Corporation.
Jim Hawkins, director of the Idaho Commerce Department, said the Governor's attempts to revive this state's economy could be threatened by the abortion issue.
''It's the damnedest thing I've ever seen in my life,'' said Mr. Hawkins. ''One minute somebody calls up with a big business order saying they'll cancel it if the Governor signs the bill. The next minute it's just the opposite.''
Abortion opponents say the bill passed by the Idaho Legislature was specifically designed to appeal to one Supreme Court Justice, Sandra Day O'Connor, who is believed to hold a swing vote on abortion.
But some abortion opponents, among them Richard Wilkins, a law professor at Brigham Young University who conferred with Governor Andrus yesterday, say the Idaho bill is far too restrictive to pass a review by the Supreme Court.
 
Bill Provides Four Exceptions
The bill would ban all abortions except in cases of rape reported to police in seven days, incest if the victim is younger than 18, severe fetal deformity or threat to the physical health of the mother.
Under the language of the law, a woman who is raped could be refused an abortion if the alleged rapist wanted to challenge her claim.
''It puts the government into the business of finding out who's reponsible for a pregnancy,'' said State Senator John Peavey, the chairman of the Senate Democratic caucus. ''There are some serious constitutional flaws in that bill, and I think the governor is starting to pick up on that.''

HEADLINE: Black Enrollment in College Up After Long Decline, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
Reversing years of decline, enrollment of black students at colleges and universities in the United States increased from 1986 to 1988, particularly in private institutions, according to new figures compiled by the United States Department of Education.
Much of the rise is being attributed to an institutional trend toward being more creative and aggressive in recruiting minority students while offering them more financial aid, experts said yesterday.
''We frankly don't know all the reasons for this,'' said Richard Rosser, president of the National Institute of Independent Colleges and Universities, which on Wednesday made public its analysis of the Federal statistics. ''But clearly, we've seen a major increase in the effort.'' 
 
Modest Rise in Public Schools
Black enrollment rose 7.1 percent at private colleges and universities from the fall of 1986 to the fall of 1988, the data show. At public institutions in the same period, the rate of increase was much more modest, 0.2 percent.
Similar increases are also found in figures compiled by the United Negro College Fund and obtained yesterday. They show a 5 percent rise last year over the previous year in the entry of black students into the fund's 41 member institutions.
Minority students make up 19.9 percent of the student population at public institutions and 18.4 percent at independent schools.
Adrienne Rhodes, spokeswoman for the organization, said much of the increase was represented by college-bound black men, a dramatic reversal.
Throughout the 1980's, college enrollment by black men was on a steady decline, prompting educators and sociologists to voice concern about a socio-economic gap emerging between black men and women.
Last year the American Council on Education reported that the ratio of black women to black men in college was higher than any racial group. About 60 percent of black college students were women in 1986, according to the council.
 
Reagan Cuts Cited
Over all, black enrollment fell 5.4 percent at independent colleges and 4.6 percent at public institutions from 1982 to 1986, according to the Federal figures, which are compiled every two years. Some educators attribute that drop to sharp cuts by the Administration of President Ronald Reagan in Federal student grants and loans, which greatly affected minorities who disproportionately tend to come from families with low incomes.
But Dr. Rosser, who for 10 years was president of DePauw University in Greencastle, Ind., said independent colleges and universities had doubled their financial assistance to students since 1980. From 1970 to 1980, he said, assistance rose only about 9 percent.
Gay Clyburn, a spokeswoman for the American Association of State Colleges and Universities, said public colleges, where most of the country's black students have enrolled because of the generally lower costs and more liberal admission requirements, had made a concerted effort to recruit blacks. Despite that, she said, for the last decade the association's figures showed black enrollment decreasing.
Mrs. Clyburn said the Federal figures showing black student gains ''were a surprise to us.''
 
Call to 'Focus on Retention'
But Ed Wiley, the assistant managing editor of Black Issues in Higher Education, a biweekly publication based in Fairfax, Va., said: ''We should not get too excited over these figures in isolation. We have to focus on retention as well.''
Some schools are reporting substantial results from programs that link public middle and high schools to colleges, such as use of mentors, college counsels, and tutors.
At Earlham College, a four-year liberal arts school in Richmond, Ind., administrators began offering black applicants from Indiana grants rather than loans, said Len Clark, the college provost.
He said black parents ''don't like to go into debt, and they worry about their ability to pay the loans back.
''We are pretty clear that this policy is having a positive impact on black applicants,'' he said.
Minority students make up 10 percent of the school's student body of 1,100, Dr. Clark said.
''We think the best liberal arts education is one that exposes students to the diversity of people in this country and exposes them to the world,'' he said. ''We are not doing this for blacks; we are doing it for students because we know they learn from their environment.''

HEADLINE: For Eastern Europe, Free Trade, Not Aid

BYLINE: By Phil Gramm; Phil Gramm of Texas is ranking Republican on the Senate Subcommittee on International Finance.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As Eastern Europe emerges from an economic dark age, America has a unique chance to create jobs, hope and opportunity there -not through aid but through free-trade agreements, like the one we're now discussing with Mexico.
To be sure, there should be strings attached: international trade requires convertible currencies, private property must be guaranteed and there must be free movement of labor and capital, including the right to emigrate and the free flow of foreign investment.
Poland is probably the closest to meeting these conditions, but other countries, such as Czechoslovakia, are not far behind and should be offered a free-trade agreement as they qualify. 
This is the only economic program for bringing Eastern Europe into the modern era that is almost guaranteed to succeed. Instead of reinforcing weaknesses, as foreign aid tends to do, increased trade draws on the strengths of our economy and the creativity of a new breed of European entrepreneurs.
Foreign aid as an instrument for promoting development in Eastern European has two drawbacks: it costs money, and there is no reasonable assurance that our money will buy any particular economic result, much less a desirable result.
Even the Philippine Government, which rode a wave of popularity to power, teeters because the economy remains in shambles, as it was under President Ferdinand E. Marcos. There is continued large-scale Government control, cronyism and interference in the marketplace.
Government domination of the economy failed in Eastern Europe, not simply because it reflected oppression but because it did not work. And it has not worked anywhere else, even when supported with our tax dollars and good intentions.
Trade is the only way we can help bring about social and economic modernization in Eastern Europe; it will also generate benefits for the U.S. instead of simply costing us money. By any measure, international trade dwarfs any foreign aid that we or the rest of the world can provide. The total of foreign aid from every source in 1988 was $65.7 billion; total world trade was $2.45 trillion.
Countries such as South Korea, Taiwan and others that we call newly industrializing have received U.S. foreign aid, but they have relied primarily upon international markets to drive their economic development.
Economics aside, a free-trade agreement provides a political vision of where Eastern Europe (and the rest of the world) should be heading. The Eastern Europeans haven't been filling the streets merely for the right to vote: they have risen against government control of their lives.
A free-trade agreement with the Polish people - and other nations as they are ready - will do more to liberate them from the constraints of controlled economies and controlled politics than any other action the U.S. can take.
With total U.S.-Poland trade at about $1 billion, there is plenty of room for an embryonic trade relationship to grow. If our trade with Poland doubled as a result of a free-trade agreement, it would still be less in dollar value than our trade with Costa Rica.
Consequently, there should be few U.S. industries facing measurable dislocation from a U.S.-Poland pact, while many U.S. businesses would benefit. The same would be true of pacts with other countries that once were members of the Soviet bloc.
Eastern Europeans are ready to reject the tangle of protectionist practices that only shield special interests, foreign and domestic. We can sharpen their hope for freedom and economic opportunity. That hope springs from trade, not aid.

HEADLINE: Fire in the Bronx;
Social Clubs Quickly Turn Heavy Profits for Investors

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
The economic ladder in the social club business spans the gap between street-smart entrepreneurs in New York City's poorest neighborhoods and wealthy, established real-estate operators - and along the way, everyone seems to make money.
Club operators - like the owner of the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx who died in a fire that killed 87 people - generally pay no taxes, buy and sell liquor illegally, take in up to thousands of dollars a night, and occasionally cut corners when it comes to health and safety.
Building owners, sometimes working through intermediaries who sublease the property, can take in far more rent from social clubs than they can from other legitimate tenants in low-income neighborhoods, making the risk worthwile, for some.
 
'Will Look the Other Way'
''If you rent a store for $2,500 a month that could get only $1,500 on the market, some owners will look the other way, figuring that nothing will happen,'' said Mark Engel, the president of the Bronx Board of Realtors.
Mr. Engel, like many other building owners, said he considered social clubs an often unavoidable nuisance that, despite an occasional crackdown, continue to be a way of life in growing immigrant neighborhoods. At present, he said, he manages only one building with a social club - a property owned by the city. 
A review of hundreds of building records from the last few years lists what the Police Department terms nuisances - mainly illegal clubs large and small - and shows that many are owned by long-established real-estate investors, with the City of New York the largest owner of all. Some of the clubs are believed by the police to have been shut or moved elsewhere since they were included on the list.
One of the largest individual owners on the list is Alex DiLorenzo 3d, who owns the Happy Land property. A check of Manhattan and Bronx properties on this list showed that he owned or managed 11 club sites, 3 of which, including Happy Land, had received vacate orders because of safety concerns.
Mr. DiLorenzo, who is an heir to part of what once was one of the largest real-estate concerns in the city, has purchased commercial property in several low-income neighborhoods. Records show that at each of the three locations ordered closed - at Happy Land, at a second club around the corner at 877 East Tremont Avenue and at 3650 Broadway, near 150th Street, in Manhattan - arrests for illegal sale of alcoholic beverages were made after the clubs had been ordred closed.
 
Others on List
Also on the list was one property owned by Seymour Durst, the Diplomat Hotel on West 43d Street, and one at 3825 Broadway, near 159th Street, which is listed in the name of Sol Goldman, who before his death had been a partner of Mr. DiLorenzo's father in the 1960's and 70's.
Mr. Durst, in an interview last night, said he could not explain why the hotel, which now houses a few long-term tenants, was put on the list. He said much of the building, which formerly had late-night clubs, is now shut down.
Also on the list is a building at 4000 White Plains Road in the Bronx listed in the name of Robert A. Mosbacher, the United States Secretary of Commerce. Stanley Stern, who works for the Mosbacher family, said Mr. Mosbacher was a trustee of a trust that owned the property and that no improper activity was carried out there.
Inspector Frank Biehler, the commander of the Social Club Task Force of the Police Department, said the Mosbacher site was put on the list at the request of the police precinct after complaints that a bar at the site was unlicensed. He said that subsequently the bar either obtained or produced a liquor license.
 
Indelible Part of Landscape
Both real-estate executives and anthropologists who have studied the situation have said social clubs have been an indelible part of the landscape in many communities, dating at least to early in this century when Italians and Jews, often from the same town or village, gathered in their own clubs.
Xavier Totti, an anthropologist and professor of Puerto Rican studies at Lehman College who has studied social clubs, said they often function as a network for jobs, housing, schools and a market for people who want to buy and sell posessions.
He said Happy Land, which catered to Hondurans, was typical of many of these clubs. It charged $5 for admission on weekends and $3 for a drink. Just down the street, he said, a large Puerto Rican club called Visions, which had live musicians, charged $110 per table for admission, a bottle and setups. The club closed down the day after the Happy Land fire.
While some social clubs are quite small, others like Happy Land accommodated hundreds of people a night. One Bronx real-estate executive noted that a club like Happy Land could earn its steep monthly rent on a weekend night. The monthly rent, originally $1,500, had since gone up to $1,950.
 
Big Profit on Drinks
''No one ever thinks about whether they're illegal or have a license,'' he said. ''Many people are used to thinking of licenses as something you get by bribery. Sometimes they apply for a liquor license for a one-night fund-raising event or party and continue to display it.''
Inspector Biehler said many clubs make their biggest profits on drinks. Bottles, bought for $7 or $8, sold by the drink for $2 or more a shot, can bring in $50. And bottles are routinely refilled with cheaper liquor.
''Anybody who thinks that because a bottle says Dewar's, he's getting Dewar's ought to go to the hospital for a mental examination,'' he said. ''There is no way in the world to know what's in those bottles.''
This has led to illegal cost-cutting. Karl Felsen, a spokesman for the State Taxation and Finance Department, said tax officials had uncovered a smuggling ring bringing in untaxed rum from the Dominican Republic, which was intended in part for the social club market.
Since social clubs are cash businesses, requiring little capital for a rudimentary establishment, the opportunities for profits are large, and the temptation for landlords willing to cut corners is great.
At Happy Land, the property owner, Mr. DiLorenzo, leased an entire block of stores to a second company, Little Peach Realty, for 30 years, which in turn leased a storefront to Elias Colon, the Happy Land operator. Mr. Colon died in the fire.
Bronx real-estate dealers said the net leasing of the property is often used by Mr. DiLorenzo and other property owners, who are speculating that a property will increase in value over decades, but do not want the hassles of finding tenants and collecting rent in poor neighborhoods.
 
Long-Term Lease
The company or individual taking a long-term lease to manage the property cannot make money on the appreciation of the assets and is under pressure to push up the rents to cover the cost of the long-term lease and assure a profit.
Mr. Engel said that, while he was not familiar with the Happy Land operation, he thought that most property owners tried to be responsible and to check out potential tenants carefully and look for and follow up on illegal uses of the property. But he said that evicting social clubs through the courts can be difficult.
A review of the city list shows that many social clubs have at one time or another found a home in city-owned buildings. A review of building records in Manhattan and the Bronx shows that at least 49 social clubs, including 36 in Manhattan, were identified in city-owned buildings.
 
Seized Over Taxes
Many appeared to be commercial buildings, seized for the nonpayment of taxes, that were managed by the city's Department of General Services. In a statement issued late yesterday, the department said it could not respond in detail until the list is reviewed.
''No illegal activity should be taking place within any of these buildings or establishments owned by the city of New York,'' the statement said.
Marilyn Sopher, whose husband, Morris, is listed as the owner of seven properties in the Bronx reported to have had social clubs, said the clubs grew in number gradually over time.
She said only ''one or two'' had been leased for the purpose of being a social club, while the others pretended they were leasing the building for another purpose. She said that when this happened, it was particularly difficult to evict the tenant.
