LENGTH: 1141 words

HEADLINE: Fire in the Bronx;
Fire Survivor Tells Of 'All the Screams' He 'Can't Forget'

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
A doorman raced up the narrow back stairs of the Happy Land Social Club, a light wave of smoke trailing him. ''Fire! Fire!'' he shouted as he burst onto the dance floor, but the scores of revelers hesitated in fear.
The eyewitness account of how so many perished when the illegal club was set ablaze early Sunday was given yesterday in an interview by Felipe Figueroa, one of two people who were on the club's crowded second floor and survived.
Despite the smoke, Mr. Figueroa, who calls himself Phillip, said he managed to rush down a second staircase and find his way to safety, essentially unharmed. 
Lieut. James Malvey, a principal detective on the case, said he and others who questioned Mr. Figueroa believed his story. Mr. Figueroa's presence was also corroborated by a friend of his, Ruben Valladares, who was the club's disk jockey and the only other survivor, the detectives said.
Mr. Valladares remains in critical but stable condition at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx with burns over about 40 percent of his body. Doctors have given him slightly better than an even chance of survival.
 
'My Mind Can't Stop'
Mr. Figueroa, a part-time disk jockey who was dropping in at the club to help Mr. Valladares, described his own, less visible wounds.
''I can't sleep here anymore,'' he said, slapping the boiler outside his cramped, $60-a-week room in the basement of a South Bronx tenement. The boiler's muffled roar, he said, reminds him too much of the screams he heard.
''My mind can't stop,'' he said. ''All the screams, all the noise, and the moment when my friend came out of there screaming. I can't forget that.''
Fire Department officials estimate that 68 of the club's 87 victims were trapped and asphyxiated on the crowded second floor of Happy Land. The police and fire officials believe that four, and possibly six, people on the ground floor of the club also escaped.
None of the survivors have explained in detail how so many were killed.
Mr. Figueroa said he came to New York in May 1986 from the Honduran coastal city of Trujillo. He has worked mostly as a $200-a-week delivery man for a Washington Heights furniture company, saving what he can for the records and sound equipment that he hopes will allow him to earn a living as a disk jockey back home.
For more than a year before the fire, he said, he spun records at Happy Land or stopped by the club to help his friend Mr. Valladares, who grew up in the same Cristales neighborhood of Trujillo. Scattered around his tiny apartment, old fliers recalled parties he entertained at the Happy Land and other clubs and dance halls in the Bronx.
Last Saturday night he stopped by Happy Land, on Southern Boulevard just off East Tremont Avenue, with thoughts only of a good time, he said. Around midnight he was ushered in free of charge, as usual, but stayed only a short while before heading for another club in the East Tremont section.
Mr. Figueroa said he returned to Happy Land at about 2 A.M. on Sunday. He remembered passing the new coat-check woman, Lydia Feliciano. She was talking to a man who Mr. Figueroa now believes was Julio Gonzalez, the unemployed Cuban immigrant who the police say set the fire in a fit of jealousy.
The atmosphere on the second floor was ''pretty good,'' Mr. Figueroa said, but some people were already starting to leave. Mr. Valladares reached for a favorite Jamaican reggae song, ''Young Lover,'' by Coco Tea.
''The floor got so full that a lot of people couldn't dance,'' he said. ''Then you heard it coming up the stairs.''
 
'People Went Crazy'
The shouts were those of one of the club's two doormen. The other doorman, Mr. Figueroa said, was on the dance floor with a girlfriend.
''He was yelling, 'Fire! Fire!,'' Mr. Figueroa said, his voice rising. ''He came onto the floor and yelled, 'Fire! Fire!' Right away, people went crazy. ''Some ran this way and that way. Some people didn't make a big deal out of it. I could see a little smoke coming upstairs.''
The doorman waded onto the dance floor, he said, apparently sifting the crowd for his own girlfriend.
''He was yelling in English,'' Mr. Figueroa said, ''so I started yelling, 'Fuego! Fuego!' Ruben turned off the music and turned on the lights and yelled 'Fuego!' into the microphone.
''People were already desperate. Everybody was running around. I think that since so many came from families, they were all looking for their relatives.''
 
Oxygen Supply at Risk
It might already have been too late. A Fire Department spokesman, Efrain Padilla, said that under the club's low ceiling - so low that the 5-foot-6-inch Mr. Figueroa, standing flat-footed, could touch the mirrored globe revolving above the dance floor - the fire could have sucked out all oxygen in minutes.
A spokeswoman for the Medical Examiner's office, Ellen Borakove, said the second-floor victims were believed to have died of smoke inhalation. But Mr. Padilla said the lack of oxygen could have caused them to lose consciousness in seconds.
''I looked downstairs, and all you could see was smoke,'' Mr. Figueroa said of his vantage point at the disk jockey's booth, just next to an alternate staircase at the front of the club.
He rushed down the steep stairs anyway.
 
'Down, Let's Go!'
''Everyone saw me go for it,'' he said. ''I yelled, 'Down, let's go!' There were a lot of people around those stairs, but nobody followed me. I could hear all the cries, lots of people saying, 'Mama!' I heard something explode, like a light.''
Downstairs, Mr. Figueroa said, he could barely see. By mistake, he burst into a storage room filled with coats. But knowing the club well, he quickly found the northern exit door, through which Elena Colon, the wife of the club owner, Ms. Feliciano and at least two young patrons had already scurried. Mr. Figueroa hit the crash bar on the door and suddenly found himself on the street.
Perhaps a minute later, Mr. Valladares stumbled through the other door, wrapped in flames.
''He let out some screams that I remember too much,'' Mr. Figueroa said. ''I didn't even know who he was - he was so burned, all deformed. But he wears a lot of chains, and I recognized him by the chains.I ripped off his shirt, which was still on fire. His whole body was shaking.''
 
'I Couldn't Let Go'
In what seemed like seconds, Mr. Figueroa said, his friend was gone in an ambulance.
''I couldn't let go of his clothing,'' he said. ''When I got to the house of his sister, to tell her, I was still holding it.''
Mr. Figueroa ran a thumb and forefinger along the border of a prized snapshot taken during a party at the sister's house last summer. It shows Mr. Figueroa on one knee, toasting the camera, with Mr. Valladares flashing a broad smile over his shoulder.
''He's never going to have that smile again,'' Mr. Figueroa said.

LENGTH: 848 words

HEADLINE: Cuomo Reveals List of Big Cuts In Budget Pact

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 29

 BODY:
To goad members of the Republican-led State Senate to drop their insistence that the state's budget gap be made up through spending cuts alone, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today made public the list of cuts that he and legislative leaders had agreed on privately.
The cuts, totaling $500 million, would significantly reduce state aid to higher education, mental health and local governments. Some state agencies - the New York State Commission on Cable Television, for example - would be eliminated and 600 employees throughout state government would be laid off.
New York City, which is suffering from its own budget problems, would lose about $100 million in aid that it had been expecting. The cuts are subject to approval by members of the State Legislature. 
 
'Study This List'
Mr. Cuomo said that by releasing the list he hoped to demonstrate that the Republicans' demands for deeper spending cuts were unrealistic and destructive.
''Study this list, ladies and gentlemen of the State of New York, and tell me whether you think we should do more,'' he said.
The Governor and the Assembly Speaker, both Democrats, say that the most judicious way to close the gap is through a combination of cuts and taxes. The new taxes Mr. Cuomo has proposed include an expansion of the state sales tax to cover new items like non-prescription drugs and an increase in the taxes on alcohol and cigarettes. The Governor and legislative leaders from both parties agreed to the $500 million in cuts in meetings this week after Standard & Poor's reduced the state's credit rating on Monday.
The list being circulated is expected to provoke a fierce round of lobbying by groups, like public employee unions, that would be affected by the cuts. And with only two days left before a new state budget is supposed to be in place, many officials said today that they were fearful that the release of the list could further delay an agreement. $1.5 Billion Budget Gap Explaining his action, Mr. Cuomo said, ''At one point the public has to be allowed into the process.''
The spending cuts enumerated by the Governor today are intended to help close a budget gap that is now estimated at $1.5 billion.
This gap represents the difference between the spending proposed by the Governor for the upcoming fiscal year, which starts on Sunday, and the revenues that the state now expects to collect during the year. Cuomo aides have attributed the gap in the $51 billion proposed budget to an unexpectedly sharp downturn in the economy.
Senate Republicans have maintained that the entire gap should be made up through spending cuts, though privately many concede that new taxes will be needed.
Today, the Senate Republicans appeared nonplused by the release of the list of cuts, but said that it would not affect their stance.
''Clearly it was a political move to put pressure on us, and I'm sure it will,'' said the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I. ''But it's just one of the moves in the budget battle. And I don't think the Governor got a lot out of it.''
 
Reducing Existing Services
''We're realistic,'' Mr. Marino said. ''We realize there's a limit to the cuts. But we're trying to make a very important point, and that is we've been overspending all these years.''
Some of the spending cuts outlined today would necessitate reductions of existing state services. Other cuts would reduce the amount that was supposed to be spent to start new programs or expand services.
Of the proposed cuts, these would be the most substantial:
* A 2 percent reduction in state aid to the City University of New York, totaling $15 million, and a 2 percent cut in the State University of New York, totaling $21 million.
* An $85 million decrease in new state aid to local school districts.
* A $67 million reduction in spending on social programs, including Medicaid and foster care.
* An $18 million cut in state spending on mental health programs.
The administrative budgets for the Governor's office, the Legislature and the judiciary branches would all be cut by 2 percent, for a total savings of $26 million.
Dozens of smaller programs would also be cut. Advertising for the state's lottery, for example, would be reduced by $2 million. One of Mr. Cuomo's favorite programs, the Liberty Scholarship program for poor students, would be cut by $700,000. And the Christopher Columbus Quincentenary Commission, headed by Mr. Cuomo's wife, Matilda, would have its budget cut by $100,000, or 66 percent.
The cuts include a reduction of about 1 percent in aid to local governments across the state. Officials in New York City, who expected to receive about $10 billion from the state this year, said the decrease in aid would be painful.
''They're trying to shift a lot of the state burden to us,'' sad the New York City Budget Director, Philip R. Michael. ''We'll balance our budget, but it's certainly not going to be pretty.''
The Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, called the cuts ''a very painful list, if you really take a look at it.''

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Up Slight 0.4%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29

 BODY:
Consumer spending narrowed to a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in February, the Government said today.
Analysts blamed weak car sales for the slowdown, but some said buying momentum was building in other areas of the economy. 
The Commerce Department said personal consumption totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.63 trillion, the smallest increase since a three-tenths of 1 percent gain in October.
Consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, jumped 1 percent in December and January. The January increase was even stronger than the six-tenths of 1 percent originally reported.
Personal income rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.64 trillion, after a seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in January, which was revised down slightly from the eight-tenths of 1 percent first reported. The February income gain matched a nine-tenths of 1 percent advance in November.
''The spread between income and consumption growth in the near term is a negative, because consumers have buying power but are not unleashing it,'' said Michael P. Niemira, an economist with the Mitsubishi Bank in New York.
The increase in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, totaled $15.9 billion.
Spending on durable goods - expensive items expected to last more than three years - dropped $14.6 billion, due in part to weak car sales.
''Autos were still a depressant going into March,'' Mr. Niemira said. ''But, on the other hand, department store sales were doing quite well in March.
Purchases of nondurable goods gained $10.9 billion, while spending on services rose $19.6 billion.
The report said individual incomes after taxes rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in February, up from eight-tenths of 1 percent the previous month.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New Incentives Offered by Ford

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 29

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company fattened cash rebates and lowered interest rates on some company-financed loans on six car and truck lines. The car maker's current incentives will extend through April 30 to try to move some of its slow-selling models before the 1991 versions appear. 
Ford is offering buyers of the Escort incentives that include company-financed loans at a 2.9 percent annual rate. The company will begin selling a new 1991 Escort on April 26, although it plans to continue producing the older model through the end of May. Escort sales are down by 25 percent from last year. The new incentives cover the Cougar, Thunderbird, Taurus, Sable, Probe, Mustang, Aerostar van and Bronco II models, as well as the Escort.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Temporary-Job Pioneer Giving Up Olsten Title

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
William Olsten, a pioneer in the temporary-employment business, is stepping down as chief executive of the Olsten Corporation at age 70, but plans to remain active as chairman.
Mr. Olsten will be succeeded by Frank N. Liguori, 43,, who is currently president and chief operating officer. His titles will now be vice chairman and chief executive. 
Mr. Olsten's son, Stuart, 37, has been named president and chief operating officer. The Olsten family owns 38 percent of the company's stock, which is traded on the American Stock Exchange.
William Olsten started the business 40 years ago in New York City. Today, with revenue of $761 million and 535 offices, the company, based in Westbury, L.I., is the third largest in the temporary-employment industry.
As World War II started, Mr. Olsten, who grew up in Yonkers, began working in the General Motors assembly plant in Tarrytown, N.Y., which had converted from making Chevrolets to assembling Avenger torpedo bombers. Mr. Olsten was in charge of the left wing, and his workers were mostly women, whom he trained.
He was soon drafted, and ended up with the Third Army in Europe. After the war, Mr. Olsten began working in sales and marketing for a company that made caps for milk containers, but he decided to go on his own. ''I'd heard about this industry,'' he said of the temporary-help business. ''It wasn't an industry then, it was just getting off the ground.''
Mr. Olsten's one-man office grew and he opened offices in other cities. Today, Olsten is in all states. The business is sensitive to economic downturns, Mr. Olsten said. ''We feel it first, but we get out of it first,'' he said, explaining that toward the end of a recession, as business picked up, the temporary industry benefited as employers remained wary of hiring permanent workers.
The new chief executive, Mr. Liguori, is a graduate of St. Francis College and worked for the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand before he joined Olsten in 1971. Stuart Olsten, the new president, is a graduate of Syracuse University and joined Olsten in 1975.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Olsten, The Olsten Corporation

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dealers Don't See a Trend In Sharp Drop of the Dollar

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar dropped sharply yesterday against the Japanese yen and other leading currencies, but dealers argued that the decline did not signal an end to the recent upward trend.
''This is not a change,'' said Richard E. Witten, vice president for foreign exchange at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York. ''The trend is intact, and that is for a higher dollar.'' 
In late New York trading, the dollar was at 156.26 yen, down from 158.60 on Wednesday. Against the mark, the dollar stood at 1.6930, down from 1.7110. The dollar also fell against the British pound, the Canadian dollar and the Swiss franc.
The fall of the dollar against the yen began in Tokyo, spurred by a newspaper report that the Ministry of Finance, in an effort to support the sagging yen, had asked big institutional investors to curtail their buying of dollar-denominated securities. Although the report was officially denied, it drove the dollar down.
Still, traders wrote off the decline as an ''expected correction'' that always occurs after a currency moves quickly in one direction or another. The dollar had moved almost 5 yen, or 3 percent, higher in just four days, and more than 6 percent since the start of the month. The fall against the West German mark also came after a recent, but much less dramatic, upward move of the dollar.
While the upward trend might not be over, yesterday's decline may have reined in the dollar at least until traders hear the results of a meeting of the Group of Seven nations in Paris on April 7. The dollar's strength, particularly against the yen, is expected to be a central topic.
At the last several meetings of the Group of Seven, comprising the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada, the finance officials have initiated moves, backed by coordinated selling of dollars, to bring the dollar down. But then the dollar was considered to be too strong against both the yen and the West German mark.
Now the dollar is far stronger against the yen, even at the 156-yen level of yesterday. It is far outside the range of 120 yen to 140 yen that the Group of Seven is believed to prefer.
But the dollar, at 1.6930 marks, is below the Group of Seven's preferred range of 1.70 marks to 1.90 marks. Still, both the West Germans and American Treasury officials have indicated they would like the dollar to move a little lower.
This dichotomy reduces the likelihood of major action. Neither the West Germans nor the Americans seem to be in a position to lower interest rates, which would weaken their currencies.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Cocoa Soars to Highs Again On Concerns Over Supplies

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The price of cocoa futures surged to seven-month highs yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York on speculation that economic turmoil in Brazil and the Ivory Coast could disrupt supplies.
No disturbances were reported yesterday in the Ivory Coast, the leading cocoa grower, after a violent confrontation on Wednesday between the police and demonstrators in Abidjan, the capital of the West African nation.
On other markets, livestock and meat futures were mostly lower, grains and soybeans advanced, precious metals gained and energy futures finished mixed. 
In New York, cocoa futures settled $21 to $27 higher, with the contract for delivery in May at $1,190 a ton, the highest settlement of a near-month cocoa contract since Aug. 16. The rally followed a $47 increase in the May contract on Wednesday.
Harry Schwartz, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. in New York, said most of the buying was again by speculators.
The collapse of cocoa prices last year to 14-year lows was disastrous for the Ivory Coast. Its citizens have recently been calling for the resignation of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, who has ordered strict austerity measures to save the country from bankruptcy.
In Brazil, cocoa movement out of the country remained extremely slow amid continuing confusion about economic reform measures introduced two weeks ago to fight inflation. ''In the fullness of time, Brazil will get its house in order and start exporting again,'' Mr. Schwartz said.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, precious metals edged higher, as the dollar weakened against most primary foreign currencies.
Gold settled $1.70 to $1.90 higher, with April at $370.80 an ounce, while silver finished 2.9 cents to 3.1 cents higher, with April at $4.946 an ounce.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, livestock and meat futures fell. The selling came before the Agriculture Department's quarterly report of hog-and-pig inventories, scheduled to be released today. The report is expected to show a 2.6 percent decline in the American hog herd.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark crude, settled 5 cents lower to 13 cents higher, with May at $20.03 a barrel, while heating oil finished 0.06 cent to 0.44 cent higher, with April at 56.17 cents a gallon. Unleaded gasoline was 0.22 cent to 0.60 cent higher, with April at 57.67 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Securities Prices Tumble

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, pushed lower by overnight selling in Japan and end-of-quarter liquidations by American dealers.
Market participants said the urge to unload securities in Japan was stimulated by reports that the Ministry of Finance was advising big institutions against taking large positions in dollar-denominated assets in the coming fiscal year, which begins on Monday.
In addition, dealers said banks and other market participants were unloading securities to tidy up first-quarter balance sheets.
''For reporting purposes, a lot of banks and other players don't want to have a lot of longs and shorts on their books at the end of the quarter, so they sell them out,'' one government bond trader said. 
But Edward J. Sawicz, chairman of the Discount Corporation of New York, a primary dealer in government securities, said the bulk of the selling was related to the reports from Japan.
''I don't know if these reports are true or not, but people are treating this as if it were fact,'' he said. ''The reports have been weighing on the market all day.''
 
Sharp Drop in Prices
The sharp drop in prices, which amounted to nearly 1 1/4 points for some issues, or almost $12.50 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, nevertheless left yields inside the trading range they have occupied for the last few weeks.
''The recent yield range on the 8 1/2 percent five-year Treasury notes, which I like to watch, has been between 8.73 percent and 8.44 percent,'' said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc. ''At a yield of around 8.60 percent, where they are now, they are moving toward being on the cheap side.''
An announcement from the Resolution Funding Corporation that it will sell an unspecified amount of 40-year bonds on April 10 provided further incentive to sell longer-dated securities.
Refcorp, created by Congress to finance the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, said it would announce the size of the auction on Wednesday. Most analysts expect that $5 billion of securities will be sold.
 
Refcorp Auction
The Refcorp auction will be followed in subsequent weeks by Treasury auctions of 7- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.
''A good part of what is happening in the long end of the market is in anticipation of future supply,'' Mr. Brachfeld said.
Reflecting that concern, prices of the Treasury's bellwether 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered late yesterday at a price of 99 2/32, down 1 7/ 32 points, to yield 8.58 percent.
Among note issues, yields on the two-year and four-year notes that were auctioned earlier this week rose sharply.
The 8 1/2 percent two-year notes auctioned on Tuesday were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.64 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent four-year notes, which received an enthusiastic reception at Wednesday's auction, were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 8.65 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills moved modestly higher.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.82 percent, up two basis points, or hundreths of a percentage point. Six-month bills rose by the same amount, to a late offered rate of 7.82 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by four basis points, to 7.75 percent.
Yesterday the Treasury sold $13 billion of 16-day cash management bills at an average discount rate of 8.15 percent.
The plunge in Treasury prices spilled over into the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds.
Traders said prices of actively traded long-term securities fell by as much as 1 1/4 points. Intermediate-term issues dipped by 1/2 of a point to 5/8 of a point.
By comparison, the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds emerged relatively unscathed.
Market participants said bids on some issues fell by 1/4 to 3/8 of a point in thin trading.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board said two of the three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended March 19. The nation's basic money supply measure, M1, was unchanged.
Also, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said it had named SBC Government Securities Inc., a subsidiary of the Swiss Bank Corporation, as a primary dealer of government securities. The New York Fed also said Drexel Burnham Lambert Government Securities is no longer a primary dealer.
The addition and deletion keeps the number of primary dealers at 44. Primary dealers are the designated securities firms that deal directly with the New York Fed.

HEADLINE: Public Found More Hopeful

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Consumers feel more optimistic about future business prospects than they did last month but less positive about current business conditions, a survey released on Wednesday has found.
The Conference Board, the business research group, said its consumer confidence index for March rose by 3.5 points from February, to 110.2, the best improvement in five months. The survey, conducted by National Family Opinion Inc., covers 5,000 households in the United States.
About 20 percent of the respondents said they thought that current business conditions were ''bad,'' the survey found. That is an increase of 2 percent from last month. But looking ahead six months, people were significantly more optimistic about job prospects and business conditions than they were in the first two months of the year.
More people said they planned to buy a car, although fewer reported planning to buy a house. Interest in buying major appliances also fell.

HEADLINE: Idaho Governor Vetoes Measure Intended to Test Abortion Ruling 26

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho, March 30

 BODY:
After a week of intense lobbying and threats to the economy of his state, Gov. Cecil D. Andrus of Idaho tonight broke ranks with some supporters and vetoed a bill that would have given Idaho the most restrictive abortion law in the country.
''The bill is drawn so narrowly that it would punitively and without compassion further harm an Idaho woman who may find herself in the horrible, unthinkable position of confronting a pregnancy that resulted from rape or incest,'' Governor Andrus said.
Mr. Andrus said his decision was not influenced by the threat to boycott Idaho products, issued this week by groups that support abortion rights.
 
No Chance for an Override
He also lashed out at anti-abortion groups outside of Idaho that wrote the legislation in an effort to bring a challenge to Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion nationwide. ''Somebody thought Idaho looks like a patsy,'' he said. ''I submit to you: Idaho is not a patsy.'' 
The bill, which passed the Idaho Legislature last week, would have outlawed about 95 percent of all abortions in the state. A woman would have been able to obtain a legal abortion only in cases of rape reported to police in seven days, incest if the victim were younger than 18, severe fetal deformity or a threat to the physical health of the woman.
The Legislature recessed for the year shortly before Mr. Andrus announced his decision, meaning that it will not have an opportunity to try to override the veto.
In any case, supporters of the bill said they did not have the votes to override a veto, which would require a two-thirds majority. The original votes on the bill were 26 to 17 in the Senate and 47 to 36 in the House. In addition, backers of the bill said they had no plans to place the measure on the November ballot as a citizens' initiative.
Mr. Andrus's veto ended what many opponents of abortion had said was their best chance to enact a state law that could be used to challenge Roe v. Wade.
 
Abortion Opponents Criticize Andrus
But Guam, an American territory in the Pacific, enacted a law banning most abortions and making it a crime for a doctor to provide one. A Federal judge has blocked enforcement of the law until a trial of a lawsuit challenging it, which is scheduled to begin on May 8. That case could also be used as a challenge to the 1973 Supreme Court ruling.
Given the past statements of Mr. Andrus, supporters of the bill had said they thought they had an ally in the three-term Governor, who has said he will seek a fourth term this fall.
Abortion opponents booed and made catcalls at the Governor's announcement and said they no longer considered Mr. Andrus an ally, who had long been supportive of opponents of abortion.
''The Governor has no right to call himself pro-life,'' said Brian Johnston, the western director of the National Right to Life Movement.
Mr. Andrus, a Democrat in a state dominated by Republicans, said his decision was not a change of views on abortion, but rather a reaction to what he called objectionable portions of the bill. He had hinted at his decision on Thursday when he voiced many of the same objections he gave today as the reasons for his veto.
 
'Compound the Tragedy of Rape'
''This law would force the woman to compound the tragedy of rape,'' Mr. Andrus said. Referring to the seven-day reporting requirement for victims of rape, he said, ''On the eighth day, she ceases to be the victim and becomes a criminal.''
The Idaho bill, which followed language advocated by the National Right to Life Committee, was aimed at the perceived objections of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who is considered the swing vote on a divided Supreme Court.
While Justice O'Connor has voted to uphold abortion restrictions in every case she has heard on the Supreme Court, her written opinions have stopped short of an unambiguous declaration that Roe v. Wade should be overturned.
By putting the onus on doctors to decide who meets the requirements of the Idaho law, abortion opponents say they hope to satisfy what they see as Justice O'Connor's main objection to abortion restrictions: making a woman criminally liable if she has an abortion. In essence, the Idaho legislation shifts that burden entirely to doctors.
Mr. Andrus said he was upset by the the legislation's being directed at one Justice. The bill, he said, ''was conceived outside our state for the sole purpose of getting this issue back before the Supreme Court. I believe, and am confident the people of Idaho believe, that we can make our own judgments on this terribly important issue.''
 
One of Several Efforts
The Idaho bill was one attempt to ban abortions in several state legislatures after the Supreme Court ruling last July in the Missouri case Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, in which the Court supported state limitations on abortion and which many saw as opening the way for states to take more authority in regulating access to abortion.
Mr. Andrus said anti-abortion legal advisors told him ''there is not the remotest chance of this legislation being found constitutional by the Supreme Court.
Even some strong anti-abortion scholars and political leaders believed that the Idaho bill went too far to gain acceptance by the Court or the Governor.
Among other things, critics noted that under some circumstances the bill would have made it illegal for a victim of rape to obtain an abortion. Only incest victims under age 18 would have been able to terminate a pregnancy. And while the bill contains a provision allowing abortion if the physical health of the woman is threatened, no exception is made for mental health.
Some abortion opponents say a pregnancy can never be terminated, regardless of who fathered the child. Those who draw a line at incest or rape or physical impairments are often accused of being in favor of limited abortion.
Such questions posed problems here and are likely to continue to divide the ranks of abortion opponents nationwide.
As the Idaho measure made its way through the state Legislature, some suppporters urged amending the bill to give it a better chance of gaining approval from Mr. Andrus and the Supreme Court.
But leaders with the National Right to Life Committee said they would withdraw support for the bill if it was was significantly altered.
Even before the Legislature passed the bill, abortion rights advocates here had gathered nearly half the 39,000 signatures needed to put an initiative on the ballot in November. That measure, if passed by voters, would make abortion legal in Idaho through the first 26 weeks of a pregnancy.
For the past week, Mr. Andrus has been saying that his decision would be based on ''what is best for Idaho,'' and today he said the lobbying and the threats were the major reasons for his decision.
Idaho provides about a third of the nation's potatoes, and advocates of abortion rights have threatened a boycott of the state's potatoes. It is unclear exactly how much a nationwide boycott could hurt this state, which is enjoying record prosperity after years of a faltering economy. But in the last week, food and tourism business had reported cancelled orders and trips.
Tourism, which is worth $1.5 billion annually, is the fastest growing segment of the state's economy.

HEADLINE: 81 Nations Seeking More Food Aid for Africa

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, March 30

 BODY:
The United States and the representatives of more than 80 other countries appealed today for additional donations of food and money for Ethiopia, Angola, Mozambique and the Sudan. They called existing pledges inadequate and said that without further aid hundreds of thousands of people could die of starvation this year.
The appeal was made at the end of a weeklong meeting of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's Food Security Committee. It expressed concern that world cereal production had fallen behind consumption for the third straight year, reducing stocks, forcing up prices and curbing donations of food to famine-stricken countries. 
The committee noted that food was becoming increasingly scarce in those African countries because of drought and long-running civil wars. It also called for a new international agreement guaranteeing safe passage for relief supplies to ''those in need.'' Such an accord would work to stop governments locked in civil wars from trying to starve their opponents into surrender by cutting off outside aid, as has happened in Ethiopia and the Sudan.
 
'Further Human Suffering'
In a communique, the committee appealed for ''further bilateral and international assistance to meet the substantial uncovered emergency relief needs of Angola, Ethiopia, Mozambique and Sudan,'' saying that without such additional food supplies, these countries faced ''further human suffering and loss of life.''
Rough calculations by the Food and Agriculture Organization and the World Food Program, which distributes much of the free food nations provide to countries threatened by famine, suggest that at least 1 million more tons of food are needed by these countries, on top of the 1.3 million tons already promised, to avoid famine.
''Without a further substantial increase in food-aid pledges, we will be risking serious famine and many deaths in these worst-affected African countries,'' the organization's Assistant Director General for Economic and Social Policy, B. P. Dutia, said.
Strife-torn Ethiopia, according to the organization's calculations, faces a food-aid ''gap'' of around 600,000 tons this year, with needs of about 1.1 million tons, but has pledges of only about 500,000 tons so far, including 175,000 tons from the United States.
 
Another Critical Problem
Getting the food to needy people is also proving to be a critical problem, said Bronek Szynalski, the World Food Program's Director of Relief Services. The Ethiopian Government is allowing relief agencies to truck about 3,000 to 4,000 tons a month from Assab to needy people in rebel-held areas in Northern Wallo on the border of Tigre province.
The Food and Agriculture Organization puts Mozambique's unmet needs for food aid at 233,000 tons this year, with a total requirement of 755,000 tons and pledges so far of about 522,000 tons. But the World Food Program has just raised its estimate of the country's food-aid gap to 436,000 tons.
In Angola, the F.A.O. estimates that current pledges for food aid fall about 127,000 tons short of the country's needs of about 282,000 tons this year. But the World Food Program has just raised its estimate of the country's deficit to 435,000 tons.
Officials of the Food and Agriculture Organization say that in the Sudan, adequate supplies are available now for dispatch to needy people in the civil-war torn southern half of the country, following the Government's recent decision to allow relief operations to start up again. But money is still needed to pay for transportation.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Kohl Emerging as Europe's Top Leader

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 30

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany is becoming the dominant leader of the 12-nation European Community, something that seemed evident today in his confident mood and manner after two days of talks with the community's biggest skeptic, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.
At a joint news conference, the leaders said they agreed that a united Germany should remain part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, with all of its territory under the protection of NATO's nuclear umbrella. But when Mrs. Thatcher said she disagreed with Mr. Kohl that German unification should speed up European political and economic union, he just smiled.
He also made no attempt to conceal amusement over Mrs. Thatcher's growing domestic political troubles, chortling when she made what amounted to a retraction of critical comments about him in an interview published in the West German newsmagazine Der Spiegel last Monday. 
 
'A Great Lady'
''Margaret Thatcher is a great lady - a very strong-minded lady,'' he said afterward. ''I have my own ideas, too; my opponents have been underestimating me for years, and I've made a good living out of it.''
Mrs. Thatcher has never liked him, her aides say, and a year ago she barely concealed her contempt for Mr. Kohl's refusal to agree then to proceed with modernizing and increasing the number of American short-range nuclear missiles stationed in West Germany. In the much different world of today, Mrs. Thatcher conceded on Thursday night, NATO could probably reduce its short-range weapons in Germany, and today no obvious difference existed between her position and his.
The new respect Mrs. Thatcher and the other European leaders have shown for Mr. Kohl reflects several facts. First, Mr. Kohl led his Christian Democratic allies in East Germany to a spectacular election victory on March 18, increasing his chances of re-election as Chancellor in the West German vote in December.
Second, after agreeing with Britain and France in December that Mr. Kohl was pushing too fast for unification, the Bush Administration switched in February and came down on his side, helping to create the four-power negotiating framework between the two Germanys and the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union.
Finally, after months of refusal to acknowledge that reunification could not mean regaining lost German territory in Poland, Mr. Kohl bowed to pressure from Warsaw, Paris, Washington and London and agreed to say that the existing borders were inviolable.
When the East German elections came, Mr. Kohl's political stature was rising, while Mrs. Thatcher and President Francois Mitterrand of France were mired in political troubles.
But during the uncertainty of last winter, the momentum toward greater European political and economic unity after the realization of a single European market at the end of 1992 faltered. Mr. Kohl said today that the prospect of elections for a united German Parliament as early as the second half of next year ought to get it moving again.
''Those who want a united Germany to be firmly integrated into European structures must logically support further progress in European unification,'' Mr. Kohl said, and when the 12 European Community leaders meet in Dublin on April 28 to discuss the German question, he said he would press not only for economic and monetary union but political union, too. ''For me, the goal is the political unification of Europe,'' he affirmed today.
 
Words 'Mean Different Things'
Mrs. Thatcher said: ''I think sometimes that words are used which mean different things to different people. We already have extensive political cooperation.''
Asked whether she agreed with Mr. Kohl that the powers of the European Parliament should be strengthened, she replied coolly, ''At the moment, I see no need for any further increase.''
Mr. Kohl spent considerable time during his visit repeating his support for a joint pledge by the East and West German Parliaments on the German borders. In Der Spiegel's interview, conducted last Friday, Mrs. Thatcher had dug up the hatchet:
''I heard Helmut saying, 'No, I will not guarantee, I will not accept the present border' - I heard him say it at Strasbourg after dinner,'' she said in the interview, referring to the French city where the European Community leaders met in December.
Mr. Kohl's spokesman, Hans Klein, said today that Mrs. Thatcher's remark must have been discussed privately by the leaders at 10 Downing Street this morning. Asked about it today, she said she had sent messages of congratulations to Mr. Kohl after he changed his mind three weeks ago ''and I congratulate him on it now.''
Turning to him, she asked, ''Do you want to add anything?'' Mr. Kohl, a smile as wide as the Rhine on his face, said, ''I am very, very satisfied with this answer.''
Mrs. Thatcher continues to be skeptical about Britain's prospects of joining the European exchange-rate mechanism, the first stage of European monetary union, soon. She insists that the other countries must allow full freedom of capital movements throughout the community and that Britain must reduce its inflation rate -now at 7.5 percent, and expected to rise soon - before it can join.
But a remark Mrs. Thatcher made to Der Spiegel best sums up the change in the European chemistry. ''We have to get used to having one country in Europe that is far stronger than the rest,'' she said. ''Everyone has to accept that there is a bigger Germany.''

HEADLINE: Harry Bridges, Docks Leader, Dies at 88

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Harry Bridges, a leading figure in America's 20th-century labor movement who organized the West Coast longshoremen in the 1930's, died of emphysema yesterday at his home in San Francisco, the longshoremen's union reported. He was 88 years old.
The Australian-born Mr. Bridges, who entered this country by jumping ship in 1920, was an unyielding unionist at a time when dock strikes could still cripple segments of the economy. He was labeled a Communist by Congress, which sought to deport him as an ''undesirable alien.'' 
He was a dapper, hawk-faced man with a disarming smile who mellowed with age. The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, which he headed until 1977, has lost much of its membership and influence to technology.
 
A Salute From San Francisco
Mayor Art Agnos of San Francisco ordered city flags to be flown at half-staff in his honor. ''Harry Bridges' death leaves a void that can never be filled,'' the Mayor said. ''He was a legendary figure in the labor movement whose courage and devotion to principle will never be forgotten. All of San Francisco mourns this loss.''
Alfred Renton Bryant Bridges was born July 28, 1901, in Kensington, a suburb of Melbourne. He began his working life as a store clerk, but the novels of Jack London lured him to sea when he was 16. He was shipwrecked twice, once staying afloat on his mandolin.
In 1920, he entered the United States aboard the barkentine Ysabel, but left the crew after arguing with the skipper about the treatment of seamen. He drifted from San Francisco to Mexico, working in the oil fields and as a rigger, and later returned to sea on American merchantmen.
He was in the crew of a ship that arrived in New Orleans in 1921 during a strike. He reported for picket duty and was in charge of a picket squad when the walkout ended. But first he was arrested and jailed overnight, an experience that prompted him to join the Industrial Workers of the World, who were called ''Wobblies.'' He thought the moderate American Federation of Labor had betrayed the strikers.
 
Toll of the Hard, Hard Work
Years later, he recalled that he left the Wobblies after three years because he lost faith in them - ''I forget why.''
Mr. Bridges, who never lost his Australian accent, came to the San Francisco docks in 1922, when stevedores reported for the ''shape-up'' before sunrise to be picked for work or sent away. Continuous hefting of cases and the steady pull of the longshoreman's hook left one hand like a claw for the rest of his life.
His passion for union organization and growing militancy came to the fore in 1933 when he led a group of organizers to establish a longshoremen's local on the San Francisco docks. In six weeks, most dock workers had signed up for the new International Longshoremen's Association local, which demanded wages higher than the prevailing $10.45 a week, coast-wide recognition and a 30-hour week.
Mediation failed and the I.L.A. struck in May 1934. On July 5, the police charged a picket line in which two people were killed and a hundred injured. Martial law was declared. A general strike followed, stopping most industries for three days. The Pullout From the Old A.F.L. Mr. Bridges pulled his I.L.A. local out of the American Federation of Labor in 1937 and took it into what was to become John L. Lewis's militant Congress of Industrial Organizations, He also reorganized his own union, renamed the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, independent of I.L.A.
Antagonism between the rival organizations persisted for years, with Mr. Bridges denouncing the I.L.A. for ''corrupt'' dock-work practices and the I.L.A. shunning him as a ''Communist,'' though he denied ever having joined the Communist Party.
As president of the I.L.W.U., Mr. Bridges enjoyed strong support from his men when Congress tried to deport him in the 1940's. The House of Representatives voted 330 to 42 to deport him, to be oveturned later by the Unites States Supreme Court. In fact, the Court twice ruled in his favor against charges that he was a Communist and had lied about never having been a party member.
 
The Support From the Reds
Mr. Bridges insisted that it was the rank and file that built his union. ''I just got the credit for a lot of it,'' he told an interviewer in 1985. ''I happened to be around at the right time.''
About his acceptance of Communist support, he was not apologetic. Without a treasury to speak of, he explained, the union needed all the help it could get. ''Some of my ideas I had before I knew anything about Communists,'' he said.
Despite his radical reputation, Mr. Bridges also was proud of the ''mechanization and modernization'' agreement he worked out with management in the 1960's to reduce labor costs through improved productivity. In return for higher wages and pension guarantees, the agreement allowed cargo to be handled with mechanical loaders and shipped in prepacked containers.
At the time, the agreement prompted a rising by militants who charged that the former labor revolutionary had become ''a partner of the bosses.''
Mr. Bridges is survived by his wife, Noriko; four children, Julie Fales, Robert Bridges, Jackie Jourdan and Katherine Bridges, all residents of the Bay area; five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.
The union said his ashes would be scattered in San Francisco Bay. A memorial will be held by the LOcal 10 of the I.L.W.U. at Longshoremen's Hall in San Francisco Saturday, April 14.

HEADLINE: Barbara Baer Capitman, 69, Dies; Created Miami Art Deco District

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Barbara Baer Capitman, whose vision and persistence helped to turn a rundown area of Miami Beach into a vibrant Art Deco historic district, died of congestive heart failure on Thursday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach. She was 69 years old and suffered from diabetes and heart tremors.
Ms. Capitman, who had lived in Miami since 1973, applied her talents to arouse renewed interest in 1920's and 1930's buildings throughout the country. Radio City Music Hall and the Chrysler Building are among the best examples of Art Deco. 
''My whole life had been Art Deco,'' she once said. ''I was born at the beginning of the period and grew up during the height of it. It's a thing of fate.''
 
Headed a Preservation League
In 1976 she helped to found the Miami Design Preservation League, which in 1979 won Federal historic designation for the South Beach district of Miami Beach. Her outspoken, unorthodox manner later led to her ouster from the group.
''She would push and agitate and cause trouble until people wouldn't speak to her,'' said Michael Kinerk, chairman of the Art Deco Weekend festival. ''She was interested in results, not social sensitivities.''
The South Beach district is now on the National Register of Historic Places, the only 20th-century district on the register. That status brought Federal tax relief to what had been a depressed area. It is now enjoying an economic and cultural rebirth.
 
Chapters in Other Towns
Mrs. Capitman, president of the Art Deco Society of America, helped found chapters of the society in several cities, including New York, Washington, Chicago, San Francisco and Los Angeles. She was the author of ''Deco Delights'' (1989; E. P. Dutton).
She was born in Chicago and attended New York University. She later wrote advertising copy and was a reporter for The Atlantic City Daily World, which has ceased publication.
Her husband, William Capitman, died in 1975. He was a market researcher and economist and in later years a teacher at Florida International University.
Mrs. Capitman leaves two sons, Andrew W., who lives in London, and John A., who lives in Cambridge, Mass., and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: For Mexico, It's No Fad

 BODY:
This week's announcement that Mexico and the United States would seek to negotiate a bilateral trade agreement appears to be part of a trend. Last year the United States and Canada signed such a pact, and now Senator Phil Gramm has called for offering similar agreements to the struggling countries of Eastern Europe if they create market-based economies.
Are bilateral free trade pacts a sound policy -or a dangerous fad? In the case of Mexico, a close neighbor and large trade partner, the answer is sound policy. In the case of more distant nations, the answer is dangerous fad. A proliferation of bilateral pacts would undermine current U.S. efforts to negotiate multilateral, non-discriminatory trade agreements. 
There is obvious appeal to the idea of a free trade pact between the U.S. and Mexico. U.S. capital and high-tech exports would flow into Mexico, directly helping consumers and forcing Mexican businesses to produce better and cheaper goods. And the mere fact of such an agreement would mark an end to Mexico's 80-year policy of economic protectionism; foreign investors around the globe would be likely to respond favorably.
The U.S. will also benefit - from inexpensive Mexican oil, textiles and manufactured goods. And a more prosperous Mexican economy should ease the flow of illegal immigrants, alleviating a serious source of friction between the two countries. Yet bilateral free trade pacts may also victimize innocent allies. If Mexico, or Eastern Europe, for that matter, gains privileged access to the U.S., exports from Central and South America of items like textiles will suffer. Michael Aho, Director of Economic Studies at the Council on Foreign Relations, predicts that the politics could become ferocious and might subjugate important trade policy to legislative whim.
Furthermore, bilateral pacts can damage the U.S. economy by diverting trade from low-cost foreign suppliers. For example, Brazil may sell dresses to the United States for less than Mexico. But if the U.S. imposes tariffs on Brazil but not Mexico, U.S. consumers will buy from Mexico anyway. As a result the American economy will have to spend more of its output on dresses than it needs to.
Still, in the case of Mexico, these possible drawbacks are far outweighed by the potential benefits to both countries. Where economies are so entwined and negotiations are possible, governments have an obligation to explore the possibilities.
Extending the same offer to more distant nations makes much less sense. Negotiations over a new international trade agreement are at a delicate stage and are scheduled to conclude by the end of the year. A rush to sign new bilateral pacts would signal a weakened U.S. resolve to establish fair rules that apply equally to everyone. Now is not the time to send such a message.

HEADLINE: The Case for the Mentally Ill

SERIES: Help the Homeless Off the Street - New Calcutta: An occasional series

 BODY:
Under the budget cuts, whole mental health clinics would be closed. What will happen to the people who depend on them for therapy? The suicidal will become more suicidal. Some will die. The extremely irrational will become more irrational and even less able to cope. 
Those fears come in a letter from a New York mental patient anguished by news of proposed cuts in the mental health budget. He raises a compelling point. As the state's bureaucrats and legislators struggle with New York's fiscal crisis, there are some consequences they dare not ignore.
With the Governor and lawmakers now agreed on a budget gap of $1.5 billion, no spending category can be immune. But mental health stands out because even modest cuts could have devastating effect, both on mental patients and their communities.
Cities around the state are struggling to help thousands of troubled mental patients. New York officials have recently become willing to acknowledge the failure of past state policies and to try to help. The cuts announced so far would suspend, if not reverse, that effort.
State officials argue that cuts to mental health aren't out of line. Mental health administrators were counting on $509 million next year to keep up with inflation and sustain existing programs. Budget makers reduced that by $46.9 million but allowed about $26 million in new programs. The list of additional cuts released on Thursday would deduct an additional $22.5 million. Why all the fuss about the net loss of $42.5 million?
Because the cuts fall heavily on programs that keep the mentally ill off the street. In Suffolk County, cutbacks would strand some 700 patients who now rely on three programs for daily support. New York City would lose 674 workers in mental health clinics, along with money for psychiatric emergency rooms and single-room-occupancy housing. Services to more than 5,000 patients would be curtailed. The city's new mental health commissioner, Billy Jones, fears ''a permanent dismantling of the community-based mental health system.''
A budget crisis is no excuse for such an abandonment of basic decency, especially when past state mental health and housing policies did much to create the problem of the homeless mentally ill.
Beyond that, the proposed cutbacks mean that millions of New Yorkers will be forced into more daily confrontations with the bizarre, even grossly offensive behavior of mentally ill people who manifestly deserve supervision and care. A budget crisis is no excuse for that either.

HEADLINE: Will Albany Save Our Heritage?

BYLINE: By John B. Oakes; John B. Oakes is former Editorial Page Editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:
It will be a tragic failure of vision and leadership if, because of the New York State budget crisis or other reasons, the single most important initiative of the Cuomo administration is permitted to founder.
The $1.9 billion Environmental Bond Act of 1990 was proposed earlier this year by Gov. Mario Cuomo for submission to the voters in November. Its most important provision now stands in danger of being compromised away or sabotaged altogether. For the sake of the future, this must not be allowed to hap-pen. 
New York State is facing an environmental emergency. Unlike global warming or ozone depletion, this is one that can be solved only by New Yorkers acting alone.
This is an emergency that says: if we do not take strong action to protect and preserve the best of what is left of our environmental heritage -scenic landscapes, wild forest and wilderness areas, pristine lakes and streams, natural habitats, underground water reserves - we and our descendants will never have the opportunity again.
For this reason, exactly half the bond act as the Governor originally proposed it - $950 million, to be expended over a 10-year period - is to be allocated to the state's most pressing environmental need: land acquisition.
Under the Governor's plan, $175 million more was designated for municipal parks and historic preservation. The remainder was to be divided among other environmentally related activities, including $230 million for closing of landfills and recycling of solid wastes.
Of those items, preservation of open land is far and away the most urgent. Every day, top-quality open space is going down in quantity and up in price.
Even during a temporary economic slowdown, as at present, the continuous pressures of speculative real-estate development on such land -whether along the Hudson Valley ''greenway,'' in the pine barrens of eastern Long Island, the Finger Lakes, the Adirondacks, the Catskills or on the Ontario lake shore - are irresistible. The consequent destruction of natural values is irremediable.
Because of lethargy, bureaucracy and inadequate funding, much that should have been protected for the future in these and other particularly vulnerable areas has already been lost.
The state has totally exhausted its resources for direct acquisition of land. Not a dollar is left. The floating of long-term bonds is the most conservative, fiscally responsible and traditional way of funding the purchase of land or easements. New funding is essential now, while the opportunity to buy from willing sellers at relatively manageable prices still exists.
The annual budget crisis provides no excuse for sabotaging the bond act, which is a long-range program that the state can well afford. It will average out in cost to the taxpayer in debt service less than $130 million annually over a 30-year term. This is peanuts in a $51 billion annual budget. There will be no cost at all next year.
The $950 million allocated by Governor Cuomo to land acquisition will yield only $100 million annually, which is no more than what was spent last year. This is barely minimal, considering that at least $2.5 billion needs to be spent for such projects, to be acquired by the public for permanent protection.
The strongest push for re-slicing the bond-act pie comes from politicians with their eyes on fat contracts for their constituents in the construction business. They want more than the $230 million already provided to municipalities for solid-waste management - and want to take it from land-acquisition funds.
The mandatory closing of municipal landfills as well as the start-up of recycling programs and other public works indeed present municipalities with tough financial problems. But they furnish no justification for robbing the state of funds to insure the most fundamental aspect of its environmental future: the protection of sensitive natural areas.
The political maneuverings over the budget and the bond act must not be allowed to shrink the present land-acquisition allotment so much that an environmentally enthusiastic public will come to look on the Environmental Quality Bond Act of 1990 as a fraud.

HEADLINE: Legislators Say Rises in Tuition Are on the Table

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 30

 BODY:
For months, lawmakers here had vowed that raising tuition at the state's public universities would be unmentionable when this year's budget negotiations came around. That's because they tried it last spring, but were humiliated when students seized campus buildings in protest and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo vetoed the increases anyway.
Now, in what many Albany officials are rationalizing as a sign of the dire nature of their budget problems, tuition increases are not only being mentioned, they are also being actively promoted by legislative leaders.
But this time, still clearly stung by the debacle they suffered last year, the legislators insist that they will take no action unless the Governor assures them beforehand that he will go along. 
''Sure, you can say the idea is out there, it's on the table,'' one lawmaker said today. ''But you also better say the Governor has got to push for it.''
Tuition at both the City University of New York and the State University of New York has remained constant since 1983. At SUNY it is $1,350 a year, and at CUNY it is $1,250. Both figures are well below the national average for public universities, according to the Education Commission of the States, a Denver-based research group.
 
Not Ruling Out Increases
Mr. Cuomo maintains that he is opposed to increases, preferring other ways to raise revenue, but will not rule them out.
''I don't think the Governor would ever be so unwise as to say that higher tuition is absolutely, positively, unequivocally out of the question,'' his spokesman, Gary G. Fryer, said today. When asked about raising tuition at a news conference earlier this month, Mr. Cuomo said, ''At one point, if common sense and logic overwhelm you, then you do it.''
Whether it will be done remains unclear, as the budget is still being pieced together, and the decision now appears to be entirely in Mr. Cuomo's hands. Aides to both the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, an Oyster Bay Republican, and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, said they would support tuition increases if Mr. Cuomo does.
The increase vetoed by the Governor last spring was $200 a year for both systems. That amount, minus the extra tuition assistance that the universities would be obligated to pay, would bring in about $26 million in added revenue from SUNY students and $15 million from those attending CUNY. These would go into the state's general fund, thus reducing the present budget gap.
A $200-a-year tuition increase has been most often cited by lawmakers this week, but some have suggested that the increase should be even higher. The national average for tuition at public universities is almost $2,000 a year.
 
No Effect on Poor Students
Last year's tuition increase set off protests by students that included the seizing of buildings at eight CUNY campuses. At a news conference on Thursday in New York City, CUNY student leaders said they would again oppose any increases but stopped short of promising another round of takeovers at campuses.
The president of the student association at SUNY, Judith Krebs, who is also a member of the SUNY board of trustees, said she was strongly opposed to higher tuition, which she maintained would drive away some students. SUNY officials said higher tuition would have no effect on poor students because financial assistance for them would be increased.
Meanwhile, Dr. D. Bruce Johnstone, the SUNY Chancellor, suggested this week that public university tuition be raised annually at a rate tied to inflation, which he said would be more intelligent than sharply raising tuition every few years.
Many other university officials have lobbied behind the scenes for tuition increases, though they have publicly emphasized that a final decision was up to Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature.
Lawmakers were furious with SUNY officials over last spring's tuition drama. The officials lobbied them vigorously and successfully for authorization to raise tuition for in-state students. Then, instead of criticizing Mr. Cuomo for his veto, the SUNY officials worked with him to restore new funds and in the process used at least $5 million from a rainy day fund that some lawmakers said they had known nothing about.

The Economy
 The nominee for the top savings regulatory post won a vote in a Senate panel. After intense lobbying by Treasury Secretary Brady, the Banking Committee voted, 11 to 1, to send the nomination of T. Timothy Ryan Jr. to the full Senate. [31.] NBC News reported that in Mr. Ryan's F.B.I. file he admitted having used cocaine in the 1970's. In a statement, Mr. Ryan confirmed that report. [Page 42.] The Pentagon said it would no longer block exports of some computers to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, leaving control of such sales to the Commerce Department. [32.] Factory orders rose 1.8 percent in February, after a January plunge that was the steepest decline in 16 years. [32.] Prices farmers get for raw products increased 1.3 percent from February to March, raising the overall commodity index 2.7 percent above a year ago. [32.] 
 
International
 An inventory of global trade barriers was published by the Administration, listing 35 countries and 2 regional trading blocs that it said presented the ''most important'' obstacles to American exports. [31.] The U.S. and Japan reached a telecommunications accord that is expected to open the Japanese market further. [33.]
 
 
 
Markets
 Corporations held to a steady pace in issuing securities during the first quarter, but that was little comfort on Wall Street, where underwriting fees continue to sag. [31.] Stocks slid after traders turned off ''buy'' programs that take advantage of momentary price swings. The Dow lost 20.49 points, ending at 2,707.21. For the week, the Dow was up 2.93. [34.] Prices of Treasury securities continued to decline on new signs that the economy might be improving. [34.] The dollar rose sharply against the yen, but finished mixed against other major currencies in hectic trading. [40.] Copper futures jumped to new life-of-contract highs in New York amid fears of a strike by miners in Papua New Guinea. [40.]

HEADLINE: Wall St. Underwriting Fees Are Staying at a Low Level

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Corporate America kept to a steady pace in raising money from the securities markets in the year's first quarter, but that trend brought little joy to Wall Street, since underwriting fees remained low.
A respectable total of $77.7 billion in securities was issued in the quarter, which ended yesterday, according to the Securities Data Company. The total was up 6 percent from the $73.3 billion issued by corporations in the first quarter of last year. But it is down substantially from the record $91.3 billion that was raised in the fourth quarter of 1989, according to Securities Data. 
In a sign of how difficult business has become on Wall Street, the total fees reported by the firms remained at a level considered low - $592 million in the quarter, up about 5 percent from $564.1 million in fees in the first quarter of 1989, which was one of the poorest quarters since 1984.
The results are, in large part, the result of the collapse of the ''junk bond'' market, in which firms earned huge sums for underwriting the high-risk securities. The demand for many types of debt offerings slackened, leaving firms to concentrate on stock issues, which produce comparatively little in fees.
Wall Street executives said there were widespread expectations early in the quarter that interest rates would head lower, causing many issuers to postpone financings.
But ''there has been a general sentiment that the economy has bottomed out and that rates might go higher,'' said Mark Seigel, a managing director at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''And so, we have seen an increasing sentiment among issuers to consider accelerating their financial plans.''
Accordingly, Wall Street executives said they think they have come through the worst for the year. ''We expect an active second and third quarter,'' said Edson Mitchell, head of global debt financing desk at Merrill Lynch & Company.
People on Wall Street were most surprised about the signs of life in the market for new equity issues, an area that has been fragile since the market collapse in October 1987. ''There was finally some signs of a turn in equity issuance in the first quarter,'' said Kevin Kennedy, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
More than $7 billion was raised through stock issues in the first three months of 1990, an 82 percent increase over the comparable period in 1989.
Initial public offerings totaled about $4.3 billion in the quarter, compared with $3.1 billion in 1989 period.
But issuance of debt securities slid during the quarter. The fixed-income market raised $25.6 billion, down 33 percent from the $38.4 billion raised in the 1989 quarter. The rest of the offerings the quarter included an array of securities like mortgage-backed securities.
The turmoil on Wall Street led to some significant shifts in the underwriting ranking of the securities firms. While Merill Lynch, which has led the ranking for years, kept the top spot, its share of the market fell to 16 percent, from 18.9 percent in the 1989 quarter, according to Securities Data.
Other firms, which have announced large layoffs or have had significant losses from investment banking activities, slipped in the ranking. For example, the First Boston Corporation, fell from third to sixth, as its market share plummeted from 14.4 percent to 6.5 percent. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. fell from sixth to eighth.
The beneficiaries of this turmoil were a diverse group of Wall Street firms.
Goldman, Sachs had the best performance after Merrill, and had a slight increase in market share, from 14.8 percent in the first quarter last year to 14.9 percent.
Morgan Stanley had a big gain in its share, taking 13.1 percent of the market, compared with 7.2 percent in the 1989 period. This year it ranked third, up from fifth.

HEADLINE: Japan Sobered by Recent Stock Slide

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 30

 BODY:
As prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange shuddered and plunged last week, the switchboards at the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation lighted up with shareholders expressing amazement, shock and disbelief: This was not supposed to happen, they all said.
For millions of Japanese who began investing in stocks for the first time in the last few years, the continuing slide in the Tokyo market -down nearly 25 percent since the start of the year - is the first reversal they have experienced, after years of steady gains.
''In a way, we think it's natural for them to get angry,'' said Hiroyuki Ishihara, chief of the stock division of Nippon Telegraph, the world's largest company as measured by the value of its equity. ''We're feeling very regretful.'' 
Japanese investors may be disillusioned but, by most accounts, they are not yet pulling out of the stock market altogether. Moreover, analysts here expect only a modest spillover from the stock market drop to the Japanese economy.
In the United States after the October 1987 market crash, there was deep anxiety about whether Wall Street's troubles would spread to Main Street, which eventually proved unfounded. In Japan today, similar worries have been expressed, but there appears to be even less cause for concern.
To be sure, Japanese analysts are beginning to scale back their sales forecasts for big-ticket items like luxury cars and expensive television sets - the kind of goods typically purchased by wealthier people who own shares. Still, retail sales rose 10 percent in February and the Japanese economy remains vibrant.
One reason the effect of the market's slide is likely to be modest is that stocks are held by a comparatively small proportion of the population, despite the many individuals who have become first-time investors in recent years. The Tokyo Stock Exchange estimates the number of individual shareholders in Japan to be about 10 million, or only 8 percent of the population.
By contrast, the most recent estimates of individual shareholders in the United States, which has twice the population of Japan, is more than 40 million. The weight of individual investors in the stock market is also much greater in the United States than in Japan. Though their percentage of all stock holdings has declined for a quarter of a century, American individuals own about 55 percent of the value of all shares, according to the Securities Industry Association. In Japan, individuals hold roughly 22 percent.
Japanese stock traders and analysts agree that the recent market downturn has altered the psychological climate for stocks and investments in Japan, but not scared them away from the market completely.
 
'Many Wonderful Moments'
 That seemed to be the sentiment this week of most of the office workers and shoppers who came to a downtown branch of the Nomura Securities Company, the nation's largest borker, to stare at an electronic board listing the latest stock prices.
''I can't quit because I've had so many wonderful moments in the last few years,'' said Hideki Saito, a 36-year-old advertising executive. ''It's like horse racing, I guess. Even if the odds are bad, you feel so good when you make money.''
Many shareholders consider that they have not lost on their original investment, given the tripling of the exchange's value in the last half of the 1980's, so the recent dip has not been devastatingfor most of them.
''Before the last few months, people began to think that the stock market is a one-way street, and that it can only go up,'' said Akio Mikuni, president of Mikuni & Company, a credit-rating service. ''It's been a shock to many people.''
Indeed, until the recent drop, Japan has ridden the crest of one of the most extraordinary stock booms on record, drawing housewives, farmers, small-business men and salaried workers into the market.
 
Many Types of Investors
 Typical of the new class of investors is the 35-year-old housewife who wrote an anonymous column in the Asahi newspaper last month entitled ''My Stock Experience.'' She said she had invested her husband's bonuses and savings and earned $13,000 on a $32,000 investment since 1988.
''But since the start of this year, it's been no good,'' she wrote, explaining that four of the five companies, many of them retail chains, in which she owned shares had gone down. ''Since they are strong industries, I think prices will go back up, so I am waiting.''
At a small branch office of Nikko Securities in a town outside Kyoto in western Japan, the deputy chief for sales said in a telephone interview that he and his colleagues had spent much of the week reassuring wary investors.
''Thank God, we did not have much trouble with our customers,'' said Tatsuya Nakajima, the deputy chief. ''We've had complaints from people who said we had promised the market would rebound. But at least we haven't heard of anyone committing suicide, which we heard about many years ago.''
At the Nomura offices in Ginza, investors repeatedly said that they would not drop out of the stock market.
''A few people might have been shocked at this drop, and they sold their stocks,'' said Teiji Kishi, a bank manager, as his friend nodded. ''But if it keeps recovering, this might be a good time to put more money in.''
 
View of the Have-Nots
 Many economists say that the soaring prices of stocks and land in Japan over the last several years have created resentment among many Japanese who have not participated in the boom. Indeed, there was some evidence that the have-nots of Japanese society may have taken a bit of pleasure in the misery of others who suffered losses in stocks recently.
''I'm a student and I don't have any funds of my own,'' said Yuichiro Kuwamura, a 21-year-old in faded jeans and leather jacket who was inspecting an automobile showroom near the Nomura offices. ''If too many people start to get easy money from the stock market, the basis of our economy could be lost.''
