HEADLINE: U.S. Lists Barriers To Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
The Bush Administration published an inventory of global trade barriers today, listing 35 countries and 2 regional trading blocs that it said maintained the ''most important'' obstacles to American exports.
As expected, Japan, which accounted for nearly half of the $109 billion American trade deficit last year, was accused of maintaining the most barriers, followed by the European Community, Canada, South Korea, India and Brazil. In the 216-page volume, Japanese restrictions took up 19 pages.
Pressure has been building in Congress and in the Administration to get the Japanese to relax trade barriers, and intensive negotiations have been under way regarding satellites, supercomputers and wood products. 
 
'Must Keep Up the Pressure'
 ''Until the long list of barriers that U.S. business faces in Japan is cut down substantially, the U.S. must keep up the pressure on Japan to open its market,'' said Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who is chairman of the International Trade Subcommittee of the Finance Committee.
The Japanese Embassy declined to comment. Hideaki Ueda, press counselor at the embassy, said Japanese officials had not yet had a chance to study the document.
The list, mandated by Congress, has been released annually for the last five years. But under the so-called Super 301 provision of 1988 trade legislation it has assumed greater importance as part of a process by which the United States designates ''priority'' countries and trade practices for intensive negotiations and possible retaliation. Under the statute, the Administration has until April 30 to designate the countries and practices that will be given priority in its trade policy this year.
 
Countries Facing Retaliation
 Japan, Brazil and India were designated as priority countries last year and face retaliation if barriers are not lifted by June 16. The retaliatory measures can include tariffs that would double the price of selected imports from the offending country.
Most of the restrictions cited today have appeared in earlier listings. Progress was reported in a few areas, as in quotas on beef imports by South Korea, which have been progressively reduced.
This year's report identifies some new impediments, like shipbuilding subsidies in Finland, Japan, Korea and Norway. Under pressure from its domestic shipbuilders, the United States has been fighting such subsidies within the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. Today's report suggests escalation of the anti-subsidy campaign.
The new listing of a Japanese barrier involving amorphous metals, which are used in electrical transformers, could be a sign that it will be designated a priority matter next month.
 
Complaint by Allied-Signal
 Unlike conventional metals, amorphous metals have no crystalline structure, making them highly effective converters of electrical energy. The metals are made by Allied-Signal Inc. of Morristown, N.J. The company has filed a complaint about the Japanese restriction under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974, The trade office has until April 19 to decide whether to retaliate.
Today's report cites the Allied-Signal complaint, which was taken as a sign that the Government is seriously considering pressing the case with the Japanese. David C. Hill, senior vice president of Allied, said the company believes it could get an additional $100 million of business in Japan if the barrier was lifted.
Israel was named for the first time among the countries with significant trade barriers. Joshua Bolten, general counsel of the Office of the United States Trade Representative, said no adverse inferences about American-Israeli relations should be drawn. ''No broader political interests are brought into play here,'' he stressed. The report is prepared by the trade representative's office, but goes through an interagency process involving the State, Treasury and Defense Departments.
 
No Dramatic Growth
 The United States has a five-year-old free-trade agreement with Israel that American officials say is operating reasonably well, although it has not led to the dramatic expansion of trade that both Governments had expected. The two-way trade was $6 billion last year, with the United States in deficit by $400 million.
The report took issue with what it termed Israel's ''extensive'' agricultural import restrictions and with taxation, standards and import-licensing procedures that it said generally discriminated against imports.
In discussing barriers in the 12-nation European Community, the report said that the subsidies from four members - Germany, France, Britain and Spain - for Airbus Industrie remained a concern. The subsidies are viewed as giving the European commercial aircraft builder unfair advantages over American companies like Boeing and Lockheed.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Rebound With 1.8% February Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
Orders to factories for manufactured goods in February bounced back 1.8 percent from January, when they had their steepest plunge in 16 years, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and nondurable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $231.6 billion in February. Factory orders plummeted 5.5 percent in January, the steepest drop since a 7 percent decline in December 1974, the department said in revising the January figure downward. The department had initially said orders dropped 5.4 percent in January. 
Analysts said the February report was more evidence of sluggishness in the industrial sector of the economy, but they also found signs indicating improvement.
 
'On a Plateau'
 ''Manufacturing is aimlessly drifting along on a plateau,'' said Robert G. Dederick, the chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. ''The mini-recession in manufacturing is still there.''
Evalina Tainer, a senior economist for the First National Bank of Chicago, agreed, but added that the report suggested ''the manufacturing sector has bottomed out and we could be a little bit on the mend.''
Both Mr. Dederick and Ms. Tainer saw signs of optimism in a category often used in measuring future business investment.
''Capital-goods orders, less aircraft, are looking a little firmer than they did before,'' Mr. Dederick said. ''They're showing some signs of underlying support to the expansion. I'm not saying strength, but weakness is not developing.''
The Commerce Department said nonmilitary capital-goods orders, less aircraft, rose 2.2 percent in February. While they declined in January, the drop was revised today to 4.1 percent from the 4.4 percent decrease originally reported.
Orders for durable goods, expensive products expected to last at least three years, advanced 2.6 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $120.9 billion, after sinking 10.5 percent in January, the biggest drop in the 32 years of record-keeping. The January decline broke the previous record of 9.2 percent set during the last recession in February 1982.
Durable-goods orders have been affected most by the Federal Reserve's high-interest policies because they are often financed by loans or credit cards.
The department said durable-goods orders were concentrated in transportation equipment, up 10.4 percent, to $29.9 billion. Transportation orders had led the overall January decline with a drop of 29.4 percent. Excluding transportation, orders were up six-tenths of 1 percent.
Orders for nondurable goods rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, to $110.7 billion, after a January gain of six-tenths of 1 percent. The largest increases were in food and printing and publishing.
 
Military Orders Climb
 Military orders, which are often volatile, advanced 21.7 percent, to $7.9 billion, after falling 33.6 percent the previous month.
The Commerce Department also reported shipments rose 3.3 percent, to $234.2 billion, after a 1.8 percent decline in January. Inventories eased one-tenth of 1 percent, to $373.9 billion, after a gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent the previous month.
Analysts watch inventories closely because if they increase without a corresponding gain in new orders, production cutbacks and job losses could occur as factories try to get rid of goods stored on shelves and back lots.

HEADLINE: Prices Paid to Farmers Post 1.3% Increase

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
Prices farmers received for raw products increased 1.3 percent from February to March, raising the overall commodity index 2.7 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.
Higher prices for hogs, eggs, cattle and potatoes were mostly responsible for the increase from February, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report.
 
Milk Tumbles
 But the report said lower prices for tomatoes, milk and wheat partly offset the gains for the other commodities. Most prices are mid-March averages, which will be revised next month. 
''Hog and cattle prices moved up sharply from February, while the all-milk price declined for the second consecutive month,'' the report said. ''Tomatoes declined sharply from February, but continuing short supplies kept prices well above normal for this time of year.''
Milk prices had risen to record levels until they tumbled sharply in February, reflecting production increases.
''Prices of feed grain, food grains and oilseeds were mixed,'' the report said. ''Corn and soybean prices increased slightly, while the wheat price was down. Hay prices showed a moderate increase from February.''
Department economists say the net cash income of farmers in 1990 may be in the range of $54 billion to $58 billion, compared with about $53 billion in 1989. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988.
Consumer food prices are forecast by department economists to rise 3 percent to 5 percent this year after gaining 5.7 percent in 1989, the sharpest rise since 1981.
 
Livestock and Poultry Up
 Based on the preliminary figures, the March price index for livestock and poultry was up 2.4 percent from February and averaged 7.5 percent more than a year ago.
Milk prices dropped an additional 60 cents in March to an average of $13.80 for each l00 pounds. Even so, the preliminary March price was up $1.10 from March 1989.
Over all, crop prices rose eight-tenths of 1 percent from February but were 2.9 percent below the level a year earlier. Fruit prices, led by grapefruit and oranges, were up 7 percent from February and averaged 6.4 percent more than a year ago.
The index for commercial vegetables dropped 4.9 percent from February but still averaged 39 percent more than in March 1989.
The report said that cattle averaged $75.40 for each 100 pounds of live weight nationally, up from $74.60 in February and $72 in March 1989. Hogs averaged $52 for each 100 pounds, compared with $48.20 in February and $39.30 a year earlier. Eggs were 79.3 cents a dozen, compared with 70.4 cents in February and 80.1 cents in March 1989.

HEADLINE: Fed Stayed With Policy In February

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers decided at their February meeting to continue the policy aimed at maintaining high interest rates to keep inflationary pressures under control, according to minutes released today.
The Federal funds rate has been steady at 8.25 percent since the Fed let it drop from 8.5 percent on Dec. 21, after the previous Fed policy meeting on Dec. 18-19. The Federal funds rate is the interest banks charge one another for overnight loans and is the primary lever the Fed uses to control short-term rates. 
The policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee, met again on Tuesday and analysts said they believed it voted to continue the current policies. Minutes of that meeting will be released in May.
 
Meetings Eight Times a Year
 The committee holds closed meetings eight times a year to formulate monetary policy and confers by telephone as needed. It consists of the seven Federal Reserve Board members and 5 of the 12 presidents of the Fed's district banks.
At the conclusion of the Feb. 6-7 meeting, the committee voted by 8 to 3 not to change policies, although they agreed some firming or easing of credit would be acceptable, depending on economic developments.
The session was marked by an usually high number of dissenting votes. Three members objected to the directive - W. Lee Hoskins of Cleveland because he wanted ''some firming'' of policy, Robert H. Boykin of Dallas because he wanted a directive ''tilted'' toward tightness if conditions warranted and Martha R. Seger, a board member, because of a preference for ''some easing.''
 
Three Dissents on Targets
 The minutes also showed three dissents in adopting monetary targets for 1990, the substance of which was disclosed before Congress shortly after the meeting. On this, the no votes came from Mr. Hoskins, Ms. Seger and Gary H. Stern, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis.
At the meeting, the information on economic conditions ''suggested continued but sluggish expansion in overall economic activity, with conditions uneven across sectors,'' the minutes read.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
A.T.&T. Card Offers New Connection

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Millions of Americans are being asked to try yet another credit card, this time the American Telephone & Telegraph Company's new calling and general-purpose card. The first word is that it seems to be a good deal for many consumers.
''This is a tremendous potential boon for the 35 percent of card holders who pay off their entire credit card bill each month,'' said Elgie Holstein, director of the Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer group. ''Secondly, it is good news for those people who make a great number of long-distance A.T.&T. calls and want the convenience of a combination card with a 10 percent discount.'' 
 
Variable Interest Rate
 The interest rate on the combination card - the A.T.&T. Universal card - will be variable and has been initially set at 18.9 percent, just slightly below the 19.2 percent average rate of the top 10 issuers of bank cards. Since the A.T.&T. rate will move in tandem with the prime rate, it could rise substantially in the years ahead. But if it does and consumers are unhappy, they can cancel the card at any time.
A.T.&T. is trying to emphasize how its card is different from the bewildering array of offerings in the credit-card market. While other large card issuers have previously offered other amenities like discounts on merchandise to lure cardholders, the battleground seems to be shifting to widely used services like telephone calls.
Basically, the new card is another version of a Mastercard or Visa issued by a bank, in this case, the Universal Bank of Columbus, Ga., and has many of the same attributes of other bank cards. But there are major differences that could tip the scales in its favor.
For example, there will never be an annual fee for those who become members in 1990 and make at least one purchase a year using the card. In addition, members will get a 10 percent discount on all A.T.&T. long-distance charges for calls made with the card.
With A.T.&T.'s resources, marketing clout and brand name behind it, there is no question that the all-in-one card will be a major contender in the multi-billion-dollar credit-card sweepstakes. Cardholders will be able to buy goods and services at seven million locations and get cash at 300,000 banks and automatic teller machines.
Mailings to A.T.&T. customers and holders of its existing calling cards are under way and applications can be requested by calling 800-66-APPLY; the entire application procedure can be handled on the phone. If applicants do not specifically request a Visa or Mastercard version, they will be allocated one or the other. Those whose income, credit references and other characteristics qualify them for a gold card will automatically receive a gold Visa.
''The combination of a calling card with a credit card is a logical expansion of services to A.T.&T.'s existing clientele,'' said H. Spencer Nilson, publisher of the Nilson Report, a credit-card newsletter.
A.T.&T. is betting on two things: First, that millions of consumers will apply for the card. Second, that a large percentage of those who get the new card will throw away their other Visas and Mastercards, as well as some or all of their department store, oil company and other single-purpose charge cards, and send that business A.T.&T.'s way. The more credit cards a person has, the larger the potential amount that can be borrowed - a situation that some lenders consider a negative factor in deciding whether to to grant more credit.
 
Some Are Skeptical
 Despite A.T.&T.'s muscle, other telecommunications corporations have already staked out a share of the multi-purpose credit card field.
The MCI Communications Corporation has signed up 13 banks that will bill its long-distance calls on Visa cards, and the U S Sprint Communications Company is marketing a combination long-distance calling card and Visa card. Even one of the local telephone operating companies, the Southern New England Telephone Company, offers a combined calling and credit card.
Paul Kahn, president of A.T.&T.'s Jacksonville, Fla.,-based A.T.&T. Universal Card Services unit, explained its entry into the competitive market by observing that people ''want to carry fewer cards and have those cards do more.''
Just by announcing its plans, A.T.&T. has become the talk of the credit-card industry. This week at a regional conference held in New Orleans by the American Bankers Association, experts presented a panel that analyzed A.T.&T.'s card and other credit cards that compete with the traditional bank cards.
One panelist, Allen R. DeCotiis, president of Payment Systems Inc., a Tampa, Fla., consulting concern, thinks that A.T.&T. was much too late entering the market. ''They're 18 to 24 months late at a minimum,'' he said. ''The market growth now is less than in the early to mid-1980's.''
But other financial-services consultants see the A.T.&T. card as a definite plus for the consumer. ''You're going to get no annual fee and a lower interest rate for those balances that do roll over,'' said Bruce Brittain, president of Brittain Associates of Atlanta, another panelist. ''This will give consumers an opportunity to vote with their dollars.''
 
 
 
WHEN USING A PAY PHONE
 The new A.T.& T. Universal card can be used at any pay telephone. There is a 10 percent discount from the regular price, but procedures vary depending on the type of phone used:
 With a ''swipe'' phone that reads the magnetic strip on the back of the card when it is run through a slot on the phone, dial the area code and phone number, followed by an assigned four-digit personal identification number, or PIN. Then a caller will hear a recording that says, ''Thank you for using A.T.& T.,'' and the ringing will begin.
 With a regular push-button phone, punch in 0, the area code and phone number, the 10-digit calling card number printed at the bottom of the card (not the large-type number in the center of the card) and the PIN. Again there will be an A.T.& T. recording before the ringing starts.
 A warning: If the pay phone is not presubscribed to A.T.& T., the call will be sent along the lines of another long-distance carrier and there will not be a 10 percent discount. The indication that it is not an A.T.& T. phone is that there will be no A.T.& T. recording after punching in the required 25 numbers. At that point, hang up before someone answers. Then, start all over again by dialing an access code - 10 - ATT - and begin the same dialing procedure.
